Because of this, I probably wouldn't order a thali. The thalis I am used to are a bit different than what I saw here. Definitely seems like an ideal food for a food truck, which they have. 

My Kati roll was just ok. I wouldn't dissuade someone from going to Kasa, but it also wouldn't be my first choice. The place itself is rather loud and I can tell that when it gets busy seating might be a problem. 

My biggest gripe is that the chai is tiny and the taste of cardamom or pepper is overwhelming. It wasn't horrible, but by the time I got midway through the tiny cup (seriously, it's barely above Dixie cup size) I couldn't finish it.
author: Bianca U.

description:
Upon entering Kasa, you will notice that it's a fast food Indian eatery.  I'm good with that, as long as the food tastes good.  However, to me, it didn't  taste like authentic Indian food.  Too bad the food didn't meet my expectations after I had read so many positive reviews on yelp.  

I was excited to try this place since I'm a fan of Indian food., then quickly disappointed. Not sure why people are raving about the tikka masala.  It was all dark chicken meat.  I was starving and just couldn't finish my meal.  The lentil soup was good.  The cauliflower and potatoes were okay.  I hate to say it, but the only thing I enjoyed was the bread and chai tea.
author: Dannash M.

description:
tasty and flavorful rolls. i got the chicken marsala.
staff was helpful and courteous.
feels like a chipotle style type of place.
atmosphere was relax and casual. great for neighborhood folks to pop in for something quick.

down side, i saw flies flying around
author: Jason C.

description:
Kasa is mobile indian food. kasa  started with a physical location and expanded to food trucks recently,

locale: eat real festival (9/23)

menu: samosa(3) bowls (5), kati rolls(5)
fillings for katie rolls & (rice) bowls :
-chicken tikka masala
-saag paner
-gobi aloo (cauliflower)

sampling: katie rolls (5)
-"flaky, buttery handmade roti, lime marinated onions and cilantro chutney rolled up with filling"
-katie rolls kind of small, not a lot of filling, eating mostly dough, not a lot of flavoring. some chicken, mostly rice and dough

foodnotes:
-small size makes offerings on the pricey side.
-was sized reduced cuz of eat real? not sure
-may retry sometime else at a later date and location.
-kati roll looks similar to a burrito but isn't, totally different and similar.
author: Victor G.

description:
Great, real, comfortable food. Super delicious and simple menu. Friendly/genuine staff. Casual dining environment - don't need to go to some fast food joint to get gross food when you can come here and get great food just as quick.

Overall a great go-to!
author: Adel J.

description:
Kasa is pretty amazing. This restaurant is pretty small where you order your food at the counter and you pay at the register before you seat yourself down. They offer to go and delivery as well. I have heard about their food truck from friends and co workers but I haven't been to it myself. I did hear that they only serve their samosas on their food truck which sounds amazing!

My co workers and I usually come here pretty often and I usually order 2 kati rolls ($4.50 each) and a side of daal ($3). For the Kati rolls you usually pick which dish you want and it is rolled up inside a roti or naan like bread. It is pretty amazing. My favorites dishes for the Kati roll are the Aloo Jeera which is Cumin-spiced sautéed potatoes and their chana masala which is the garbanzo beans cooked with spices. I believe the chana masala is only there sometimes for the daily special. When I order the daal, I usually ask them to put a little bit of rice inside which is a nice touch.

I eat a lot and the food is really filling so don't feel that it is necessary to order as much as I did. You can always go back for more! ;) But this place is awesome, you should definitely check it out!
author: Anthony H.

description:
I gave this place another chance, partially because I was craving for masala chai tea at the time. I ordered the Paneer Kati Roll and it was really good. Just based solely upon that, I'l be coming back. The naan was nice and soft, with a great texture. The paneer was done really well and had really good flavors all around.

I'm still not a fan of their yogurt but I can let that pass.
author: Brenda T.

description:
I have no idea why this place is so popular.  The food is just OK, and if you come later in day it's not really fresh, and is about lukewarm at best.  

Also, my husband has gotten food poisoning here several times. Granted, his immune system is not the best as he has a blood condition, but he rarely gets food poisoning anywhere else-he refuses to get anything here anymore as every time he did he was getting sick.

All those freshness, warmth, and hygiene concerns aside it doesn't even taste that great-and is not that cheap.
author: Carlin S.

description: This place is great!  Food is delicious and the same as when my Aunties make it!  Fast service and fresh food. I can have a big meal here without feeling like I ate a brick.  Have definitely eaten here a few days in a row before.
author: Jean G.

description: Working in the area and decided to yelp for good spot to grab some lunch. Indian sounds good walked in greeted by nice friendly staff, place is nice and clean menus are well highlighted and lunch specials are a must. Place gets crowded quick and parking can be kind of hard to find with meters but don't let that keep you from stopping by. They also have a street food truck that serves same menu. Food portion is great for the price. If you are in doubt about what to get don't worry staff will explain it well.
author: C. S.

description: Heard about this place, so stopped by for lunch while in San Francisco. Very simple menu and healthy. I got the Chicken Tikka Masala kati roll. It was good, cheap, quick Indian food. I was surprised at how good it was. Very rare to find an Indian restaurant like this. Would definitely recommend.
author: Ava K.

description:
Yea, no. Cute establishment, graphics, and overall concept, but the food quality is just not there.

I wanted to order the chicken tikka masala kati roll, however, on a 2pm on Sunday afternoon they ran out of chicken tikka masala. Say what? Really? Instead, the woman suggested I get the chicken tikka roll, and she'd spoon the masala over the top of it. Great.

Anyway, just as I had experienced at the Kasa location on Fillmore (which is now closed, mind you), this was was not up to par. The roti was a slight improvement upon last time, but the inner filling was still just so MEH. For $5 for a miniature-sized burrito concoction, this was NOT good. Kati rolls I've had in India, England, and even in New York have superceeded that of Kasa's. It's unfortunate, because the Bay Area has yet to present a decent kati roll.
author: Mansi A.

description:
Probably one of the worst among Indian restaurants. 

I went to this place about 10 days ago and after getting oriented with the menu, I ordered a plate meal to go - With Chicken Tikka masala and Saag Panner. The samosa was a last minute addition and it cost $2.50 - quite expensive for a small samosa.

When I got home, I noticed that the onion and mint chutneys was slapped onto the curries and it got all mixed up with the Chicken Tikka masala and the Saag Paneer. After fishing out the chutneys, I managed to eat it with the rice and the roti that came with it.

Looked like the roti was made from white flour - not very healthy. The curries were mediocre. The amount of rice was less than half a cup and the roti was small. I was left with a lot of the curries once I finished with the rice and roti.

All in all, mediocre food that is overpriced.
author: Prasad T.

description:
Finding light, fresh, flavorful and authentic North Indian food at a restaurant is almost impossible, not only in the US, but even in India itself (my parents are from India, and I lived there for over a year as an adult, so I know the food quite well). In India, people expect restaurant food to be heavy and fatty (the healthier stuff you can get at home, so why buy it from a restaurant, or so goes the reasoning), and I think most Indian restaurant owners in the US have that same mentality.

The end result is that 99% of North Indian food in the US is dull, oily and woefully generic (find me a North Indian joint that doesn't have tikka/butter chicken or aloo gobi/mutter paneer and I'll buy you dinner at said establishment).

As such, I had high hopes for Kasa, which sounded like it was aiming for something different. It looks almost like a Chipotle and you stand in line and pick your dishes. To be fair, the food here was pretty good, but my criticisms stem from a lack of variety and some unusual decisions in how they make standard Indian foods (such as dal and roti).

You can get either a kati roll ($4.50 a piece for this flaky tortilla-esque bread, filled with your choice of curry) or a thali plate ($10.50, and comes with rice, two curries and some side salads). Unfortunately, the kati rolls are not vegan (the dough is made with butter); similarly, the roti is not vegan (which is amazing to me, as roti is almost always vegan, whereas naan is usually not).

As such, I opted for the thali plate. Of the five vegetarian curries, only two of them were vegan, which was disappointing. This was sign number one that Kasa is not aiming to offer the simple, light, flavorful Indian food that I dream of.

The only two vegan dishes were the aloo gobi (sigh, how predictable) and an aloo jeera (potatoes and cumin).

To make matters worse, Kasa doesn't offer brown rice. As I hate white rice, and they couldn't give me roti (which is traditionally vegan and made of wholewheat), Kasa did offer to give me more of a curry, so I got an extra heaping of the aloo gobi. That was nice of them.

The food wasn't bad at all. I'd like more variety (two potato dishes is a bit much), and it would be great to have vegan options of dishes that are usually vegan anyway (such as dal), but the food here was about as light and simple as I've found in the US.

If they had more vegan options for curries, and offered vegan breads (they said they can make vegan bread with advance notice, but it takes them about 40 minutes or more to make the stuff), as well as homemade chai with almond or coconut milk, Kasa would get another star. For the price, too, it's not a bad deal, as you get a pretty filling meal. Kasa has much room for improvement, but if you're looking for decent Indian food in the Mission, this is your spot.
author: Kedar D.

description:
I got food poisoning here.  'Nuff said.

Not sure if it was the chicken tikka masala, the aloo gobi, or the samosas.  Won't be eating here ever again.  Also, the food was pretty below average.  Not worth the price or pain.
author: Rose D.

description:
Wow, this is painful.  I love the food at Kasa, or I loved it.  But its health-inspection score plummeted from 90 in January 2012 to an all-time low of 79 last September.  All seven violations have apparently been fixed, but that's pretty bad for six months.  The Healthy SF thing is weighing on me as well.

So sorry, Kasa, but I think you deserve this; and I truly am sad because I loved your food.  I don't wait for the bus outside your inviting doors anymore, so not visiting you won't be as difficult as it once would have been, but I'll no longer bring my sister or other out-of-town guests here, and that's really a shame.
author: John S.

description:
I'm not going to lie, while I have been eating Indian food for awhile, I've never been that adventurous.  I stick to my chicken tikka masala, an occasional curry, and that's about it.  I ordered the Thali platter and did not want any of the sides (the dips, salad, ect.).  I explained that to the lady, but while I was distracted and paying, another employee came up to my plate and added everything.  None of the employees were friendly or made eye contact, just in a rush to get me out (it was not incredibly busy).  

Even though I did not want the extras, It was probably a good way for me to try something different.  Over all everything was descent.  I enjoy naan bread more than the wrap like bread they give you.  Maybe I would like the actual wrap better than a thali platter?

Maybe this is the place to stretch my Indian taste buds, but for my safe haven, I'll stick with other places.
author: Shelby B.

description:
Okay, so this awesome place I once gave 5 stars has mutated to one of the worst Indian restaurants I've ever been to. Premises stayed the same but the food has massively gone downhill. Appearently the management tries to cheap out on the ingredients, that's why I (who hates to waste food and therefore very very rarely returns a dish, even if I don't like it) had to return my kati roll with lamb curry as it was way too greasy. With that I mean there was barely any meat but only lamb fat in a curry sauce which forced me to return it. I swapped with a chicken tikka masala kati roll which was also only mediocre compared to what I'm used to from Kasa. This made me sad and angry.
Back when I tried the lamb curry for the first time it was tender and simply delicious and no comparison to what they offer now.
And btw, I never got the $1 back for the lamb curry upgrade, since the chicken is cheaper. But maybe that and this review can contribute to an improvement and Kasa becomes the awesome place it once used to be. Sorry for the harsh words but I'm somewhat disappointed :(
author: Ilay I.

description: I ordered vegetarian Kati Roll. The description of the item says it is a "Roti" stuffed with potato and cumin mix. I w as disappointed for two reasons 1) it is NOT a Roti. It is a tortilla. Huge difference, and not original; 2) the size is pretty small, not sure if it is good value.
author: Shweta K.

description: Kasa is not a restaurant that waits on you but the food is great. I ordered both the chicken tika and the paneer. Both are excellent. This restaurant is really great if you are in a hurry.
author: Paul D.

description:
I inadvertantly stumbled across this restaurant because they provide the food for the Red And White Fleet's Indian Dinner Buffet and Dance  http://www.yelp.com/biz/kasa-indian-eatery-san-francisco#hrid:ErVURk6btEdIH0ym4y_pqw   .  While I'm not an expert on Indian cuisine, the Indian Tour Group that was with us seemed very happy. 

I really enjoyed their food, they had different chutneys, Roti, Raita (yogurt) Chicken Tikka Masala, Karahi Paneer (my favorite) Daal's. Vegi Salad and a few other dishes.  They even had this really good dessert that isn't on the menu.  It was wonderful and we couldn't get enough of them.  They are called Gulab Jamun and are fried dough in a cardamom and rosewater syrup.  Think of a cake doughnut hole, fried and dipped in heaven.  YUM.

The servers were wonderful, especially the young man in dreads who talked to us for a bit after dinner and asked us how we enjoyed dinner.
author: Bee D.

description:
This place use to be bomb or at least the location in the Marina, but that was over 2 years ago. My visit last weekend was one of disappointment. Not having a chicken tiki masala roll in I don't know how long I was fiending for the perfect roll. But that was all ruined by the gentleman putting my roll together. 

Before he even put any meat on, there was a tear in my roll. Shouldn't this have been swapped out for one that wasn't torn? He put all this meat and less of the other stuff. As he was rolling it together it tore some more. Typical guy like thinking, I'll just leave it cause I'm lazy. Eating my roll was a complete mess, everything fell out when I first grabbed it. I wasn't going to let that ruin my roll until I took a bite. There was too much meat, sauce, not enough of the other stuff, and the roll was cold and undercooked. 

Thanks for leaving me with only a memory of what a chicken tiki masala roll use to taste like. 

Luckily my friend enjoyed his roll, but than again this was his first Kasa experience.
author: Justin D.

description:
Fun, fast, and flavorful! They have a great selection of meat and vegetarian dishes.

Their Chicken Tikka Masala Roll is mouthwatering. You can get the rolls 'Unda Style,' where an egg is cooked into the naan making your dish just a little bit yummier! Each roll comes with Raita (yogurt), which definitely adds to the dish as well.

I didn't get a chance to try their Housemade Chai, but I look forward to doing so on my next trip to SF! :)
author: H B.

description: I predict that Kasa will soon be joining the growing list of closures in the Castro. My updated review 4+ years ago went from a 5 to a 3 and now down to a 1 Star. I noted then the change in ingredients and how they didn't taste as good or sit as well. Now it's pretty much a tasteless bunch of salt and probably MSG or something similar. I'm still chugging chatter 5 hours later! The staff seem dazed and confused. The music blaring in the cold (often literally cold) space does not make for a nice lunch experience.
author: Mark V.

description:
The owners of this joint have definitely lost their passion for food.

I was so disappointed by my experience at Kasa Indian Eatery!  I remember wanting to write a review the moment I laid eyes on my food. My first concern was the appearance and the plating of the food on the Thali plate.  It is plated on a metallic tray which is not appetizing to me at all. DO NOT be fooled by the beautiful saturated photography displayed on their walls and website. In person the food looked mushy, runny and boring. The man who served it seemed lifeless and bored as he splattered the other condiments lazily onto the tray. Where's your pride in the food Kasa? 

When eating I have to admit that the flavors are there, the food did taste pretty good. It was just the vessel that was used for the delivery failed to excite me. Who knew! The runny peas thing did have some flavor to it! One thing that ultimately upset me the most was the roti. Described as a flaky, buttery roti bread, that was a downright lie. My bread was hard and rubbery. I had to cut into it with a knife which took quite a bit of effort. What was even more disappointing was when I looked across from my table my neighbor's roti looked fresh and it actually was rolled whilst mine was so rubbery it just sprawled itself out on my plate. 

Don't I deserve to have the same quality? 

Is this really food that would make your grandmothers proud? Was my food a representation of that pride?
author: Sueann W.

description:
OMG. Best  $11 lunch I've ever had. Staff was cool too. 
Here's what I had... Thali combo platter with  chicken tiki masala & turkey kebabs. Spicy, tasty, & plentiful!!!! Couldn't finish my plate. Worth a share & a samosa appetizer if you're dining with a friend. Wish I didn't live so far away.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: The husband and I stopped by here for a quick bite before catching a show at the San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival.  Service was friendly and fast.  I recommend the Thali plate - you pick 2 dishes and it comes with a bunch of sides.  A lot of food for about $11.
author: Rose A.

description:
I had a thali for lunch, and really wasn't very impressed. The atmosphere and presentation made me recall school lunch ladies plopping ladles of unappealing food in my tray. The food was all pre-prepared, and my chicken tikka and lamb curry were both quite bland. To be fair, this is probably more representative of the traditional Indian cuisine they claim to be replicating, but it really failed to arouse my taste buds.

I think Kasa would appeal to a certain type of person, but I'm not sure why they've received such glowing reviews. Curry Boyzz is close by, and will probably be my choice of restaurant the next time I crave Indian.
author: Jade M.

description:
Awesome healthy fresh cheap eats!  A great place to stop for a bite after yoga.

I tried a Chicken Tikka Masala Kati roll.  Picture an Indian burrito. Delishous and filling after a tough power yoga session.  For $5, it can't be beat.
author: Nicole R.

description:
Delicious
Quick
Tasty
Veggie and Vegan friendly.
Warm atmosphere.

Satisfies cravings for Indian food.
author: Mojo J.

description: I wish there was an option of negative stars. Really terrible food, completely tasteless and the Roti was kind of burnt. On their wall they have a statement that says " we want to serve food that our grandmother would be proud of". Well if their grandmother ate what we just ate, she would be in tears and no it won't be tears of joy.
author: Priya J.

description: Quick and delicious. Those guys made my wedding last year at Dolores Park. Our first reservation got canceled an hour before the wedding and those guys managed to prepare tons of kati rolls and have our party saved! My favorite wrap is chicken masala with extra cilantro in it. Try their samosas which are also excellent. Staff is helpful so no confusion by the counter. Thumb up!
author: YelpMadeMeDoIt L.

description: The chicken tikka masala was not cremey the way i was expecting it to be. That would be the only reason why its not a 4 star. The meat was flavorful but my order was cold once it was delivered. :(
author: Sherelle K.

description: This place will do the trick when you've got that hankering for some sweet sweet Indian cuisine. I recommend the combo dishes for maximum price:food efficiency. Could use a bit more of a selection, but they've got pretty much all the hits.
author: Alex C.

description:
In our continuing quest for Indian food in San Francisco, we discovered, thanks to something called "Yelp", the Kasa Indian Eatery. Yelp's a perfect thingy to find new places to stuff your craw, if you had one, and Kasa was an affordable Indian homestyle that is now bookmarked as a place to go back to if I'm ever again in the area.

Take this place: we'd come off of a Sunday hike to Mount Davidson Park and were looking for an Indian restaurant nearby that was open on Sunday's before 5 PM. Yelp led us to this place on a corner in the Castro on 18th and Noe that is a little like a cafeteria and an Indian Bistro.

You get two main choices: a wrap called a Kati Roll, which is a filled (with one of the choices below plus marinated onions and chutney) roti rolled like a burrito for a inexpensive $4.50 each (order 2 or 3 for a meal) AND/OR what we had which was a Thali (A Combination Plate).
 
For about $11, you get an authentic homestyle round and sectioned stainless steel tray that holds many wondrous things: first, two choices of the following selection:

Chicken Tikka 
Chicken Tikka Masala
Lamb Curry
Turkey Kebabs
Karahi Paneer
Aloo Jeera
or one of the Daily Veggie Specials (like today's Saag Paneer)

Also with that you get a Daal (lentil) with basmati rice, a large handmade wheat roti, a veggie salad (that is to plotz for), two chutney's (including a cilantro one) and a large spoonful of raita (yogurt).

This is a lot of very good food, served up by friendly and efficient people behind a counter. You then can order drinks or a mango lassi ($3), and find your seat in this small restaurant.

We three did the Thali with: 
Chicken Tikka 
Chicken Tikka Masala
Karahi Paneer
Saag Paneer

And we all agreed how real the food tasted (locally sourced or naturally raised BTW) and how much great food you can get for relatively little in SF. The daal was spicy as was the Karahi Paneer, but the perfect tempering of the raita and the fresh flavors and crunch of the fresh salad tempered this spice. With all the fresh, different textures and flavors that were served on a single platter, we found this a welcome change from the many standard Indian buffets we've had in our past, where we would tend to stick only with "what we knew".

The Chicken Tikka Masala was meaty with a sauce that did not come with that super-creamy opaque sauce, which allowed you to better taste the moist, grilled nature of the chicken. So many other Tikka Masala cream sauces try to cover up cubes of chicken that had gone dry too many hours ago, but this was done in small batches and the result was simply excellent.

Saag Paneer was really good and generous with their Paneer. Their large roti was really tasty and felt homemade rather than commercial.

The service tends to remain behind the counter and you are obligated to clear your own table and set your used dishes in a slot under a counter near the drink machine.

But this rather small place is clean, fast, and delicious; not much more to ask for in the City. We will definitely return.
author: Glenn H.

description:
This place has a different take on Indian food, presenting kati rolls as a sort of "burrito"-style entry to delicious savory wonders.

The ingredients are much more high-quality and less "mushy" than your typical cheap Indian food fare (a lot better than Naan-N-Curry). I love to stop by every now and then when I'm in the Castro, but the spicy-ness level (even without their head-splitting green paste) is too much for my stomach to handle nowadays.

Try out their chicken tikka masala kati roll - has intense flavors. Don't go here if your tongue likes mild flavors!
author: Rahki L.

description: I like this place because it is so different from other Indian restaurants. The ingredients used here seem to have a better quality than the standard indian restaurant, and the food tastes fresh. I usually get the combo platter and yes it is a tad more expensive than the average platter or thali. But the food tastes so good as if home made. The paratha or bread tastes like someone's mother rolled it out. There is a uniqueness in the simplicity of some rice, daal, fresh salad and assortment of chutneys which is very satisfying. I will keep coming back certainly!
author: Seema K.

description:
My main problem with Kasa is that it is eerily authentic. I mean, mother can't cook Indian food this close to what we'd get in the motherland. And not Indian restaurant in India authentic. I'm talking visiting relatives in some 2nd tier city removed from western mores type authentic. 

Totally freaks me out. They only way to deal with it is to eat more Kasa. Nom nom nom nom ok I'm better now (removes face from plate, looks up)... hey, I don't think I've seen someone so hipster AND a gentleman so uncle-ji-llokin' stand so close to each other. 

Must be San Francisco. 

It's in Castro, so tons of queer dudes. I only bring this up because I saw a guy holding a sign saying "If God hates us, why are we so cute?" Can't argue with that. 

I am yet to have a disappointing dish from Kasa, except perhaps the lamb by itself which may have been too mild. Flavorful and light, and you can eat here everyday and not be bored of it. It is a fantasy I am yet to live out. Curry should be a kink on Fetlife.
author: Vineet S.

description:
You guys have EARNED my complete respect!

This is the best Indian wrap I've ever had! I had the spinach and Indian cheese wrap. I also had some raita (yogurt sauce) which paired perfectly with it! 

It was heavy but small enough that it was the perfect serving size.

We had this catered at the office and I'm a little saddened that it's not in the Fidi :( I could eat this on a regular basis!
author: Kathy S.

description: Really disappointed!  I have not been here in a few years,  and the food was cold, dry and tasteless.  Plus, there was no chai tea!  Wont  come back. Maybe I'll try Polk Street instead.
author: Cathy S.

description: I love this place so much! I go almost every week. Kati rolls with chicken tikka masala is amazing, as is the thali platter. Don't forget the mango lassi!
author: Billy S.

description:
"Fresh Indian" is one of those phrases that doesn't seem that intuitive ...sort of like "Pleasantly Overweight" or "Heterosexually Challenged". It sounds like it could be interesting, but somehow you can't get your head around the concept. Well, Kasa has somehow figured out the idea of "Fresh Indian" food because it doesn't have the oily residue of most dishes I've had at Indian restaurants. In fact, this isn't really a restaurant but a casual place to grab a bite in the Castro.

It took over the Castro Tacqueria, which I am embarrassed to say I never tried. I was meaning to, but now it's gone. I didn't even get to say adios. Now I can say namaste. It's a cool open space with counters on one side, a few tables on the other, and a small community table in the middle. The menu is not too complex. You either get the Kati Rolls (one for $5.50, two for $8.95 or three for $11.95) or the $10.95 Thalis, which is described as a "deconstructed Kati Roll" and comes with daal, roti, basmati rice and raita. But they come in six varieties, so there's plenty of choice.

I went for the Lamb Curry Thalis, and it was very fresh-tasting without the tell-tale grease you would get at the buffet places. It's amusing that it's served on an aluminum plate tray that looks like it came from an upscale prison. Now usually I have a Diet Coke with something I know will be spicy, but I tried their Belgian beer on tap. I believe it was called "Tripel Karmeliet", and that was so smooth. I think this will be a new pit-stop for me. Namaste, dude.

FOOD - 4 stars...Fresh Indian...I get it now
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...clean, open, the whole gen-Z vibe
SERVICE - 4 stars...friendly and young
TOTAL - 4 stars...finally a fresh alternative in the Castro to the stodgy Bombay Indian well worth a stop
author: Ed U.

description: After reading all of the great reviews I was so excited to try the kati roll. I thought burrito and chicken tikka masala in one, life couldn't get any better but boy was I disappointed. Concept was good but lacked execution. The chicken tikka masala is like nothing I've had before. Chicken tikka masala I always had was tender chicken with a thick creamy and chalk full of indian spices but the chicken tikka masala here was the exact opposite. I really did like the concept of the kati roll but left sad and disappointed.
author: Julie C.

description: One of my favorite lunch spots. The service is fast, the food is fresh, and it's all super tasty. I like getting the Kati roll lunch- comes with two rolls and a drink. My faves are the saag paneer and gobi aloo. Don't skip out on the hot sauce and onions.  This is an order at the counter place where you can take it to go or eat in. Either way you're in for a treat.
author: Rocio G.

description:
This has become my favorite Indian spot in San Francisco.  The menu is confined to a few items specific to that day.  But you can order them in a full thali or in a kati roll.  This is definitely on the casual side.  But the food is very fresh and their range of sides that come with the full thali makes you feel you're getting quite a nutritious variety.  Lunches come "upgrades" of lassi and chai.  

I've never been disappointed here.
author: Christopher A.

description:
I wandered into Kasa on a whim. I was hungry and up for trying a new place in the Castro. After perusing the menu, I decided the best option for me was to try the Thali, which is a homestyle Indian platter with one or two of their house dishes, roti, daal, rice, veggie salad, tomato and cilantro chutneys and raita. I opted to try the Chicken Tikka Masala (marinated, char-grilled chicken in a spicy, creamy tomato sauce) and the Karahi Paneer (wok-tossed Indian cheese with green preppers and tomatoes). Both were fresh and delicious. I especially liked the paneer because it was prepared a way I hadn't had it yet. The sides were delish with one quibble, the roti was a bit greasy for me. Regardless, I ate it all, and it was a decent sized portion.

PS.  I liked the open interior and big wooden table. I don't expect atmosphere in my fast food, but adore it when I get it. I will definitely go back and try more things.
author: Nicole M.

description:
Most Indians abroad love to talk about "ghar ka khaana" (or home-cooked food) - simple delicious Indian food, usually prepared with fresh ingredients and lots of love (and served best with nostalgia). Kasa definitely gets the simple and delicious parts right.

This is my go-to comfort food. It's not expensive and won't leave me in food coma for hours. The food's not greasy or spicy either (I always skip the hot chutney) so my stomach loves me all the more for it.

Chicken Tikka Masala unda-style (where the roti is coated in egg) and the Saag Paneer are my favorites. This is probably the only Indian place where I don't like the mango lassi (it's too thick and has way too much cardamom). The chai is really good though. Service is friendly and quick. 

On the whole, I am glad this place is in my hood.
author: Amrita M.

description: We ordered tonight on Postmates and eh! Out of all 3 of us, no one was a fan. The chicken masala was very fatty, red, greasy and, clearly low quality. Rice was strange tasting. Only OK thing was the Naan but can't mess that up.
author: Alexis T.

description:
I hesitated between 3 and 4 stars for this place, but the vibe is cool so I'll err on the side of 4.

Stopped in today for a quick bite.... other reviewers are right, the "Chipotle" of Indian food.  Well, almost Indian food.

Had the keema muttar kati roll and samosas (veg).  Not bad... not really Indian per se, but I'd eat it again.  The keema was minced turkey; would be better if it were lamb.  A bit light on the masala blend, no real heat... thankfully I got it "hot" or it would've been unbearably bland.  Sad that the kati aren't made with naan, but that would be tough to do at their price point.  Samosas had been sitting a while I think, and were rather on the small side.  Potato mixture inside was spicier than the keema (plain) but still not quite "Indian" for my taste.  Raita was tasty.

Got there just in time (no line, no wait!) for right after I sat down the place filled with a line to the door.  Is it authentically Indian?  Not really.  It's Indian Lite.  Would I eat here again?  Yep.  For a quick bite.   Would I eat here for REAL Indian food?  Nope... there are more authentic places all over the city. 

Good location, off the madness of Castro.  Quick in and out if that's your thing.  Close enough to the bar scene (if that's your thing) to be convenient.

And, despite hearing horror stories about people getting food poisoning here (I think those reviewers were talking about the Polk location), no problems here (so far, LOL) and the place seemed fairly clean.
author: Scott T.

description: Cottage cheese, the way they make it, is a blasphemy in the name of Indian food. It's dry, without any flavor and well, just not soft enough - to the point where one can question about it being stale. Enough said.
author: A B.

description:
Saag Paneer wrap and two somosas to go. That was PLENTY. I'd love to try the Chicken Tikka Masala. It looks excellent. The staff were very nice. The ordering interface is pretty good but not totally clear in terms of everything you "get." The restaurant is small but very comfortable, with big windows on 18th street.

Considering they are in one of the highest rent parts of the city, this place does pretty well on prices and almost competes with places like Shalimar (Pakistani, actually) and Naan n' Curry in the Tenderloin. I found the hot sauce to be not all that hot, but very tasty. Their spiciness is a bit lower I found, but I have yet to try everything. i consider their portions to be generous and the food does taste authentic to me.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
I am a fan of the veg Thali served there.

Really light and tasty.
author: Nidhi G.

description:
Good food at a good price. I love the Roti rolls w/ egg. I usually get mine with Lamb curry.. Spicy. Under $6

Their thali plate are nice too. You get a couple different dishes, daal, raita, salad, and fresh bread.. All for $11.  

I find the food consistent and makes for a great dinner after a long day of work.
author: Mel D.

description:
I stopped by this place when I was visiting San Francisco a while ago (back when they were in the Marina/Cow Hollow area) and I searched around online to find a delicious eatery near where I was going. Good I checked, because I probably would never have ended up here otherwise. 

Their approach to Indian food is really interesting, and BOY do I wish they had a location back home. Really simple options that are easy to take on the go.

Mango lassi was absolutely incredible.
author: Mark N.

description:
Came here for a lunch special while floating through castro.   

Kati roll with tikka masala 
- very flavorful wiht the right amount of spices and savory juicy chicken
- came with a unique tasting saltier yogurt
- the roti was crispy, soft, and buttery
- my favorite part of the lunch deal

Side of Daal
- very salty, but otherwise bland, beany soup
- would not get again

Mangolassi 
- upgraded the lunch special for $1 to get mangolassi instead of soda
- seems like they used the same salty yogurt that came with the roll
- had black seeds(?) which did not go well with the mango, i would have rather they used plain yogurt to make the mangolassi

bottom line, i would come here for only the kati roll and maybe try their thali
author: Tina A.

description: Ordered chicken tikka masala and the saag paneer on uber eats. The saag paneer was the ok. The chicken tikka masala was pretty bad. It was super salty and had no sauce on it. I wouldn't order from here again.
author: Kenzie T.

description: This place is awesome! It's a face India buritto! Tastes amazingly good! One of my favorite Indian restaurants in the area! It's a must when u are in the area!
author: Amanda F.

description:
Indian street food. Order/pay at counter and find your own table kind of deal. Great if you just want to grab some quick good eats.

I found this place from the 7x7 best cheap eats list. While I've definitely had better Indian food elsewhere, their chicken tikka masala is amazing, and the food is not really greasy and of good quality overall.

I'm a small to average eater, and I can clear 2 kati rolls (Indian style wraps). Bigger eaters can aim for around 3. Like I mentioned, I really like the chicken, but I was partial on the veggie dishes that I tried. They serve raita with the kati rolls, and you can also get a super spicy sauce on the kati rolls or on the side. I'd also recommend getting the eggs in the kati rolls -- definitely makes it taste better.

If I live or work in the area I'd stroll by all the time to get some food.
author: Alice C.

description: We love Kasa's food, and order takeout from Kasa frequently (it's delicious.) We were using Caviar for delivery, until I noticed Kasa now had its own delivery app (powered by ChowNow and UberRush), and as it's cheaper than Caviar, we tried that -- BIG MISTAKE. Our food never arrived!! The order was marked as "delivered" about an hour after I was texted that it was "picked up", but no sign of our food. We called ChowNow, who told us there was a "problem with their driver", and cancelled the order. And now we're stuck here hungry (and possibly $40 poorer to boot, but hopefully they will refund us.) So, in summary, I highly recommend Kasa's delicious food, but I'd strongly recommend NOT using their app! (4 stars for Kasa, zero stars for the app).
author: Alexandra M.

description:
Their kati rolls are the bomb.

I've never had one before and it was the perfect snack size.  And in true Indian food style, packed with flavor.  Their raita is some of the best I've had.  I could just eat that up alone with a spoon (and I did).

In all honesty, the plates look like a better deal - the kati rolls are $4.50 each and they aren't huge.  But for that flavor, I'm willing to pay.
author: Jennifer A.

description: I used to like this place for the two Kati role lunch special. I got the Chicken Tikka Masala. The flavor and spice level are good, but, recently, the price went up and the amount of filling went down. I might give the place another try to see if the low filling amount was a fluke by an employee who didn't know the correct portion amount.
author: Paul L.

description:
Went to Kasa Indian Eatery in the Castro.  You can take the Muni to the Castro station, but I walked cuz I hate paying $2 for Muni.  

From Market St Civic Center it's a long walk to the Castro.  Once at 17th St, go down the road & Left on 18th, then Right on Noe.  It's on the corner.

We got there early before 11am when they open.  You order at the Order counter, then help yourself to silverware & get your food when it's ready.

I got:

The Veggie dish special in the lunch special 2 Kati Roll w/ fountain drink $7.95.  They were Gobi Aloo & Channa Masala.  R. liked them, one more than the other, but forgot which.  Side of Raita - fine. I upgraded to hot Chai for $1 more  & it was tasty enough, but tiny paper cup.

I got Chicken Tikka Masala & Aloo Jeera lunch special 2 Kata Roll w/ fountain drink $7.95.  I liked them fine, they are small & just ok, side of Raita (yogurt) was fine - wanted more.  I upgraded to Mango Lassi for $1 more - it was tasty enough, just small.

Charged it.  They play popular music in there kinda loud.

One unisex bathroom available.
author: Ann L.

description:
Great food - I've eaten here a few times and decided to get delivery last night. The man was cautious at first because I live in GP, he said it was outside of their delivery area but he said ok anyway - I thought that was coolio.

The driver called me a little confused and showed up 5 minutes later. The food - Lamb Curry and Chicken Tikka Masala was much spicier than most Indian places I've been too - and really delicious. I'm not in love with the Roti - I would much rather have Naan, but hey that's what they have and sell and I was glad to have it.

Even though these people are not all Indian working here, I think the food is quite delicious and it's nice that it wasn't bland and had some spice. Also - the price is right. If you go to the restaurant, they are often busy and have good beer on tap.
author: Rew C.

description:
Came on a busy Friday night. The service was disorganized and inefficient (they REALLY need to get a system down), but the food was fresh and yummy. One of the rare Indian places that taste good without making you feel super heavy. The tikka masala chicken and cauliflower with potatoes were my fave out of everyone's dishes; did NOT like the turkey patties. 

The line starts getting unreasonable around 8 so come early!
author: Judy L.

description: Dal was very watery and tbh the food overall was just very unflavourful. Service was ok. Parkings a drag in the Castro FYI and it's pricey for what you get and the quality
author: obgyn K.

description: I'm sorry to say that as fast-Indian food goes, I have had better. I found my lamb curry to be watery and under-flavored. The naan, chutney and other sides are about what you would expect of mass-produced offerings, but certainly not from something that has been made in-house.
author: C B.

description: I have always like this place. Good food, and it's convenience. I probably go there at least once a week. But tonight I was shocked at the bad level of service. The young guy who helped me didn't seem like he wanted to be there. He was shorted and rude, and seem like he wouldn't give me the time of the day. I don't understand why would someone like him would get a job in customer service or why was he hired in the first place.  After I had to deal with him, I no longer had my appetite the the food that I used to love.
author: Hung T.

description:
I came here last night.  Save your taste buds and stomach some time and go to Curry Up Now.

We got the chicken tikka masala kati roll and platter with chicken tikka masala and saag paneer.  Nothing was that great.  I also realized they charged me an extra $7
author: Jenny S.

description: sad excuse for indian food. if you're drunk and starving, you might like it.
author: Eileen T.

description:
This place solves the problem inherent in getting Indian food. 

No one needs an enormous platter of curry, and spinach, and rice, but that's usually the only way to order at Indian restaurants so you end up with a bunch of heavy food just because you wanted to try each thing.

Well Kasa gives you just a bit of a bunch of different things. Each dish I had was delicious, spicy, flavorful.  You can mix and match as you like.  It's like an Indian Chipotle except run by really nice, accommodating, welcoming folks.

My only gripe is that they should expand their menu.  It was so good I want to try MORE of what they can do

Can't wait to go back
author: Meg M.

description: Better than Curry Up Now with a solid kati roll.
author: Dimple B.

description:
So this is just a delivery review since I'm all crippled and on crutches so I'm ordering delivery like crazy.  Anyhow, Kasa is really quick to deliver and although they only deliver after 6pm it's solid!

I had two different Kati rolls - chicken tikka masala and Karahi Paneer.  Both were quite tasty.  Each is like a mini burrito and comes with some delicious raita.  Two filled me up quite nicely but since I had to meet the $15 delivery minimum I ordered a side of chicken tikka masala and rice.

The rice is very light and the chicken tikka masala was delish.  Not super oily like some places and I dug the little peppers that were mixed in.  Nice little kick and makes me want to definitely try many of the other options they have at Kasa!
author: Gene X.

description: Cheap Indian food in the Castro.   It does satisfy my Indian craving, but I think the meat dishes could be more flavorful.  The pepper sauce that is really hot was not to my tasting.   The naan is too flat, as I like mines fluffier.   But again a cheap Indian food eatery to get a meal.
author: Marck N.

description: Wasn't impressed with the food. This is more like a Panda Express version of Indian food. Reasonable for a quick Indian meal, but nothing special, not a "must"
author: Yin How L.

description: The food Here is decent but this place is horribly managed. The employees are rude and the entire place seems dirty. I've been in here probably 4 times (it's right next to my apartment) and always seems filthy.
author: Alexandra S.

description: Roti tastes like old tortilla. Tika Masala wasn't even close to good. Tika is good. Don't care about this place too much. Not coming back.
author: Noc F.

description:
Kasa is the best Indian food in San Francisco.  There, I said it.  I know many people will object, and point out Shalimar or Pakwan (or any number of other places).   These places represent the typical breed of Indian restaurants that I have been going to since I was a kid- heavy, salty, food so greasy that you literally have soft, slick bowel movements for the next two days. 

Kasa is different.  Kasa reminds me of the food I grew up eating (dare I say it) at home.  You can taste the spices.  You can actually taste the vegetables! Yes, there is some ghee and/or oil.  But it's at the level an Indian mom uses when she's having guests over for dinner,  not the pools of grease that are typical for most Indian restaurants. The level of fat is balanced to accentuate, not overpower, the fresh spices, produce and meat.  

They were first know for their kati rolls, which Indian foodie-purists will tell you are not very traditional kati rolls at all.  But never mind what they are called.  The components are such high quality, which is ultimately what matters.  I generally will get a thali and then add the vegetable special of the day and a Kingfisher.  The resultant meal is hands down better than any standard fare Indian restaurant in the city. 

I was sad when they closed the Marina location (because we lived closer to it and they delivered to us).  I guess not enough people in that neighborhood recognized the brilliant simplicity.  Thankfully they still have the Castro location and a food truck, so  I can still get my fix anytime I am missing home cooking.
author: Rakesh J.

description:
Just too sterile for me.  The stainless steel plates aren't warmed, and they mix the cold food and the hot food in the same area of the plate.  The menu signage is hard to follow -- the thing you need to know first (plate or roll) is posted last.  The choice and ingredients aren't posted, except  for the vegetarian options...which taste just fine.

Owner is never there I guess, because boy when the food truck workers appear and the door flies open, they prop it open so we freeze, and then they parade in talking to themselves like there are no customers in the store trying to have a pleasant (and room temperature) moment. 

The counter workers have always been nice, though. But why does it feel like a Subway?
author: David S.

description:
Totally found this place my mistake...er...wasn't looking for it and lured in my a patron rolling his eyes in ecstasy when asked "is this place good". 

I ordered the samosas and he chicken tikka masala. I ate both (what?!). So flavorful and cooked to perfection. Plenty to share and was so good I almost ate it all. 

They serve it up cafeteria style on silver platters with plenty to share. Excellent little patio area, too. :)
author: Abra B.

description: I was excited to see a kathi roll/thali concept, but was disappointed upon tasting the food.  The curries were bland, the kathi roll itself was a small piece of roti which was filled with -dish of your choice- and then rolled into an over flowing tiny burrito.  The mango lassi was too watery with very little flavor.  The prices are decent and the location is wonderful, but not sure if that means much.
author: R C.

description: Very tasty Indian style burritos. I got the chicken tikka Kati roll, super tasty and made with decent ingredients.
author: Carolyn G.

description:
Kasa! How have I not reviewed you yet?? Literally eaten here like 20+ times over the last few years and it is a staple.

I LOVE THIS PLACE. They have really tasty food, excellent chai, and reasonable prices. As others have said, their Kathi Rolls are really some of the best I have had so definitely try those out (Saag for veggies and Chicken Tikka Masala for meat eaters).
author: Raina B.

description:
A City Food Tale 

Once upon a time, (about 2 years ago, to be fair) Goldilocks, in the form of the speed freak blonde homeless guy who hangs out in the Castro, came in to Kasa when I was there.

First he sampled the food from a table where a couple had just left. Ok, he was hungry, and has taste. I get that. 
Next, he started to sample out of the trash. Really really hungry I guess.  

I should have offered  to buy him something, but if you know who I'm talking about then you know he's unpredictable in a scary way.  So I didn't. 
Finally, some other people got a little freaked out and left.  So he sat down and ate their food.  They were nowhere near done with their food- I think just done with the experience. Gotta admit, I left shortly afterward for the same reasons. Really uncomfortable.

What did the guys at the counter do? Appeared to me they did nothing, same as me.  
Maybe they called the police who just hadnt arrived yet? They might have had  previous experience with this guy too, and were afraid of setting him off.

The food was actually pretty good ( thus the three stars) but I have not been back.  I think the physical layout of this place ( counter and kitchen in the back) and the fact that there's no real table service is kind of a flaw. Do I think it's likely that you'd have a similar experience if you ate here? No. But it was memorable.....
author: El B.

description:
Had a Thali plate with a friend recently. For a "fast food" Indian meal is was ok. The chicken curry had a medium spiciness so most Americans could eat without setting mouth on fire. The lamb 'stew' was a bit flavorless but may be it had been sitting on steam table too long. 

Rice was loose and nice texture. The dal was a disappointment. Hardly any lentils to be found. Raita was plentiful, cool and yummy. 

For the price $10, and amount, enough to split if 2 people aren't famished, I'd say it was an average but nicely  different meal from burgers, burritos, and other eateries nearby.
author: Armando H.

description: Gone downhill. Kati roll is overpriced for very little meat...soggy roll...watery consistency...just not a good food experience.
author: Ianto J.

description:
The hype? I don't get it...

Kasa's got 4 stars here, a 2011 Michelin Recommended, and a window full of articles from 2009 proclaiming it the "cheapest hottest new spot in the Castro". So maybe I was a bit presumptuous when I walked in with high hopes for some quality Indian food.

From their friendly, minimal menu I chose a vegetable special, the Saag Paneer (puree spinach with cheese cubes), and the Chicken Tikka Masala. The paneer was solid and I finished all of it, but the tikka masala was way too salty and scarcely seasoned. I kept thinking where's that bold flavor?

The sides were palatable and the portions decent, American-sized if you will. But what good is a plate full of food when you don't want to finish it? At Kasa I get the vibe of an establishment that used to be truly wonderful but has since become complacent. I know there's something good hiding behind that slick purple decor -- but I'd check back in a couple of months if I were you.
author: Ayumi Y.

description:
Fast, good, cheap, and friendly staff! Great recommendation by a friend. We both got the Thali plate and finished every last bite! Well, my friend helped me finish mine.

- Turkey Kebab: spicy! pretty good like mini hamburger patties
- Lamb Curry: not enough spicies but has a clean good taste
- Chicken Tikka Masala: creamy, good
- Daal: sooo good! best I've had
- Veggie Special Curry: okay, a bit bland
- Roti: chewy and good
- Veggie Salad & Raita: simply refreshing
author: Linda C.

description:
Really great spot to grab rolls ! This place reminds me of KAthi roll in NYC - of course not as good. 

But in SF i would say this is the only place offering hot kathi rolls and I loved them. 
Lunch special is great - 2 rolls + lassi for $11 

I had the chicken and paneer rolls. I have to say I liked paneer more. My chicken was slightly burnt.
author: Priyanka P.

description: Place is still delicious. But this time my only compliant is the chicken samosa. It was very bland and dry and seemed to have been sitting under the hot lamp all day. Everything else tasted so fresh just not the chicken samosa.
author: Corey F.

description: I have only eaten here once. It's actually not bad because the food is inexpensive. Also they are really big portions. Obesity party for one.
author: Vinson H.

description:
Kasa, oh how I love thee. Let me count the ways:

Karahi Paneer
Saag Paneer
Kati Rolls

This is seriously one of my favorite places for lunch and definitely bests most of the Castro eateries.

I love the freshness of ingredients, the bright flavors of the raita, marinated onions, and chutney. The daal is pretty spicy and all the better for it!

I love the kati rolls because they are quick and easy, but often get the Thali plate which, all laid out on a metal plate, is just plain beautiful.
author: Ennis O.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVED EVERYTHING!! (and this coming from an Indian who misses home cooked non greasy food) YAY !!
author: Meher S.

description: Solid. Just super solid, reasonably priced, good ingredients Indian food with beer in a great location. They are usually very friendly and I've never had a problem when coming here consistently for many years now. Hope these guys are here to stay!
author: Teo C.

description:
CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA! I can never get enough of it. I totally get why it's the number 1 dish in London, well according to Gordon Ramsey. Speaking of Ramsey, why do all his restaurants in Kitchen Nightmares always end up failing or closing down after he leaves? 

Anyway, when I need a quick chicken tikka masala fix, I stop by Kasa for their kati rolls. This is served with yogurt to off-set the spiceness. DELICIOUS!
__
Jan '12 Health Score - 90
author: Dennis L.

description:
I went back twice today. The name alone sounds like it's NOT "authentic" Indian food. It doesn't bother me.

I made a specialized meal and it was great! The roll is little enough so it essentially is a snack. I like it that way though because I'm an on the go person and need just enough to fill me up. They stuffed it both times I went. I also ordered the drink near that cash register and geez, that is amazing!

STAFF was hilarious and easy going. Amazing service both in the daytime and evening!

Love trying new places and I've seen this around so many times, glad it didn't dissapoint.
author: Sweets N.

description: This review is a bit bias since I am part Indian. I don't really know why I came here since I can get kati rolls for free all the time...except we don't call them kati rolls because you can put anything in roti and eat it. So part of my issue with this place is I just don't understand the concept and the hype. I absolutely adored the staff, but I was not highly impressed with the cuisine. I got the paneer kati rolls and aloo one. Both were just okay and had me wishing I would have saved the money and got some home-cooked "kati rolls" instead.
author: Surge C.

description:
om nom nom nom nom!!!!
I am LURVING the lunch special: $7.95 for 2 kati rolls, a side of raita and a fountain drink.

The roti on the kati rolls are purrfekshun! The veggie special today 12/18/09 was gobi aloo. Man, it was perfectly spiced w/ cumin..nice, fresh, big hunks of cauliflower and an even proportion of potatoes. 
The lamb curry kati wasn't all that, I think the flavor in their gobi aloo was much more powerful. 

Mad props to the amigos making all the food, I loved it.
author: Susy C.

description: I don't think they deliver anymore. Booo.
author: Antonio L.

description:
I was in pain for hours in the fetus position and walked around like a penguin side to side. I factored in the cost of the Pepto Bismol and Alka Seltzer in the Price Range I had to pick on Yelp.

No no no no.
 
Went there once before, it wasn't terrible. Not great but not terrible. Second time around though was stomach clench central. I was warned against it (food poisoning) but still went feeling Indian and iron stomach invincible. 

No no no no! (Get a burrito instead).
author: Anish B.

description:
Excellent food made from scratch.  If you are very hungry then go for the Thali.  If you are in the mood for something light then have a kathi roll. I also I like to get a side of dall with rice.  

They have an excellent lunch combo of thali and lassi for quite a bargain.

Updated on October 17:
Noticed that the  service is good.  So rating them 5 stars now (was 4 stars earlier).
author: Chet M.

description: Vaguely "panda express" in feel and flavor; there's nothing spicy about the tikka masala or even the hot sauce. Just meh.
author: Scott W.

description:
The chai here is really good!

Plenty of great options for veggies - it's simply sabji rolled into rotti, so you can't really go wrong with that!
author: Ankur J.

description: Their tika masala is extrmemely spicy and it's way too much with the Kati rolls but over all okay on the Kati rolls. The samosas on the other hand are grand! The environment is really purple and people like.
author: Laura P.

description:
I was debating on 2 or 3 stars, because...
- My lamb stew wrap was tasty, altho the yogurt dip was ok, not great, but ok
- The service was really great, the wrap maker and cashier were super nice, knowledgeable and friendly
- but the serving size was itty-bitty, I'm talking teeny weeny mini portions. If I'd had known I would have ordered sides, the plate or taken my biz elsewhere

Needless to say, Im still hungry! 
 
I'm a petite female, I generally only eat 1/2 of my Ike's sammich or Farolito burrito, I cannot finish them and am stuffed at half. No worries, I like knowing I have a nice snack for later.

Kasa's wrap is so tiny, I'd say its 1/4 the size of a Farolito burrito. I just ordered the wrap, no sides. It was TINY and $6.11 with tax. How is that one "$"? This is at least a two$$ eatery - if you want to get full, that is. 

I'm really bummed. I picked it up "to go" on the way home. I ate it in 4 bites. I'm still hungry and dont want to go forage for more food. If I had gone to one of my staples - Ike's or Farolito I would have spent a couple bucks more at Ike's, spent a couple bucks less at Farolito but I'd be stuffed with leftovers in the frig! 

Nope, won't be back.
author: Yolanda I.

description:
Menu as easy as 1-2-3
Bright and clean space with plenty of seating.
Fresh and healthy ingredients (that tastes good too)
The Chicken Tikka Masala Roll is delicious with it's yummy wrap and saucy chicken.
Veggies on the side, yes please.
If you like quick Indian food and you're in the Castro/Dolores area you can't go wrong with Kasa Indian.
P.S. They also have a food truck roaming the streets of SF as well so you can catch them on the go.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Couple of things 
I have eaten here before and it's always been good. 
Today I ordered pickup 
I requested for two things
a) not to make the lamb Kati roll spicy
b) my veg thali gluten free
I go to pick up my food and when I get there request for extra yogurt sauce for the roll. 
The guy at the counter realized he gave me a roti with my veg thali even though I had specifically requested for gluten free. 
I get home  and I am really disappointed

a) the aloo gobi is myeh- no flavor
b) the lamb Kati roll was spicy
c) had I not requested for extra yogurt sauce I would not have had any yogurt with the Kati roll. They simply forgot to add yogurt sauce to my roll when I went to pick it up. 

Needless to say I am not coming back here.
author: Tenzin B.

description: Love some Kasa! We ordered expensive takeout the other night from another Indian place nearby and wasn't nearly as good as Kasa. They are just consistently good and the employees are super friendly. Decently priced and great food!
author: Lana S.

description:
Getting put on hold for ten minutes to order delivery, and then proceed to completely misunderstand every word I say: 

Not a big deal, phone orders can be tough.

Taking an hour and half to deliver my food, and then complain upon arrival that I'm out of their delivery range: 

Out of my control, but forgivable.

Getting more sick after eating their food, then the entire 2 and a half months I spent in the region known for food born illness and me eating from every food cart:

Unacceptable. I think I almost pooped my pants. That was traumatic, and I never get food sick.

NEVER AGAIN :(
author: Ben J.

description:
This review is really only 2.5 stars. Though the people working there are really nice, and the minimalist cafe style is fun, the food really pulls this place down.

The kati rolls are made with parathas (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paratha) not naan or roti as some of the other people mentioned. The parathas are pretty well made, actually. The stuffing isn't great ... and really why this place gets pulled down to 2.5 stars. Overall there's nothing special or great about the food.

The lassi has a lot of cardamom, which is quite weird and makes it hard to drink.
author: Akash K.

description:
First meal off the plane is at Kasa. As we're gawking at the menu trying to understand what's going on, this lady behind us is like, "I think you, uh, order over there?" And I look around, and I'm like, "Oh, you mean under the huge 'ORDER HERE' sign?" and she's like, "Yeah, well, I didn't want to say that..." Thanks lady for pointing out that I'm totally oblivious to the obvious.

Anyway, DK brought me here, so he suggested ordering a couple of kati rolls (handmade bread) to share, as well as a thali (plate). So we tried the chicken tikka and the lamb for the rolls and the gobi and turkey kebabs for the plate. 

The roll was made of this buttery version of what reminded me of a corn tortilla (my super primitive and uncouth description). It was good, but I think it was a bit on the buttery side for me. Everything was really tasty, although the turkey was a bit on the hot side. 

I can see someone easily finishing two rolls, or a plate, but I'm glad we shared everything. For all that, I think it was about $25 or so. Not too many seats in there, and there's a counter, so this place probably gets a tad crowded around lunchtime. This is not something I crave, since I'm more of a naan girl.
author: Ming-Jou C.

description:
I've eaten here easily 75 times.  It is in my neighborhood and has a great vibe.  I have to say though that once upon a time the hot chiles were under control.  You could still taste the individual  ingredients and herbs used to prepare awesome veggies, chutney, chicken tikka masala, etc.  In my mind, the hot spices are out of control.  So, if you like heat, go for it.  Otherwise, order very carefully.  

The chai tea is delicious...  

Also, should a side of veggies be the same price as a side of meat?  Just asking...  I so wish they'd sell the coconut cilantro chutney to go.  It is amazing.
author: M M.

description:
This review is for when Kasa catered for my company.

A slew of tin foiled wrapped rolls arrived in the office today from the heart of the Castro. I wanted to be bold and daring, but somewhat reserved so I went for the Karahi Paneer Kati roll and Chicken Tikka Kati roll. My bold choice, the Karahi, was a little on the plain side, but dipping in Raita (yogurt sauce) added that extra ingredient that made it pop. I took an intermission with the veggie salad. Not much there, but the description did say "simple veggie salad" so I wasn't expecting much. Then came the final element, the pièce de résistance, chicken tikka. Even for catering, these guys hooked it up with extremely generous chunks of chicken that were lathered in a perfectly spiced chutney. Rolling that in raita made my mouth water for each bite. If this place can hook it up for catering, then I would definitely pay them a visit.
author: Eric T.

description:
The Thali plate is awesome -- all the main dishes are excellent, and the sides (raita (yogurt), kati rolls, and vegetables) are great, too. Reasonably priced, super tasty, and all around healthy too -- a good place for take out or for a casual dinner. They're not kidding about their Chai being the "best in SF" either.

My only cautionary note: don't get the turkey... your stomach will thank you in the morning.
author: David B.

description:
A solid, satisfying 4 stars!  

So happy this is one of my neighborhood joints!   Where have I been all this time?

Food is quick, convenient, super tasty, and reasonably priced.  That's what I'm talkin' about.  Love it when I can save a buck.  

Here's how it works:  You make a choice between two meal combos.  Then you choose which dishes you want to include in your meal.   

****My recommendation:  YOU MUST GO FOR THE ROTI!  I grew up on roti and curry, so believe me when I say that Kasa's roti is bomb*****
author: Angella S.

description:
This is my new favorite restaurant!  I love  the fact that its fast, fresh and affordable and let's not forget delicious.  This isn't like your typical Indian joint such as Naan 'n Curry.  It has it's on twist on Indian cuisine, like rolling the food in the roti roll and the Thali plate.  I love that they have a veggie of the day since I am a vegetarian.  Also, you must try the chai it is a nice balance of spice and flavor.

When I order I usually get the $8.95 special but instead of 2 rolls I get my other side dish a la carte, which leaves me feeling satiated and not uncomfortably full.  But if your hungry go for the two rolls or better yet the Thali plate which comes equipped with 2 sides, lots of chutneys, daal, roti and more, yum!  I just wish they had mango chutney.

Yes, the atmosphere is very modern and not like your typical Indian place, but I think that is the point.  Oh and It can be a little loud in there when the place is full, but other than that its a perfect little Indian eatery.  Lastly, the staff are very helpful as well as welcoming.  You rock Kasa!
author: Molly M.

description:
If you want a small, quick bite to eat but have intense, complex & truly amazing flavors in each and every bite, then pass by Kasa and pick up one of their $4.50 Kati rolls ..... (aka "Indian burritos").  

What a treat.  

We had one stuffed with chicken tika masala and it did not dissappoint.  The protein was amazingly tender and the sauce was phenomenal.  We need more places like this.
author: Rico O.

description: I have eaten at this place many times since my last review and I can now see why it is so popular. The quality of food is consistently good and fresh, just like at home. You can eat there every week and not get bored with the flavor. Unlike other Indian restaurants, you feel good and satisfied...but not heavy after eating here.  Now that deserves an extra star :)
author: Balu V.

description:
I was kind of thrown off by this place... It's essentially a build-your-own-wrap or plate type of place. I walked up to the counter unsure of how to order... and sure enough, the person at the register just stood there with no explanation. I'll spare u the rest of the details... I went with the tikka masala wrap and a sambusa.  I guess the concept is cool, but the food itself isn't that great.  I thought the sambusa was good, but the chicken tikka masala was dry, not saucy at all and really lacked some flavor.

If I was in the area, I might grab a bite to eat here again, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go here. It sure as hell did not satisfy my indian craving...
author: Diane L.

description:
If I lived in the neighborhood, I would definitely be a regular at Kasa.  I came for a light meal, and the Kati roll did the trick.

I chose the veggie special of the day, which was aloo gobi (potatoes and cauliflower).  They take the roti, which is like an Indian tortilla, and fill it with your dish of choice, add some chutney and red onion, and then roll it up like a burrito.  On the side is some fresh raita.  It's perfection at $4.95.

To drink I had their mango lassi.  It wasn't as sweet as I've had at other Indian restaurants, which was good, and had a subtle hint of cardamom.  They also serve beer and wine, as well as Indian sodas.

Kasa may be a fast-casual restaurant, but it rivals some of the best gourmet Indian restaurants I've been to.  I loved this place!
author: Amy K.

description: I had a Thali combo plate with tikka masala and cumin potatoes. The rice was kind of cold but still tasted good. I like how they gave some side sauces and salads. It was a bit pricey. $11.99 for two sides and rice.
author: Richie C.

description:
This place is over estimated. Came here and ordered thali plate with chicken masala, potatoes, rice, and lentils. The chicken tasted like burned, the cilantro sauce was super bitter, the rice didn't have flavor at all! And the lentils were mah! 
I paid like 12 - 13 bucks for something that isn't worthy at all. The service was ok
author: Itzel L.

description: I like the kati rolls, my favorite being the aloo gobi and least favorite being the chicken tikka masala. Because it needs to stay wrapped in the roll, the chicken tikka masala kati roll lacks the plentiful sauce that would normally come in a plate. The aloo gobi is also dry, but this lends to the meatiness of the cauliflower, which I like. The wrap is nice and crisp when fresh, but keep well as leftovers. They are a small, but decent size. It comes with fresh, thick raiti and a little salad of tomatoes. If not from the food truck or catering however, I would recommend the curry plates here because they are much more interesting. Catering is not cheap, but they make it so easy and it's a crowdpleaser for most.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Yum! I have had the Lamb Curry Kati Roll and the Chicken Tikka Masala Kati Roll and the Samosa.  So tasty and cheap.  They also have a fountain soda machine- great for soda addicts like my husband and I.  

We will be back!
author: Christy L.

description: Good for on the go rolls , chicken tikka masala is the way to go. Limited options but wraps are good. Thali is overpriced.
author: Sameer C.

description: It is a nice environment, and very clean. Lots of options, and I picked the paneer roll. It was okay, and I thought it lacked flavor/spice. Would recommend adding more chutney. Didnt really put together my roll very well, the entire thing fell apart even though it was wrapped in paper. Also felt like jail food for a second when they served my plate, because he threw the yogurt down on the plate. I would return, but hoping the taste and service improves a bit.
author: Veeral S.

description:
This food was absolutely the worst. Not only was this bad Indian food, but just bad food in general.

I ordered a plate of the Lamb Curry, Aloo Gobi, Chicken Tikka Masala with some Daal and Rice along with a bunch of Samosas. All this food was for my coworkers and myself.

The Lamb Curry had NO CURRY and was DRY. The Chicken Tikka Masala was just as bad. The rice was BLAND, just boiled and unseasoned. The Daal was basically soup, it was so WATERED DOWN. The Aloo Gobi wrap was not only child-sized, but was essentially a brick of salt. Maybe it was named after the Gobi desert.

The only items to reach the heights of mediocrity were the Samosas, though I suspect they were just frozen and mass-produced and  probably bought at Trader Joe's.

I bought all this for my co-workers, but it was just embarrassing. My BOSS ACTUALLY THREW UP 10 minutes after her meal.

I'm sure the employees are great but - honestly - NO ONE SHOULD EAT HERE! It's a miracle they have 2 locations and a truck. This food belongs on a truck, all right - a GARBAGE TRUCK!

The food was so bland they gave us a gallon of chutney to drown out the lack of flavor and atrociousness.  American, watered- down food. STAY AWAY!

This place is for people who have ABSOLUTELY NO TASTE for good Indian food.
author: Ghandi R.

description:
Kasa was recommended by a friend who is originally from Chandigarh, India.  I have not a single complaint about Kasa.  Ingredients (meets and veg.) are fresh, complex, and NOT greasy! Rarely do I find or even say chicken is flame kissed.  

The chai is some of the best I have tasted.  It's spicy, hot, and not too creamy.  No sugar needed.

IMO, they are pretty reasonably priced for the quality of ingredients they use.  If you are looking for cheap food (flavor and price), then go somewhere else. You don't deserve Kasa's food.
author: Vannezsa S.

description:
This is not an Indian restaurant it's a fast food joint and a lousy one at that. The food is pre-prepared, they scoop it into trays. There are two, count em two entrees on the menu, and the food is TASTELESS. 

Kasa is appropriately located in the slag section of 18th St. in the Castro.
author: Chuck S.

description: Bad food...pricey for the quality of the food...hate sayin this about a small business...but the truth is the truth
author: Kavitha B.

description: Their choice is limited but whatever they do they do it well. Love their Kati rolls - chicken tikka and lamb curry are favs. Absolutely love their chai - you won't ever call Starbucks chai a chai after this.
author: Sankara R.

description: The Kati roll, while small is a pretty nice bargain considering the neighborhood. Chicken Tikka filling was a mildly bland, although to be honest who's expecting Jones street flavor in the Castro?
author: Anthony R.

description: I've seen Kasa food truck at Off the Grid a million times... but ironically my first taste of this place was at their restaurant location on 18th street. I got the Kati Roll filled with Chicken Tikka Masala, I asked them to make it spicy and OMG it was freaking spicy. The server wasn't kidding when she said it can make you cry. It took me a little while to finish the roll, but I really liked it! ...Although next time I think I'll stick with mild spiciness.
author: Elaine N.

description:
I had their Chicken Tikka Masala Kati roll (a small and tasty Indian burrito) for lunch. A flaky, buttery roti (handmade bread) wrapped around one of the dishes listed below with marinated onions and chutney. Served with raita (yogurt). 

It was delish! I loved the hot sauce. It added the extra kick, which added to the experience. I would definitely come back and try some of their other dishes.
author: Kristina S.

description:
Feaking yum.  

Coming back from a show at the Castro theatre we just stopped off here for a bite.  Plenty of vegetarian options and tasty tasty rolls.   You can either get thali platters or rolls and have your choice of a few fillings.  That's about it but they are so tasty that that's all you need.  Decent beer selection as well.  

Don't confuse this with a nice sit down table service place, this is much closer to street food, and the atmosphere reflects that, however, the food is great and that's all you really need to know
author: Travis B.

description:
I've had lunch and dinner at Kasa close to a dozen times this past year.  

Ambiance:  Clean and casual.

Service: Friendly and very accommodating for food allergies.

Food (gluten-free dairy-free perspective): They serve quick, convenient, and flavorful dishes.  They're also very knowledgeable on the ingredients they use for their dishes and can tell you what is gluten and dairy free.  I usually order the combination platter and hold the daal, yogurt sauce and bread.  Overall the food (considering it's 'fast food') is consistently great!
author: G B.

description: Been to the truck, now to the B&M.  Never too much food, just the right amount for a healthy sized snack (I love Indian food, so it's easy for me to go overboard.)  Always a veggie option.  Nothing to complain about here.
author: Monica R.

description: This is one of my favorite Indian restaurants because it's flavorful and very convenient. It's not super spicy or super authentic, but it's very well executed and has a variety of strong flavors. My favorite is the kati roll because the bread is delicious and very soft. You can get this with a variety of curries, my favorite is the Chicken Tikka Masala, but the lamb curry is also good. Everything also comes with a tasty yogurt sauce to put on top. It's not dirt cheap, but I consider it a really good value and it's very filling.
author: Nicolas H.

description: So so food. Chicken tikka masala did not taste authentic at all. Also they have no wine! With Indian food you must offer red wine! Otherwise place is ok.
author: Lauren S.

description: Kasa was once my favorite go to place in the neighborhood. Unfortunately, it has lost its ranking with me. The food is no longer fresh - often, the rice has that "left in the pot too long" taste, the flavor of the spices in the various dishes are inconsistent from day to day, the kati bread is more like cardboard. The tables are often dirty and the help seems inattentive to the issue. It's sad that Kasa is no longer a quality restaurant.
author: Cheryl L.

description:
Recently I seem to crave Kasa more than I have previously. No I'm not preggers, and couldn't be even if I so desired, but I digress.

I like the food here. There is flavor, so thats good, but also the employees seem happy :) That is really important to me. I also like the fact that you can text your comments to them. Not only do they read it but they get back to you (with something besides a canned message).
