They are trying, they serve good food, and it seems like they find happy people and manage to keep them content - all while being consistent. I can't really ask for more; Kasa, you are good in my book!

(reading my original review, it seems like their service has always been stellar. Also to my previous point about taking feedback seriously, the tea is now just right)!
author: Vivek N.

description:
Maybe I'm not the best person to be reviewing an Indian restaurant, but I know from my experiences with good and bad meals that I have had and how to compare it to this one. 

Yes, I think the variety you can order from the combo plate is great, and the server who I believe is the owner and also the chef, was very patient with me in describing what was being offered. But in the end, I didn't feel as though I was given enough food for my tastes. I typically like to eat large dinners, and this was not enough food for me.  I was left feeling hungry shortly after the meal. 

I was expecting to find Tandoori Chicken available or maybe a Murgh Madras. But understandably these are dishes that might be a little more expensive for this place or maybe there's not enough to be made in order for the number of people that come in. 

One of my favorite Indian restaurants in the city is Roti Indian Bistro, it's not really super fine Indian dining, and it is one that I grew up with in the West Portal neighborhood. This was my yardstick.

Yes the meal was inexpensive. This is also a great place to hangout and talk it out with some friends for dinner. One of the saving graces for me was that they had a whole pint of Taj Mahel, which I finished off with a smile.
author: Michael C.

description:
Chicken Tikka Masala was not very good.

Lamb was bland and a bit minty.

Saag Paner - cheese and spinach was the highlight of the meal. 

Not the best indian food around the neighborhood.
author: Mike I.

description:
A very interesting Indian place in the middle of Castro. I've never been to India or have had 'real' Indian street food but from what I've seen on TV, it seems like this is would be similar to it. A very unique way of eating where patrons get to pick two entrees and then a metal plate of food consisting of basmati rice, chutneys, lentils, and other sides. It is a very big meal. I think the metal plate is the thing that makes it the most interesting. It's nothing special but not a lot of places in the US give metal plates and dinnerware.

Anyways, as for the food. I had the Tikka Masala and lamb curry. I'm not sure what is considered 'authentic' Indian cuisine but the tikka masala i received here was not in its usual thick creamy sauce. Nor was the curry. It wasn't bad at all and in fact quite delicious. To sum it up it was just different. A new experience of what we often consider 'traditional Indian cuisine'.

I recommend this place if you are looking for something new and fun.
author: edward k.

description: Amazing! And cheap. Fun, interesting, and spicy. And that's just the people serving. The food was outstanding. Come here for a great, flavorful food, without the fancy- stuffy feel.
author: Julian C.

description: This place has okay food, more like a fusion. The cooks over here are all non-indians so its toned down, mostly non-spicy food. We tried the thaali with chicken tikka masala, aloo gobhi and daal. Although chicken tikka masala is very good. You can try it with rice. Other dishes were okay. Its fast food so you don't have to wait. Would have given more stars if the other items would have tasted better.
author: Manveer C.

description:
I REALLY didn't want to like this place.  They stole my business idea :(  and are very sucessful.  In light of that, I will not use any exclamation marks in this review.

The food is off the chain.  It is amazing Indian food at a very reasonable price.  The people are nice too, damn it.  Parking sucks!  (OK, one exclamation mark.)

The thali is a ton of food.  Everything tastes extremely fresh and home-made.  Many vegetarian options.  The meat isn't mystery meat nor does it have the frozen/recently defrosted taste that some places have.  Also, as much as I love me some Naan&Curry, it's a lot lighter than other cheap Indian food places.

My mom LOVED it which is a huge compliment because that woman doesn't like anything.  Pretty much every time we eat out, she'll sniff "I can make this better....and cheaper...$15 for eggplant???  Do you know how much eggplant costs on Clement Street"  OK, mom, I'll relay your message to Michael Mina...

Be careful with ordering your food spicy.  It is really, really spicy.  

Good job Kasa, I knew it was a great idea.  :(
author: A S.

description: I've been meaning to review these guys/gals for a while. Love the kati rolls, everything is delicious. I actually had them cater my birthday party back in October and it was a great experience. Everything was done very professionally, the setup was prompt and professional, and all my friends were somewhat blown away that I had bothered to get catering, so I think that gave me cool points. woo!
author: Tasha D.

description:
For a quick bite to eat, the price is reasonable, the food is ok, and seems fresh. I would eat here again, but certainly wouldn't go out of my way to do so.

We ordered the Chicken Tikka and Chicken Tikka Masala combos. Unimpressive. Certainly edible, but a far cry from what you'll get at a good Indian restaurant. Chicken Tikka was just grilled chicken with some not particularly flavorful spices. Very disappointing. The masala was better, but still just average vs. most other Indian restaurants, especially if they use a Tandoori (or something like it). Considering they aren't especially cheap (combo is $11... rice plus CTM at most restaurants will set you back about $15-$20 and you'll get 2-3 meals out of it). Not sure how anyone can rate this place 5 stars if they regularly go to Indian restaurants. Maybe the vegetarian dishes are better, but being a carnivore I didn't try them.

I also did not try the Kati. Sounds like that may be one of their strong points, so maybe get that instead of the combo.
author: Jim T.

description:
Good food.  I am told this is very traditional.  
Atmosphere is good but busy and not meant for a long hangout.
You walk up to a counter with a short menu hanging above and pick what you want.  Again, very few options, I'd say between two we had half the menu in one go.  Short but all dishes were good.  My disappointment is the lack of naan bread :(...I need me some nann!!

I don't know if this needs to be said but it is in the castro district which is known for being very open to all human being and sexual orientations.  So if that scares you I would suggest going back to what ever conservative god fearing rock you crawled out from under.

Over all good place and I would come here again.
author: Dane S.

description:
Probably the best North Indian Thali in San Francisco. (can even compare to some places in the hub of Indian food scene...South Bay). Good quality food. 

Lamb, saag, paneer and various other dishes are delicious. 

Kathi rolls are good too but expensive...2 small kathi rolls for $10...whereas the thali is a great deal...enough for even 2 not so hungry folks.

Good thing is service is fast, there could be a long line at times.
author: A K.

description:
Solid, pretty healthy, cheap dinner (thali plate). I normally love paneer, but actually dig the gobi (cauliflower) in whatever formation they pick even more. Limited menu, but it's all pretty tasty. The extra spicy sauce is SPICY, they are not messing around.

Kati rolls are maybe not as healthy, but are tasty and portable. I like that they usually have a good beer on tap (like Tripel Karmeliet). Ambiance is very cafe/cafeteria-ish.
author: Ara S.

description: I have eaten here before and thought the food very good.  Today I went and the food was almost inedible.  I ordered the Thali plate with chicken masala and chicken tikka.  The masala dish tasted burnt and the grilled chicken was extremely dry.  the sides did not look nor taste fresh.  Two of us shared the plate and though we were very hungry we threw most of it away.  I am bummed because I used to enjoy this place and will now not return.
author: mi m.

description:
Pretty much what everyone else is saying, Indian version if Chipotle.  Very efficient and yummy way to get quick service Indian food!  

Ordered the kati rolls with chicken tikka masala and was pleasantly surprised.  The place has tons of food traffic but you're likely to get a solo seat at the family style bar table or individual tables all around.

Came here for dinner...ordered, seated and out the door within 30 minutes and all for less than $10/person.  Can't really complain and the food tastes delicious!  To be honest, I don't have much to compare with what we order here, but I can tell you that my taste buds LOVE the texture of the kati roll, the juiciness of the meat and the side sauces for dipping.  My taste buds are buzzzzzzing with happiness.  The portions are decent but I did notice that many of the men would order 2 of the kati rolls.  I guess if you were to compare portions each kati roll would be equivalent to half of a mexican burrito.  I guess it depends on how hungry you are!

Very trendy, not traditional!
author: Sandy L.

description:
This place USED to be great  - at least innovative. The quality of the food and service has really slipped.  The curries are bland, overcooked, very mediocre. It has the taste of raw ingredients sourced from Costco-sized canned goods and ready-made commercial spice blends.  

The service has also slipped a lot - a constant rotation of new staff who don't really understand the food, serving slop as though they were working in a high school cafeteria.  And god forbid you take anyone who is a traditional vegetarian Indian there, because the cross-contamination of dripping meat juices everywhere from careless handling will disgust them. Last time we went in the guy was literally pushing piles of lamb down with his full hand, and then continuing to work, touching everything else. Keep your Indian parents away!

Really, I should give them 1-star, except I'm still grateful those times I want to fill that craving for curry in a hurry.
author: Lester N.

description:
Yelp tells me I'm a regular at this place.  That's only amazing because I just started going there a few weeks ago...and I can't stop.  You might think it's a little embarrassing to walk into a place less than 24 hours after your first visit and order the same exact thing you had the day before from the same dude who took your order the first time.  It's not.  It only starts to get a little weird on day 3...or 4.  

Regardless, this stuff is good.  Super good.  The Kati rolls are  delicious.  Even 4 days in a row.
author: Renee D.

description: Food is good, good choices daily. Had thali for 11$ which came with rice, roti, dal, 2 curries, salad and couple of hot salsas. A fountain drink too. I recommend this to veggi lovers and folks who are interested in quick bites.
author: Nagaraju R.

description:
Mmm mmm good... great kati rolls and thali plate options... the roti was really that darned fresh. There are at least 6-8 options for filling/entree to accompany that. Itz sorta cafeteria-style set up with better than cafeteria-style tasting food!!!!

At prices of $8 or $9 (respectively), that come with a drink for the lunch hour, very cool. Plus, the flavor of almost everything was spot-on, save the lamb curry. it was quite bland, seasonless, and definitely not in a curry! looked like rehydrated meat and tasted just a tad better. basmati lacked that buttery fragrance that some places can do just so well. 

The yoghurt side was done perfectly. Clean, airy, nice environment that   seems more modern and updated. Kudos to them for doing a great job. Oh.. and the Groupon tack-on was the icing on the cake!
author: Jana C.

description: Maki rolls are the worse. Lamb was better than chicken. Chicken roll felt like I was eating paratha from 3 days ago with a loaf of salt. Yuck. I would not recommend this place at all specially if you are hungry and want good indian meal.
author: Ayesha M.

description:
This is a long and over due re-review of Kasa. Kasa has become my favorite go-to Indian restaurant! It's my comfort food. The flavors are so fresh and the food affordable, especially if you go for lunch during the week. I almost always get the thali plate with chicken tikka masala and the saag paneer. Yum!!

Never again did I see someone peak into the rice cooker while the rice was cooking nor have they ever run out of rice :-)

Request: Please bring some eggplant into one of the daily specials soon!!
author: Leslie T.

description:
I love me some Indian food, and when I'm in the area and looking for a quick bite, Kasa is at the top of my list. 

One of the best things is that you can order a thali and be able to try several different delicious things.  At most places you have to make the nail biting decision between palak paneer and chicken tikka, or end up over eating at a buffet, but a thali offers you some options without the regret. Aside from the 1 or 2 entrees, it also comes with daal (lentils), roti (sort of like naan, but more tortilla-like), rice, salad, chutney and yogurt.

Minus one star because it gets crowded, and last time I was there they were doing a sloppy job of keeping the used dishes and trash area clean.
author: Charlotte C.

description:
I'm declaring it...  Kasa has the best Indian food in the city.  Not because the food has the most complex flavors or is made with the crazy exotic ingredients.  It's exactly the opposite - simplicity which makes it so good.  To top it off it is fairly inexpensive and they also has some awesome beers.  I'm here very often - once a week for sure because I crave it so much.

Kasa mainly serves north Indian food: various Kati rolls with different vegetarian or meat fillings and thalis.  The thalis come with two main dishes, rice, daal, roti, salad, and yogurt.  They are quite large - way too much food for one person in my opinion.  So bring a friend and split it.

My usual order is a karahi paneer wrap and a side of daal and rice in one bowl (they'll combine the two if you ask) for a total of about $8.  This includes a side of yogurt or salad as well.

The chicken tikka masala and and turkey kababs are great too.  I haven't tried my wrap "anda style" (with egg) but my friends order it often.

Add a bottle of Tripel Karmeleit and you have a hearty meal with booze for about $13.

I'd give this place 6 stars if I could!
author: Samir C.

description: Kasa is great for Indian on the go! The food tastes authentic and they have a very convenient wraps (the Kati roll) or to-go plates if you are a bit more hungry. The curry selection isn't the most extensive, but what they have is delicious. I look forward to many more meals at Kasa.
author: Sophia A.

description:
I thought the food was good... not the best compared to some other places I've eaten... but good. 

my only issue is the price. I thought it was a little pricey especially if you have to pay $2.50 for a small cup of chai thats usually free at other places.
author: Ish A.

description:
I started going here around the time that they opened and every time I've been its a great experience, both from the food and service perspective.  I've been there about 10 times and I think I've ordered the same thing all ten times.  Kasa offers a small variety of choices include Kati Rolls with different fillings, Thalis, and specials on various days.  

I've always ordered the Kati rolls because they taste so darn good.  My favorite is the lamb kati roll and the chicken tikka masala roll is a close second.  I like dipping them in the yogurt I get on the side before I devour eat scrumptious bite.  Its very reasonably priced too.  I get 2 Kati rolls for around $10 and if I want a third its around a total of $13.  2 rolls are filling for me, but if you are super hungry you can add on a third.  

One thing about eating there is that it always feels cold.  Not sure if its the metal decor or if the windows are always open, but I'm always cold there.
Definitely recommend and will be back to chow down again.
author: Ash S.

description:
I love this place! It really is like a taqueria for indian food. 

Love it because it's open all day (no closing in between), fresh/refreshing flavors, the decor, the food, the chai, the location, and yea pretty much everything they have to offer. OH and their lunch specials are a deal!! 

I've been here a few times and every time the food's been awesome. Although it gets cold fast, it's still delicious. I like the chapati or i guess they call it roti. I usually don't eat a lot but i find myself always ordering an extra roti to finish off my plate. All the other side dishes they add to the Thali plate is fresh and the sauces are flavorful. 

The chai here is the best I've had so far. Not overly sweet or watered down, it's perfect. 

During my break, I'd dash over here and enjoy a nice late lunch with a book or anyone else willing to come with me on a late lunch. 

Definitely try it if you're in the area!
author: Connie M.

description:
This place was a real disconnect for me. The interior design looked like a modern vegan looking joint, but the restaurant claims that it serves real authentic home-made Indian food. Just because you have a picture of Indian boys giving themselves a bucket bath in the co-ed bathroom, does not mean your food is authentic. But heck, what do I know. I've never been to India so the food could actually be pretty darn authentic.

The food was decent. I got a chicken tikka masala kati roll, which is about 3/4 the size of a chipotle burrito. It was the perfect size - your full, but not so full that you want to keel over. The chicken was well prepared and the roti bread had a nice texture to it, but I just think the overall roll was very dry. I would have liked the yogurt to already be in the roll (like sour cream in a burrito) without me having to dip it. The same comments go for the lamb kati roll.

Finally, the people who work there were very nice. One worker was bored so he cleared our table. Much appreciated.
author: Margaret R.

description:
I've had their chicken tika masala wrap two days in a row now, and damn is it tasty.Slightly spicy, but easily offset with a dunk into the provide yogurt dip. The ingredients taste fresh and when I did a pickup order today the girl behind the counter was friendly and polite and fast. 

The place itself is more of a fast food style where you order at the counter and then eat at communal tables. They basically do either wraps or dishes, and their roti bread is amazing.
author: Jordan C.

description:
I really like this place! It's modern. It's tasty! It's not greasy! It's not that expensive! And...you don't leave smelling like food! It's sorta a cafeteria like restaurant. The decor kinda reminds me of Chipotles with their steel tables.

Anyway, I had the Thali plate (with their yogurt, soup, rice and other condiments including salad). I like how it is on this metal plate and I had my Thali plate with chicken tikka masala. It was so delicious. Usually when I eat Indian food (especially late at night) I feel like a dough girl that is rising while sleeping (not a good feeling). I could immediately tell that Kasa's food was just not like that because it's not greasy. Quite possibly the closest I have had to homemade Indian food? I also took a few bites from a veggie kati roll. Yum! Their food is just delicious. I highly recommend this place.
author: Natalie S.

description:
I like this place a lot! When they say simple home made type food, that is what you actually get for once!
I got the karahi paneer kati roll. I grew up in India, so its really hard for me to imagine why I'm paying $5 for a roti with veggies inside it. That being said, I quite enjoyed the kati roll. Although you would need about 3 for a dinner type meal, so it can end up being quite expensive. The kati roll in itself was quite tasty, moderately spiced and comes with yogurt. I would like to try the other vegetarian ones, they seem interesting. 
The place has a cafe style system, with not very much seating. No real points for ambience or anything.
author: Shruti T.

description: Bummer--this place seems to have gone downhill since I overdosed on it a few years ago (I remember it being so good!). Of my $12 thali plate, 15% was edible. Potatoes were undercooked, chicken was borderline undercooked, daal was basically water. Even though I love the concept, I'll stick to takeout from Pakwan.
author: Melissa G.

description:
Kasa Indian Eatery offers Kati wraps, much like Indian tacos made with paratha bread for $4.50 each or a larger plate of food with two choices for $10. If you need a full meal and you want the wraps consider ordering 2 or 3 or ordering the plate of food.

This is really good Indian food, this is some of the best Indian food have ever had. But keeping in mind its more of a new, westernized style Northern Indian food rather then traditional. I wish I lived closer. The CHAI- to die for. OMG I am drooling just thinking about it. 

My digestive system is really sensitive these days, I am getting elderly (I just turned the big 3-0)- as is my partner . After this meal our stomachs were rioting, gas, belching. I am not blaming Kasa's however its a warning, do not take a new date here, it could be a bad combo. Despite the tummy turmoil, I will be back soon. It's that good.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
Lamb Curry and Paneer Karahi Kati Rolls were fantastic.  I definitely recommend getting them Unda-style.

I love the statement their website about ingredient sources:

"We believe that natural, local ingredients are better for the environment and create more scrumptious meals. As a result, we use only naturally raised meat and source all of our produce locally when practical."

http://www.kasaindian.com/indianrestaurantsf/heartofkasa/
author: Tessa M.

description:
I totally heart the kati rolls.  Yummy fillings (my favorite is the turkey kebab, which is totally awesome, chicken tikka, aloo gobi and a few daily specials also on offer) inside the most delicious Indian bread ever - dense, a little chewy, probably ghee-laden.  You can also get the fillings as the mains in a thali.  

Pretty limited menu - kati rolls, thali, a few drinks (yummy mango lassi) and that's about it.

Upscale diner-ish atmosphere, very casual (order and pick up at the counter, serve yourself a soda from the fountain) hip quick service restaurant.  Great spot for a quick bit in the Castro.
author: Katy M.

description:
I was expecting the food to be phenomenal after seeing the large amount of impressive reviews it received here on Yelp. However, the "wow" factor simply wasn't there for me, so I rate this eatery three-stars for "A-OK."

What I did enjoy is the inexpensive prices for a a meal, and the simplistic menu choices. I ordered the kati rolls with chicken tikka, since they had a pretty good deal going on that consisted of two rolls and two fountain drinks for $7.99. I ordered it with the green cilantro sauce and the red tomato sauce. Pretty good, but not super delicious. I have visited Indian eateries in the Central Valley area of CA where I live, and the food tastes much more authentic than this place. Again, the food at Kasa was pretty good, but not "Wow!" 

Overall I'd say it's a cool little spot it you're searching for something inexpensive, are in a hurry (service was prompt),  and something kid-friendly (my 10 year old enjoyed the kati roll very much). But, if you are searching for something with a little more pizzazz and with more of an authentic taste,  I'd say look elsewhere.
author: Sonya M.

description: You have the option of kali rolls (fried burritos) or thali (piled plates of food). If youre in a hurry, go with the latter. If you want a sit-down meal, choose the thali. You get two choices of entrees per thali, and a wide selection of sauces to try with them. Kasa gives you more food than youll ever need in a meal, so dont sweat it when you can finish it in one sitting! Overall an authentic atmosphere that has a contemporary feel to it.
author: Cory N.

description: Oh Kasa, you don't care anymore do you? I used to love the rolls in 2010, but of late, it just seems like the owner has given up. The rolls empty themselves out of the bottom, and the egg wasn't cooked through. I'm Indian, and perhaps my palate isn't the target anymore, but to me the thali tasted like a mediocre meal cooked by someone who doesn't like you very much. The rice was dry, the roti was like leather, the dal is thin and bland, and the tandoori chicken was charred to bitterness. Maybe I'm not the target audience, but I know you can do better because you HAVE done better in the past. This makes me sad.
author: Jackson P.

description:
This may be uncultured of me to say, but I would define this as an Indian Chipotle, but classier.  I had two roti rolls, which I label Indian tacos (once again projecting a bit of Westerncentrism).  

Whatever, naan or tortilla.  Tikka Masala or Carne Asada.  Yogurt sauce or Guac.  It's all good to me.  The lunch specials (11 to 4) were pretty tight.  I would have liked a bigger portion, but I also appreciate when restaurants limit my aggressive appetite.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
I had always heard from my old roommate that Kasa was a must-try and finally made it out there (of course after I had moved from San Francisco to San Diego) and was thoroughly impressed! The layout of the restaurant was bright and modern and included some beautiful photography. I especially loved the wonderful communal table in the middle of the dining room. 

The menu was quite approachable and included many Indian favorites like Saag Paneer, Lamb Curry, and Chicken Tikka Masala. I absolutely loved the Lamb Curry as it truly highlighted the lamb and it's natural gaminess and tastiness. The accompaniments were also fabulous! The cilantro coconut chutney was such a delight and provided a great, cool, flavor packed accent to all the main dishes. The roti bread topped it all off and made for the one deliciously, fresh combo plate. 

On top of a great meal, the service was top notch, not even considering that Kasa is a walk-up, steam table kinda restaurant. We ordered the creamy, spicy, homemade Mango Lassi, and the server who had scooped our plates out, was so proud that he could put his name on that batch and with good reason since the drink was damn good. 

I'd recommend Kasa to anyone looking for a quick, authentic bite in the Castro. Hope to be back soon!
author: Christina N.

description:
The Chipotle of Indian food.

Great food but a little expensive for the actual amount you receive.
author: Sean H.

description:
For several years I dressed Indian (even purchased several saris), cooked Indian, read Indian authors, visited India, practiced yoga, stocked up on Indian gift wrap, and went to many Indian restaurants with my dear friend (who is Indian).  I was looking forward to my kati roll and some chai or some Indian soda, Thums Up (cola) or Limca (lemon lime) at Kasa (even though it's in a non-Indian area).  

The menu is simple - 6 dishes in kati roll form ($5.50 for 1, 2 for $8.95, 3 for $11.95) or thali (plate) form ($10.95).  Order at the counter.  They wrap up the rolls quickly.  Choose a mint chutney or a spicy chutney which they put in your roll.  The roll is about 1/3rd of the size of a burrito.  The homemade roti is thick and chewy, resembling a thick tortilla.  They didn't make chai that day and I really wanted some.   

I had a lamb curry kati roll with spicy chutney and asked for two other rolls to go.  The rolls come with sides of raita (yogurt sauce) and a chopped veggie salad with carrots, cucumbers and red bell peppers.  The dishes I had were all flavorful and not oily.  They tasted distinct from one another as well.  I'm not sure how spicy they are because I asked for spicy chutney for all my wraps.  The meat rolls are mainly meat with hardly any veggies.

* Lamb curry: Juicy cubes of lamb in a brown curry, not much potato, my favorite dish.

* Turkey kebab: Ground turkey reminded me of meatballs. Flavorful but dry.  

* Aloo jeera:  Mainly soft sauteed potato cubes and just a few onions.  Not much else.  A little boring.

I felt the sides were weaker.  It's a shame you don't get to choose the garnish salad.  The one that I had was crunchy and light but didn't have much flavor and didn't taste particularly Indian.  It would be better if you could choose a side, e.g., choose to have dal instead.  The raita was more sour than average.  And also it would be nice if they provided extra chutney on the side.  Instead of a salsa bar, how about a chutney bar or chutney in squeeze bottles?  

The service was a little odd and overeager.  Since you get your own utensils and I was ready to bus my own table too.  Well, before I had finished my food, one of the employees tried to take my tray away.  Then he took my dirty paper napkin and brought some fresh napkins (I didn't ask him to do this).  I've never had this happen before.

I would come back because the food is affordable, healthy, veg friendly, and fresh.  Also, I still want to try the chai.  They should consider adding dessert options, like some Indian ice cream.  And the chutney bar!
author: Lolia S.

description: Kasa Indian Eatery had delicious Indian koti wraps and samosas.  I loved the Lamb curry and Chicken Tikka Masala. Food was full flavored & spicy. Yummy. We sat outside because we brought our dogs.
author: Win C.

description:
I had an Halloween meeting with my co-workers nearby in Eureka Valley. And my empty stomach has landed at, what was once the hottest business on Yelp. (I think, the business is still on that current list). 

The menu selection is small. But there was a lunch special sign posted in front of the door. For $7.95, you get two Kati rolls with a Mediterranean salad sauce and a tangy & savory Yogurt sauce and a fountain soda (Coca Cola). The Kati roll comprises a choice of filling (any available meat or veggie) wrapped in a grilled Roti sheet. The wrap is very similiar to Mini Chimichanga (junior burrito). I got the Tandoori Chicken and Curry Chicken as my filling. The tendered and slow-cooked meat was spicy and flavorful. I used the two sides as a secondary filling making my wraps very hearty.   

Being a stranger on my debut making my visit very welcoming with the friendly workers. I feel like an emperor with great hospitality. 

I paid my lunch in cash, assumingly they accepts credit cards as well.
author: Matt G.

description:
5 Stars for the plate, 4 Stars for the kati roll. 

This place is a lesson in not judging a book by the cover. My first visual impression of the food was that it was gonna be super not authentic. Let's face it, for having a shitload of indian people, the bay area has TERRIBLE indian food.

So yes, it looks not-so-hot but it tastes really damn good. I think the plate is one of the best food deals in the city. The kati rolls (unda style) are delicious but a terrible value. I liked that the food tasted fresh and had flavor and a lot of heat (of the chili variety). I also didn't feel like dying after eating it because everything isn't soaked in oil and ghee. 

I'll be back.

Oh, and the mango lassi should be renamed to cardamom lassi.
author: Shyam P.

description: I like the wraps here. Its like curry stuck between some nan bread. Very handy for a quick bite.
author: Kenson K.

description:
Amazing Kaathi Rolls, I asked for the paneer tikka as spicy as they could make it and it was truly a trip!

Props to any restaurant that can make me sweat while eating, I'd highly recommend this to anyone in the area. Also be sure to grab a bottle of Thumsup if you're daring enough.

Staff was friendly and the crowd was pretty nice, most people who lived in the area that seemed to be grabbing a bite to eat after work.
author: Punit S.

description:
I ended up for a time in the Castro after starting my day at Fort Baker in Marin at 7:30 AM to cheer Gayle on during her Susan G. Komen Walk for the Cure.  But first, my travels took me to Union Street, the Marina, and Japantown, with an eye at ending up at the Bi-Rite Creamery to see for myself whether the tales of ice cream nerd-vanna were true.

But it was lunch time and as I waked down 18th, the clean modern lines and the metal chairs, counters, and plates of Kasa drew me in.  I had one of their rolls which were delicious and had a really good kick.  What I really needed to cool that down was the ice cream and not the beer, but the Kingfisher was a great chaser nonetheless.

I look forward to coming back for the Indian and ice cream loop again!
author: Eric B.

description:
Soooo Good!

I'm used to more "unhealthy" Indian food (i.e. cream based curry), so Kasa was a total delight when I discovered them walking to Dolores Park one day.

For the price you will walk away full and happy.

If you're looking for something healthy, delicious and different than your typical lunch or dinner, check them out. You will not be let down!
author: Carlos H.

description: As a die-hard Indian food lover, I've got to congratulate this place on delivering an authentic, scrupulous experience. I highly recommend their Chicken Tikka Kati Rolls, with each bite embodying an array of sweet and spicy flavors, and the spices complimenting each other oh-so-smoothly. The decor, complemented with a subtle, mind-blinding aroma, drags pedestrians right of the street. I can't brag, however, about the portions, as each Roll seems to be gone in a matter of seconds. Neverless, Kasa sets the bar fairly high for Indian eateries throughout the Bay Area. Well done.
author: Daniel H.

description: Their chicken tikka masala Kati roll is amazingly delicious! Always fresh & after introducing them to my family, they're crazy about them! Their service is great as well! Friendly and personable :)
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I'm going to try as hard as I can to avoid opening night bias.  So, let's get all the unique factors out there.  Huge line out the door, massive operational difficulties, high levels of anticipation, and smiles on everyone's faces.  Goods and bads.  Let's talk about the food.

I got three kati rolls.  Chicken tikka, lamb curry, and karahi paneer.  I wasn't too impressed with the kati rolls.  The rolls here were very thick and chewy, whereas I was expecting something a little bit more buttery and flaky.  The rolls could be chalked up to opening night jitters, they were probably the largest bottleneck in the evening's production.

The plate came to just under $12.00. Well-priced for the quality and amount of food I received.

The chicken was well-cooked and spiced.  I highly recommend complimenting it with the spicy sauce (which was supposedly named "The Urban Turban," but I think that got dropped at the last second).  The paneer was very underwhelming, and got totally lost between the other vegetables, the sauce, and the bread.

The lamb curry was absolutely delicious.  Big, savory pieces of lamb and delicious soggy chunks of potatoes.  A delicious roll.  If I had to go again I'd get three of these guys.

The atmosphere isn't anything special -- simple and sparse decor, a few tables and a somewhat cold-looking bar area.  The staff was friendly, even for an opening night.  Our party struck up a conversation with almost everyone in the assembly line (as well as the co-owners).

If you like going to new places -- do it.

If you want a variety plate of delicious food, you may want to try it if you're in the neighborhood.

If you're vegetarian -- skip it.

If you love tasty lamb -- run!!!
author: Bill H.

description:
This place is fricken awesome! If it was in my hood I swear I'd come here everyday! 
The food is fresh, authentic and delicious! I tried the turkey kebob, the paneer, as well as the chicken kebob roti. My favorite was their cilantro chutney...you can taste the difference when it is made fresh!

The owners are sweet folks who are passionate about what they do--bringing fresh, authentic cooking and making it simple for every day eats. 

Rumour is that they may even serve up their good eats for weekend brunch...I can't wait!
author: Mimi T.

description: Just bad, bland, insipid, cafeteria-style platter. Plates are cold and metallic. Comes with chewy Roti. Had to get an extra samosa because the veggie platter didn't fill me up. came out to around $15 bucks for fast-food truck style Indian food. The menu was also hard to follow. Tried to make it easy but just ended up confusing. Cooks were all Mexican and the servers looked like stoner/skater/bros. Very disappointing and definitely won't be going here again.
author: Macaulay H.

description:
I've been watching Groupon like a hawk lately.  That zany, fuzzy black cat has a way of making me spend more money than I would have otherwise spent if everything weren't so incredibly cheap.    I thought, "Hey!  I like Indian food.  And I really love cheap Indian food!"  And so, money was spent and  I ended up with a Groupon to Kasa.

I like the look of the place.  Getting Indian food can kind of be a lengthy and elaborate affair - the lunch buffet, the dinner buffet, the fried appetizers, stewed entrees, and chilled desserts - it's wonderful in its own right, but it also instilled in me a real appreciation for Kasa.  The place is clean and tidy, but relatively small, simplistic, and modern.  You order from a counter, and the selection is rather limited...

...but boy, is it good!  You can either choose a Kathi roll, which I did not, or a Thali plate, which I did.  The plate was huge!  As the menu indicates, it comes with daal, roti, rice, chutneys, salads, and then two entrees - I chose the Aloo Jeera and the Karahi Paneer.  It was perhaps not the most authentic Indian food I've ever had, but it was still exceptionally tasty, and healthy to boot!  There's very often a lot of oil involved in the making of Indian food, but I didn't find anything to be too greasy at all.  The cheese was mild and chewy, the peppers were hot, the daal was just salty enough to provide a nice counterbalance to my starchy-and-simple potatoes - I ate pretty much the whole plate, and that's unheard of for me.

The service was excellent, too!  They were rather busy, but the servers and bussers took the time to be friendly with my boyfriend and me.  They didn't have the drink I wanted, so I got some chai for free!  Not that it was even necessary - with the Groupon that I had, the entire meal cost nothing!  That's two incredibly hearty dinner plates and a mango lassi for under $30.

So, to sum up: hearty, healthy Indian food for less money than seems reasonable.  Not the place to go if you're looking for a romantic evening out, perhaps, but otherwise it's an excellent place to indulge all of your naughty Indian food cravings - you won't come away feeling naughty at all!
author: Becca S.

description:
Is there such a thing as a 5 star fast food joint? In my opinion, there is now with Kasa. They serve kati rolls, a Kalkota street food that can be described as Indian burrito. It's actually more familiar than it sounds if you've never had it because you choose from a selection of popular Indian dishes such as chicken tikka masala and saag paneer to fill your kati flatbread. They'll add condiments, chutneys, and sauces before they roll it like one would roll a burrito. The roll is served with a cool raita dip, which helps to tame the heat if you chose to go spicy. Most guys will probably need 2 kati rolls to be full, but plenty of girls will be satiated with just one.

However tempting it may be to get yours to go, or worse to eat it on the run, DON'T! Kati rolls are delicious and seemingly compact, but pretty damn messy to eat and transport. You need every square inch of the big silver tray they serve your rolls on for the splattery mess you're about to make.

If eating Indian dishes in burrito form is not your thing, you can opt to do a platter for a little over $10 and eat with real silverware. Either way, you can enjoy your food with beers on tap! I tried the mango lassi, which had too much cardamom for my liking, but still kinda yummy. The establishment is fairly clean with a stylish decor and several Indian patrons enjoying their food as well.

For what it offers, I'd say Kasa Indian Eatery deserves all 5 stars  in its price point.
author: Rina W.

description:
Great food, great prices, really nice staff, and they deliver. 
Can it get better than that?

The food always tastes fresh and during the day it's lively but not too noisy.
author: Lisa R.

description: This place is awful. Expensive tiny portions, spoiled mango lassi (prepared 3 days ago according to the date written on the cup), pieces of chicken in the paneer dish, and everything generally devoid of flavour. The worst Indian restaurant I've tried in SF.
author: Greg H.

description:
Would have loved to write a review based on the food - but unfortunately, that did not happen.  Similar to Mia L.'s review below, I had a botched delivery experience.

Called at 5:45 PM placing a for-delivery order.  I specifically asked them if they delivered to my area, in which they replied yes.  I was then told the food would be delivered 6:30 PM.  About ten minutes later, I received a call from Kasa informing me that the food would actually be delivered at 6:45 PM.  To my surprise, the driver calls me at 6:30 telling me that he is "too far away and cannot make the delivery".  

Say whaaaaaaaaaaat?

I then call the restaurant directly to ask why they cannot fulfill my delivery...no response.  I wait a few minutes and call again.  No response.  At this point, I think they are screening my call, just to avoid me.  I call from another phone number, and guess what?  They pick up.  Their excuse..."Oh, the person that took your order does not know the city very well."

Do yourself (and your stomach) a favor, and do NOT order delivery from Kasa.

*EDIT*

After posting my above yelp review a couple month ago - the owner Tim (nice, professional guy) took the time to reach out to me and invited me back.  After trying out the food in-restaurant, I'm a fan.  The only downside is the size of the place - a little small and hard to get a table.  The service is a bit slow too.

But overall, the food is good (watch out, some dishes are a bit spicy).  I'm glad I gave them a second chance.
author: David S.

description: First off, you can not beat the lunch special's they have to offer! Personally I have the  Kati roll , which can consist of lamb curry,turkey kabob,chicken masala or the chicken tika masala, and have the bowl of daal  ,with a soda of your choice, all for $7.95!!
author: Curtis L.

description:
3.5

The tikka massala was good and tasty, but maybe it's a bit much to be charging so much for one of these bad boys!?!  $5 and it was basically something I would consider snack size.
author: Brian Y.

description:
Proprio come essere a Kasa.
Questo grazioso, modesto posticino e' persino
vicino a Kasa mia.

Adoro il formaggio tradizionale indiano, Paneer.
Il piatto e' abbastanza abbondante, l'atmosfera e' cozy,
i prezzi contenuti.

Casa Dolce Casa.
Provate Gente, Provate!
author: Meli M.

description:
This place is so incredibly yummy!
It sucks thats its like an hour away from my house, else I would eating here pretty much much more regularly :(
All their veggie rolls are full of awesomeness.. they always have a paneer one, a gobi one, an aloo jeera one.. they also have a changing special.. today's was saag, which didn't look that appetizing
the thali option is pretty good too!
they have this mango drink called mazaa here which is also really really awesome!
author: Aditya M.

description: Good price, nice portions. Didn't enjoy that much of the flavors .. Chicken tikka wasn't so flavored ..
author: Nicolas D.

description:
How could you not love fast-food style Indian Food?  When you arrive at Kasa, everything is made and ready for you to gobble up with your eyes through the glass case.  You can order a dinner plate (Thali) or get little rolled up Indian "burritos" (Kati Roll).  They have several dishes including Lamb Curry, Chicken Tikka Masala, Turkey Meatballs, a cheese & pepper dish, a potato dish, and several other weekly specials, matched with sides of lentils & rice.  My personal favorite is the Chicken Tikka Masala Kati Roll.  They make it for you right in front of your eyes, leaving your mouth watering by the time it gets to you.  Beverages available include: Beer/Wine, hot Chai Tea, Mango Lassi, & a soda machine.

** if you come before 4pm they have amazing lunch special prices.
author: Lauren P.

description:
Finally!  London's Masala Zone (http://www.masalazone.com) comes to SF in the form of Kasa.
 
I don't think there has been as much excitement over a new Indian restaurant since Dosa opened in the Mission over a year ago.  But trust me, Kasa is even better and I hope it gets all the same hype.

While you can get the wraps, I highly recommend the thalis.  Here's a quick def for you not yet in the know ;-):

"the thali is a stainless steel platter with little bowls ("katoris") consisting of a wide variety of different dishes providing nutrition, texture, flavours and colours. it is the way indians have traditionally eaten at home for centuries."

The vibe here is like nice cafeteria/cafe.  You order at the counter and they put together your food in front of you.  Then you pay and find a seat at one of the small tables or communal bar.  The food comes out quick (like a cafeteria) but the decor is more like a laid back cafe (no vinyl flooring here!).  

But most importantly, the food.  Oh the food!

I can't vouch for the authenticity but my oh my is it tasty!  I've never had such good meat curries before.  The lamb curry was really lamby flavored and super tender, like fork tender.  The chicken tikka masala was grilled first, then added to the masala sauce - giving it that nice grilled flavor which blended well with the sauce.  To give you an idea of how much I liked the food, you should know that i cleared my plate much much faster than hubby - and that is very rare indeed.  In fact, I'm not even sure if we talked that much during the meal.

The roti is made by hand (you can see them behind the counter) and have a wonderful flavor on their own.  The sides (rice, daal, raita, et) are okay.  I would have liked the daal with a little more punch.  

But the curries, oh the curries.  How can I complain?
author: Jean K.

description:
Hands down - The best Indian restaurant I have been to thus far. It's modern, it's traditional, it's delicious, and it's affordable! I had the combo platter with two sides of Chicken Tikka Masala and a potato mash dish. The combo platter also included spicy and tangy sauces and pickled vegetables, all for a little over $10. I also had their homemade mango lassi drink; it was creamy, sweet, and had a certain spice to it - try it!

Style: Indian
Cleanliness: Very clean, bus your own tables
Food: 5 out of 5
Price range: $
Staff: Friendly
Recommend: Yes!

http://thephilinafinds.wordpress.com/2013/06/07/kasa-indian-eatery/
author: Philina L.

description:
I'm brand new to Kati rolls and after my first bite of my chicken tikka roll, I'm in L-O-V-E!

How could one complain about a joint which has cheap and delicious food?  I especially loved it when my friends and I arrived only to be among several other groups of Indian patrons.  I give lots of respect to a place that can pull it off.  I like knowing that if I'm going to a place that calls itself "Indian" to have Indian patrons - they're the ones that are going to tell you if it's good and/or authentic.  

Being in the low key mood my friends and I were in that night, we opted to group together to the most bang for our bucks.  I was only hungry for 1 Kati roll that night while my friend, Thomas L., was ready to try 2, which worked out great.

The place has a very simple atmosphere and can get loud if there are lots of people.  They also have tasty beers and interesting juice options here.

Would I come back?  You betcha!
author: Lisa R.

description:
I biked here for dinner from downtown and it was totally worth the hills, freezing wind, and homicidal buses. They have the best chai ever!! It's not too sweet and has a really nice spice to it. I would bike back there just for the chai.

As for the food, I needed 3 kati rolls to get full and I am a small Asian girl. For $4.50 each, I thought I could get away with just ordering two, but they are tiny!! Like, smaller than a mcdonalds snack wrap. The plates are decently sized, but will probably only leave you about 75% full since it's a lot of veggie and goopy stuff. You only get one piece of roti and a bit of rice.

Portions are made up for in flavor tho. I loved every little spoonful. The raita is my favorite, followed by the green leafy stuff that came with the plate. 

I spent 30 bucks for three rolls, one plate, a soda, and a chai. Not too shabby for sf!
author: Joyce Man H.

description: Didn't think it was possible to get a satisfying snack in SF for less than $10. Add that to the list of things I've been wrong about. I'm a sucker for Indian food and the tikka masala koti roll has a lot going for it. Saucy, spicy, savory, crispy. Yum. 1 roll and a side of saag does the trick if you're a little hungrier (or just love saag), and they've usually got a tasty IPA on tap. Combo plates are great for sharing too.
author: Jeff S.

description: It's no Udupi palace but they r nice and its good.  Solid lunch plate.
author: David G.

description:
I cannot understand how anyone could eat the vile glop served here and have a good thing to say about this restaurant. Any resemblance between what is dished out here and Indian food is strictly in the mind of the owners. The naan was a stiff piece of cardboard, barely eatable. The lamb was swimming in a pool of who knows what, the special Aloo Gobi, was written on the blackboard as Gobi Aloo (shows you what they know!) and consisted mainly of tasteless cauliflower core. We left most of the food, and guess we can only feel gratitude not to have gotten food poisoning as other yelpers have reported.
Having recently relocated from SoCal, can only say that Samosa House in L.A. would show Kasa how to run an inexpensive, yet incredibly tasty Indian eatery.
author: Carla B.

description:
I came here for the first time craving some Indian food. I came in and after being rushed to order something I got the Thali. I really thought the food would be spicier than what I had. I really tasted only a minor heat, tiny amount of kick. 

My $10 plate was filling to the point I felt stuffed, but had not filled my craving for Indian food. I guess I really need to head back to Naan-N-Curry.
author: M C.

description: I really love this place.  Not only do they have excellent quick food, there is never a line (unusual in this neighborhood), they're kid-friendly, and wonder of wonders for an Indian restaurant, they have great beer.  Yes you can get Kingfisher if you must, but you can also get Dogfish Head 90-minute IPA on tap.  And great chai -- and I don't even like chai.  Possibly best of all: the cardomon-infused mango lassi.
author: E S.

description: So many Indian restaurants in the city and this one would be the last one I would go to by choice.  I live in the neighborhood and even if I'm starving - I'd try eating my hand first.  Sorry Kasa but my mother would be so unhappy to know if she knew I ate at your place.
author: Anjali K.

description:
4.5 stars.
I came across this place right after it first opened and have been MANY times since.
As a big fan of  eating with my hands (burritos, sandwiches, empanadas, etc), I love the Kati rolls. 
Each day they have a vegetarian special like: delicious turnip, sumptuous cauliflower or green beans. Mmm!

If rolls aren't your thing, then get it on a plate. 
Prices are reasonable and they are quick for take-out. 

Try it, you might like it!
author: Claire S.

description: I love their Samosa, Chai and Roti .. and of course Chicken Tikka Masala ..
author: Angel S.

description: It's not bad, just okay. It's like Subway for Indian food.
author: Heather R.

description:
Kasa Indian Eatery serves home-style Indian Kati rolls and combination Thali plates in the heart of the Castro. On the restaurant's website, chef and co-owner Anamika says, "We want to make Indian food that would make our grandmothers proud." I do not know what her grandmother thinks, but I love it.

The Kati rolls include a meat or vegetarian filling of your choice wrapped in a flaky roti with onions and chutney. On my visit last weekend, I ordered one Chicken Tikka Masala roll and the daily special Gobi Aloo roll, a combination of cauliflower and potato. The Chicken Tikka, served in a creamy tomato sauce, is very spicy and delicious. The Gobi Aloo is mild in comparison and lacked the kick of the Chicken Tikka. It would be a good choice if you enjoy less spicy foods.

The rolls are served with a cool raita sauce in which to dip them. The sauce is an especially great accompaniment to the spiciness of the Chicken Tikka. The rolls are relatively small. I usually order two ($8.95), which makes a nice meal. If you want a snack, order one ($4.95); if you are really hungry, order three ($11.95).

To drink with your meal, Kasa serves assorted beer and wine, a selection of Indian bottled and standard fountain sodas, house-made Mango Lassi ($3), and house-made Chai ($2.50). On my last visit, I ordered a glass of Tripel Karmeliet ($5.50), a beer from Belgium. I would not order it again as I tend to enjoy a fuller bodied and more hoppy beer and because I found the small 20cl glass (approximately .35 pint) overpriced.

Bottom line: Go to Kasa for the delicious Kati rolls. If you wish to imbibe, grab a beer at a nearby neighborhood watering hole after your meal.
author: Z. M.

description:
Finally got around to using the Groupon.

I will believe that this is tasty Indian food, but for my palate, I just can't handle the spice and pepper level. There isn't a mild option to be had. 

Having said that, I could tell that each bite was full of flavour, and I did like the variety of small sides on the plate option. Sadly, I just can't handle the heat.
author: Scott B.

description: Disappointing return. We used to order often. They have changed the recipes on the roti and the filings. The bread is now soggy. The chicken tika masala sauce has lost its authenticity. Probably won't be back.
author: Diego V.

description:
Staying with a friend in the Castro, I got hungry and felt a craving for some good Indian food.  Kasa was the closest Indian restaurant to me and I thought to visit after learning it was a popular spot. 

Getting there, I thought, what is this, a cafeteria? It's like a prison cafeteria with the metal trays and really tiny selection of foods that actually don't look appetizing at all. 

I got the food anyway, since I figured it can't be THAT bad if there were lines wrapping around the block when this spot first opened as well as a fair amount of people inside eating. Seriously, I don't know how they managed that feat, because it was hands down the worst food, Indian or not, I have ever had in my life.  

The rice was insipid and tasted like air, no flavor AT ALL. The  Lamb Curry wasn't even curried and dry as a bone, tough to swallow and tough to chew. I think it must have been a 20 year old goat living on a sparse mountain top rather than a lamb, the meat was so tough and dry!  It was shredded up in an attempt to make it more palatable, but nothing can mask the inferiority of that meat.  The Chicken Masala, oh god, even worse.  Dry chicken and a greasy, congealed orange mess of a sauce that hardly had any flavor.  I didn't even know you could botch masala that badly.   The dipping sauces that came with were flavorless and also unpalatable. 

I have thus erased this place from my mind and memory. They serve FOOD at restaurants, and that is not what they serve at this establishment.
author: Annie W.

description:
Never have I been to an Indian restaurant that reminded me of a modern nightclub/diner.  But don't let the stark, metal decor sway you-- the flavors here are as warm and spicy and complex as any Indian restaurant around!

For $10.95 I got a "plate," which basically came down to me eating everything in the joint.  The Lamb Curry is not terribly pretty looking but the meat was tender and nicely spiced.  The Chicken Tikka Masala had a lot more of a grilled taste than you get at most cheapy Indian places-- a really sophisticated touch.  The lentils are awesome and I wouldn't mind taking a bath in the raita.  You get all that, plus a big heaping portion of rice and flatbread AND several different chutney options.  

Its a flavor explosion that you can enjoy twice-- I'm going to go have my leftovers for lunch right now!
author: Kristin P.

description:
Oddly I'm only two blocks away but I never think to come here. Popped in for a quick "light" lunch. I ordered a thali with the curry lamb and the curry cauliflower. The woman that helped me was so sweet. We had a good bit of banter as she prepared my food.

 The cauliflower was nice and spicy and not cooked to mush.The lamb lacked curry flavor but was so damn delicious anyway! The dal seemed a bit runny, but still tasty. I seriously love all the little condiments added on. There is some great heat in the mustard and the yogurt (totally blanking on the proper name of this condiment) is perfect for cooling back down. 

It was a "light" lunch because I only went in for a bite but was stuffed by the time I left. Definitely good value for the money. But the portion size is also related to the missing star in my rating. You only get one roti and you need at least two for all the food on your plate. Next time it's a kati roll for me!
author: Jim F.

description: This is a review from a Vegetarian, if I ate meat, my rating would likely be higher. On the night that I went out for dinner, the vegetarian options were all potatoes or cheese which means you are substituting carbs and saturated fat for protein. I could see on the menu that there was one curry with brand, but that was not available. I had the Thalia which for a vegetarian is rice, potatoes, roti, Dal, and Sag Pander. I also had a samosa which was filled with...... more potatoes!  While the staff were super friendly and the food was quit tasty, I left a little dismayed by the lack of healthy vegetarian options (beans and lentils rather than potatoes and cheese).
author: Robin L.

description:
Thank you for this, Yelp!!  We wanted good inexpensive Indian in the Castro or Mission areas, and Yelp didn't mislead us.

Atmosphere - Clean, new, comfortable community feel, table & bar seating.  Cafeteria style: order at the counter, pay & take it to a seat.

Food - excellent, good value.  7 dishes ordered in a "Kati Roll" wrap (roti instead of a tortilla) or on a "Thali" plate with sides.  

We ordered 2 Kati rolls: Chicken Tikka Masala and Turkey Kebab.  Turkey was my favourite!  Tons-o-flavour spicy but not fry-thy-tastebudlets.  It's top of my list for the next visit!  Chicken Tikka Masala was also good.  Portions: I was hungry and couldn't quite finish the 2 rolls, my husband might have needed 3 if he were really hungry.  Roti was perfectly done, not greasy...excellent.

We ordered a 2-item 'Thali' (or plate) with Karahi Paneer and Aloo Jeera.  The Karahi Paneer was a disappointing; I LOVE cheese, but found this blah. The Aloo Jeera was very nicely done; good flavour and it would be another repeat dish for me!  A perfect vegetarian option.

2 photos posted.

Drink - Kudos to Kasa for having Maudite (from my favourite Quebec, Canada brewery) on tap.  Yay!!  They also offer wines by the glass.

One beer, 2 Kati rolls, one Thali plate = about $25.  They deliver, too!

Maybe they should get a 5.  The only reason I gave them 4 is because I think over time I'd desire more choices on the menu.  Then again, they're doing what they know they can do well, in high volume, so they've probably called it right.
author: Littlefish B.

description:
I was in a funky, shitty, hungry-but-don't-like-anything mood and saw this place as I was driving by. I found parking and decided that they were either going to make my night worse or make it somewhat okay. They made it amazing.

I loved how very simple the menu was. In my frame of mind I needed that. I loved the friendly staff who didn't make me feel like I wasn't cool or hip enough to be there. I loved that no one there was pretentious (cuz they were prolly all over in the Mission that night), I loved that my plate was so big and full of food!

I am a huge fan. Once is a while a place will surprise you and I was pleasantly surprised. :) 

Small, intimate, bistro-y but not bitchy, good food, good peeps, good price. 

Yay!!

Thank you Kasa I will be back in a better mood!
author: Melisa B.

description:
This place is located conveniently in the castro, and it's good!

I personally would get their entree (on a plate, not the kati roll), simply because you get more food. The Indian Burrito Wrap is just a bit on the small side.

I did thoroughly enjoy their Paneer, I wasn't a fan of their Chicken Tikki Masala as I've had better (perhaps because most indian restaurants I go to, they dose it with a ton of butter), so my opinion is jaded :)

If you want something quick to eat, it's a a indian version of all the taqueria's available.
author: Eric A.

description:
kasa is not vik's and vik's is not kasa. but if both of them met, hit it off because of their similar restaurant visions, and decided to have a messy one night stand, they would make one tasty baby.

umm, huh? FAIL! *smh* 
okay. trying again... 

kasa makes damn good roti. vik's makes damn good rice. kasa has that organic kick going on. vik's isn't afraid to deep fry. kasa's plates are bigger, with fresher and healthier preparation. vik's has desserts, and their dal is outrageously good. both have great qualities, great business models, and both reteach us how to throw things away.

bottom line: kasa is super affordable, earth-community conscious, and offers delicious food with healthier preparation. they also sell wine/beer. someone please do something about the ridonk acoustics-- it is SO loud.
author: Vanessa D.

description:
While the menu at Kasa is limited, the food they do offer definitely impresses.  We stumbled into this place after pride, looking for a quick snack before heading home.  Kasa's menu incorporates just 4 curries (Chicken, Lamb, Potato, and Cheese/Tomato) and two meats (Chicken Tikka and Turkey kabobs).  You have the choice of either having the curries or meat rolled up in a Kati roll with onions and chutney, or served on a plate.   

The guy working that day was pretty friendly and helped suggest two Kati rolls for us to try.  We went with the Chicken Tikka Tandoori and the Potato curry.  He put the fillings I selected in two separate kati rolls with onions and chutney and rolled them up like little burritos.   

I must say, having no expectations, I was thoroughly delighted with the food.  The Kati rolls were warm and soft and were a terrific compliment to the chicken and spinach curry.  The meal is served with yogurt which also proved to be a very refreshing addition when drizzled inside the mini burrito!  

I will definitely come back to Kasa again.  The restaurant is clean, service is fast, and the food tastes great.
author: Timothy C.

description: Kasa was a fantastic lunch spot on the go as a San Fran visitor. I got to sample many different Indian dishes on the combo platter for $10. Conveniently located in the Mission District, I walked off my meal and sweated out the spices in Mission Thirft.
author: Sarah Rachael W.

description:
A couple weeks ago, I was sitting at home with a growling belly, trying to envision a filling and reasonably healthy meal under $10.  While mentally sifting through the Indian options, Kasa came to mind, and I spontaneously zipped across the Bay Bridge to get me a kati roll.

A kati roll, as described by Kasa, is a "small Indian burrito," and the price tag is $4.50.  The wrap is a roti, which is like an Indian handmade... tortilla.  For an extra $1, you can get it done "unda-style," meaning egg-infused.  There are several options to fill it, including with turkey kebabs (mmm), chicken tikka masala, karahi paneer (Indian cheese and peppers), or aloo jeera (spiced potatoes).  It comes with raita, a yogurt dip type deal.  One roll is a decent size, but two are properly filling as a meal.

You could alternatively do a thali, which is like a dinner plate of a chosen 1-2 items served with rice and with the roti on the side rather than wrapped around it.

They have chai, and wine, and beer. And mango lassi, and mango juice. And cookies. And a compost bin, of course.
author: Leena K.

description:
Here is the great thing about this place - you get the authentic taste and cuisine of India, but not a million choices like some restaurants. You know, sometimes you'll visit a place in the TL, and then you're bombarded with all these options...and what goes with what? Is one better than the other? You're swamped!

With Kasa, you have a small list of choices (I believe it's about 6 or so) that you can mix and match with your roll combinations, to have a tasty sampling of such wonderful food! And, if you are like me and panic that you haven't made your decision as to what you'd like, the folks that work here are super sweet as can be and will make a recommendation based on what you like. In fact, I asked for something and was told that it would take a little bit (they were out at the moment) but Anu (this sweet and rockin lady that works there) recommended the special (brocolli and cauliflower) which was delicious.

The sizes are just right. You can go from tasty mid-day snack (one roll) all the way up to haven't eaten in a month (three rolls). And they're good sized, so don't think you have to order three to be full. If that's the case, it's possible you might be asking for a doggy-bag.

The atmosphere is chic and simple...nothing too overdone. It's bright, but has a very open feel, so it's easy to just relax and enjoy your meal with friends and chatting. Plus, the decor doesn't overpower the food, like a few restaurants I've gone to where you're too distracted at things around you to actually eat.

The price is right, the service is superb, and the food...delicious! Check it out if you're in the area. Or, just get off your ass and make yourself be in the area. :)
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Clean restaurant, affordable and good portions. Yay.

I tried the Thali (with lamb and Aloo gobi). Yowza!! Every component on that plate was tasty. I want to return to try a kati roll or two.

Wish this place was in the east bay =(
author: Hilda Z.

description:
They have two style of dishes - you can either order Thali (more food for the money) or dinner rolls, that kinda look like an Indian burrito. The service is great, everyone is very nice and you get your food very quickly. 
On the low side, their selection is not impressive (they have like 6 things on their entire menu) and the place was freezing inside. It was a big downer because I wanted to chat with a friend after dinner on a particularly rainy and grose Friday and ended up leaving early because we were so cold!  All and all good spot for a quick, casual, Indian-style bite, but don't go there for a romantic dinner! LOL
author: Barbara M.

description: Kasa is probably one of the early pioneers that rebelled against the classic stereotypical notion of an indian restaurant - a pseudo-fine dining sit down place with rich and copious amounts of curries (that are meant to be shared...sucks if you are going there alone), thick buttery naans or perhaps an enormous lunch buffet consuming which makes your stomach bloat up like an inflated  balloon. What Kasa did instead was to provide a casual fast food ambiance with indian meals (aka Thalis) that have small servings of multiple curries ordered and served chipotle-assembly-line-style. Great concept. Great branding (all with that purple colored building, attractive logo etc). No wonder this place received a lot of 5 stars in its early days. But here's the problem now...there are lots of indian restaurants in San Francisco that have adopted this concept and taken it to the next level, while Kasa has been left behind riding on its glory days. Specifically, I was disappointed with the quality of the food, the careless and sloppy presentation of the meal which reduces my appetite even before I start eating, all for a price that's heftier than the other indian alternatives. Kasa is still a decent place to go to, but I give it a 3 star rating because it's not worth the hype... there are better and cheaper alternatives out there.
author: Srivatsan S.

description: i ordered delivery via ubereats $5 promotion to try out the service. the food arrived fairly fast within 20-25 min. ordered a salad, a naan, and the chicken tikka marsala + chicken tikka combo (i called to ask if i can substitute the chicken tikka with lamb curry. dude on the phone gave me a free container of the lamb curry which was very cool). initially i thought the food was pretty good - partly because i was starving so perhaps it biased my culinary critique, but also because i did think it was pretty good. then again i'm not an indian cuisine expert and i started to remember how the numerous times ive had it in my life at regular sit down indian restaurants the food was all pretty spicy and full of aromas and flavor and yet the food at kasa was actually pretty bland. kind of like americanized indian food catering to the bland american palette. also the lamb curry was extremely fatty with very poor cuts of lamb and flavor was not very curry-ish at all. the daal soupy thing was very watery and had no flavor as well. overall decent enough for cheap indian-american food when you dont want to pay more at a sit-down restaurant serving more authentic indian food.
author: p f.

description: Masa is getting lazy.  They aren't cooking the chicken in the masala sauce, they are just dumping chicken tikka in masala sauce already both made and the chicken just doesn't stew in the masala like it used too.  It's kinda weak.
author: Jason B.

description: Too spicy. U cldnt taste anything but hot! Lol other than being spicy it was bland. I knw that sounds like an oxymoron, but it was! Service was terrible. I asked a few questions the broad at the counter w the glasses offered NO suggestions and in fact sat my tray down and began assisting my fiancé! I wanted to smack her ass w a wet towel! Any way the only thing tht was good was the jasmine rice. Everything else from the shakes, to the food and service was GARBAGE! Don't waste ur time, u will only leave feeling cheated and still craving Indian food!
author: isabelle l.

description:
As a big Indian food fan, I read a lot of reviews before deciding to make the trek to Kasa.   First, this is not your typical Indian Restaurant but more of a quick Indian meal takeout / restaurant which serves generous portions of staple Indian dishes such as Chicken Tikka Masala, Chicken Tikka, Lamb Curry and Aloo Jeera just to name a few.  They also have a chalkboard for specials. The day I visited the place was hopping and they were out of an eggplant dish I wanted to try so I opted for a few of the other meatless dishes because these tend to be better way to judge the real execution.  While waiting in line, it became clear the staff knew many of the regulars by name - a nice touch.  They were also helpful to patrons who were not quite sure what to order from the Indian choices as were the couple in front of me.  

Basically, at Kasa you have two choices of how the food is served.  One style is an Indian Wrap known as a Kati Roll and the other the more traditional Thali which is a stainless steel platter holding servings of multiple dishes. The Kati Rolls look interesting - especially if you want something simple, and quick to go. This night I opted for the Thali plate which was a nice filling combination.  The dishes were not overpowering and were quite well executed.  While I was there there was never an open table and only very few seats at the "bar" locations - a sign of good food. 

Overall, if you are in this area of the city and looking for a quick, good Indian meal, then Kasa is your answer.
author: G M.

description: I used to live across the street but found this place on Yelp my first night living in the Castro. "Oh hey, right across the street," I thought. I've since gone there waaaaaaayyyy too much. For the most part, the line moves pretty fast and the staff are always really nice. This one skinny gay guy is so happy-go-lucky it just puts me in a good mood coming in. They have a pretty solid selection of wine and beer, a pitcher of beer between a few people is the route I went when I ate in. I tried to order my Kati Rolls spicy one time and was forced to have one of their iced Lasies (spelling?) because it was so spicy. Ample seating, it's a perfect place to grab dinner because if you don't want to eat much just get one Kati Roll and if you're hungry get two, if you're somewhere in between just get the plate rather than a Kati Roll. Love, love, love me some Kasa!
author: Chris W.

description: Still lovin' my Kasa. It's become a weekly lunch date spot for me and some friends. New veggie items keep appearing on the specials list and I am now certain that this is the tastiest chai in town.
author: Jaina D.

description:
Bought a groupon, was disappointed.  Expected way more from this place, especially since its got a 4 star average!

I don't know how to explain it, it just wasn't authentic Indian food.  Not like actually going to an Indian restaurant and walking out smelling like curry for days.

It was more like how fresh mex-chipotle/baja fresh is to a taqueria... just not the real thing.  Good but not home-made.  Also it wasn't that fresh, I mean the food sits in those warmers for a while.

But hey, they had Anthony's cookies!
author: L V.

description:
Kasa is no Lahore Karahi, and really they are nothing similar. Come here for a kati roll or two or three or four... Okay, I really could only eat two for lunch, but if you're hungry, three should do it. And order anything but the veggie ones. Just sayin'. I tried the Gobi Aloo before, and this time, it was still not cooked to tenderness. I couldn't blame it on my teeth because even Ryan found it tough, and he's got teeth that can open beer bottles. He just doesn't do it often - no dental insurance. The karahi paneer just wasn't for me either.

The meat-filled rolls are quite tasty though. The chicken tikka masala is a tad too spicy for me, but if you like that burning sensation, make sure to get it! My favorite is the chicken kofta [meatballs], and Ryan's pick is the lamb curry. The side of raita helps it all go down.

I'm glad the kati rolls come in the portioned size that they do. You can mix it up a bit in terms of flavors. It's the perfect snack size while you wait in that ridiculous Ike's line down the block. Or if you want to avoid the line altogether, you can get a thali [plate] at Kasa.
author: Tinna H.

description: Oh my my. This place is delicious! Their Kati rolls are just a beautiful thing to behold... The daily options are not always vegan, but they always have aloo gobi, and another one that is always available. Just get one for a snack, or two with sides for a meal. Love this place!
author: Giovanna C.

description: I always get the Thali to go, usually with chicken tikka masala and gobi aloo.  Unless there is a delicious daily special that grabs my attention.  It's a ton of food, i have never finished it all.  You get your  2 mains plus lentils, basmati rice, yummy cabbage slaw, a roti and a few different delicious sauces.  Everything tastes super homemade and fresh, with tons of flavor!  My girlfriend and i love this place and eat here about once a week
author: the c.

description: Dig me a good kati roll! The thali plates are great too. Lots of flavor, quick, reasonably priced, delicious. Not oily either. So far I've had the chicken tikka masala, karahi paneer, and turkey kabobs; all were tasty and distinct, would order any of them again and can't wait to try all the dishes Kasa offers. I can't wait to try all their options. I'm not Indian, but I have traveled there, and the flavors here definitely remind me of casual food there, in a very good way. This place also endears itself to me because they serve limca soda from India. My go-to place in the neighborhood for a spicy Indian bite.
author: Erin H.

description: Kati rolls in a taqueria-like setting. I think I had the lamb curry and chicken tikka one. Always a fan of roti and this place is quick and clean. Decent alternative to the crap you usually find in the Castro. Get the thali so you have the little sides and the sauces.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Indian fast food...but its REALLY good. Tikimasala, potatoes, lentils...all had great spice. 

Would definitely go back but only if Im in the area. Parking sucks big ones here.
author: E. Y. G.

description:
I freaking love this place. It's the perfect low-key, casual Indian place with solid food. The wraps themselves are delicious and smooth, and the dishes themselves are usually great. There are usually a lot of options, and their veggie dishes are usually good (the gobi aloo can sometimes be a bit bland, but besides that I've never had a bland dish). The yogurt sauce is great and the mango lassi is delightfully yogurty and smooth.

My only complaints are that if you're really hungry, it can be slightly unsatisfying. You know, two rolls aren't quite enough, but three are too many? Not really the fault of the restaurant, but you know. Also, service is hit or miss -- it can be slightly unfriendly/slow, which can result in longish lines.

But actually it's really good and you should go. It's fortunately located so that you can make sure you're properly fed before hitting the town!
author: Justin S.

description: My roomies favorite Indian place. I love how fast you can get your food and it always tastes great! The employees are also very nice and helpful in explaining what everything is to the newcomers I bring in. Super cute decor and clean. I have nothing bad to say about this place. We love you Kasa!
author: Sarah S.

description: Fckn amazing. .. I had the spicy eggplant and the saag paneer roti wrap.  My friend had the lamb and the chicken tikka masala. Served with raita it all rocked our world's.  Ignore any negative reviews. .. It's great!
author: Sean W.

description:
We enjoyed this place tonight on opening night.

** stars for a good friendly staff that was dealing quite well with how packed the place was

** stars for really yummy roti

** stars for the flavors

** stars for being open late (10pm)

** stars for good daal

** stars for painting your ceiling the same deep purple as mine

We had three kati rolls (2 is enough, husband said) and one thali. Lamb was his favorite and I enjoyed the Chicken Tikka. The one with potatoes was also a treat!

Thank you for giving me a quick spot to eat that's not burrito or pizza! Welcome to the neighborhood (and thanks for sprucing up that corner!)
author: Nikki M.

description:
