After my kiddy day, I was ready to get back into the land of adults, so me and the BFF went to Kasa Indian in the Castro.  It was pretty good.  I don't do Indian food that often but this place might just change my mind.

I had the chicken tikki masala with the potatoes which was great--not too strong for my western taste buds--though probably a bit bland for my Hindi speaking friends.  The chicken had just the right mix of spices, and the potatoes hit the spot too.

My friend had the lamb, which she liked, and the vegetarian dish which she didn't.  I'm not sure why exactly--she just said she "wasn't into it."

It was super cheap and I could totally see coming here just to grab some of their wraps and take them down to Delores Park on a nice sunny day and have them there.  It isn't really that much of a sit down experience though.  It has a cafeteria style ordering--you stand in line, point and choose.  Someone else in a review said it was like Chipotle in that sense--that's a good description of the ordering process.

I didn't really like the outdoor tables and chairs either--the metallic look is kind of an eyesore.

Next time, we will definitely take it to go.
author: Nikki K.

description:
I have to confess that I knew Kasa existed but I didn't know their food until a few weeks ago. I am a parent at Alvarado Elementary and Kasa donated some food and at the yearly auction. I was so impressed by what I tasted that I couldn't stop thinking about how I had to have an event just so I could taste more of their food. So I had my birthday party last Saturday and although I didn't have time to plan a formal catered event, with the help of the nice guy who answered the phone we worked out a wonderful assortment of Thali plates for our guests. I order about 7 thali plates and each was filled with about four main items plus two sauces/toppings. They delivered them straight to my house and were really warm when they arrived.  

What a way to taste the food!  My guests and I loved the lamb curry, the Karahi Paneer, aloo jeera, and the turkey. Also there were some other tasty meats but I am not sure which they were. The cauliflower was great. the pita/nan stuff was great but there was this thin little wrap tortilla like thing that was in the bread that really rocked our world. It was perfect for getting the food. They packed everything so nicely and the delivery guy was very nice.  Thank you Kasa for helping make my birthday a success!  I will come visit soon.
author: Sari S.

description:
Got the platter, excellent chicken tikka masala as well as the lamb curry. The lamb isn't so much curry as it is lamb marinated with its natural juices, but I didn't care, tasted great!

Make sure you get the spicy sauce on the platter, it's pretty hot. They don't serve you nearly enough rice to eat everything they give you however.
author: Michael K.

description:
Kasa is a cool place if you happen to be over in the Castro or Mission-Dolores district and have a hankering for Indian food.

Kasa does a great job of providing an authentic like experience by serving food in plates and trays typically found in eateries in India plus Indian beverages like Thumbs Up and Limca, house-made mango lassi and chai tea in addition to wine and beer.

Food wise, you can get basically two different kind of eats: Kati rolls which are like small Indian burritos (just to give you a visual idea), and Thali which is a plate served with rice, two meat dishes or veggie, raita (which is a yogurt sauce with cucumber, though mine seemed to be sans cucumber), veggie salad and roti. I had the Thali with turkey kebabs and lamb curry. The kebabs weren't bad but a little dry and the lamb curry didn't resemble curry at all and was on the salty side, though I will say the meat was tender.

I tasted the chicken tikka and tikka masala which were also just ok. On the overall, I can't say that the food was as authentic as they claim it is. Maybe authentic by American standards only, but I think most Indians would give it a Thumbs Down and laugh in their Thali. Does this mean that you shouldn't patronize (meaning support, not make fun of) this restaurant? Of course not. Go, eat and make merry. Just understand that this is Americanized Indian food.
author: Lenneal G.

description:
Visited this place for the first time after reading great reviews. Kathi rolls are India's answer to burritos and are immensely popular in India. I am glad finally someone has introduced them to the Bay Area palate. The preparations were nice and the chutney and raita are awesome. 

I liked that the Mango Lassi had elaichi (cardamom) in it.....super cool. Nice corner shop for a great lunch in the city. I would not go to this place for dinner, somehow did not give me the dinner feel but definitely a great place to grab a $10 lunch.
author: Jeev S.

description: Poor service, ok food but looked shabby and the meat had weird parts in it.
author: Julia S.

description:
Indian Street food. Order and pay at the counter, service is fast, food is excellent, staff are friendly, restaurant is clean, spacious, in great location right off of the Castro. The Vegetarian Thali is fantastic, The Kati Rolls are amazing. 

Do yourself a favor and frequent this spot!
author: Shane J.

description:
I had never had a Kati roll before, but since we had a Groupon to spend we decided to get a wide variety of rolls, ranked below in order of deliciousness:

1. Chicken Tikka Masala (YUM)
2. Saag Paneer - spinach and cheese, it was a daily special, and it was delicious.
3. Lamb Curry
4. Chicken Tikka
5. Aloo Jeera - potatoes... I liked the spicy sauce but overall this was more of a "filler" roll.

Other Notes: I had hoped the decor would be a little less cafeteria so we got our rolls to go, but it didn't decrease the food quality at all so they keep all 5 stars. The creamy yogurt sauce that comes with the rolls is really refreshing. Also, the Mango Lassi was not overly sweet (according to the boy) and my Chai was perfect (but be careful, my lid didn't create a proper seal and I ended up with Chai all over my lap)!

5 rolls, 1 Lassi, 1 Chai: $30.66.
author: Shannon B.

description: I love their roti. Great tiki masala, yummy lamb dishes, delicious chai and mango lassi. Clean inside, cool interior. Clean bathrooms. Service is pleasant and quick.
author: Heather B.

description:
In the months since I started my review of this restaurant, they have lost a star, which is kind of sad. Had I bothered to finish my review back in September (gosh I'm slow), they would have gotten five stars, but not now. 

Why is that, you might ask? Well, to be honest, they've started really skimping on the amount of food they put into their kati rolls. I've noticed a slow downwards progress over the past year: back in 2010, two rolls would fill me to being stuffed. Now, I could stand to go for a third. 

This doesn't stop me from loving this place and frequenting it multiple times per week. But it does make me grumble a bit.

Grumble grumble.
author: P Z.

description:
This is a charming and heartwarming restaurant for me. My friend has taken here twice. The food is OK and the prices are unbeatable. It's all self-serve. The great thing about this restaurant is not the food but the people who eat there and work there. It's a melting pot of people. The only Eastern Indian I saw working behind the counter was probably the boss -- she was the head cashier. The rest of the crew consist of cooks who seem to be of Hispanic origin. The tall Caucasian dude with the curly fro seemed to be in charge of dishing out the food -- he was making various wraps. Another Caucasian dude was helping to dish up food for the customers. 

The customers are varied, ranging from East Indians to the neighborhood girls who moved to SF from the Midwest or Texas. Excellent!!! It's so good to see people of various persuasions enjoying East Indian food. 

The two times I was there were Saturday evenings. The place was packed. Grab a seat or a table before you odor, if you intend to eat in. 

The sole bathroom (unisex) is clean and well kept -- a very good sign. 

Everyone, including the staff, seemed happy being there and eating with people from different walks of life and ethnicity. That's America; THAT'S SAN FRANCISCO!!!!!!! Hopefully, I was able to convey why this nice establishment warms my heart.  (I would have given more starts but the food isn't that stellar.)
author: Peace L.

description:
Enjoyed the dinner plate with 2 sides, Chicken Tikka Masala (creamy tomato sauce) and the veggie special of the day spinach/ soft cheese ($10.95). The plate was huge and besides my 2 main choices it also came with lentils, fluffy rice, chutney, veggie salad, yogurt and a nice homemade type of Indian bread.
Everything is already made, simply order what you want at the counter and pay, your plate is ready to enjoy in or takeout.  Fast, easy, fresh, good quality and best of all great taste!
author: Bill B.

description: We used Kasa to cater our wedding. The food was well priced and commensurate with their dining in prices (most places charge way more for catering). Anamika was very communicative. Our guests raved about the food. I did have some trouble getting in touch with them the day of the event and my sister reported the set up support left some things to be desired, but overall the value and quality of food were so good I have to give five stars.
author: Gabby G.

description: Honestly, I've loved this place ever since it opened.  Nice atmosphere.  Lots of cute customers.  Great food and nice location at a reasonable price.  But here's why it's getting 3 stars instead of 4 or 5.  First of all the food is usually not hot enough.  Their steam tables are not hot enough and that's worrisome.  And here's the other thing.  I just went there tonight, after being away for awhile and I was shocked at how shabby the restaurant looks.  It really appears that they don't care anymore.  The place is dirty and there appears to be lots of deferred maintenance happening.  When a restaurant stops caring, like this, it's usually the beginning of the end.  I really hope that they start doing necessary repairs and keeping up with keeping their decor.  It's really looking tattered. Sad to see.
author: Daniel S.

description: I was there Sunday night Nov. 9.  The food was decent, not great, but the music was so loud and of too fast a tempo that it made me nervous.  There is no reason to have music this loud!  It's not a night club!
author: chauncey h.

description:
We heart Kasa!

It's YUMMY. It's a great price for food and we've decided it's the place we order for take out, and sneak with us into the movie theater. Far classier fare than popcorn.

The Aloo Jeera Roll is perfect and the Chicken Tikka Masala Roll is decent. Kari is the gobi-half of the relationship - she says that the cauliflower rolls hit the spot. We're sad to say that  on a few visits the food wasn't spot on great.  But we are big fans. And we plan to keep them in business.
author: Shanta J.

description:
sorry kasa, ya know I gave the nob hill location one last hurrah before swearing off ye for life. Just incase somehow I was mistaken, I mean if you had to close the Fillmore location take a hint.
My experience at the castro location was;
the food tasteless, 
Food only luke warm
service pretentious hurried and rude, even thought it wasn't busy 
WAAAAAAYYYY over priced for the tiny portions and terrible food.
Chai tea was the best thing about it.
And I read that the health score here fell waayy down aswell this year, its back up now I guess but still....
Taking my business elsewhere.
author: Ann M.

description:
I like the chicken wraps with yoghurt .. Yummy this place :)
And the workers are very nice .. Thx Maisa
author: Shadi K.

description:
Noisy kitchen when cleaning at 9pm. Not nice.   It adds to the "school canteen" feel.    Which is kinda weird when they sell wine or fancy Belgian beer. 

Having the wine and beer is good, on the other hand. 

I like the taste of their food, nice to eat.  Maybe a tad not cheap/not a deal, but hey it pays to be cool and young there!
author: Jordan G.

description:
Super authentic and not different to what I ate growing up.
The hot sauce is super hot.  I was a happy camper.
Minus a star for the lamb curry.  I was not a fan.
author: Yo M.

description:
Meh meh meh is exactly how i feel about this place! So what is the big deal about this place again? I'm so with Paul B on this one.... 
 
It's a cafeteria style place that charges $9+ for their "kati rolls".. essentially, naan wrapped cafeteria-style indian food... as it is, their selection is meager at best. When they first opened they were pretty much 'standing room only' and the line was out the door. These days, notsomuch. and it's obvious why. 

Oh, but to their credit: they have an all you can drink soda bar. That is nice. 
But, I don't think it makes that much sense to spend that much money on food that has very little variety. Call it a Kati Roll, call it a Indian Special Roll, whatever.. all the same, it's pretty dullsville, as Indian fare goes. 
I don't even recall seeing a Mango Lassi as a choice on their menu. what the????  

What was even *more* fascinating was the fact that the woman standing in front of us had the gall to whine and complain that SHE lives in this neighborhood and she was SICK AND TIRED of people from the OTHER parts of the city taking over HER neighborhood. What an uncomfortable moment that was.... 

If you're in the neighborhood, give it a try, if you feel like, but I'd rather head up the street for other fare myself....
author: M'ia K.

description:
I love this place, it's the best Indian eatery, hands down! It's clean, fresh, and doesn't cost you a fortune. You won't leave here filling hungry and your clothes won't smell, I'd promise!

The food choices here are simple. Everything taste wonderful. Lamb, Chicken, and Veggies are all good in the hood. I'm glad it's close by. Parking is difficult. I would call ahead and pick up. It doesn't take long to get the order ready, they also delivery but I would ask them how long. Ask for more sauce, it's the best!
author: Stanley K.

description:
Behold! Off in the distance a Indian eatery oasis teeming with exotic flavors and irresistible aromas. 
Step past the threshold into a space reminiscent of a recycled tuna can, assembled from cold war era sheet metal. Although the place could use a few cushions, or a woven tapestry to add some warmth, the flavorful food is what brings me back. 
I have yet to be disappointed with the quality or variety here. 
The staff is always friendly and the Kati roll lunch special is a great value.
author: Ollie O.

description:
I'm sorry, but there's just something unappetizing about watching my food prepared with a guy wearing tattered and stained surgical gloves.  Reused endless times over and over again, they look like they've been around since the mid-80s.  The guy even took his gloves off inside-out, handled some money, scratched his head, and then put them back on inside-out; how lovely.  

Is it really that expensive or time-consuming to put on a fresh pair each time?  I'm sure they're pretty cheap at Costco.  At least at fast food places like Subway, they don a fresh pair of food handling gloves for each customer.  I know Kasa isn't the only place utilizing the used glove technique and maybe this is partly me venting, but it's turned me off such a wonderful place.  Sorry to be harsh on you Kasa, but it's tough love.  

The food here is mighty tasty, quick and easy.  The staff have always been totally nice and friendly, as well.  If I wasn't so nit-picky about the used gloves, I'd totally give this place five stars, hands down... freshly-gloved hands down, that is!
author: Ryan L.

description: Amazing food!  You must try the chai tea, it's delicious.  The ambiance is simple and the restaurant is not very big.  Also keep in mind when it's busy it can be pretty loud.  FYI, you will order your food first then sit down--the design is similar to a taqueria.  Parking is hard over there so perhaps go during the week or early in  the day.  This is probably one of my favorite place to eat, I love it!  Enjoy!
author: Megan M.

description:
Every now and again a friend introduces you to a new substance you're probably better off not having. All's fine and well until your cravings hit again, and you find yourself wanting to sneak back to the joint, buying enough to service a small army, and shooting it in the back of some dark alley.

For me, it's the kati rolls at Kasa Indian Eatery. We both had lamb and chicken rolls with egg and they were satisfying. It went down so nicely with a bottle of 90 Minute IPA.

Also, the cocaine was pretty good.
author: Keane L.

description: I come here once a week to get my Kati roll fix. The food is cheap and tastey!  Feels like a home cooked meal. And the service is always super friendly!
author: Craig C.

description:
The first time I ordered Kasa, it was great. I got the paneer thali and was impressed. 

The second time I ordered, I also got the paneer thali. The next day, I had excruciating stomach pain and vomited all morning until finally I went to the doctor and they wanted to test me for appendicitis or to see if I had an ectopic pregnancy (read: baby stuck in my fallopian tube). You know what it ended up being? GAS. From paneer. 

I don't know why I just did this to myself but I ordered from them again and went with the chicken tikka masala to avoid the gas. But the chicken is undercooked and everything is luke warm, the roti is greasy, I can count the number of lentils in my "daal" on one hand, and what kind of tikka masala does not have a curry? No kind, I tell you. 

This place is a lot of hype for food that sucks. If you want to eat Indian food then go to Little Delhi -- it's cheaper and far more delicious. And no gas from there. Ever.
author: Victoria P.

description:
The food isn't bad, and the service is okay, but the prices and portion sizes are ridiculous.  It's at least 8 bucks for anything filling, and if you want to have a real dinner, with a Roti Roll, Daal, and rice, it's over $11.  

This is too much for medium-grade Indian short-order served by white people.  There also isn't much on the menu besides the roti rolls and an occasional daily special.  If I'm going to eat Indian in the Castro, I'd invest my money in Curry Boyzz, which actually feeds you for $8.
author: Roger R.

description: Came here with a friend when visiting SF. The Best lamb I've ever tasted in Indian restaurant, tender juicy and well seasoned. One feels the caring going into the preparing of the foods here. The price is good, too. Will definitely come back again!
author: Ya Ya C.

description: It was very good for 2 reasons. The date/company and the the food itself.
author: Erik R.

description: I thought that this place was alright. I do like how they have "Indian Burritos." The food tasted fresh and the staff was nice. I wouldn't recommend getting the Mango Lassi--it wasn't really that good compared to other places that I've had it. If I come back here again, I'm just going to get a couple burritos. The white sauce is pretty good.
author: Marlon T.

description:
So, over the weekend, K and I decided to try a new place for the blog. We found Kasa in the Castro and read it's the best authentic Indian food under $15.

The scene:

What was off-putting about Kasa was the Panda Express style food bins. Who knows how long food has been sitting there.

To order, you first choose if you want a Thali (plate) or a Kati roll (think Indian burrito). If you get the Thali, you get a choice of 2 different curries. The Kati roll contains one kind of curry but is wrapped in a buttery roti (thin bread) with marinated onions and chutney. I have never seen anything like that before and at $4.50 each, you can't go wrong.

The food:

I got the Thali ($10.95) with the Chicken Tikka Masala and the Ghobi Aloo. K got 2 Kati rolls - one with Chicken Tikka Masala, one with Karahi Paneer (Indian cheese). The total came to $22.

Thali - I actually wasn't too impressed with this. The plate was huge, but there really wasn't much of the Chicken Tikka Masala or the Ghobi Aloo on it. The server was carefully assembling the curries in the small divider portion of the 24 plate. I felt kind of ripped off since I was paying $10.95 for this. There wasn't even enough rice for the small amount of curry. A majority of the plate was covered with different kinds of salads that I didn't even touch. There was chutney, red onion salad, a mix of raw veggies, and lentils. The lentils were great, but I was still hungry after my meal.

Kati Rolls - I took a bite of K's and it was pretty good. I don't eat onions or whatever's in the chutney, but it tasted pretty good to me. At Kasa, it seems like the kati rolls are the way to go. The Karahi Paneer tasted very similar to fresh mozzarella. I've never had Indian cheese before, so it was an interesting experience. For the big eaters out there, you can definitely get full on 2 Kati Rolls for $9 total rather than the $11 plate.

Mango Lassi - I've never had Mango Lassi before and decided that night to try it. Wow, it is definitely not my cup of tea. It' s like drinking a heavy yogurt with a hint of mango flavor and a strong taste of spices that seem like they shouldn't even be mixed with a sweet delicious fruit.

Despite the rave reviews on 77 and Yelp, I don't think I'll be coming back to Kasa. I might just be too picky of an eater to really enjoy what they serve.
author: Sam L.

description:
I've only been once, but I'm hooked, and since then have been heavily bothering my significant other to go with me again when we debate food choices ;).

The food here is delicious, well priced, and from what I understand, often locally-sourced. The vibe is fantastic and friendly and the staff are uber-helpful. The location is nice -- close enough to the Castro's main drag for a little post-meal walk, but far enough away for a little peace and quiet.

I had their Lamb Kati roll -- the Kati rolls are delicious, but more for a snack or light meal (if you get 2). If you're hungrier, I recommend getting the platter, which can even be split between two people if your appetite isn't too huge.
author: William C.

description:
Had lunch over there yesterday and it was horrible.
Good: Nice variety. Nice staff
Bad: Food was cold, samosas were stale. I can get better stuff at McDonalds. Enough said
author: Nitesh A.

description: I'm not going to paint you a very flowery picture, but this place was GREAT. I ate almost the entire plate and I didn't feel sick, like other Indian places that cook mainly with oil. This place was fresh and had amazing depth in flavor. Prices are just right, and I came on a day they had Baingan bartha, which pretty much sells me. Their Tikka Masala had an amazing smoky flavor to it, which definitely added to their rating. They also have awesome yogurt, which was devoured immediately by the boyfriend. I didn't think I was going to eat the whole plate, but I don't regret doing so. What else can I say? LOVED IT!!
author: Camille T.

description: The thali here tastes like India minus the fear of getting sick. Simple food, tasty and fair price. Great for a quick lunch with a chai.
author: Nico. P.

description:
loved our lunch here yesterday.
great food.
amazing service for such a casual spot. i was so impressed.
good attention to quality ingredients (the best part).
definitely get the lassi. OMG love the creamy cardamom flavor. so good.
great for vegetarians... i ate all veggie and loved it so much.
i do know if it is really "authentic" (i like true authentic cuisine) but i think it is all around really yummy and i am definitely going back.
author: K E.

description:
All you people who live in the neighborhood had BETTER be going here! If it doesn't stay open, I will be MOST displeased! Really good food, immediately ready, in the Castro, for like $10? Are you serious? Why would you ever get a bite before a movie or mid-bar crawl at any other place? No, that is not a good reason. The servers here are cute too.

Needless to say, I love it. Five stars for a fast food Indian place, you say? Yes, it is best in its class. My boyfriend likes the decor. And they have good beer. Kingfisher, of course, is what you really want with the food. But they have Belgian, dark, IPA, a little of everything.

So, what are you waiting for? Stop wandering aimlessly around, not really wanting the slice of pizza you are going to end up eating before meeting your friends, and walk your arse down to Kasa.
author: Brian B.

description: The food here is really inconsistent.  Sometimes it's so awesome and other times it's flavorless or off.  The flat breads are really good.  It's kind of expensive for not always being good.  Meh.
author: M C.

description:
OK so after writing the previous review I was contacted by the owner who apologized for the way I was treated on the phone.  I thought this was very nice of him and although I have yet to try Kasa, have decided I'm not going write them off either.

I will update again after trying the food:)
author: Mia L.

description:
A lot of food (thali plate with lamb curry and chicken tikki masala and a mango lassi for $15.  The lamb curry was delicious but the chicken tikki masala left something to the desired, it was too salty and the chicken was too dry for my taste.  The only downside of serving everything on a metal plate is how fast everything cools, so by the time I was done, most of the food had already gone cold.

As for my mango lassi, it was too heavily spice with cinnamon (strike one), and made with slightly sour mangoes (strike two), so ended up being a huge disappointment considering how much I love my mango lassi.
author: Ben T.

description:
My wife and I loved it!  We tried a little bit of a lot of things, and they were all delicious.  We ordered a Thali with Saag Paneer and Aloo Jeera.  These two dishes were by far my favorite.  Insultingly delicious.  (The kind of taste-bud fantasy that makes the food you have over the next week just not seem up to standards.)  I am craving these again.  

We also tried two Kati rolls: one Lamb Curry and one Chicken Tikka Masala. I didn't enjoy the Kati rolls as much, but I've heard others rave about them.  To each his own, I guess.  The Chicken TIkka Masala was very good though, and I would get that on a Thali next time.  

For drinks I recommend the Mango Lassi and the Chai (both made from scratch in house). Be prepared to taste real Chai, however, not that bogus boxed brew.
author: Joshua S.

description:
I went to Kasa for lunch. It was OK. It could have been worse, but there was a lot of room for improvement.

I ordered the thali with chicken tikka masala and gobi aloo. 

I found the meat in the chicken dish to be of poor quality - sinewy. It doesn't speak highly of the meat when I have to pull bits of meat out of my mouth because they weren't chewable. The sauce was tasty and not too heavy, but the meat really dragged this dish down.

The gobi aloo was tasty but very, very greasy. The whole dish was glistening and when I started getting to the bottom, the bottom layer of vegetables was swimming in oil turned yellow from the turmeric. This made me a little sick to my stomach, so I didn't finish it.

The daal was quite good. I mixed the rice in with the daal. This was my favorite part of the meal.

Overall, I wouldn't go back, and I wouldn't recommend it to others, but I wouldn't actively dissuade others who really wanted to try it.
author: Jack M.

description: Delicious! Had the lamb curry kati. Really good flavor and spice. I'd pass on the vegetable salad next time. Will be back for sure in July!
author: Jonas H.

description:
always nice, never greasy, easy on the wallet, pure & simple ingredients that haven't been sitting around for hours, fresh, clean, streamlined menu. 2 katis fill me up. 
oh and LOVE the plehtora of Vegan options.
author: S B.

description:
Indian food has so many forms in which it comes, I'm glad to see another style in SF's copious Indian cuisine locales. I am a Dolores Park junkie by nature & I work in the Castro area. Kasa is on the way to the park or close enough to get food during work time. The flavors are amazing, and you will need a napkin. Usually busy, it is best to get a table first if you are a larger group. I am a fan of take out or sitting outside at a table watching the sunset. The options are great if you are a Vegan or a Omnivore, so its good with diverse crowds. 

The only thing, the staff turn-over. What's going on there guys? Seems like you are always training new people. Your food is amazing!
author: Kai N.

description: Blown away by their Kati rolls. Apparently Kati rolls are supposed to be cheap/to-go food where they use Roti and stuff meat in it.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Kasa breaks all stereotypes in the book.
It's an axiomatic rule of the Castro that there are no great restaurants in this city's Mecca of the lousy cheeseburger. Kasa may be fast-casual rather than a place to consume 13-course feast replete with wine and servers clad in collar shirts, but for a low-key, high-taste Indian shoppe, Kasa gives the Castro a more favorable culinary rating.

Second, Indian food is a style of cooking always heavy and consistently carb-filled, where every single dish kind of tastes like lamb rogen josh or chicken vindaloo. Not so with Kasa. In fact, I don't think I've ever had Indian food where I could clearly discern a variety of complex flavors in each mouthful. This fare clearly had time and love put into every serving-- you could literally smell and feel the subtleties in the food here. 

All this from an eatery that serves its food in metal plates, not unlike those used in the kind of prisons where rich, crooked hedge fund managers go after they break the law.

The last law Kasa breaks is that a restaurant with this kind of throughput-- I would guess they served over 40 people in the 30 minutes in which I ate-- would have owners who are out of touch with their clientele and merely trying to serve the faceless masses as fast as possible (then urge them out the door). Kasa beats the odds with three owners who are kind, patient, and extremely friendly-- Tim is never too  busy to share a mango lassi with a friend.

I'm a big fan of Kasa. Cannot wait for the opening of their Marina restaurant since I'd rather have trouble parking around hot blonds with fake tans than men with mustaches and leather.
author: Ross S.

description:
I like the food here a lot.  Kasa definitely lets you switch it up from pizza and tacos while still getting your food in mere minutes, but a restaurant is more than food.  

Kasa is pricey ($$ not $)!  And that means you can take your money to better Indian restaurants if you have the time.  Edit: Someone brought up that they are organic. So I guess they are reasonably priced. 3.5 stars! 

Some of the serving staff are just bad listeners.  They aren't rude or incompetent; they just don't have that listening skill!  

And they were closed today at 11:45, though their front door says they  open everyday at 11.  I like your food, but I'm not going to stand around on the sidewalk on the off chance that you'll open your business.
author: Luke M.

description:
The owner contacted me and said that with advance notice, they can probably accommodate those needing their food without gluten.  

Hopefully, I can eat here soon and update.
author: Bo D.

description:
First time eating here. The interior threw me off a little cause it felt like we were about to have Chipotle...similar dining setup of sparse metal tables and chairs. 

Food is served fast - you order receiving line style...choose a wrap or a plate, your main course(s), and any extra sides and everything is placed on a tv dinner-like plate with compartments to keep the various sauces and chutneys from running over into each other.

We tried the chicken tikka masala, lamb curry, and karahi paneer as our main courses -- our plates included sides of rice, chopped veggie salad, two types of chutneys, daal(simmered lentils), raita (yogurt), and roti bread...not the typical naan bread that I'm used to - more like a thinner crepe style bread. The sauces were much lighter and less creamy than we were used to with Indian cuisine, but the meal was still delicious and filling.

We'll be glad to come back here again!
author: Elaine W.

description: Cheap, large portions and fast, Brigtly lit, good service.  My only complaint is that the food was completely without heat.  I suppose they get a wide variety of customers and have to keep things mild, but I like my Indian food to be at least remotely spicey.  Overall, perhaps not the most authentic Indian food, but still good with fresh ingredients.
author: D M.

description: Love the concept! an Indian 'Chipotle' --was my idea first ;) -- it's simple, quick, yummy, cheap and plentiful. All my items were right: spicy and yummy, not dry.
author: Carlos L.

description:
I've been here twice and can say that Kasa is a great place to eat! 

Since I am gluten intolerant and therefore cannot eat almost all bread-like products, I went with the thali. The staff was very accomodating and gave me extra rice in replace of the bread. AND they double-checked with the chef to ensure that there was no wheat flour whatsoever in the chicken tika masala, the paneer, or any other parts of the thali.  

So... aside from the bread, the rest of the thali that Kasa offers is entirely gluten-free... and delicious! Who knew gluten-free could still be so good? And It's a pretty good deal ($11.99 total), considering how many different explosions of flavor you get in one sitting...
author: Deirdre P.

description: Food taste is getting worse by the day. As it is, they have very limited menu to work with, worst kathi rolls I have had....
author: strfrm y.

description: the meat is now cooked on a flat top grill, instead over a fire, and while that may be healthier, it doesn't burn off the fat of the chicken thighs, which makes the meat grisly and rubbery.  Just sayin'.   You had a PERFECT recipe.  I actually mourn your old tikka masala.
author: Nicholas C.

description: I was craving Kasa this weekend so I ducked in and had a Thali plate with chicken tikka masala, lamb curry and EXTRA raita.  YUM!!!  I don't know if this is new, but they also have a spicy green condiment that I hadn't tried before.  It adds a great flavor to the food and packs some killer heat!
author: Vicente G.

description:
Whoever thought of the idea of making Indian burritos is a genius. 

1 for 4.95....2 for 8.95.....3 for 11.95. I got three teeka masala Kati rolls and I was stuffed. Two is enough unless you're a big eater. Plus it's more like a fast food sort of place. You won't get the fancy dining experience but you will get fast convenient and cheap good food. I'm not the biggest Indian food lover but this place is tasty and cheap.
author: David C.

description: Great Thali. Love the authentic bhajis. Roti on the kathi rolls is a bit thick but great spot. Dig the attention to good beer and wine!
author: el b.

description:
I first ate at Kasa a week after they opened, and I wouldn't have given it glowing marks.

Just tried it again a couple years later and seems like they have tightened up the menu. The kati rolls (chicken tikka, chicken masala, and the veggie) were all delicious. The raita was nice and thick - not watered down as I've experienced in some other places. Good punchy flavors - lots of spice, perhaps a little too much raw red onion (in combination with the dry spices not my favorite), but I would definitely eat there again and try some other options.
author: Mariangela S.

description:
I must be crazy to be craving Indian food a week before going to India... even crazier that I'd go to Kasa where the cost is exponentially higher than what I'll be paying in India. 

One kati roll is now $4.50 and there aren't any deals for buying more. I guess they didn't like people trying to share 3 rolls to save money. You can add egg (unda style) for $1 which is good with the aloo jeera (potatoes). I still think the roti is delicious and holds up well to the saucy fillings. One roll could actually be filling, but I have no self control...
author: Mimi L.

description:
Not a family friendly place at all. They keep the high chairs and booster seats in the bathroom (which I find very gross). We asked the owner many times to be so kind to keep them outside but they are still in the bathroom.
We like the place and food is good but we won't go back until the high chairs are out of the bathroom. We will go to "Curry Up Now" on Valencia Street which is very family friendly.
author: Cinzia B.

description:
This was really good. Even just to get away from the normal choices in the Castro. It looked very modern, clean, great smells and the food was wonderful.

The menuboard is confusing, just remember...  On a Plate or in a Rolled bread.
I prefer the plate for a dinner as you get the wonderful lentils and rice and sides.
The Marsala and the Lamb were the choices and they were absolutely delicious.

I'm going to go back more often!
author: Nick R.

description: Very good good at a very reasonable price and the service was great. They are very friendly and the food was fresh and full of flavor. Pretty darn good!
author: Rick R.

description:
Loved it. The rolls are just awesome. We got in on the groupon deal and the 2 of us struggled to eat our $30 worth of food. It was nice to just walk in and order at the counter but still receive something fresh, made of quality ingredients. It took us a few moments to get our bearings with the menu and ordering system, but the staff was helpful and friendly. 

The chai was possibly a little bit over-sweetened and  the dal may have been a touch spicier than I'm used to but it was still very good. The mango lassi was awesome though. The raita was perfect. Don't forget to grab some napkins. It was pretty oily.
author: aaron f.

description:
This place sucked!!!! The food was cold and very bland and the rotis were under cooked. 
The only thing I liked about the place was the art work. The photos are really touching.  
They should remove the blurb on their wall about the place because food like that will NOT make anyone's grandmother proud. AND that is not the way Indians eat at home.  Sorry guys, you get two stars.
author: Swati K.

description:
I'm a big fan. Kasa is not your typical Indian restaurant with a large menu of various meats and veggies prepared with a long list of lavish sauces. Instead, Kasa focuses on two dishes and does them well: roti rolls and Thali.

I like the roti rolls. Roti is a rich, buttery flat bread that is extremely tasty. They make the rolls small - 2 of them would be a light lunch - which means you can sample several of the fillings. I really like the chicken tikka masala (who doesn't?) and the turkey kebab. For the latter, I was expecting a shish kebab-style grilled turkey chunks, but it's actually ground meat, which I don't usually like but is quite tasty at Kasa (it says all this on the menu, but I was too hungry to read past the titles). I'll be back soon.
author: Adam B.

description:
Savory, aromatic with wonderful flavors - spicy, hot and lip-licking good.

We both had the Thali - hubby tried the lamb curry and chicken tikka masala. I had the chicken tikka masala and turkey kebabs.  $10.95 each, comes with daal, fragrant basmati rice, chutney, chopped veggie salad and raita.  The chicken masala was really, really good and I would love to try it again.  Didn't care much for the 2 meatball sized turkey kebabs - dry, spicy.  Hubby's lamb curry was gamey but OK.  The roti was really good - a large crepe that you can dip into the sauces or fill with meat, so good.  I could've eaten another piece (side = $1.5 each).  

The other entree is Kati rolls - a roti stuffed with onions, chutney and one of the 7 fillings.  Comes as 1, 2 or 3 (prices $4.95 for one, $11.95 for 3) and looks like a burrito.  We didn't try any because we were quite full from our Thali plates.  The food was served on metal compartment trays.  You have a choice of 2 fillings from a list of 7  items for the rolls or Thali plates:  chicken tikka, chix tikka masala, turkey kebabs, and 3 vegetarian choices: karahi paneer (Indian cheese), Aloo Jeer (sauteed potatoes), or vegetable special of the day.

Hubby had the mango lassi and I tried a sip - a watery mango drink ($3) but I didn't care for it.  A simple menu loaded with lots of flavor. The food's not mild, can be a little spicy-hot, but so, so good!  A definite must visit again!  They have a huge community table that you can share with others or counter dining and some tables for 4.  Parking's difficult in his neighborhood but if you can score one, it's worth a visit to Kasa.
author: Ry T.

description: I want to ding them because both of the times I've visited post-doctor-in-the-neighborhood visit, they have had a different pretty boy at the cash register, and both times he's been completely incompetent.  It's fast food, get it?  Your looks don't matter to me.
author: Robin W.

description: Great food at a low price, especially the tikka masala kati rolls. And they cater too -- arriving early to set up the dishes and signs is just the extra dollop of raita on a fantastic meal. Highly recommended!
author: Kat A.

description:
I had high expectations of Kasa, and I'm sorry to say they disappointed. 

While the fillings inside the roti were good, the roti itself was chewy and pretty flavorless. The kathi rolls I've had before were much better, though they also cost twice as much (and were at least 30% bigger). 

It seems to be run by hipsters, so it didn't feel as authentic as I expected. They were friendly hipsters, though.
author: David Z.

description:
It is so simple to substitute a little rice for the kati bread, why do they insist on being so difficult with people who have gluten intolerance??

I've been to Kasa a few times, and every time they act like I'm asking them to turn the world inside out. I want to get the $4.50 kati roll plate, but get rice instead of the kati bread because I have celiac disease. IT'S SO SIMPLE, yet they refuse. Instead they want me to pay more than double for a thali plate, or $3 extra to to get two side dishes. DON'T PUNISH PEOPLE WITH EXTRA COST BECAUSE THEY CAN'T EAT BREAD. Just substitute with some rice and say "Thank you, enjoy your meal."

The manager also responded to my simple request by calling me a "Dope" on the receipt. Thanks.

My two-star rating is for the service.

UPDATE 3 YEARS LATER! ...
From day one their food has been amazingly delicious, and since sometime after I posted the original review above they proudly say that all their food is gluten-free (except the naan bread) and always offer a papadum (a crispy fried lentil pancake like a taco shell) instead of naan to make it totally gluten-free.

They are my favorite source for a quick yummy meal!
author: Stefanie S.

description:
indian street food? what is that??? 

that's the question i had when i first heard about kasa. one of my coworkers (who is indian) recommended this place in the castro and I was curious to try it out since it seems to be reasonably priced and it's always a reassurance when people from a specific culture say a particular restaurant is good and authentic. 

when i arrived, i was mesmerized by the lovely curry smell and big plates of food people were having. I ordered 2 kati rolls with that day's special (some sort of veggie mix) and a chicken tikka, my friend ordered a plate with lamb curry and chicken tikka masala. i was very impressed by the chicken tikka because i've definitely had super dry grilled chicken meat before, so when it's tender and juicy, i couldn't love it more. the lamb curry was my favorite. it's very lamby (for all of you who adore that special pungent lamb taste) and flavorful and went very well with basmati rice

i dont really dig their chai tea though, it's not bad but i find it weird that there's a very prominent lavender taste in there, not really my cup of tea!

but overall, i would say the food was really good and i would want to return in the future and try their other curries.
author: Joyce C.

description: Can't wait to get back to San Francisco to Enjoy Kasa again.  Quick, delicious, and fresh Indian fare.
author: Bryan W.

description:
Admittedly, I am not a huge Indian food fan. My BFF has to basically drag me kicking & screaming. But we stopped by Kasa for a quick lunch and I was really pleased with my experience. The space is simple and minimalistic; the colors are bright and pleasing (white & shades of purple.) I liked that the food is laid out in front of you (almost cafeteria style) so I can see what I'm getting into before I placed my order. The guy who served us was pretty cool & explained what several items were. 

We ordered their lunch special, which was 2 roti and a soda for $7.95. We paid the extra $1 to upgrade to mango lassi, which is a tangy, yogurty mango "smoothie" with a hint of spice--the consistency is smack in the middle of watery & thick, which I'm not used to but the flavor was good. I had the Aloo Jeera (cumin spiced potatoes) and the chicken tikka masala. Both were spiced just right and very flavorful. The BFF also had the chicken, as well as the lamb curry, which he said was very mild in flavor (not the least bit gamey.) I really enjoyed the roti-it was flakey and soft. 

The price was right & the food was filling.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Cool, hip location with flavor.  The food brought me back to my ethnic roots (ok, just kidding ;).  Actually, it brought me back to great memories of time spent working abroad in Bangalore.  The flavors are true to Indian food friends shared with me.  And, Kasa's milky sweet chai is true to the chai we had every morning and afternoon in India.

My top pics at Kasa include the Chicken Tikka Masala, Lamb Curry, and Dal Makhani.  They are all flavor packed and moderately spicy (look to the chutneys if you're after the "kill me" levels of spiciness).  The meats are free range and grass fed, respectively.

This spot is also a great value, especially at lunch when you can get an entire thali plate with either a mango lassi or chai for less than $10.

The staff here is friendly, upbeat, and flexible - they'll let you mix and match selections (ex. 1/2 chicken, 1/2 lamb, extra raita, no chutney, etc.).

My only quibble with Kasa is that I wish they had as great a selection of vegetarian options as carnivorous options.

ps. Try the mango lassi - it is spiked with bits of ginger and pistachio!
author: Heather W.

description:
To read that you naive sycophants equated indian thali platters with incarceration trays disgruntles this desi food hound in a way that i can't intrinsically decipher right away. It's so brazen and unforgivable. I came out of hiding for this, and this alone. As soon as i distinguish a proper action plan...... oh, well, you'll know. 

Excellent Aloo Jeera! I don't know if I've seen that outside of India.

I have nothing else to grievously mutter. It's a ripe cacophonous monster of uncertainty on our hands that i have to guide. i must educate the linear bound privileged consumers of the world. 

Hmmm. I just got giddy.
author: Christopher J.

description:
we had our doubts about kasa.  with its hip, modern ambiance, and fancy ingredients, it just seemed to be trying so hard to fit the sf scene.

but we went anyway, and promptly ordered a thali and a kati roll...

and it was all delicious!  the flavors were big and fresh, and i appreciated that it was not overly creamy.  the raita was the best I'd ever had, and i found myself eating it by the spoonful.

in fact, the only bad thing was the price.  that, and i wished there was one in oakland.

thanks kasa, for proving me wrong.  you were a wonderful surprise!
author: Jill k.

description: The food is pretty good, but I'm rating this restaurant a bit lower because I think it's sterile and cold, and kind of more like a cafeteria than a restaurant. It's probably alright as a takeout restaurant, or a place to grab lunch, but as far as ambiance and experience, it's a bit cold, and definitely not a place I'd like to go on a date. The process is that you place your order, and then watch as they scoop it from a steel container onto a try, which you then pay for, then seat yourself, and eat. I mean, it's like a fast food process, but Asqew Grill has the same process, and manages to make it feel a little more welcoming and cozy than that.
author: Amanda F.

description: Super friendly staff.  The Kati rolls are bombtastic.  Chicken was very tender and juicy.  The spices was just right.  This is definitely a fantastic spot after one or two beers.  Have not tried their combo platter, but it looks gooooood.  Will definitely come back to check that out.
author: Sai Kiu H.

description:
This is my new favorite place to eat!

I had the Chicken tikka Masala kati roll....
oh my god, i have found heaven...it was so good it seriously took the wrinkles out of my penis!

I had been wanting to try this place for months, but was always in a big rush...finally I stopped in, and i am so glad i did!

I went there last weekend with a friend...she had the lamb..but what you dont know is they will fry and egg and put in the kati roll as an extra treat..its sooo good...i may have to try this next time!

Next time you are in the castro and craving a burrito...skip that...and come here...the food is a little spicy...but if your sinuses have been clogged like mine have been because of the allergies this year..you will leave breathing clearly and you will be quite satiated!
author: Ripley B.

description:
Nothing quite hits the spot like Kati Rolls when you're hungry (but still somewhat choosy on what you want to eat).  One chicken tikka masala and one saag paneer is the perfect combo.  Even better, you get it for less than $10 and within 5 minutes after ordering.

Love it.
author: F. P.

description:
So my friend says to me..."Have you been to Kasa?" I go "No, what type of food is it?" and he goes "Its like an Indian burrito." 

Indian burrito? You have got to be kidding me. I came, I saw, I have been converted. This is the Indian love of my life. Their Kati Rolls are amazing. Rich, flaky, and filled with Indian goodness, you can bet that this unique Indian styled wrap will leave an little impression on you heart so that you'll come back.

The Kati rolls are quick and affordable. At about $5 a pop, you save more by buying more, but they sit pretty heavy so one will usually do. They basically take your choice of an Indian entree and wrap it into one. The wrap reminds me of a larger samosa but with more filling. Its a little unconventional and totally cool - fitting into the Castro neighborhood lifestyle just perfectly. "Come hungry, leave happy"  ;)
author: Candy C.

description:
Who would have thought of Indian fast food? The geniuses at Kasa did. This is not your typical Indian Restaurant with traditional Indian food. They serve "Kati Rolls", which are like "Indian Burritos" and you have several meat and vegetable choices to pick from. If you're very hungry I'd recommend two rolls because one won't fill you up or you can order the "Thali" (plate) which comes with Rice, Meat, Vegetables, Lentils (Daal) and Salad. And if you have room for dessert, try the Mango "Lassi" (a yogurt drink that has the consistency of a smoothie). 
I would highly recommend the Aaloo Jeera (potato & cumin) Roll or the Karahi Paneer (cheese, green peppers & tomato) Roll if you're a vegetarian. And for meat lovers I'd recommend their Turkey Kebab Roll.
What's also unique about them is that they have a Truck going around town, which stops at different locations in the city, so you can get a taste of Kasa without having to go to their Restaurant in the Castro. To find out where the truck will be next, go to their website or follow them on Twitter.
author: Amir J.

description:
FINALLY, I got to try Kasa after bookmarked it "to try" for over a year. 

Came with my 2 girlfriends, they both got the rice platter, and I got the lunch special 2 rolls. The rice platter look great for people who need lots of food and love rice, it's got everything, rice, 2 item from the list, veggies, yogurt, beans, and a flatbread. Great deal.

But I hate rice, hate beans, don't eat a lot, and the rolls are PERFECT! The flatbread is so buttery and soft/chewy with great flavor. The lamb curry looked pale but tasted great. The veggie curry was a great contrast with the lamb. 

Get the Chai!
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Yuk - gross - never again.

Soggy, bland, sub-par indian food wrapped in something bready and flavorless.  It made us all feel ill after.
author: Bob C.

description:
On the way back from Philz on a Saturday afternoon, my sister and I stopped here for a bite.  We were looking for a curry-in-a-hurry place and this was perfect.

Friendly attitude with snappy service and pretty cheap to boot.

The turkey kabob was crumbly and delicious and with raita, it was perfect.  The paneer was amazing and my sister said the chicken tikka khati roll was awesome too.

For the price, I think this place is even better than Pakwan.  The food wasn't very greasy so I feel like I could eat here regularly.

I'd definitely come back.
author: Ankur P.

description:
Growing up in coastal Southern California, I went to middle school less than a quarter of a mile from the beach. More specifically, a couple hundred feet away from some very steep cliffs. 

As a kid, we would watch in awe as surfers nimbly handled the steep descent, one hand firmly on the sharp rocks jutting out and the other on their boards. And then when we got old enough, we realized that it was a favorite place for those attempting suicide. We'd be on the football field during PE, hear the familiar whirring of the rescue and media helicopters, and go home to a news story on so-and-so from San Pedro driving their Prelude off the cliff. 

You may remember in the mid-90s when some teenagers committed suicide by jumping off a cliff. Marilyn Manson was blamed. Yep, happened in my backyard. Jealous? 

On a seemingly unrelated note, I wandered past Kasa for nearly six months with little more than moderate interest. One day I stepped off the precipice and plunged headfirst into two delicious kati rolls. One chicken tikka, one lamb curry, and washed down with a refreshing mango lassi. Like the surfer gods of my youth, I deftly maneuvered around the roti, embracing every last piece of buttery hangover curing goodness. 

Alright, terrible analogy. But with a place like Kasa, it doesn't really matter. Either you jump off and enjoy it, or you sit on the edge looking down. It's not healthy in the slightest, but for those of us looking for a slow artery clogging death, it's a perfect choice. 

New Slogans: 
Kasa: 70% better than suicide! 
Kasa: Marilyn Manson approved! 
Kasa: Who the fuck cares? It's a delicious Indian burrito! 
Kasa: Good enough for an unfunny navel gazing review!
author: Devon S.

description:
2 rolls for under ten bucks.  I'm there.

The food is very delicious.  I would recommend getting one of your rolls unda style -- it means with egg.  It adds another dimension to the wrap. I usually get the daily veggie unda style.  

My three-year-old likes the Channa Saag wrap (not spicey).
author: Michael G.

description:
I tried this place for the first time last night.  I had the Chicken Tikka Masala kati and the Aloo Jeera kati with egg option.  Both were stellar. Staff were outgoing and super friendly in answering my questions and explaining the options.  The cashier promised I would LOVE it, and when I was done he asked me what I thought, to confirm that he was right.

He was right.
author: Dave M.

description: Kasa is the best! They're very generous and happy to help local organizations with donations! Plus their food is delish! Thanks Kasa! You're a local gem.
author: amy W.

description:
I know, I know, they are not authentic kati rolls like you can get in NYC but they are filling and not greasy.  I'd been here a while back before they opened and everything I tried was good.  I thought it would be a great late night after drinking spot.  

I went back recently and had the chicken tikka masala and the aloo gobi kati rolls.  Both of them were tasty and maybe you can eat them with your hands but it seemed kind of messy so I used a knife and fork.  The kati rolls along with a Kingfisher and I was a pretty happy lady.  I just wish they were open later on the weekends.
author: Seong P.

description:
When I went here for the first time a few months ago, I erroneously made the decision to go with the thali (plate) option. It was good, though -- just not unbelievable.

I went back today for the kati rolls (had chicken tikka masala and the karahi paneer). They were extreeeeemely satisfying and perfectly portioned. This is the only way to go in my opinion, don't screw around with the plate...
author: Evan M.

description:
Tried this place after reading so many great reviews. We had one wrap and another full plated meal. The flavors on the dishes was very tasty but the quantity was a bit on the light side. The wrap was cheaper than the plated meal obviously, but there were some items on the plate that i could have enjoyed a great lunch without noticing. My conclusion is to next time get the wrap but add one or two sides to it instead. Price works out better and you are getting almost the same meal but without the other small tiny portion snacks. The decor is nice and located few blocks from Dolores park. Good for lunch.

I would probably prefer Sharlimar instead.
author: Ernie P.

description:
I'm giving this place 4 stars because I can see myself coming back for more. It's a quick service - where you order first, pay and then find a seat. It has a clear simple menu. Either choose a 1) Kati Roll or 2) Thali Plate.

Kati Roll is an Indian Wrap Sandwich. Pick your choice of filling - choose from a list of chicken tikka, turkey kebab, lamb, and veggie - which is then rolled in their freshly made roti along with other seasonings. $4.50 for one. Not too big so that you can't polish off 2, though I think 1 is enough for me. They serve it with a side of raita yogurt to stave off any spiciness. I tried the chicken tikka which was nice and tender.

Thali Plate is bigger where you choose 1 or 2 mains + comes with daal, rice, slaw, green parsley chop, lime seasoned onions, and a roti ($10.95) all served on a big round silver tray with partitions for each item. I chose the Chicken Tikka Marsala and the Gobi Aloo (cauliflower veggie mix) which they put together in the same tray slot. So you don't get double when you choose 2 items, they merely fit them in the same place. It works. My Marsala was a little spicy so I was thankful for the raita. Very tasty. The Gobi Aloo was ok. Nothing too memorable.

We sat at the big communal table in the middle of the store, big enough to fit the 5 of us. It was a fun, casual easy dining experience. Love it.
author: Cindy W.

description: I'm not usually a big fan of Indian food, because no matter what, it's always so hot that I can't enjoy it. This time around, though, Kasa proved me wrong. OK - well one of their dishes was super hot, but she did warn me about going for the Chicken Masala. But hot rotis and yummy yogurt blended with some pretty awesome base dishes that had me super full. While I haven't been in over 7 months, and probably would only return here and now since my boyfriend isn't into Indian food at all, I still can say I'd recommend coming. Screw Dosa and their pretentious establishments. Kasa rocks!
author: Alita M.

description:
I'm gonna be honest... I wasn't expecting much out of this place. I was meeting up with my potential (and now fo' realz) new roommate and he suggested we eat at this "Indian place in the Castro." 

Things I began to picture in my head:
-Exotic (read: skinny and shiny) belly dancers wearing only thongs
-A dish called the Rainbow Tikka
-Starlet waiters wearing shirts that say "Caste me in your new movie"

What I found was a pleasant surprise. The place has a cool, industrial meets coffee shop vibe. The service was friendly and patient with me as I kept asking my friend what certain things were. And the food was REALLY tasty. I ended up getting 2 Kati rolls and both were equally flavorful and spicy. There was some mysterious white creamy liquid on my tray... but if you know anything me, I didn't touch it (see review for White Creamy Liquids). 

I brought a friend here this past weekend and she had the same hestitations as I originally did. She ended up loving the place and the food.  

Thank you for impressing me, Kasa. If anyone talks shit about you, I got yo' back.
author: Jared S.

description: Food itself was OK, I think I like Curry Up Now! better (just an opinion). I'm giving it a four star instead of three because the guy gave us free mango lassi's after realizing he forgot to put the included samosa in my friend's order.
author: Iana H.

description:
Lately I am addicted to Kasa's kati rolls.  The irony is that I hate Indian food because I am severely allergic to some Indian spices so I've avoided Indian food at all cost - until I was introduced to Kasa's kati rolls a few weeks ago.  Since then, I've been a regular - buying 2 or 3 vegetarian kati rolls at a time, and having them for 1 or 2 dinners, almost every week.     

 I know I am eating them at my own risk given my medical condition - but I figured what's a little hive for a hour or two when I get to enjoy those kati rolls that wake up all the taste buds in my mouth all at once.  Plus, what's life without taking some risks anyhow.  

Yes, they are that good.
author: Shirley F.

description: Healthy , light and yummy! Had a meal with lassi for 9 $ .Not the usual biryani and curry place.Different yet authentic! Kati rolls and Lentils...yummmy!
author: Sudhir D.

description:
This place is a bit pricey for what it is but the food is really good - fast and flavorful without being overbearing or greasy like some Indian food.

The next time I eat here I'll get my food to go because the place was so cold we couldn't take off our jackets and the chairs were so uncomfortable that my legs cramped up.
author: Quartknee K.

description:
Just got delivery and the food was soooo delicious!!
Though the guy on the phone was really whack (in a funny and entertaining way) and totally messed up my order, charged and sent me all this food that i din't order, I cant complain cuz the food was so finger licking good that i ate all of it anyways. 

I cant wait for my next order, yayys!!
author: Katherine C.

description:
Indian fast food!  This wonderful concept might be a home run if it was executed with more passion.

I'd driven and walked by many times and made mental notes to give it a try. So there I was staring at the skimpy Noe Valley Whole Foods Market buffet (is it my imagination or are the SOMA, PacHeights, and Potrero locations better?), finding no worthwhile Indian offerings, when I suddenly remembered Kasa and decided to scoot over the hill to give it a try.

And I found parking right away at 7 p.m!

I started having misgivings when I saw the orders in front of me being prepared.  Everything looked the same; except for  the condiments, there was little variation in colors and textures.  But I felt committed already and I had no backup plan for dinner.

Once at home with fork in hand I was pleasantly surprised.  Though the presentation was lacking, the food was tasty and satisfying.  

The best things about Kasa are 1) the food tastes fine; 2) it's well-organized for takeout business; 3) it's fast; 4) decent portions.

This is not gourmet Indian and doesn't claim to be.  But it would be a more repeatable experience if the proprietors worked on perfecting the presentation.
author: Francisco G.

description: I came here for a late night snack.  The kata roll here is soooo good!!!  I ordered it with chicken marsala.  The meat was really well marinated, juicy and tender.  The sauce had the perfect amount of spicy kick.  One roll is equivalent to half a burrito....perfect for a snack, however, if you are hungry order 2.
author: Eva E.

description: As an Indian eating Indian all my life I usually never eat at Indian restaurants because they are extremely greasy, fat filled with cream and ghee,  curries tend to sit there and be reheated day after day, and no one can cook like my mom.  Kasa defies all the traditional Indian greasy buffets by offering a california fresh twist on Indian food and it is great.  The food is not amazing  (like my mom's) but it is still very good and fresh and fairly cheap costing the same as groccery sushi.  My only complaint was the mango lassi which only had a subtle mango taste and was over seasoned with cardamon.   I will keep coming back.
author: Christopher T.

description:
I can only agree with the positive reviews... delicious, inexpensive food, in perfectly sized portions, served promptly with a smile. I was looking for something light, and one of their sub-$5 chicken tandoori kati rolls fit the bill exactly. One roll is a big snack or a light dinner, two rolls is a meal.

And it's in the Castro, where food bargains are as rare as hen's teeth! How did that happen?
author: Larry C.

description:
Thanks to groupon I learned about Kasa and I'm so glad I tried it out. My husband and had 5 kati rolls (Chicken Tikka, Chicken Tikka Masala, Lamb Curry, Turkey Kebabs, and Karahi Paneer), a side of rice and daal, and mango lassi.  I had an order mix up - I ordered a side of rice but they thought I ordered daal, so since they charged me for daal, they gave me a side of rice and some daal.  They were very nice about it.  

Everything was really yummy!  Even the red onions they put in the rolls were yummy and I'm NOT a fan of onions, especially raw.  The karahi paneer was my favorite!  My husband loved the turkey.  The chicken was very moist and flavorful.  The raita (yogurt) they serve on the side is delicious and I wish they gave you more!  The rice was very flavorful.

5 rolls were more than enough for us but we did have an early dinner.  Just one kati roll and a side of rice is enough for me.

The atmosphere is very modern, relaxed, and clean.  We were there around 4:30 and it got busy around 5.  There's street parking around but it can be difficult.  We ended up parking about 4 blocks away.  It was a nice day so we enjoyed the walk.
author: Stacey L.

description: Kasa is open until 10 and the Chicken tikka is delicious. The best thing, however, is their chi tea. I think it's a beautiful spicy/sweet balance. This isn't a big place, but the hustle/bustle was just enough background noise to be a perfect "work from home" environment for me. It's nice for a quick meal and (i thought) good to settle in and get some to-dos, to-did but you shouldn't go on a date here unless you want to break-up.
author: Joe W.

description: Probably one of my new food obsessions. I can't seem to get enough of this place. Their lamb curry and the tika masala are very good. The potatoes and cauliflower as a side is also very good. Try one of their mango drinks, they usually have them next to the cashier.
author: Erick I.

description:
Star Worthy Stuff:
Aloo Jeera Kati (move over naans and dosas I love katis)
Riata

Room For Improvement:
Charbroiled chicken tikka needs to be less charred.
Daal were delicious.  Tasted like it had bacon in it though I know it was vegetarian.  Just one thing though, can you please serve it hot?

Notes:  Didn't try the kati unda style (egg batter) but will definitely try it next time.  Need to try the unfamiliar sodas too.
This is how I feel about charbroiled and barbequed food in general.  Grill lines are okay, the entire perimeter of food blackened is not okay.
author: Rachel R.

description:
My wife doesn't like this place.  I only feel comfortable telling her that she's wrong in the safe confines of the internet, where everything is anonymous and speech is free.

My wife is wrong.  This place is very good.  I've had every item on the menu and enjoyed each one.  Has anyone said that this place is Chipotle for Indian?  Ok ok, fine.  Well I'm saying it too.  Get over yourselves snobs - Chipotle is awesome.  Chipotle for Indian food is awesome.
author: Brian D.

description: The kathi rolls never disappoint.  Leaning on the high standards that this place encourages, 1 star off for the minuscule raita portions.  But aside from that, hard to find fault with this place!!
author: Vandana N.

description:
Kasa is pretty yummy. Less like an Indian wrap and more like an Indian burrito. Seriously it felt like I was in Pancho Villa in Mumbai. Assembly line wrapped food construction. You choose the filling for the wrap thing (Kati) from a list, or you can have it 'deconstructed' (Thali) - a description which seemed silly to me since its basically just a plate of Indian food at that point. Whatever, they can describe it however they want - what's important is that its good.

I went with the plate of two Kati rolls. Lamb and Tikka Masala. The Tikka Masala was OK, not really inspired but good. I think I may be losing my interest in Tikka Masala in general. Its not a legit Desi dish anyway. The lamb, however, was superb. Succulent and spicy, it had the texture of good chile verde. I would come back for that and get a three roll plate any day. I'm also kicking myself for not getting the Turkey. See, I have to go back. They have a good selection of sodas and some interesting indian beverages.

The interior is a little sterile and I actually found the photographs a little distracting. With the combo of minimalist design and cafeteria style service, its more of a lunch or dine alone spot than a dinner resto. I'll be going back. If the turkey impresses, this might evolve into a semi-frequent destination.
author: Zac H.

description:
1. Legal: Marriage between a man and a woman.

2. Illegal: Marriage between two men or two women (which is such blatant discrimination but I'm not going there, this isn't a yelp of prop 8).

3. Unknown: Marriage between indian food and burritos.

You can argue the first two (seriously, with a failure rate of 50%+ what's this sanctimony argument all about anyway?), but you can't argue with #3. It's freaking delicious. And what's so good about Kasa is they set it up so you can sample a few of these marriages with a 1/$5, 2/$9, 3/$12 roll pricing system. I went with the chicken roll and turkey roll and loved them both. Don't make me choose. Kasa didn't.

Even more bonus points for warming my roti without butter. Why they swapped in a salad instead of yogurt as my side is unknown, but I think they were catching my healthy vibe.

This is a marriage made in heaven.
author: Jason B.

description:
My friend Kat W. and I were walking around the Castro looking for something to eat while our friend was wrapping up his yoga class. 

http://www.flickr.com/photos/jrobert484/3335329737/

Kasa hasn't been there very long, but already it is one of those places that you will run into someone you know, or several someones, while you're eating. (It happened to us three times last night.)

Fortunately, the tables are long and perfect for a communal dinner. Although the interior is a bit cold and industrial feeling, what with all of the steel and sleek lines, it can't diminish the warmth between friends happy to see each other.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/jrobert484/3335329731/

Not only does this place have an uncanny ability to reconnect friends, but it mashes them together at the perfect times in their lives to bond over recently similar experiences.

For example, Kat W. had just recovered from a bout of TMJ which interfered with her ability to chew for a time. Her friend, who we ran into there, had also just recovered from the same thing... which to her dismay prevented her from performing acts of oral gratitude. How lovely of fate to bring these two together to celebrate their regained independence.

I had their vegetarian specials, which I don't remember what they were because I got pretty wasted after dinner... but I think it was "aloo" this and "gobi" that and it was fresh and spicy... just like me. I do remember that the roti was good.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/jrobert484/3336164122/

Our friend finally wrapped up his yoga class, and then he joined us and wrapped up his masala in a roti. He liked the  food so well he helped me finish my plate.

Food: Good.

Company: Great.

Conversation: Fantastic.

That's a wrap!
author: John R.

description: I've only been here twice but it hits the spot when you're really hungry.  I got the karahi paneer and I was pretty happy with it.  They also had some delicious cookies that you could buy.  I highly recommend getting a cookie for dessert.
author: Rachana S.

description: I stopped in here for kati roll and to see what all the buzz was about.  Delicious roll.  Nice blend of sharp and savoury flavours,  My only complaint is that the price is a bit high for the amount of food you get.
author: Douglas P.

description: Really awful. Dried out, over cooked food, small portions, over priced, noisy, never going back. Ordered the thali plate and shared it with a friend. There was no sign or taste or hint of curry in the "lamb curry" and it was over cooked, grayish, and really soupy. The chicken tikka masala was way too salty. What's with Indian restaurants and over use of salt?  The rice was cold and had no flavor and with the whole plate we only got two tiny slices of naan. Oh yeah and $7 for a tiny small glass of lager beer. They don't even deserve one star. All of you who rated this place high, must've been high and hungry after hanging out at Dolores Park smoking pot all day. All food taste great when you got the munchies!
author: Marc N.

description: Good food, but at $12 calling this Indian "street food," seems somewhat misleading.  I've been to India, and street food would never set you back that much. Neither does most sit down Indian in sf with food of similar quality.
author: Bob L.

description: Clean as fuck for indian with that amazing carrot zuchini vege dish I wish you guys can just keep it on your menu all the time I would be there everyday for that dish.
author: Chris D.

description: Kasa was more casual and minimalistic than I expected, and the menu is limited, but this place works. I had 2 kati rolls: one Gobi Aloo and the other Shulghum (turnips and peas). The Gobi aloo was a bit on the dry side - not sure if it was the roti that was dry or the filling, but it was still tasty; my Shulghum roll was pure joy!! Yummy and moist. The raita complimented both rolls beautifully. If I lived in San Fran I would visit Kasa at least once a month!
author: Emily R.

description: I love Indian food. I came here with a friend unexpectedly but was excited because I had not eaten there...I got the veggie plate. Lots and lots of veggies! Tofu, cauliflower, lentils, onions, veggie salad and rice galore. You get a hefty portion but aren't spending a lot (which is good!).  I would definitely come back here to try some meat dishes! Glad we stopped in! :)
author: Mel P.

description:
For the love of chai, stop calling them "Indian burritos"! "Burritos" make me think huge, large, stuffed with meat and rice, big enough to last me for lunch and dinner. Have I said large yet? Kati rolls are not at all like burritos, especially in size.  They're more like egg rolls size-wise, if you must draw a simile. I consider it overpriced.  Ok, ok, my palate is based on my wallet and I can't get over the price to accurately describe the food. It's just expensive, small, Indian food to me. I don't like it. 2 stars

But I'm still in love with their chai. A million stars! I love messing with the cashier's mind by planting myself right in front of the register:

"Um, you order over there. (you know where the lines of people are and the signs point to and duh)." 

"Nope, I just want chai."
author: Yan E.

description: The chicken tikka kathi roles and the chicken tikka thali plate is great. Amazing food for the money. I'll be coming back here again!
author: Kem K.

description: OMG the chai. They have a little hand-written sign that says its the best in the city, and they're not joking. It's way better than the chai down the street at Samovar.
author: Christian N.

description:
Local & organic meets Indian classics with style, at last.  This delightful establishment uses high quality ingrediants while keeping the prices affordable.  I love the lamb dishes, moist and perfectly spiced.  The chicken tikka masala is a classic for a good reason here at Kasa.  The mango lassis have a delightful touch of cardamom.    

I really like the modern design of the interiors.  It's not your mom and pop's Indian restaurant -- and the decor suggests something different, something cutting edge.  Beautiful photographs bring color and life to an otherwise crisp setting, making it an inviting place for lunch and dinner.
author: Caricia C.

description: A decent selection of food that is tasty and served quickly.  A nice and decently priced alternative to the other counter service restaurants in the Castro.
author: Travis H.

description:
I didn't have a very good experience here at all.
The food wasn't terrible, but it wasn't anything I'd pay for again.
The people preparing the food were definitely half the problem. I already knew what I wanted when I stepped up to order, but still had a question or two, and they gave me some serious attitude. They didn't explain anything and rushed me through the process. I wouldn't have cared if it was busy, but it was empty and no one was in line behind me.
Go figure. 
Like I said, food was alright. I tried as much variety as I could and all of it was very spicy. I love spicy food though, so this didn't bug me. 
Regardless, I won't be going back.
author: Hope D.

description:
Addiction (n.): Kati rolls 

Kasa is one of those places where you go for lunch and then want to go again for dinner.  Yes, it is that great and that affordable!  Savory classic Indian dishes wrapped up in a roti---so divine!  So addicted.

Enough said---5-stars.  If you want details from an addict, read on:

Favorites
Karahi Paneer!!!  The turkey kabob and chicken tikka masala are tied for second.  Sorry I just can't choose.  If I could eat three at a time, I would.  Two is more than enough for me, but I plan to soon work my way up to eating three (as any good addict would).

Portions
One: $5.50, for a snack or light meal.
Two: $8.95. more than enough for anyone with a normal appetite.  
Three: $11.95, if you haven't eaten all day or simply have a large appetite.
Thali: $10.95, I haven't tried one, but I have had the rice and daal on the side (just ask!) and both are as good as it gets.  The daal is so savory; the rice fragrant.

To go
To bring my addiction home, I recently picked up two kati rolls to go (chicken tikka masala and the turkey kabob).  The roti was substantial enough to make the journey from Kasa to mi casa without getting the least bit soggy.  I had to know if they would make it home to me okay, and I was skeptical, but overjoyed that it worked out!  Each roll gets wrapped in foil, like a taqueria burrito, and the thick and creamy raita and fresh side salad are packed up in separate to-go containers.

Overall
