As an addict, I've tried everything on the menu and all of the regular six choices, plus specials are to-die-for-delicious!  The super fresh side salad started off a little too "plain" for me, BUT, the sous chef came out to ask about the food--maybe since I'm there constantly (?!)---so I shared my opinion on the salad and about two weeks later IMO it was improved . . . they are looking for and listening to customer feedback for sure!

Feedback on Feedback
Those who write about the food being bland or not spicy enough must have *dead* taste buds because the spice level is PERFECTION, from the curry, to the fresh-buttery (not oily!) roti, to the daal, nothing here is bland!  Kati rolls should also not be compared to burritos in terms of quantity/size because kati's are filled with the main dish plus just the right amount of chutney and red onions, not with the big fillers of rice & beans.  Plus, they taste 1000x better than a burrito.

5-stars
Fresh, quality, amazing food.  Great concept.  Affordable, great value.  Wine and beer on tap, Indian drinks, includ'g chai.  CLEAN + design-conscious place to eat in the Castro (but not pretentious or trying too hard).  Friendly, helpful customer service that doesn't cost an arm and a leg!

Finally . . .
Great place for groups (sit at communal table or at tables w/benches).  Everyone orders and pays separately so no dealing with splitting the check.  Or go alone and people watch at the window facing counter while you devour your newest food addiction . . . AND last but not least, it's kid friendly if your kid is awesome enough to like Indian food!  

Can't think of a better addition to 18th Street!!!
author: TC C.

description:
Absolutely, yummmyyy!! Very nice food, less options to choose from but whatever served tastes delicious and healthy. Never felt heavy on my stomach. Wish they had more outlets. I also tried their food truck and they had the same amazing stuff. Their service is quick and they are very friendly. They have never failed me in the past 1 and1/2 years.

Any yes don't forget to try out their chai very flavorful. Love you Kasa!
author: Vinni T.

description: I discovered Kati rolls at Vik's and read there was a place in the Castro that specialized in them. Finally figured out where it was and it turns out I'd walked by it several times already. Well it was delicious! I had the lamb curry. It had big chunks of lamb rolled in a roti bread like a burrito. The roll itself was sort of small but I wasn't too hungry. I think you're supposed to order more than one. It'd be 5 star if it wasn't so tiny. Anyway, this is a food trend I'd love to see more of.
author: E. M.

description:
I love the food here..

Home-made, yummy and a very pleasant crew! - 5 stars!
author: Vivek S.

description:
FINALLY! An Indian joint that won't kill me with cinnamon!!

I am deathly allergic to the stuff, so the idea of most Indian, Moroccan or dessert foods is something that I don't often do because, well, I kinda like my life and want to enjoy it a bit longer.

So imagine my glee and delighted surprise when I actually found a spot that had only one item on the menu that I couldn't eat! Sweeet! I tried one of their 3 item combos and loved the "tofu" dish and raved to my friend how amazing this "tofu" tasted. Well, duh, seems it wasn't actually tofu but instead cheese, so yeah, no wonder I loved it.

The food definitely has a hefty kick for this spice-fearing chicky, but it was really good and if you order one of their yummy beers or amazingly deelish white wines, you will be set. I say "amazingly" because i hate sweet wines, but paired with the food, it made for a dyn-O-mite combo!

Definitely put this place on your list. It's reasonably priced, the owners are really awesome and the location is grand.
author: Stephy S.

description:
Well I can happily say that my last trip to Kasa was a success! Food was great as usual - actually better than usual - sometimes it can be a bit greasy, but it was perfect this time around - mmm!

Service was much better too - no more fighting! And I actually think the people working there were HELPING each other this time - what a diff'rence a day makes, you know what I'm sayin'? A great place to stop for some good, hearty eats in the Castro!
author: Nick R.

description:
I love the simplicity of this restaurant. The food is really fresh and the various sauces/sides provided add interesting textures and flavors.

The menu is very straightforward, which I appreciate because you can taste that the food has not been sitting around for hours. It will become a mainstay of my infrequent dining out.
author: Taisha R.

description:
Yeah,  the stereotype is that gay men have impecabble taste in everything but you certainly would not know that from the pathetic choice of food available in the Castro. Sure, you can teach straight girls how to give better blowjobs or you can teach straight men how to not dress like hobos but the food in this neighborhood is just not good. 

Because of this, I give Kasa a pretty generous 4 stars. The food was good and I love the concept. Sandwiches and Indian food are two of my favorite things and combining them is a wonderful idea. However, I hate overly designy modern looking spaces like this and I thought the flavors needed a little work. But, given my penchant for Castro drink specials and Dolores Park outings, I know I'll be back here.
author: Maria D.

description:
Indian street food in a cool modern taqueria-like eatery. The husband and wife team behind Kasa offers up a simple menu that consists of their favorite dishes inspired by the wife's (who's the chef here) aunts' recipes. 
 
You can select your items a la carte as a Thali plate with basmati rice, daal and raita or wrapped up in kati rolls (which are like Indian burritos) made with homemade buttery roti bread. The chicken tikka masala, aloo jeera and karahi paneer are my favorites. The food definitely tastes homemade and isn't greasy at all.

Make sure you pair your food up with a Tripel K, Thums Up (Indian Coca Cola), wine or mango juice. So refreshing!

If I lived in the area, I'd probably be coming to Kasa more than cooking in my own casa!
author: Connie C.

description:
Remember that old acronym, KISS - Keep It Simple Stupid?  It is rather crude phrase to describe an elegant principle - the elimination of that which is unnecessarily complex.

Kasa, the new casual Indian cafe in the Castro, exemplifies this principle, from its open, pared down surroundings (consisting of 2 tops, 4 tops, a counter and a community table), streamlined menu, great prices, and simple, fresh, high-quality ingredients.  I've been here twice now, and was very pleased both times.

Service is immediate - you go up to the counter and get in line, and select from the menu of 6 staple dishes or one of the specials, which they prepare for you cafeteria style.  You can order them either as a Kati Roll with a salad, and raita, or as a Thali, their self-named "deconstructed" roll which comes with daal, rice, a salad and raita.   The Kati is the cheaper, more lunch-like way to go ($5.50 for 1, $8.95 for 2), whereas the Thali ($10.95) is more like a meal.  

I've had the Lamb Curry, the Chicken Tikka Masala, and the Karahi Paneer - all delicious.  The meat is free-range, so you can feel good about that.   There are reasons to love both preparations - the delicious roti used for the Kati, or the creamy daal that comes with the Thali.

Drinks range from beer and wine to sodas to chai.  I like the Mango soda the best.

One last great sign that good things are happening here?  The folks at Kasa listen to their customer comments.  Soon after opening, they were inundated with requests for vegan options, and now offer them daily.  If you are vegan, make sure you ask for fresh roti, which they will make for you without butter.

The owners and staff are super-cool - say hi and let them know what you think.  Personally, I wish SF had more restaurants like this - it reminds me of places that I have been to in London, which offer great food at a great price, nice enough to sit down and have a leisurely meal, but equally accommodating if you have to eat and run.

Today's thought:  lunch at Kasa - wonderful.  Lunch with Laura B. smiling all the way through it - sublime.  Now that's a great KISS if I ever saw one.
author: Liz S.

description:
Ok, so I'm bumping this up to 4 stars because the owner is seriously like the NICEST MAN EVER.  Like I bet he gives up his seat for old ladies on the train and volunteers at a homeless shelter and adopts abused puppies and stuff.

I say this because he was passing out free Roti wraps at the movie at the park last week and I was lucky enough to partake in this delicious freeness.  Yum.

And I continue to crave this place and want to go back soon so perhaps it's better than I originally gave it credit for.  Still wouldn't mind this place being a bit cheaper though...
author: Evan L.

description:
The gay look, the LA look, call it what you will--minimalist white interiors seem to be the order of the day in these parts, and as Maria D points out, the Castro is simply not a serious player in this town's hyper-competitive food scene (I guess the boys just gotta stay thin or something).  So if you want good eats around here, you don't have a whole lot of choice.

Anyway, love it or hate it, you gotta admit the menu at Kasa matches the design--there's a whopping 6 dishes on it, each of which can be served as a traditional plate or as a "Kati" roll--basically the kind of Indian burrito (or bur-roti?) that I've been jury-rigging out of naan & curries for years (really, *is* there anything better?).  At 3 for $11.95, this is probably your best deal price-wise.  And I have to say, not only are they well-constructed (leakage/collapse was minimal), but all the fillings (CTM, lamb, and kahari paneer) were loaded with flavor.  And whatever you do, don't forget their darkly sweet, deeply spicy homemade chai, which I think it's safe to say handily beats out N&C's (admittedly free) brew.

Is this "authentic" Indian food?  I don't think so.  But just approach it with a fresh and open mind and it stands on its own merits (it's like the Harry Potter movies--the more you forget the books, the better they get).
author: Wes M.

description: Very simple menu. Great selections all around. Everything was yummy. I had turkey meatballs and chicken masala. Enjoyed this little place and all the food I tried.
author: Kurt W.

description:
The Mission burrito is a longtime love that continues to please me, but Kasa is new and interesting, and dare I say... enchanting?  

I met both of the owners, and they have put a lot of work into this place.  The space is light and airy and very inviting (sure, the taquerias may be cheaper, but you don't even want to wear your shoes into your house after you've been in El Farolito).  All of the ingredients are fresh each day, nothing is frozen.  And it shows.  The food was delicious!  I noticed a lot of complaints about the small portions in the other reviews:  I ordered two rolls and then thought to myself that I should have ordered more.  However, after I was finished, I felt incredibly full.  The spice deceives, my friends.  All in all, Kasa is very tasty and once the owners work out some of the kinks (e.g., slow service), I would bump it up to five stars.

Also, Bi-Rite Creamery is on the way home (at least for me).  Yum!
author: Alissa K.

description:
Kasa continues to make customers in its restaurant wait 5-10 minutes to order food while it processes take-out orders. The line for service literally grinds to a halt and 8-10 have to stand and wait while Kasa makes even more money off its delivery service. This is rude customer service!

__________________________________________________________

Once again I waited 5 minutes to get to the front of line and was told that I would have to wait longer because a "big delivery order" just came in.  I had to stand there for another 8 minutes while the server made 8 take-out rotis and the queue grew larger.  Please, Kasa, if you want to run a take out business, do it out of a separation area, and don't inconvenience customers that have walked to your restaurant and expect to be served promptly.
author: Tom W.

description:
"Indian Chipotle" is probably the best way to describe this new Castro joint. The simple menu is clearly laid out, and it's completely idiot-proof, as far as I'm concerned. I hope the good people at Kasa haven't found otherwise.

The assembly line is quick, quiet and friendly. I ordered a thali plate (roti, chicken tikka masala, daal, rice and raita). Roti was just like my aunties make it, and that was a happy-maker indeed. The plate was filling, but not too much so. My friend who ordered three kati rolls, however, might disagree with the not-overly-filling part, though.

It's not, however, Chipotle-cheap - a thali plate is $11, so it's pricey-ish for a quick dinner, and definitely for lunch. Seeing as how you won't necessarily leave full, you almost have to go to Bi-Rite Creamery down the street, right?

A friend ordered a cola drink called "Thums Up" (no b, that's correct, copy editors), and I downed a Maasa (bottled mango drink) with my meal. I've never seen these in any local restos except Vik's in Berkeley, so points for that.

The space could use a feng shui fix, not to get all that way about it. The line (long, these days) blocks the bathroom and much of the maneuvering space in the eating area. Food was good and it fills a niche. I'll definitely go back.
author: Tara R.

description:
Dear Kasa:

Your food is fresh and tasty beyond belief! PLEASE open up a branch on King St in SOMA! There are so many vacant spots...it would be a hit here!

Anyone considering - go!
author: Mona T.

description:
I have to admit, eating an indian burrito at first really didn't appeal to me on any level. Tikka Masala....in a BURRITO!? The concept seemed to have eluded me until I went yesterday for lunch, and you know what, 

ITS GOOD. 

REAL GOOD. 

I tried the tikka masala (best seller), and the aloo jeera  - no, not the wierd news organization in the Middle East but a burrito like thing filled with spiced potatoes and cumin and tomatoes.  Whatever they roll this stuff in is seriously good too...kinda like a spiced up flour tortilla. 

Good find, good eats.
author: Morgan H.

description: Good place - the bread is interesting - a little uncooked texture and taste wise but ok.  The chicken and potatoes are the bomb though.  I would go back again.  Probably more of a 3.5 stars.
author: brittany g.

description:
relatively (er..you are NOT in India..so..!) authentic home cooked North Indian fare.

limited choices but then wouldn't you prefer quality over quantity?

In a nutshell, nothing extraordinary, but at times that's just what you need, something dependable and comforting!
author: P G.

description:
Simple.
Spicy.
Special.

You may remember this spot as belonging to a dusty burrito shop, but those days are over.  Kasa is a spic-n-span little bistro with a small, carefully considered menu.  It's like going somewhere and having expert friends hand-pick the best items on the menu just for you.

You can choose your item(s) to be wrapped up in a tidy "kati" roll, or have them all splayed out on a plate (I picked the latter).  I don't remember the name of that Belgian beer, but it was super.  I was leery of trying the paneer because I'm not a fan of cooked peppers, but it was really good.  The curried taters were delightful.  Our table even went back for a second helping of dal -- when does that ever happen?

The folks here were friendly and made us feel right at home.  The food was fresh (they make it daily from scratch!), and the flavors were bold and interesting.  Please open up a Kasa near my work?  Please?
author: Andi T.

description:
Love that Kasa's tiny but rich menu ventures outside the-eight-or-nine-things-you-find-on-every-freaking-Indian-Restaurant-Menu. Hey, they even stock 'Tums Up' and Limca, bottled-beverages-of-choice from Mumbai to Delhi to Chennai! What a great addition to the Bay Area's growing list of choices in the area of Indian food.

I'm sure the owners  won't appreciate this suggestion, but my GF and I find that sharing a single Thali is always more than enough food. But that only means we can afford to come back more often! 

They clearly know this, given the foam batting that has been installed under the tables, but further work needs to be done to dampen the echo. I recommend hanging tapestries or using noise canceling speakers. The acoustics are almost too much to allow for reasonable conversation. Also I'd like to encourage them to take even more chances with their slightly non-traditional menu and take even bolder steps in their stated mission to bring 'home cooking' and recipes to guests. Major kudos on the cilantro chutney paste. AWESOME. Lastly... please stop cooking your green peppers into oblivion!
author: Michael H.

description: I visited this place 1st time with friends. Its nice,small with good food and great staff. I enjoyed their Kathi rolls which are one of the best in entire Bay area. The thali was OK. Overall good experience. Will definitely visit them just because of their rolls.
author: Sumit S.

description:
This place is a stone's throw from my apartment, and on one of those many worn-out workdays,  Kasa is a welcomed sight and smell from home. This space used to be a mom and pop's taqueria where I would occasionally get burritos, so when I heard I could get healthier kati rolls - similar to the burrito, but smaller - at Kasa, I was sold. 

For some reason, with everything compartmentalized in the thali, I didn't think it looked like that much food the first time I ordered it. Three-quarters in and a full belly later, I realized just how much you actually get for your money. My boyfriend and I like to get 2 or 3 kati rolls with different fillings and share :). Decent prices, fresh food, and semi-late hours make this place a winner.
author: Kat E.

description:
Wow - how long have we been waiting with baited breath for the opening of this place?. A sleek new Indian joint in the Castro - just a couple of blocks from my home! Naturally, I had to try it on opening night.

Mmmm...I can't stop drooling, but... it's wasn't all peaches and cream. So, in the interests of giving the owners a leg up, here is a fair-and-unbiased take on opening night at the Kasa.

***First the good...

- The food excellent - fresh, light, spicy... Indian!

- The beer - go for the Belgian Ale - yummy and cold.

- The people were friendly and helpful.

***And the things-I-sure-hope-hope-they-improve...

- The prices are a little steep - portions are available in various sizes, but I mean, for 10 bucks I can get literally twice as much food from a tacqueria! And there are plenty of those around to be sure.

- Rather stingy on the mango chutney.

- Best dish might have been the dahl, which came only with the tahli and not with the roti. How about offering a side of dahl for a buck or two?

- White rice only? How about a brown rice option? 

- They better get those first-night logistics figured out - no way am I going to stand in line for MORE THAN AN HOUR again. I just won't. No matter how good it tastes. 

***They get three stars for now - I hope I can upgrade them soon. I hope they can straighten these things out and I can make this a regular alternative to the pizza-burger-burrito fast food alternatives in the neighborhood. I really do.





(On another note - how about those ringers' reviews? Have you ever seen so many zero-friends-one-review-five-star write-ups? 
C'mon, Yelp! Inc, do something. Real people, real reviews? I think not! That alone leaves a bad taste in my mouth.)
author: Kingpin X.

description:
Kasa is a wonderful addition to the Castro area.  The food here is simple but unique, authentic, and more importantly, out-of-this-world good!  

its menu is conceptually different than most Indian restaurants. You order in one of two methods: the Khathi or the Thali.  You can pick any of the curries to go with either and both come with delicious roti bread...it's softer and yummier than naan (if you can believe it!).

The Khathi resembles a little burrito with the roti wrapped around your favorite meat or veggie curry, and the Thali is a "deconstructed" version with the roti, rice, dal, and curry separate.  Everything is made from scratch -- how do I know that?  The kitchen is open for public purview, which I love, and you can watch your food being made.  The meat is free range and the wine/beer list is small, but quality.  The owners and staff are all very friendly and happy to provide more info about the dishes.  My friends and I loved everything we tried.

Summary: everything here is good!
author: Sid D.

description: Good food with limited options. This place isn't like "food-walmart", but I have been here twice and both times it hits the spot. Finding a parking is like a challenge since its like in a neighborhood with NO parking garages but lots of neighborhood businesses. For the price, you can find a buffet, but whatever. Food is good. it's like Indian In-n-Out!
author: Prateek G.

description:
This place serves basic Indian food for cheap.  I wouldn't write home about the food, but when you're hungry and looking for a lot of food for a reasonable price, the thalis are perfect.  The food itself is pretty solid, with plenty of good vegetarian options.  I tried the gobi aloo (is this reversed?  that's the order they wrote it), which was a daily special, and the karahi paneer which was fantastic.  My girlfriend claimed the dhal was spicy, but I couldn't taste it.  I wish I had tried the Kati Roll, that looked pretty awesome.  I think I'll end up coming here a lot because I live right near it and it's pretty simple and cheap food, but I don't think I'd choose it if I were getting a group of friends together for dinner.

Oh, and the chai seemed a bit watered down.  I really miss the rich creamy chai I had back in India.  Kasa's chai didn't compare at all.
author: William C.

description:
So as a real-life Indian person I feel like my review is worth more than everyone else's. Interestingly enough, I can come up with logic like this on more than one occasion, why my opinion is more important. But I digress. 

I called up my friend and asked her if she was game to try out this new Indian joint, Kasa. She was very scared because of all the Indian restaurants in the Bay Area I think I have only given the Radha stamp of approval to one, and in a very limited arena. 

Anyways, we show up and the line is about 5 people deep. Walking in, the place was clean (always a surprise at an Indian restaurant) and you can see the people cooking up the food (I like this so I know there aren't any dirty people touching my food, ya I know let me live in denial). The idea seems simple enough but it takes us a good 10 mins to actually get to the front and order (remember there are only 5 people in front of us). 

So I order 2 rolls, the chicken tikka masala and the lamb curry roll. I find out that the lamb is currently being cooked, but it will be ready in 20 mins. Now I'm happy that the food is being made fresh, but am wondering why it's going to take 20 mins in a taqueria-like place to get my food. Oh well, I decide just to get two chicken tikka masala rolls.

So here's the break down of why they get 4 stars:

1 - food, a little spicy, fresh, and on the more authentic side of Indian food
1 - cleaniness and somewhere I wouldn't mind hanging out for a while
1 - polite staff
1 - what the hell, I really needed some Indian food

Why the minus one star? 1/2 because of the slow service, and another 1/2 because the lamb wasn't ready :(

I'm definitely coming back...be ready!
author: Radha S.

description: This place is trying to be a hipper version of the Kati Roll Company in NYC. The paratha is made w/ wheat flour, which they say differentiates them from the NY location. Honestly, the woman who made the rolls had 'tude. The saag paneer was really good - the paneer was fresh/homemade. The chicken tikka masala had a kick. My friend got a little ill, so I have to downgrade to a 3. I likey but don't lovey.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Like Indian food?  Like taquerias?  Then you've got to try the first (that I've seen) miraculous marriage of the two.
The menu is utterly basic - they make 6 things: chicken tikka, chicken tikka masala, lamb curry, turkey kebabs, cumin potatoes, and karani paneer (cheese, spices & onions - fantastic!  seriously, best version of this I've ever had.).  Once you've figured out what you want, you can either get it wrapped in roti like mini Indian burritos, or on a plate which also has rice & daal in a "deconstructed" version.

The food is fantastic - rich, flavorful, VERY fresh, and wonderfully tender (especially the lamb, which is described as "saucy").  You should also be aware that most of it is pretty spicy; I think it's awesome, but if you're a spice wuss you should be nervous).
You also have a choice of spicy chutney or minty sauce on your rotis.  (Hint: the chutney goes REALLY well with the lamb.)  Even better, unlike a lot of cheap Indian food, you'll never get the nasty ghee oil-slick.  This is fresh and healthy stuff!

They've got Kingfisher and a fantastic light, crisp Belgian beer on tap (I forget the name), and some tasty wine as well including a very dry German Riesling which goes very well with the spicy food.

The space is plain, basic, and pretty noisy - it feels like a taqueria.  But it's good, and reasonably priced, and you can get it to go if it's too loud.
author: Don H.

description: This is a solid deli, offering a cool hybrid:  essentially buritos filled with Indian standards like chicken Tika Misala or Gobi Aloo.  At least I think that's the spelling.  Anyway, it's cool.  It's your favorite Indian done deli style.  It's cheap.  Nothing more, but, hey, nothing less.  It's clean!  It's four stars for the genre.  Zero for ambiance.  One star for white wine from Germany/ Austria.  And three stars for good solid food
author: Patrick B.

description:
I know I'm gonna get negative remarks after my review but hey its just my opinion! 

I have been to Kasa Indian Eatery thrice and they still disappoint me. I consider this place as OVERLY Americanized Indian food. Its nowhere near authentic Indian food. Most of the food lacks a lot of spices and they don't serve naan!? WTF?! where is my damn NAAN!!!! I have gone to a lot of Indian restaurants because i love Indian food and i swear to the food gods this place BLOWS! On the the plus side they serve Indian beer!?
author: Lucky M.

description:
Ooh! Lately SF has been experiencing a wave of "qualityification" of cheap eats. Think Delfina Pizzeria vs. greasebomb by-the-slice joints, or Little Chihuahua vs. artery-clogging tacquerias. And now Kasa's doing it to Indian.

People seem naturally attracted to the Kati mini-wraps, but I'm a fan of the traditional Thali plates. Maybe I'm just used to eating that way, but I find the combination of rice, delicious(!!) black dal, and more entree / less buttery roti to be more balanced than the roti-heavy wraps. It's even served authentic-style on a tin plate.

It's all literally prepared in front of your eyes and you can see the quality. I'm not usually a fan of chicken tikka masala but this one is great -- very tomatoey and not too much cream. My favorite is the spicy aloo! Also tried a great off-menu cauliflower dish. Hope they put that on the board soon.

It's funny to hear people complain about authenticity.. basing their comparison on the greasy cheap joints. Same problem with tacquerias and pizzas. You just have so much of that crap that you come to expect it and fear change. You reach a point where you won't even touch a "Vietnamese sandwich" that costs more than $3. You're just missing out at that point. We did find the lamb to be a little under-spiced (could've been an early-days fluke) but everything else was great.

The icing on the cake was the Belgian beer on draft.. Triple Karmeliet. This is a fantastic beer and highly complimentary.

In an aloo-to-aloo comparison with other dhaba-style joints, Kasa definitely wins my heart with its focus on quality over quantity. If you take it easy on the roti you can eat a healthy and satisfying quick meal on the regular here.
author: Tom L.

description: Favorite Indian in the Castro, if not the city. My go-to place for delivery too. Super fast and super happy after. Love, love, LOVE kasa.
author: Michael A.

description:
OK, so the food is pretty good. Delicious, non-greasy, somewhat less spicy than I like, but still. They are friendly, the mango lassi is great. So why only 3 stars?
1. Pricey! Damn. For $10.95+various taxes, this is expensive - and it's not even a buffet, just single servings. On top of that they can't tell me why the total is always higher than what it would be with regular tax... I have asked multiple times and the answer is 'you are the first person to ask me that'.  Really? If it's health tax, they should call it out like everyone else does.
2. Slow! Look, I am no expert but anyone can see their 'assembly line' is darn inefficient especially when there's a crowd waiting. Maybe it's deliberate to help the kitchen cope, or maybe that's their style...but it's annoying to wait in line when you see 2 people wringing their hands behind the counter waiting for the 1st guy/gal to get their task done.
Will I go there again? Yes. Frequently? No, only when I have extra time to spare...
author: What's in a nam e.

description:
Plop, plop, fizz, fizz.  Oh what a relief it is!  

For those of a certain vintage like me, you'll recognize the Alka Seltzer refrain.  After eating at Kasa, that's what I needed.  Not that the food was bad, it wasn't.   It mostly didn't agree with me.  My friend who had dinner with me greatly enjoyed the food.  The woman serving the dishes was friendly and helpful when I asked for a vegetarian dish only.  

Drinking beer with my entree was helpful to cut some of the heat of the cauliflower and potato dish and daal.  

Would I come back?  Maybe, maybe not.  Perhaps to try a kati roll with the karahi paneer (Indian cheese with green peppers, marinated onions and chutney.)
author: Scott S.

description: Food is tasty, though seems a *bit* overpriced.  Still, I've been here several times and would most likely go again if I happened to be in the mood for easy takeout.  Store is open plan, industrial hip. Service is (usually) friendly, but I've also heard otherwise from friends.  So I guess like in most cases, it depends on how you feel when you go in there.
author: Cando V.

description:
Okay, I am a confessed Indian food snob.  And this place rocks!   
Everything is made from scratch daily and the owners have done a knock out job using only fresh ingredients.  Bonus points also for using free range chicken. (I am a picky meat eater so this makes me happy)

I tried almost everything.  (the menu is not that extensive, eight dishes all done well) I had the Thalis with Karani Paneer and it was perfect.  The kati roll was buttery with the perfect density and the Paneer wasn't overdone with too many spices to hide the cheese flavor. The Masala was done right, not overly processed, or too many flavors so that you can't distinct the spices.

The seating is casual and more of a on the go vs. sit down for an hour place.  It is a perfect spot to grab a quick bite and a beer before heading out at night or to head home.
author: mika m.

description: Drooooooool. Why are kati rolls not all the rage and sweeping the nation? So freaking tasty!
author: Jake W.

description:
Order: Kati Rolls. You can order the curry-filled roti wraps in orders of 1, 2 or 3. You can also order these "deconstructed" which just come on a plate instead of wrapped (which I feel defeats the novelty of the burrito styled wrap, but that's just me). Also snag one of their bottled mango drinks. I don't usually indulge in juice (waste of cals and I prefer chewing things) but this mango juice is really amazing. I would come here just to buy the juice, really. If anyone knows where I could buy this without also being tempted to eat curry filled creations, please let me know.

Personal Notes: Beware of the whole chile peppers sometimes left inside your curry. You're not supposed to eat these suckers but it can sometimes be unavoidable. Last time I was there I accidentally chewed and swallowed an entire pepper not realizing it for a solid 15 seconds before I burst into tears and ran to the bathroom to eat paper towels from the dispenser. So consider yourself warned.

Also, if you have a real hankering for Indian food, don't come here. This is definitely a yuppified version of the real thing. Still very tasty. Very simple, very healthy. But nothing like a a delicious slimy, greasy curry from Naan n' Chutney. Kasa only serves good, clean fun.
author: Rachel L.

description:
I went to this restaurant with my sister and brother-in-law the week it opened. We were the only Indian people there. Everyone in the restaurant hovered around our table and asked us if we liked the food. Hella annoying.

First of all, they should not be allowed to call themselves an "Indian Eatery" the food is not really Indian at all. It is more like tacos with some masala. The authenticity is a bit zilch. Although that is not what they are going for, it doesn't even really taste that good.

At least they had some sodas (Thums Up, Limca, and Mango Maaza) straight from the motherland. They also had Kingfisher on tap which pretty much rocked my world. I would not go again even though they have cool pictures on the wall.
author: Shyla B.

description:
Kasa is weird, very weird. The cucumber yogurt they give you with your "Indian burrito" isn't tasty at all and the way the food is served/prepared takes all the fun out of eating Indian food!

Step 1: Take naan in hand.
Step 2: Load up naan with as many dishes as you can (i.e. tikki masala, rice, etc.)
Step 3: Bite, while strategically holding the naan as to not lose everything off of it.
Step 4: Enjoy and be proud of your eating accomplishment.

See? What fun it is to eat Indian food. Oh no, not at Kasa, though. They like to shove all the goodness in a piece of naan and fold it like a burrito as if Little India has become Little Mexico.

No, thank you.
author: Brock H.

description:
I waited nine years (count 'em, nine!) for alternative to Bombay Indian Restaurant in our neighborhood. The Castro needed more Indian dishes badly, and as the 'hood started to buckle again under yet another economic lag, restaurants started to fold. One that kicked the can was La Castro Tacqueria. A few months later, a nifty idea rose from its dust and ashes, and named itself... Kasa!  

I was right there on their opening night, and Anamika and Tim offered quite a delight. Of course, it's not authentic Indian food, nor could you place the recipes in any particular region in India.  But who gives a flying frak. The food tastes good, and I am relieved, because I really didn't want to watch them fire up then shut down six months later (which seems to be happening a lot around here).  Unfortunately, the prices are steering towards unaffordable, not because of the actual prices, but because we're in a recession, for Christ's sake.

The staples here are the Kati rolls, unto which you choose a meat or vegetable stuffing. They're a bit heavy and butter-laden, but admittedly one order will fill you up just right. Specific kati hits include the lamb and curry, or the chicken tikka masala, which are both truisms in any Indian shanty.  If you don't know what to try, just ask the lovely lady with a British accent.

If you want to go easy on the buttery bread, then order the Thalis version of your dinner, which is what they refer to as a "deconstructed kati". Deconstructionism right here in the Castro. How sublime (and appropriate).  

Now, it's time to throw plenty of good energy at this place. If there is any way to help keep these people afloat, I will oblige. It would be just swell to have Kasa as a permanent fixture on 18th Street.
author: Daniel C.

description:
A great little casual place with good food, nice beer and they are mellow about letting you take your time after they close. It's great to stop in for food here if you don't want a lot of formality and you don't want a burrito or a burger. The Kati rolls are delicious. 

My only complaint is that some of their silverware is bent, but I threw away the bent fork I got so you won't have to.
author: A R.

description: I love the whole street food concept, and when my Indian friend tells me that this is what he eats, I'm sold. Two kati rolls are a perfect sized meal. Love that I can get two types of fillings since I can eat two and I cant resist the yogurt sauce that comes with it. And they deliver! This place was high on my list when I wasn't eating meat, and is still up there on the list now that I'm eating meat again!
author: Christine L.

description:
My friend described this as an indian burrito joint. "Imagine your favorite indian food in a burrito"  I have to say, I met this friend in India and while I 'got it', the description didn't even begin to describe the place.

The first review I read said, 'this is the kind of place you go for lunch and want to go for dinner.'  My comment after crushing a Thali, which is no small dish, was to say "I want to order another one."

It was amazing, the spices, the flavors, daal, rice, everything mixed together.  

As to the spiciness, i sweated through the last half of the meal.

Love this place, so authentic, the large tin they serve the meal on.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Roque V.

description:
Great find! My friend told me about Kasa yesterday and I checked it out tonight (I don't waste any time when someone gives me a hot tip!) 

What they serve are like little Indian burritos! The menu is definitely simple, with 6 choices for the filling plus one special per day (of which one of the employees informed me is always vegetarian) Out of the 6 mainstays, though, 4 are meat-based and 2 are vegetarian. 

Then you can chose how many you want: 1 for $5.50, 2 for $8.95, and 3 for $11.95. All are served with a side of raita, which was delish, and a cucumber/pepper/carrot salad (the only thing that didn't really knock me out). Their pricing system is just perfect for me, because I can order just one if I'm alone, or get two or three and share with someone else, all of which make for very affordable meals.

The roti itself was fantastic! The food, on the whole, tasted very home-made and clean, with just the right amount of seasonings and oils (in other words, this is not gut-bomb style Indian food with super heavy, creamy sauces, like paneer tika masala, and this is quite nice, for a change). They also serve beer and wine. Will definitely be back soon!
author: Shannon R.

description: bad bad, this place needs to be reorganized. we never know qhen we will have a better service.
author: B H.

description:
STOP THE FUCKING PRESS.

I thought a glowing, 5-star review of a restaurant in the Castro would have come along after hell had frozen over. But this great-idea-of-a-restaurant has proven me dead wrong. And from the looks of its patrons, it may just become the Castro's first "destination" restaurant. 

Kasa gets it right by capitalizing on the awesome flavors n' spices you love about Indian food, and revamping the annoying things about most Indian joints: musty surroundings, low-quality greasy ingredients and dubious kitchen. Kasa gutted that old taqueria and streamlined it  to make way for a clean, portable, fast and friendly experience. 

The roti rolls are absolutely DELICIOUS. From afar they look ordinary. Look closer, my friend. Flaky and hearty, and just the right thickness, they're the perfect foil for the SPICY-ASS (really) chicken tikka masala or garlicky ground pork with marinated onions and cilantro. Ditto for the deconstructed platters with roasted daal.  And get this. Their yogurt doesn't suck. It's thick n' creamy, not watery. Yes, I'm talking about the yogurt. Dirty minds! 

Of course, this place just HAD to open the month after I moved out of the Castro... but I'm not holding anything against Kasa. Hallelujah, Hallelujah, there's finally something edible in the Castro!
author: BroSauce J.

description:
so i wrote a lengthy review praising the Kasa in the Marina, but now that it's closed, I have to get my fill of Indian burritos in the castro, which is fine by me.  

I love the concept.  I love the kati rolls, the green herb paste they spread on them, and obviously the fillings.  Even the yogurt sauce for dipping is a perfect accompaniment.  I typically get the chicken tikka masala, lamb curry, and if I'm hungry enough I'll go for the turkey.  I think my favorite is the lamb, though the chicken is a close second.  

I wish there was a Kasa closer to work because I'd grab lunch there all the time.  I never order the plate meals because the kati rolls are what I come here for.  The only thing I could think of to make this place better would be to expand the filling options, but there are already enough flavors I cover the basics of everything, so I can't really complain.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
Having lived in Southern India I can assure you the food at Kasa, at least as far as the dishes on which it is served, is quite authentic.  The flavors are good, the naan and daal are also quite delicious, although the daal could use a touch more ghee.  As far as being "authentic" I've got news for you kiddies - it ain't, but it IS good and that goes much further than rest-stop (which is where this type of food is usually served in India) authenticity in my book.

I like Kasa and all the "Oh I'm down with the third world and especially this AUTHENTIC Indian rest-stop food" Castro-ites who self-righteously snack away here - they make me feel superior in a "Muthafuckah I've actually lived in India" sorta way.

UPDATE - Gotta take the stars down to three. The morning after eating here I shit so hard I damned near sprained my asshole. Tone down that spicy curry man!!!!
author: Shane H.

description:
I was excited to try this place after reading about it on thrillist sf. I hadn't yet seen the yelp reviews, but my roommate and I were hungry - delivery indian food typically hits the spot after a less than interesting monday. plus, our go-to indian restaurant was beginning to see our ordering pattern whenever we called.

First time to Kasa, roommate got the chicken tikka masala, and I ordered the lamb curry roti roll. To get our order up to the $20 minimum delivery fee, I ordered a second roll - the cumin potato one - plus a mango lassi. 

wow, were we disappointed...
(1) the roti rolls were small and greasy. 
(2) SALTY. like really salty. please pass the water.
(3) the roti tasted more like a sub-par corn tortilla.
(4) roommate's lentils tasted like chili.

After eating, I went to yelp to see if roommate and i were alone in these sentiments; apparently we were. needless to say, we will return to our local standby eatery.

sidenote: kudos on the 45 minute prompt delivery
author: Todd H.

description:
EDIT: After posting my 2-star review of Kasa, with that low rating based on how horribly loud it is there, I heard promptly from one of the owners of the restaurant. (A first-time experience for me here on Yelp!) He was impressively non-defensive and had thoughtful responses to all of my critiques. I am heartened to find out they are completely aware of the noise problem and taking steps to rectify it. (I hope I didn't get that employee in trouble for telling me it was a low priority. I have definitely misrepresented the place I work for before - no one can know everything that's going on behind the scenes.) Good customer service is key and I am impressed with Kasa's owners. It's still a 3-star joint for me, and I don't know if I'll ever be going back myself, but I do think it is a worthwhile place to check out for yourself at least once.

I am leaving my original review, though, because everything in it (except the employee misrepresentation) is still an accurate reflection of my experience:

I hate to do this - a 2 star review for a place where the food is decent, if a bit overpriced - but after having one of the worst dining experiences in recent memory, i just have to speak my piece.

I'll say it right off - the 2-star rating is based completely on earsplitting loudness and the kind of atmosphere that made me want to bolt my food and run. If you're the type of person who doesn't care at all about noise in your dining experience, skip this section and go on to the next one, which is more of a 3-star review of the restaurant's other qualities. But for those of you who like to be able to talk to your dinner companions without screaming ("What?" "What?" "I'm sorry, what?!" "Forget it!") I would stay away from Kasa, at least at dinnertime. 

We went there last night around 8pm and the place was full. There was music on, there were people at most of the tables and counter spots. It was impossibly, indescribably loud. Kasa has cement floors and metal furniture. Every time someone pulls their chair back to sit down, or scoots their chair forward, the sound screeches sharply off the walls, ceiling, and floor (which are all hard surfaces, with no attempt at acoustical muffling) to the point where it stops conversation. Not that conversation is really possible. Everyone in the place was screaming to be heard. When I went to ask the man behind the counter if the owners were planning to do anything about the acoustics I had to shout my question several times before he understood what I was saying. (His answer: In a perfect world they might, but it's not high on the priority list.*) 

Noise aside, Kasa is a fine restaurant but not destined to become a favorite, at least for this vegetarian. I've been there twice, a couple of months apart, and both times the "specials," which double the number of veggie offerings from 2 to 4, were the same. The cumin potatoes were totally bland, and the paneer was dull. The aloo gobhi and green beans with potatoes were both tasty enough, but lacked any real brightness of seasoning or anything to really make them stand out. I remember the dal being okay the first time but last night it tasted like the liquid from a can of pinto beans.

It's nice to get a thali plate with two main dish choices and rice and chopped-veggie salad and raita and chutneys, and certainly if you ordered a serving of all those things at an a la carte Indian restaurant it would cost more than $11 (the pre-tax and tip cost), but the portions are pretty small. Definitely filling but I'd rather pay $8 to fill up or $13 and have a whole 'nother meal of leftovers. Also, an all-veggie thali costs the same price as one with meat, and that kind of bugs me. That is definitely not how meal prices are scaled at most Indian places.

I do have a couple nice things to say after all that: The chai is amazing. They seem committed to sustainable and local food, which is pretty swell, and maybe makes the price tag more justifiable. But if you are curious about Kasa, I suggest either staying away from peak dining hours, or making sure you packed your ear plugs. 

*In case you're curious, here is what the owner of Kasa had to say when he responded to this review:  "I completely agree that our space can get too loud, especially at dinner.  We try to make sure the music is turned way down at night.

It's a difficult problem for us.  We put some recording studio foam underneath all the tables to absorb some of the sound.  We've used epoxy to apply pads on feet of our chairs a few times, but they come off within a couple days each time.  If we could go back in time, we certainly wouldn't buy those chairs again.

I wouldn't say fixing the sound is a low priority (our server said that incorrectly).  We're working with it and trying a few  cost-effective things to see what makes the most impact.  We like the sparse look, but need to figure out how to achieve that with more sound dampening."
author: Scrumptious S.

description:
The food at Kasa is tasty, simple, inexpensive. It didn't blow me away, but it was definitely good and I'd certainly return for eats. I'd give 3 stars for the food.

But what I do keep returning for is their homemade CHAI (that's worthy of 5 stars). I've had my share of chai and this is among the best. It's sweet, spicy, and creamy -- you can clearly taste the ginger and cardamom -- and leaves you with a nice buzz. (I'm also convinced that crack is one of its key ingredients.)

Don't get that watery, fake chai crap at Starbucks: go for the real thing at Kasa and don't look back!
author: Alejandra K.

description:
Great concept and I liked the options-- eating lighter to a bigger meal is an easy way to order--Taqueria-style.  The food was completely fresh and this is a tall order for many Indian restaurants in San Francisco.  The small but nicely edited wine list is a plus.  I had a Belgian beer which paired perfectly with the Chicken Tikka that I ordered.  The menu and ambiance is simple and well thought out.  Some had mentioned in a review "what's up with the tin trash..." making a comparison to a prison experience.  If that person was culturally aware that stainless steel serving trays and cups is quite common in India.  I think Kasa did the right thing.  A prison meal is the furthest thing I think of when I enjoy Kasa.

I can't wait to go back to Kasa and try the large plate of ever good Indian cuisine.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
fucking fabulous!  KASA DELIVERS to so many areas!

they DELIVER!  they DELIVER!  did i mention DELIVERY!

No more zip cars!  No more thirty dollar cab rides just to eat those scrumptious wraps!!

No more diarrhea from the shit Indian restaurants  downtown!  seventh heaven -those darlings.  i love you
author: Noel J.

description:
I love this place. Like many others, I am freaking addicted to the Kati rolls and will hit Kasa about once a week. 

It's fast, friendly, filing and cheap. Sometimes that's a lot to ask for for $5 (about the cost of 1 Kati roll).

One tip: they used to serve this tasty little chopped salad alongside the Kati Roll and Raita. They no longer do by default, but you can ask them for a scoop of the salad and they'll gladly oblige. I think the salad is key and tastes great with the roll, so I always ask for it right before they've finished making my roll.
author: David P.

description:
Kasa serves among the best Kati rolls I have had and I am from India.

The good thing about the food is that it is not super oily and spicy like most other India places. It is relatively plain and simple. Feels more like Indian food made at home food. 

Service is fast and the panner kati rolls are the best. If you are starving, then go for the thaali. I only wish that they were open till much later in the night.
author: A G.

description: Maybe I'm crazy, since my friends all seemed to enjoy our stop at Kasa, but I found everything about this underwhelming. The food was bland like at the old Indian cafe on campus. The space is awkward and drafty. I wanted to like it, but I think I'm better off dining at 2223 or Lime or Osaka when in the neighborhood.
author: Sharon W.

description:
I stopped in here earlier today to grab some lunch before a visit to ImagiKnit.  I scoured Yelp beforehand searching "cheap", "open now", and "Castro".  I decided to go somewhere I hadn't been before, as a little treat for being smoke-free for two whole days now (well, one and a half... ok, less than that, if you don't include sleep-time, which I do because I'm on the patch, and I had some CRAZY dreams last night.  I seriously dreamed that I was a part of the Corleone family, and Al Pacino kept getting mad at me for gossiping to my friends about the family business.  WTF).  

Anyway.  I made the trip in the rain, and showed up drenched to the bone.  I was surly and irritable, as any new non-smoker will be, but was immediately welcomed by the staff, which reminded me to take a breath and smile back.  I ordered the one-roti plate, which was very good (I got the veg cheese dish filling - forget what it's called), although I would have appreciated another sauce or two to round it out.  The chai was sweet, warm perfection.  Exactly what I needed to warm up and cheer up.  And with a hefty tip it was still super cheap.  

Next time I'll definitely get more food, though.  One roll was great and filling, but not enough to constitute a full meal (for me anyway, maybe you're different and/or skinny), and I definitely want to try the rest of the veggie menu.

I will be back for sure.  I bet this place would be great on a nice day, as they also have tables out in front.
author: danielle p.

description:
Stopped here to recharge while touring the open studios in the Mission and Castro.

I had the Lamb curry kati roll - kind of like an Indian Burrito. It was excellent, and at $4.50, was reasonably priced. Two of them would make a pretty good meal.

The decor was nice, and service was relatively fast. I would definitely come back.
author: Dana L.

description:
There are too few restaurants that let you order and pay for the amount of food that you actually want to eat - Kasa is one of them. You could get away with paying as little as $6 for a meal, and by SF standards, that's cheap.

1 Kasi roll for $5.50, 2 for $8.95, 3 for $11.95 - all accompanied with a side of salad and cooling raita. Get the deconstructed version of the roll, the "Thalis", and you'll also get a side of slow-simmered daal and basmati rice for $10.95.

Friendly service, well-kept and clean dining area, and most importantly, delicious food. JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Very good, inexpensive Indian food. They deliver. The menu is small but every item is good and there's something for everybody. Vegetarian. Lactose intolerant. Carnivore. What's not to like?

Well...just a couple of things. First, if you want to eat at home you have to either take it out or have it delivered. Take out is nearly impossible given the location. There is zero parking in this neighborhood. That means delivery. This is a hit or miss proposition. If by chance they take a large internet order, there is a scaling problem. You're told it'll be an hour and fifteen minutes. Likely that means closer to two hours. So...it all comes down to how much you want their food. I love the food but much of the time I can't deal with the wait so I'm off to another place.

If they can solve the scaling problem their problems go away.
author: Gary C.

description:
Its about time that someone in the Bay Area started serving Kathi rolls and Kasa deserves credit for the being the first ones that I know of. The food is simple and good and they definitely get bonus points for picking grass fed lamb.  

I took a star off because I felt that they toned down the spice a bit and there wasn't an option to get achar with the Kathi rolls. Everything is quite reasonably priced - I would go for the Kathi instead of the Thali. There isn't really anything special about the Thali.
author: Abhi S.

description:
I'm proud to say I was Kasa's first customer...ever.  I anxiously waited 'til they opened at 11:00am on a Thursday and had the delight of eating their first officially served, paid-for meal.  I live right up the street and have been back numerous times but I've had interesting knowledge of seeing their food evolve as they adjust their food prep and process to accomodate "the masses."  

That first meal was amazing.  The kati rolls were MUCH smaller than they are now, and delicate, almost like a crepe.  So delicate that the balance of meat/filling to kati bread was just right.  Plus, you didn't get a "choice" of sauces to go inside.  They simply put what the chef thought should go with each filling.  The lamb was pleasantly fiery with the red sauce and the onions provided a cool, crisp counterpoint.     The yogurt raita was fresh.  The pickled vegetables were cut into perfect dices, seasoned with just the right amount of spices, composing the perfect Indian mirapoix.  

Now, I've seen the kati rolls evolve into something closer to a burrito and yet the amount of filling stayed the same.  That is to say, the kati bread became much thicker and bigger but not the inside--hence the ratio of wrap to filling is completely thrown off and it's simply too bready.  Many a times I've seen plates left on the empty tables with half eaten bread but the insides all picked out.  

In its original concept, a person could feasibly eat 3 kati rolls (it's offered on the menu but rarely ordered).  But now, there is no way anyone who knows how filling each roll is, would order 3.  My hypothesis is that rolling out the dough for the kati rolls became too labor intensive, and it became much more efficient to roll-out 1 larger dough than 3 smaller, delicate ones.  Such a shame.  

I go back there probably once a week still because all the food, ingredients, the people, the atmosphere are all still great.  I just wish I didn't have the knowledge of what Kasa was before they altered their process and food to cater to the masses and the huge lines.  I applaud them for "making it work" but secretly wish for that first meal when everything was smaller and that much more precious.
author: Tom K.

description:
It's a great place to go if you want a no-nonsense meal. The chicken tikka masala was beyond yum! I was expecting something heavy and buttery, but they totally blew me away with their light and flavorful version. The lamb curry was also another pleasant surprise as well. 

I'd highly recommend this place because it'll totally shatter any stereotypes or preconceptions you already have of Indian food!
author: Ty L.

description:
The chicken tikka masala kati rolls were so effen tasty!!! And the roti were perfect: a little crispy on the outside, but soft and warm without being tough or dry. Served piping hot. Yum! My boyfriend, who's 1/2 Fijian, thought they were some of the best roti he's had in the U.S. 

Also, it is nice to have a great Indian-to-go option. They knocked out those kati rolls in seconds. Seriously. And two totally filled me up. We'll definitely be back.
author: Arkay K.

description:
6:30pm Look up Kasa's menu and place order.
6:45pm Pick up order at Kasa.
7:00pm Arrive home and unwrap my Kati rolls
7:20pm Rub my belly after an amazing experience
7:30pm Post my review on yelp.

I inhaled my rolls, they were so delicious. One is enough to fill me up, but I had to get two so I could get a more complete experience.  This is so cheap and good.  I got the chicken tika masala and their paneer.  The chicken tika masala was the most flaverful tika masala I have ever had, but it was spicy.  The paneer was on the bland side, but I was able to enjoy the taste of the flatbread, it was a nice balance.

I'm bookmarking the menu, and putting the number on speed dial.
author: Becky A.

description: Best chai ever.  Great mango lassi.  Rolls were really good.  Service...Great.  Friendly and welcoming.  I will stop in for chai whenever I am remotely near there.
author: Amy H.

description: I just went to Kasa for the first time today and I was impressed.  The prices were very affordable and the food was delicious.  I am so glad this place opened so close to my house.  The decor is simple but nice both inside and out.  The staff was super helpful.  Kasa is a very cool place.  They also have options for vegans and vegetarians which is awesome.  I am going to have to give them 5 stars.  It's not my favorite Indian place in S.F., but it is my favorite Indian place in the Castro.  I like Kasa a lot and I will be going back frequently.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Love love love love love Kasa. Love the food, love the Chai, love the atmosphere, love the employees, love the logo and the color of the building, LOVE everything about Kasa! I always get excited about going there. The food is cheap, fast, and absolutely delicious. Love the Kati Rolls. Even the cookies they have from an outside bakery are wonderful. Bravo, Kasa, you have made my heart sing!
author: Jennifer R.

description:
I love stumbling on to new places in the neighborhood, and Kasa is one I am sorry we had not found sooner.  Granted, it has only been open for two months now, but this is a place I will be going to weekly - for sure. 

We decided to sample a few of the items and ordered a 3 Kati roll (Kebab, Aloo Jeera and Chicken Tikka) platter and a Lamb Curry Thalis.  

The Kati rolls are very good, albeit a wee bit on the greasy side. We got over that fact quick though, once we bit down on the kebab and tasted a little piece of heaven. The Aloo Jeera was also tasty, seasoned perfectly and cooked well enough to melt in your mouth. The Chicken Tikka was good, just a little dry in comparison - so I would order the lamb, kebab or Aloo Jeera again first. 

The Thalis...incredible. The lamb was cooked perfectly and mixed with small pieces of stewed potatoes. Add in the cilantro chutney and a gollop of the yogurt cucumber riata and I was hooked. 

As for the libations side of things - wash it all down with a Triple Karmeliet. Holy smokes, that is an amazing brew (Chimay like, but almost - dare I sare...better?). 

So while I hate to add to the positive reviews here as it might make our little neighborhood jaunt a lot more crowded, Kasa derserves to get mad props. It is that good. And we'll be back. Maybe tomorrow.
author: Kristie W.

description: I got a kati roll to go, and headed downtown. I bit into it when I got off MUNI and immediately regretted not getting two, or ten. So good that I made people around me uncomfortable with my noises, and absolutely did not care. Bonus for super nice staff.
author: Dani A. C.

description:
Yum.  I picked up a Thali to-go.  $10.95.  

Chicken Tikka  (not Masala) with a nice bit of heat, superb dal, lots of lovely flavors and spices.   Side salad, cilantro chutney, delicious roti.  The place was clean, clean, clean and the food was good.  

I'll be back with Indian friends soon, and I'm going to order a Kati roll with the cumin-spiced potatoes, maybe a second one with the karahi paneer.  

Thank goodness they are nearby, they may replace my favorite Thai restaurant.  The menu is simple but oh-so-good.
author: Lm C.

description:
Yes! Fast-Indian-food! Now, If I can only convince someone to open fast-Italian-food!

Enough with the exclamations. Forgive me.

I'm happy that the Indian Chipotle is located nearby. It wasn't what I thought it would be, and I like that, too.

But yeah, the layout could use some work. As, perhaps, could the system of ordering. This joint may need to go full-service, and that's mostly because the foods is awesome.

I got a lamb curry thali, and it was mouth-wateringly delicious. The "roti" (we're not sure if it was, in fact, roti. Oh, and this "we" I speak of is me and two Indian-Americans). The daal was awesome, even though I shouldn't eat lentils (don't wanna go into what they do to me). I could, of course, do without anything having anything to do with cucumbers, so I left the yogurt/cucumber (raita) dish and the side salad thing that had *barf* cucumber untouched.

I had a bite of chicken tikka masala that Tara R. got, and also a bite of another companion's kati. All were so, so good.

This restaurant opened with a beer and wine license. Awesome?

So, in sum, points off for layout and ordering system, points added for excellent food.
author: Jeff H.

description:
*** 3.5 stars ***

Dropped by Kasa after hearing about it on Daily Candy.  Hope this is not lame of me to say, but it's like eating an Indian burrito.  

They're delishooooohioso.  

2 Kati rolls, one with tikka masala and the other chicken tikka.  Honey got the thalis (dinner plate) with lamb curry.  Liked my kati's the best.  Each bite was a burse of flavor.  I didn't feel stuffed like I normally do after an Indian dinner, so I think it's a great place for lunch or a light dinner.

People taking orders were so sweet.  He apologized for the wait, but it was totally understandable cause there was a line going out the door!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Why weren't there any Indian people working in the kitchen?  Oh, I know... it's because the food could only barely be called Indian: bland, boring, and what an odd combination of spices unlike any other Indian restaurant I've ever experienced, and that's saying something.

I ordered the chicken tikka masala dinner plate, and even with the chopped up thai chilis added atop it, it was one of the most bland, tasteless experiences.

The only redeeming feature of the meal was the Lecma soda, and even that was somewhat disappointing because of HFCS as its sweetener.

I never have to eat here again, and you don't have to neither!
author: Paul B.

description:
Indian food like mom makes! This is absolutely great and such a welcome departure from the heavy, greasy, over-spiced, indulgent food popular at most Indian restaurants in SF. 

The paratha were perfect, well-salted and griddled to a crisp with just a hint of butter. The "fillings" tasted fresh and home-made: Flavorful, spicy, and without the in-your-face "hot"  that plauge the restaurants in the tandoorloin. Thankfully, nothing was sopping in oil, and the cool raita and cucumber salad provided a nice balance to the rich roll. 

Count me as a fan, I'll be back for sure. If I had one suggestion, it would be a more varied menu, maybe a daily subzi special so we can get some more variety. Oh, and one thing that would make my day, selling bulk, pre-rolled paratha (cooked or uncooked). I'd by a bag every week! :)

[update 6/24/2007] It appears that they have already started offering weekly specials!  Here's hoping for a bhindi roll.
author: Sugam J.

description:
I was very happy to see some new blood in the restaurant scene in the Castro. The space is beautifully design. Minimalist, hard surfaces, metal chairs, and high ceilings. 

One has to order and pay for the food at the counter. The woman behind the counter had a cool accent, but the live room made it difficult to hear her. I ordered the Kati Roll with lamb curry and Aloo Jeera. It came with salad and raaita on a metal plate. Each roll consisted of the filling wrapped in flaky, buttery roti.

Positives:
The raaita was a minty, sweet seasoned yogurt side dish. It was cool and refreshing.
Both lamb and potato filling were tasty and spicy.

Negatives:
The salad was almost inedible. It was so sour from the vinegar.

The roti (bread) was so very greasy. I wiped my hands on my napkin several times. By the end of the meal, the napkin was dark from the grease. 

The restaurant is loud mainly because of the hard surfaces. There were only 6 people in the restaurant. Hate to think about trying to converse when it's full.

Hope the owners read this and try to make some changes.
author: Robert C.

description:
In a blind tasting between Kasa and any of the stellar kati roll places in Manhattan, it would be no contest - Kasa still has ways to go. But the fillings are tasty, the condiments spiced well, and the service super quick. Big plus is the sunny space, which is a definite improvement from the greasy spoon locations usually reserved for the best kati rolls. 
What was missing was the flaky paratha (these were a little more like a regular roti). And, the fillings were runnier than I like, which made the whole thing turn soggy fast. Still, a solid B+ effort.
author: Purnima M.

description: Loved the kati rolls!  I had the chicken kati and the paneer.  Both very good!  And very affordable.
author: Niniane W.

description:
Good stuff! The food was fresh and quickly prepared. Helpful and friendly staff as well.

So far we've tried the kati rolls - the turkey kebab was our favorite - they were all good and we look forward to trying them again. Next time we might stay for a plate lunch.
author: Brian C.

description: Love, love, love me some Kasa. It's an obsession at this point. Their Chick Masala Kati wraps are more addictive than crack! I've never had such yumminess all wrapped up in a perfect bundle. It's different and different is good. I could go there once a day to eat. No joke. So fresh, so tasty, so amazing. I haven't been to their other location on Filmore, but if the food is the same there then I am sure your hunger will be in good hands!
author: Ryan B.

description:
I found out about this place by randomly ending up at the Hot Messes softball team fundraiser.  They are sponsored by Kasa, and after winning the raffle, the Hot Messes are officially my favourite lesbian softball team!

Another reviewer put it best:
"Kasa is one of those places where you go for lunch and then want to go again for dinner."

I really did want to go back for dinner!  Their chicken tikka masala roti wrap was amazing.  It was what I've always dreamed of in Indian food without knowing what it was!

I will definitely be back very soon.
author: Andrew N.

description:
Something -- nay a lot of things -- about this place feel a little like McDonald's.  One thing doesn't: the price.

You've got a young, high-school- aged staff of white kids serving you.  Nothing wrong with that, maybe, except that there is.  I don't pretend to be an authority on whether this is "authentic" Indian food (I think it's an unfair term, anyway).  But you're certainly not getting an authentic vibe.  And that, like it or not, admit it or not, makes the food taste worse.

There's practically nothing in each of those little wraps.  I ended up not finishing my third wrap, but that was more because they were bad and not because they were filling.  In the end you do get enough food, but only because you're eating 3 wraps worth of bread!  There's one, maybe two, pieces of meat in the curry they give you.  They're even pretty cheap with the dips they give out.  

In fact, I asked for second of one of the dips (the non-yogurt ones).  It's a good thing, because when I was running home, my bag broke and one of my dips splatted all over some poor fool's driveway.  Sure, I was literally -running- home, so the bag's probably aren't used to the swaying, but still, weak sauce. Or weak dip.  If I weren't pissed off about paying for $12 for this crap, I'd probably admit it was my fault, but I am, so I'm holding Kasa accountable and I'd like you to join me in doing so.

When I did get home to eat my sad, dip-inhibited wraps, the bread tasted stale.  Part of this place's appeal to me was that it's open relatively late, but it appears that just means you're eating day old bread.  No thanks.

Can't really recommend or unrecommend any of the particular wraps.  The chicken tikka masala was my favorite, I guess, but it's Indian food, what do you expect the best flavor to be?  The potato and lamb ones were ok.
author: Jack S.

description: Ordered delivery last night, had never tried Kasa before. I was worried the two plates would not be enough for my man and I, but was happy to find plenty of food for the two of us. We were given a 45-1 hour window, it arrives in less than 40 minutes. Every component of the plate was delicious and very fresh tasting. The paneer dish that I ordered was 100% paneer, which is usually not the case. The best part is the extremely reasonable prices. I am always amazed at how an Indian dinner for two (which is mostly veg) can be upwards of $50 in most restaurants. Our bill was less than $25 and we were FULL! Will definitely order from Kasa again and again.
author: Kylie S.

description: Good food. But their helpings have started to shrink so significantly... the Kasa folks should be ashamed sending away hungry folks.
author: noflaps c.

description: Not as good as its sister off Union Street. Got the chicken Kathi Roll. The meat was tough, and felt old. The raita was decent, and the tea was waay to milky. Should have stuck to the thums up! :-)
author: Gurpreet S.

description:
This place is different from other Indian places because you have the "Kati roll" option. They are like Indian burritos, where the wrapping is a lightly-pan-fried roti.

When you walk up to the counter, you will have two big choices to make:

Choice #1: Do you get Kati rolls ("Indian burrito") or Thali dish (full meal with basmati rice, salad, etc.)?

I say use your extra ca$h on the Kati rolls. You can get rice-based entrees anywhere else, and the Kati rolls will give you more variety:

Choice #2: Once you've chosen Kati rolls, do you get 1, 2, or 3 rolls?

For a normal-appetited person, one roll is a light lunch, two rolls is a satiating dinner, and three is just crazy.

My recommendation: go with your honey and split 3 rolls between the two of you (and ask the Kati-assembler person for two plates). That gets each of you a 1.5-roll satisfyingly-filling 3-sample dinner, with room for dessert.

Staff are friendly.
author: Rob T.

description:
I discovered Kasa while walking home by a different route tonight.  I was looking for a place to have a quick dinner, and so I stopped in.  What a happy experience.  It's fast, tasty, and healthy.  It's cheap.  They have good beer on tap.  

I had a chicken tikka masala kati roll and, at one of the servers' suggestion, a karahi paneer (yogurt cheese, spinach, green peppers) kati roll.  I had a nice, flavorful ale to go with it, the name of which I cannot remember.  Each roll was delicious and filling.  The little garnish salad they serve is fabulous--diced red onion, sweet peppers, cabbage, carrots with black mustard seed and cumin in a vinegary dressing.  Fresh and lively.  The raita was just fine.

The interior setup is done well.  It's airy and comfortable.  The folks who work there are upbeat and helpful.  My only criticism is that they don't make mango lassis.  They do have mango juice, but I'm a mango lassi kinda broad.  That's a very minor criticism.  They're new.  They're evolving.  They'll come around eventually.  

I'm just delighted to have them in my neighborhood.  I will be darkening their door often, I suspect.

UPDATE:  I hear that they're now making mango lassis (11/08), although I can't confirm that personally.  Note to self:  get ass back in there for cheap, delicious meal and check out the lassi status.
author: Earline A.

description: I'm from India and I know what a good Kati Roll tastes like. This place is really mediocre when it comes to food quality. I had gone today and tried a Saag Paneer Kati Roll and their thali with Kadai Paneer (spelled as Karahi Paneer). The Saag Paneer was very tasteless. The Kadai Paneer was decent as was the Carrot-Zucchini curry they had with the thali. But the rice was clumpy and stale, the chapati (they call roti) was soft going stiff, the yogurt raita tasted very artificial. The salad they offered tasted fresh. Overall, very disappointing.
author: Dinesh D.

description:
I love this idea: set up like a burrito counter but stocked with 1,000 times the flavor! Indian flavors either constructed into a wrap or deconstructed onto a platter, you decide.

I opted for the plater (Thali) which was awesome, but my favorite thing I tried was Alex's Karahi Paneer Kati roll. So good. Great selection of beer and wine to go with their flavors as well. Mmmmm.

Any idea if the location is opening up down in the Marina?? I saw a sign in the window the other day that it is in the works. I HOPE SO!
author: Abby Z.

description:
After walking by this relatively new addition to the Castro, I decided to pop in for a quick and easy bite to eat for dinner. Overall, I quite enjoyed my meal, and recommend the place for a quick and easy meal. 

At first entering the place, your menu options are very limited... but that is this place's intent... Kati Rolls or a Thali plate. From there you can choose one of several uncomplicated options. Stepping up the the line deep with several other ahead of me, I was expecting a pretty decent wait before it was my turn to order, yet the line moved surprisingly fast. Being my first time there, I went for the Thali plate with the grilled turkey kabob. At $10.95 I thought the quantity of food that I got was a good value, and could barely finish all of my dinner. The kabob's had a nice flavor with just enough spice, but not over-bearing. The establishment itself is fairly small, and due to the openness and seating arraignments, noise level can sometimes be on the loud side... but then again, this is not the place for that quite intimate meal. 

When all is said and done, this is a place I am sure to revisit when grow tired of the standard Castro eateries... next time to give the Kati rolls a try.
author: Matt O.

description:
2.625 Stars!

Cons: Food was okay but unmemorable.  Seating was very uncomfortable.  And the place is amazingly loud and cold.

Pros: cheap, convenient, not another pizza or Thai joint, very nice people working there.

I'll go back with more reasonable expectations.
author: Kevin M.

description:
We've started referring to it as "the Indian taqueria."  For the best deal, get a couple of the roti -- a tortilla-like flatbread that they'll fill with your choice of meat  / cheese / vegetable fillings and sauce.  Two of them totally fill me up, & they're about $4 each.  My favorite hands-down is the lamb -- soooo tender and savory -- but I also get their chicken tikki masala regularly as well.  (There are several other filling options, but I haven't had any of them enough to remember them -- I know there's a potato based one, and a cheese one that I think I've had once before & remember being pretty tasty.)

If you're hungrier, you can also get a platter that's basically a "deconstructed" roti.  (I did this the first time I was there but it was too much food.)  Don't miss the green coconut-based substance (wouldn't call it "sauce," exactly, but it's good), and the yogurt sauce is fantastic.  I like to pour it on the roti.

Also a pretty decent beer & wine selection.  If you're eating there, try the Kingfisher with just about anything.
author: Angela B.

description:
Wonderful, small place for casual Indian dining. 

I enjoy Indian food quite a bit,.. primarily because I'm Indian. We visited this place so we could try out the Kati rolls (it's essentially a wrap using a roti). These rolls were delicious.. I tried both a saag and karahi paneer roll, one had eggs on it (they toss an egg on the hot plate, then a roti on top, so the egg gets cooked onto the roti, real nice).. 

I also had a mango lassi (very very thick, but delicious)... 

The staff was very very VERY friendly.. even offered closing time chai on the house.. very friendly.. we got there LAST MINUTE and they weren't annoyed or anything.. which was nice to see.

This is the kind of place you could order on the go (like their truck they have).. and just eat while you walk or drive.. one Kati roll is pretty filling but if you're a bit hungrier, grab 2.. you won't regret it..
author: Ravi R.

description:
Shrimpy eaters, and I mean in appetite size not the seafood, be warned. They will try to get you to order two Kati rolls but all you need is one. I can eat 1/2 of a Cancun burrito. If that's your standard too, then you just need one roll here. 

I want Kasa's yogurt recipe so I can put it on everything I eat. If the okra special is on the menu and you like okra then, by golly, get it!
author: Regina S.

description: We were visiting SF and saw the food truck driving down the street.  We were bummed that we didn't get to try it.
