Then 20 min. later we were trying to find our way and we stumbled upon the truck parked outside the eatery.  JACKPOT!  The menu is limited, but the food is amazing! They also have beer and ready to go mango lassi.
author: Kristen F.

description: I love eating here, especially getting the thali plate where you can choose 2 sides dishes and get other additions to accompany the meal.  The little salad and chutneys are great tasting.  I highly recommend the chai tea as well, really flavorful.  For ~10-11 for the thali plate, it's a pretty good deal, really filling.  Favorites are any of the cheese or vegetable dishes.  Staff are friendly as well.
author: Mary D.

description: This place was delicious without being crazy heavy like other Indian restaurants. Fresh, made to order, if I lived here I would eat here allllllll the time!
author: Cristy P.

description: I've come here probably a dozen times or so and I am always satisfied. I usually get a couple of kati rolls (think small burritos with thicker naan-like wraps). Two is usually enough, but I get 3 if I'm feeling a little piggy. I switch up what I get from time to time, but my favorites are the karahi paneer, chicken tikka masala, and the aloo jeera.
author: Jeremy J.

description:
I'll be honest, I have yet to try a place that compares to my mom's cooking *Damn you mother* so most Indian places I try I'm not a big fan of. I think this place had it's good and bad points. 

Good: 
- The daal was really good.
- The turkey kebab was delicious though it could have been spiced a bit more. Please take note, I'm not one of those eaters that has proudly killed off their taste buds in pursuit of spicy food. I dont need my food to be overflowing with spices or spiciness, it just needs to have a good flavor to it.
- Taking a dramatic step forward from Shalimar, this place was clean and minimally decorated but pleasant to eat at. 
- Clearly I need to try the Kati roll since it looks like that was a big success. 

Bad:
- The chicken tikka malasa had very little curry to it. It definitely needs more. Also the taste was a little too bland and Americanized. 
- The paneer was tasty but again, too little flavor. 
- I was bummed they didn't have naan or cholle (garbanzo beans)

I think my overall disappointment had to do with the fact that there wasn't enough flavor to the dishes. Indian food has some great spice to it that you can't use in other cuisines, take advantage of that. And don't add your own twist if the original is better. That said, it was a good meal, it just could have been better. 

I hope this place does well but more flavor and spice need to be added to the food in order for this place to take off.
author: Shreya C.

description:
Three stars for the novelty and usefulness of a quick-order Indian place not in the ghetto. I thought the food was bland compared to an actual full-service indian restaurant, although I've only tried the two vegetarian fillings. The dal couldv'e used...something. The two standard sides, the raita and cucumber salad, are everything you'd expect them to be. The authentic Indian drinks are a nice touch, and the layout of the place is a slightly more utilitarian Chipotle. I thought they kind of took the menu simplification to the extreme; there aren't any sides listed on the menu -- what if I want some extra chutney?

If you're in the Castro or nearby, definitely try this place for a quick satisfying bite. Also, as drunk food goes, this would probably be amazing for an after-happy-hour binge. By no means, though, should this be a substitute for a real Indian restaurant.
author: Nick A.

description:
all my fellow yelpers have pretty much summed it up! this place delivers great indian food! fresh and delicious!

i always get the kati rolls during lunch time so i get 2 katis (one chicken tikka masala and one lamb curry!) plus a drink for like... 8 bucks! i always tell myself that ill get the plate next time but the katis have gotten me hooked! i cant even bring myself to order anything different! definitely a must try spot in the castro!
author: amelia g.

description:
I've been looking forward to this opening before I even knew what it was going to be. I live about a block away and we really need some eateries that are more interesting than the pizza and breakfast joints that we have in abundance now in the Castro. 

I want this place to make it, fast food Indian, what's not to like?  I was impressed by the lack of grease and the spiciness of the veggie options.  The daal was nice,  how about as a side option? 

 I should have waited a few days  for the kinks to get worked out, but I didn't,  I just couldn't wait, hopefully they'll get some of their freshman problems under control ...

No restaurant is worth a one hour and fifteen minute wait in line to order ... fix your service problems and you've got me, I'm close!  

.
author: Joanne K.

description:
What a fantastic way to end our trip in San Fran at this new gem in the heart of the Castro. We've been walking by Kasa all weekend since it's across the street from where we are staying. 

The fresh roti rolls are hand made to order in front of you while ordering your food. I had the Chicken Tikka and Lamb Curry rolls and they were both bursting with the perfect amount of flavor and spice. My boyfriend had the Thalis plate which I insisted upon tasting each item specifically for my review on yelp. The mint chutney tasted fresh and not overbearing, the basmati rice was soft and the garnish salad added a refreshing taste in between bites of everything!

This new kid on the block is a definite keeper. The line was outside the door and I don't see it going down anytime soon with the closest Indian restaurant located deep in the mission... my friend asked me to give Kasa three stars so that he won't have to wait in long lines for months, too bad buddy I can't keep this place a secret. If only there was someplace like this in Seattle.
author: Tyler J.

description:
I went here with a large group last week, so pretty soon after they'd opened.  The food was pretty decent, with the chicken wraps being fairly tasty, and the potato one being pretty well spiced.  Nothing really stood out to me though, and the wrap they used was far inferior to nan.  

My main issue is the price to expected food ratio.If you go in thinking, "Indian Burritos" you'll be sorely disappointed.  Each one of the wraps is pretty small, probably about 1/4 the size of a Mission burrito.  Some of my party made that mistake and ended up hungry after ordering only the 1 or 2 roll version. The 3 roll order for 12 bux was just sufficient enough for a hungry growing boy like myself.  And for a take-out counter style restaurant that is pretty pricey.
author: Randal T.

description:
Delicious.  I got the 2 item Thali with Chicken Tikka Masala and Lamb Curry.  Both good but I give the edge to the chicken.  Thali plate comes rice, daal, raita and some sauces. Also with some of the bread they use to make the kati rolls.

I look forward to trying the kati rolls next time.

Not sure what some of the folks are complaining about.  I thought the price was very fair.

Kasa also has a nice clean ambiance.
author: Aaron T.

description:
OK, I LOVE spicy food, and after reading some reviews about lack of flavor/spice I was a bit skeptical on ordering delivery from Kasa, but I did anyways...

I ate TWO whole chilis with out realizing it cause there was one more that fell out of chicken tikka masala kati roll...YES!!! My mouth is on fire, and the flavor is great. A little raita, and Im doing fine.

I also got one of the plates, just in case the roll wasnt enough...damn, that roll was enough! So now I have lunch tomorrow--Aloo Jeera Thali...and I know i will like it.

Seriously, great delivery option f you are in the area. Great portions, wonderful flavor (thank you to the cook who added hella chili's--LOVE YA!)

I am more than happy to give them my money :)
author: Sassy O.

description:
I love Indian food and happened to come upon a gift certificate for 1/2 off! I bought a $30 gift certificate and off I went.  I ordered 3 rolls; Chicken Tikka, Turkey Kabob, and the Aloo Jeera (spiced potato) as well as a Thali plate with Chicken Tikka Masal and Karahi Paneer and two extra Roti.  Now this sounds like alot of food but was disappointed that the portions are really small.  Overall the food was so so, the lentils and the Chiken Tikka Masala were super spicy. I am used to the creamy, buttery Masala whereas theirs was a thin tomato-ey spicy sauce with grilled and marinated chicken.  The rest were pretty good with the exception of the Karaji Panner which was exceptional! I could also eat the Roti and the Raita by itself, it was that good.  

So overall for $30, I felt that the prices were too high for the amount of food . I am from the Peninsula and would not go out of my way for Kasa. =(
author: Jerome H.

description: Another great meal.  Chicken Tikka Masala and a paneer dish.  I love this place
author: Matt V.

description:
Are you like burritos, are you like sit down, are you an eat in or take away sorta place?  I'm confused about what this place is....

All in all a good dinner bet, we had the Kati rolls to go.  I got the Chicken Tikka Masala and the indian cheese (um, forgot the name), my dining companion got the lamb and the chicken tikka. 

We got outta there for $20 but the food wasn't very substantive.  Also, it seemed like they had a hard time hearing us over the glass so we both got the wrong chutney on our wrap. 

All in all the food was good and fresh, but the price is a little steep for what you get.  I think I had three whole pieces of chicken in my roll.  I ended up making us a dinner salad to tide us over.  I think that for $20 we should also have some sort of carb, perhaps some basmati rice with veggies?  

The food was good, I liked the assembly line that moved things along, BUT was a little dissapointed by the size of the roll.  If this is competing with a taqueria, you are going to need to fill up the guests. 

I'll return and update in a month or so to see if any changes have been made.
author: Claire C.

description: I like that this is a modern, clean and easy to order establishment.  Their decor is great and the food is pretty good!  Came here around lunch time and ordered the Chicken Tikki Masala wrap.  Was happy with my order, sauces were great, and loved the feel of the purple!
author: Reb R.

description:
I had a great experience here.  Granted, the line was long, as other people below have pointed out.  It was opening night after all, and there was a lot of buzz about this place prior to opening night.  So, I'm putting that unique phenomenon aside (I actually thought the air of excitement was fun, and I enjoyed talking to my foodie line-mates while taking in the gorgeous aromas from the kitchen)

I had the Karahi Paneer Kati, and thought the brightness and complexity of the flavors was very, very satisfying.  (There was a 'light' quality to the food which elevates it from the typical 'buffet' kind of fare that one is usually stuck with,and that leaves one feeling sort of sick after. ) 

So, lots of commitment to using fresh, quality ingredients, and a commitment to creating a good experience too.  Despite the opening night deluge (and come on folks, last night was exceptional in that regard) the team checked-in at various times with those of us in line and displayed a real interest in delivering good food. (The owners are genuinely sweet.) 

All great signs in my book, and my meal tasted great.  

-Going back for more!
author: Mark N.

description:
The kati rolls are amazing! Just the right amount of kick without being overpoweringly spicy. Everything tastes fresh and bright.

A nice alternative to pizza on a night of drunken festivities.
author: Matt W.

description:
This place just opened near my house and the Yelpers seemed to like it, so I had to check it out, so last Sunday I took 3 others for dinner at Kasa. When we got there, the place was a mad house. The staff was obviously frazzled but they were trying their hardest to move as fast as they could, which was completely understandable since the place just opened a week and a half before.

The staff was friendly, the menu was simple and the food was outstanding. They have Kingfisher beer on tap, which rocks my world and I like the simple decor of the establishment.

I can't wait to go back in a few weeks after the hordes of people start to thin out and the staff are firing on all cylinders. 

Lastly: Good for you, you dumb bitch who was trying to save 4 seats in a packed restaurant for her friends who weren't even there yet. You got what you deserved.
author: Keau K.

description:
Nickle and dime to death

2$ surcharge where the menu board had $1!

Cashier suggested to talk with manager - but, do you really want to waste time or enjoy a meal?

Bottom line Thali (on the Menu 10.95) totalled to 14.39.

You'd do better elsewhere.  Perhaps they won't be trying to outsmart you with decoratively splitiing about 1oz serving of lamb on two sides of the plate, then doubly charging for it.  

You know something?  I'd split it into many small dots around the plate @ $1 each

food was "nothing to write home about"

try elsewhere next time
author: Bob A.

description: My combo plate consisted of a lil bit of everythang on a cafeteria tray. Saag paneer (spinach with homemade cheese), chicken tikka masala, cilantro sauce, pickled red onion, rice, yogurt.  What's nice about Kasa is that it has a nice kick and some good Indian street food type flavors without making me feel like having a food coma afterwards. What else could I ask for?
author: Leslie L.

description:
I was hungry and had 2 kati rolls: chicken tikka masala and the lamb. 
The chicken was nice and spicy and delicious.  
The lamb was good too, but got a bit heavy towards the end.  

Overall, it was really good.  Maybe I'll try the plate next time...
author: Keiko A.

description: Unique and delicious. I'm grateful for the lamb curry kati roll with extra cilantro chutney on the side.
author: Blake G.

description: Are the 4/5 star reviews by people who've never tasted real Indian food? This place is ridiculous. The concept is great - thali plate for $10.95 where you choose 1-2 of your favorite main dishes. The chicken tikka masala tasted nothing like a traditional tikka masala and it wasn't even creamy, the chicken was dry. The rice was dry. The dal was super salty. The lamb curry didn't taste of curry and was extremely boring. The cauliflower special  and the green chutney and the roti were the only edible things. The mango lassi is heavy on cardamom. Also, strangely enough, the $5.00 side of lamb curry was about 10 times the size of the chicken portion that came with the thali plate.
author: Marina N.

description:
The closest substitute I've found to Bombay's frankies and New York's kati rolls in San Francisco! Great quality, non-greasy, fresh Indian food conveniently located within walking distance...woot! I especially like the Daal and chai - both are on par with the stuff you'd get back in northern India. The rotis are great too. The palak paneer and bhindi sabzis always rock. 
You can get the roti in true "kati roll" style, which is like a wrap, or deconstructed (roti with vegetables/ meat on the side). Personally, I prefer the roti deconstructed...that way, you can get half portions of two fillings ;) Aloo gobi and the regular aloo sabzis are ok. 
I also like the fact that they make limited quantities of the daily specials and are not shy to take things off the board when sold out. Good luck with their new location in the Fillmore!
author: Shweta V.

description:
3.7 stars! 

The food was pretty good the whole "thing" they are going for... interesting.

Acoustics are HORRIBLE. It was sooo loud, i could barely hear my thoughts.
author: Art A.

description:
Kasa serves Indian cuisine fast-food style, but the place resembles nothing like your average greasy, ugly McD's. It's clean, minimalist, with beautiful wooden tables and a splash of color from fresh flowers. 

Despite the modern decor, our friend gave it a stamp of authenticity approval. She said it's like Indian home cooking. 

The menu is so simple a drunk should be able to handle the ordering ( in fact, I would imagine anyone stepping outside a bar after closing would be really interested in scoring a kati roll.) Food is pretty cheap - a Kati roll is just five bucks, and it's enough to make a light meal. 

I had the kati roll with chicken tikka masala, and it was really delicious. My husband had the kati roll with chicken tikka and he loved it. Our friends shared a Thali, and it was big enough for the two of them to share. 

I think they should start rolling carts around town like the Tamales 
Lady. Until then, I am happy to hear that they are going to open another location in the Marina.
author: Candice B.

description: The paneer kathi roll is amazing with a fiery zing to it. Not for the faint hearted! The green chutney is super spicy. If you can handle heat then don't miss.  The mango lassi is the perfect antidote to go with it.
author: Natasha I.

description: Wouldn't even come close to comparing this wonderful place to chipolte because chipolte sucks balls. Everything was perfect! Such complex flavors and spices and super cheap. Left feeling very full. Thumbs up Kasa!
author: William K.

description:
In summary a simplified, pared down decor and menu that's not bland nor utilitarian.  Because I suck at remembering the often elaborate nomenclature of East Indian cuisine it gladdened my dullard brain to find there were only six entree choices prepared in two fashions.  Of course I only remember two of the six, one being what I had:  the Lamb Curry and the other being the staple of Chicken Tikka Masala.  
I chose the Thalia version of preparation, which, for all intents and purposes was a burrito.  Good portions spread out over a gleaming compartmentalized platter included sides of yogurt, a bean dish, basmati rice and fresh, diced veggies.  All in all a good meal for $11.88.
author: Sam N.

description: Love this place! All the rolls look amazing.  Can't wait to try them all :)
author: Uma M.

description:
This place is hip!

Great location, I love the inside of this place.  Lots of window light which is always a plus.

This isn't exactly high class dining, but you order up delicious wraps that come out on a lunch tray.  Love it!  I always walk home stuffed and satisfied.

I mean, its no DOSA's, but I love it here, and think it's at least worth one trip to see if you'd dig it too!
author: Jess R.

description: Not the most authentic Indian food, but this place brought back memories of the beautiful city of Chennai, India. Checkout all the pictures of Chennai and some more pics in the restroom ;-), there is a picture of an Auto-rickshaw speeding at 40mph in 3 ft of flooded rain water !! Happens only in India....
author: Nirmal S.

description:
4.5 stars.

This place is like the Chipotle of Indian food. Except here, you get good tasty mini-burrito things that taste great (which can't always be said about Chipotle). I wouldn't say the food is super authentic (but its a good segway for some people to get into Indian food), but the food is solid.

The owner (I think he was the owner) is great and made the dining experience even better. I joking made a comment about the wine (while he was pouring a glass for another patron, I said he should pour me some while he was at it), and he actually did!

Free wine (along with a nice comment!), tasty food, and its a definite worthy 4.5 stars. I WILL return for more and with the way this place is going, I can see it becoming a 5 star establishment real soon.

Oh, and parking in the Castro, on a Friday night during dinner hours, is terrible as usual.
author: Rocky K.

description: okay, this place is not terrible, customer service was good. the servers were nice, but the food? ah-uh. I've had bad tikka masala before，but this place had the worst Indian food ever. I'm giving it one star because the food was terrible. There was too much cinnamon on everything, and the beans tasted very old. $13 for a plate, a-. if you want to spend your money on good food, avoid this place.
author: Patrick P.

description: Ate here again - the kati roll was tasty, and the thali plate was pretty decent. Nothing really wowed me though, but a decent place for convenience.
author: Carol L.

description:
I was living about five doors up Noe and have been salivating watching it come together. Three days after it opened, I moved. Oh well, it's not like I moved far, but still...

At this point I've had a few dinners and lunches here and really enjoyed every single bite. The texture and flavors have been really well balanced, flavorful with the right amount of spicy. I love the green stuff which I have no idea what the hell it is, but I can't stop eating it. 

The staff seems somewhat green and perhaps a little bit slow, but they're learning fast. Even between the first and third times I've been here service has improved. Otherwise, the staff is attentive and helpful.
author: dana l.

description:
Terrible, Terrible, Terrible......DO NOT ORDER FROM KASA.

I have never in my life had such terrible service as I did when ordering delivery from Kasa. Mind you I am in the restaurant business and it takes quite a terrible experience to get me to post a negative review!

 I stumbled onto Kasa for lunch and enjoyed it enough to consider it for dinner while studying late at home.

I placed my order over the phone and when the driver arrived he was offended that I had not met the $15 dollar minimum for delivery. I apologized and informed the driver that I was not made aware of this on the phone, nor was it listed on the website, for if it had I would of been happy to order more food for the convenience of delivery. HE replied, " Well I am telling you now," as he rolled his eyes!

Then, the driver did not have change? He only carried twenties he said? Strange. Then he said he needed to run down to the car to get change.

However, he drove off and left me standing in the doorway of my apartment for ten minutes wondering if he was returning. Mean while my food was getting cold, and I was freezing in my PJ's.

I then called the restaurant, to inquire where the driver had gone and the manager on the phone said that, " We are not an establishment that wouldn't give change and HUNG UP on me!" I am not joking. I was hung up on for calling to find out where the driver had gone with my change!

I was in complete shock. The driver returned fifteen minutes later and gave me my change. He was rude, when he first arrived and was even rudder still on his return. He then proceeded to ask me for a tip, as he placed the money in my hand. 

Mind you I am a waiter, and have NEVER not tipped, but I was so furious at this point I informed him that I didn't feel the service warranted a tip. He then told me to never order from Kasa again.

GOOD ADVICE, DO NOT ORDER FROM KASA.

The service was rude, and offensive. No matter how decent the food is I simply can't afford to support a business who treats their guests this way. There are too many restaurants in SF who value their customers, and want to be a part of the community.

DO NOT ORDER FROM KASA!
author: Anthony R.

description:
Kasa helped cater a private party for us in our apartment for 30 people. The food was delicious and they accommodated a request for no onions which was really helpful.

Everyone loved the food, even those who don't often eat Indian. I tend to have very high standards and thought every dish was great. I would definitely do it again.
author: Christian B.

description:
This place is super. The kati rolls are the way to go, because you can pick a different meat/paneer/potato filling for each of the rolls. With the thalis (basically the same ingredients as the kati rolls, just compartmentalized on a sweet napolean-dynamite-high-school-style lunch tray instead of rolled up), I think you have to pick only one.

I love the paneer with fervor and quite like the chicken tikka masala. They're flavorful and have just the right amount of spice.
author: Whitney W.

description:
Great fresh fast food.  It's like California-style Indian food.  

I love the tasty salad included in the Thali.  The rolls are a great size and quite scrumptious.  And there's Kingfisher on draft!

We had the Chicken Tikka and two specials:  Saag Paneer and Aloo Gobi.  The mango lassi was uniquely spiced.

I will definitely be back.
author: Dina B.

description:
Yummy Yummy Yummy!
Great prices! Good Food!
Cute Guys!
What more can you ask for!
Matthew
author: Matthew M.

description:
http://blog.junbelen.com/2009/10/17/kasas-kati-rolls/

How come it took me this long to taste and enjoy kati rolls?  It has always been about naan but now I cannot get enough of the buttery, flaky and delicious kati rolls.

I love Kasa.  Their chicken tikka masala and lamb curry are very tasty and more so when wrapped in kati rolls.  The place is clean and the people are friendly.  And above all it's inexpensive delicious food.

Cannot wait to go back.
author: Jun B.

description: Tried this place on a whim... Ordered chicken tikka, chicken tikka masala, lamb curry, and aloo jeera... Eaten by themselves - ehhh... But order them as a Kati roll and BAM!!! Da Bomb!!! Maybe it's the sauce combination or just a nice little mini Indian burrito = mmm... good for a great price.
author: Minh V.

description:
This is NOT an Indian Eatery, at least not by my standards. I will give them one thing: they do use what seems to be correct spices, but that's also where all similarities to Indian food ends. We ordered Rolls that were eatable - the only saving grace for this horrid place and the only reason I am even giving them one star. The lamb curry was absolutely DISGUSTING with an after taste that made me seriously question whether or not rancid meat had been used. It tasted rotten. The tikka was not like any other tikka I have ever had (and trust me, I am a huge tikka fan and eat it several times a month).

Not only was the food extremely sub-par, but the delivery was nearly an hour late. I can deal with late, but almost an hour without hearing anything from the restaurant or the driver? It's ridiculous. When we called the restaurant to inquire about our order, we were told the driver was his way - he showed up about 30 minutes later.  By that time the food was cold AND there were several things missing from our order.

There have been several reviews for this place, most of which are positive. I am very happy for the people who had those experiences and wish I could have experienced half of what they experienced. I can NOT with a clear consciousness recommend this place.

I don't think I have ever been more disappointed with a food order in my entire life.
author: Jessica H.

description:
What happened to this place?  I ate here a few times before and was impressed by the food and the reasonable prices. After tonight's experience though I don't think I'd ever go there again.

The food was over-salted and recklessly spicy.  Worse, it did not taste fresh and had a mushy, cafeteria quality. 

It seems like Kasa has become the Indian equivalent  of Chipotle. Blah mall food.
author: Meg P.

description:
The rolls are quite good, good chappati, good ingredients.  All in all, a little pricey, but very well conceived and spiced.

Also good wifi and power plugs.
author: Ben M.

description: Feel it is my duty to protest.  Why is this place so highly rated (seriously, 7x7, the best Indian food in SF?? WTF!)?  Portions are good and price is right but the food is really lacking.  Though we live just steps away and are often too lazy to venture far out of our neighborhood, we only come here when the thought of walking more than half a block or driving brings tears to our eyes.  The fiance enjoys the kati roll unde-style, but there isn't much for me here.  Try Pakwan instead!
author: Lisa S.

description: Fortunate that after all these years ... We've finally landed a simple place in the Castro serving refreshing, healthy, flavorful Indian fare.  Other ethnic restaurants around the 'hood are second-rate whereas this one - although self-cast as fine street food - is a great place to sit-down and grab a good bite with friends. Served without pretense.   Just yummy!
author: W G.

description:
Hooray for tasty Indian food in The Castro! Kasa is a welcome addition to the neighborhood, offering a variety of items wrapped in roti or as part of a thali. You order at the counter and watch as your meal is prepared, then bring it to your table yourself. The folks behind the counter are friendly and welcoming, making you *want* to patronize their establishment 'cause of the good feeling. Industrial ambiance, but it works.

On our first, and so far only, visit, we enjoyed the lamb, chicken tikka, chicken tikka masala, and cauliflower (a special), all as roti rolls. No complaints! The cucumber, tomato, and carrot salad on the side doesn't win any awards for excitingness, but it's healthy, and the raita is also adequate; the mains are clearly the stars here.

FWIW, if you're encountering lines, go around 3 p.m. on a Sunday, and you won't have to wait long.
author: Tara M.

description:
I'm giving this 3 stars, but fully expect the rating to move higher as the kinks are ironed out.

I went there on a weekday (humpday) and the place was packed. Good sign. New places need traffic to take off.

I ordered a chicken tikka kati roll; an aloo-jeera roll and a beer. The rolls are about $5.50 each, and probably 1 would be enough for a person. They look like burritos, but the similarity is only superficial.

The wrap used to make the kati roll is very good. It is basically a plain paratha that you'd get in an Indian joint; but it is very well-made.

The chicken tikka was pretty good. The chicken pieces were a bit larger than I would have liked, and the veggies (green peppers and onions) were lesser than I would have liked; but no biggie.

The aloo-jeera (potatoes and cumin) roll was slightly disappointing. There's an art to cooking potatoes for a wrap; cook too much, and they become mushy. Cook too little, and they're not done. I think the potatoes were a bit underdone. My recommendation for the chef would be to explore the option of other potatoes (which can maintain shape) and cook some more. 

OK, so why the 3 stars? The staff is a bit new to this whole "kati roll" business. One of the guys making the rolls was more interested in chatting up his (presumably) buddies and not paying as much attention. The other guy make a paneer roll for me instead of the aloo-jeera roll; two totally different things. For all they know, I could have been lactose-intolerant (or vegan) and gagged on the paneer roll. I pointed out their mistake in time and got the right roll.

The bottom line is: this place is quite good, and I'll be going back again. I am sure the rating will go up as the crew settles down.
author: A J.

description:
I was very excited to try this place, but was a little surprised to see that everything was on steam tables. I kept an open mind and went for the karahi paneer thalis, which was looooooooots of food.

It was definitely tasty, although the paneer was different in texture than what I've had in the past. I had to really, really stare at it for a long time before I decided it wasn't chicken and was okay for me to eat. :)

I enjoyed the food, but it was pretty pricey for what it was. AND, it got so packed with people waiting in line that they were practically sitting at the table with us.

All in all, I'll probably go back because the food was good, the staff was friendly and the place was clean.
author: Tamara M.

description:
I seriously can not get enough of their Aloo Jeera Kati Roll.  Thank goodness for my belly and my wallet that they're not near my office.  Freaking amazing!

I almost gave them four stars instead of five because they are really inconsistant with their roll size.  Sometimes they're big and over stuff you and sometimes they leave you wanting a little bit more.  But I stuck with 5 stars because man, it's just so so delicious.

And don't order the Mango Lassi, it just tastes like spiced plain yogurt with a hint of mango, but their food makes up for it by far... for realsies.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
I am definitely not the kind of guy that loves spicy food. However I went to that place with my gf because she is used to Indian food and she told me that I should tried also.
The result was pretty good in a sense that I was able to get a Thali (combination of rice + meat + lentils + ...) in a metallic plate that was almost not spicy. I chosed lamb as meat and it was definitely very yummy. I would recommend that specific king of mead, especially if you like lamb.
The yogurt was a good way to compensate with the slight spiciness of the lentils and the two other ingredients that they've put in the plate.
We've also order a roll of Chicken tikka Masala (which was slightly spicy) and a lassie as a drink. The drink was creamy and a very good treat.

I give to that place a 3/5 because I don't appreciate the food that I got and that was spicy (even if we asked for non spicy food). However if you love Indian food hat place will definitely worth a 4 on 5. 

Prices are okay regarding the quality of the food that you will get.
And last but not least I loved their roti! (which is a kind of buttery bread - for ppl that are not familiar with India foods).
author: Cedric L.

description:
I may open an indian restaurant some time in my life.  If I do - and its a big "if" - mosly cuz I am all talk - if I do, it will be this place.  I will open Kasa.

Why Kasa - because its very cool, very affordable, very tasty, very innovative AND because its a little, just a little, chaotic.  Its very me.

You too?  Hmmm, thought so.
author: Stephen M.

description:
Very good food at a very good price. 
The selection is not big at all so don't expect to be staring at the menu for a long time. 
The server guy at the front explained everything very thoroughly and even let us taste some of the food :)
BIG portions if you get the Thali. I recommend the Chicken Tikka Masala, it's the best out of all the choices. 
Come with a HUGE appetite if you get this plate. 
oh and they conveniently divide the food into sections for you weirdos who don't like their food touching. it all ends up in the same place people!
author: Brenda S.

description: I support eateries that buy locally grown food. If it is organic to boot, that's even better. But with tastiness, prices and cleanliness this good...wow. It's my new favorite haunt. I only wish they did breakfast too.
author: Pant SF T.

description:
Food is pretty good. I was a little disappointed in the grilled turkey I got. It seemed to be a little dry and a tad too burnt on the outside. I think it is because this place was slammed for business and they appeared to be making stuff as fast as they could (can you believe they ran out of their Naan-ish wraps and thus held up the line?). In general, this was my biggest complaint - it seems like this place isn't set up to handle crowds very well (yet?) given that its a dude-assembles-it-for-you-like-Subway-ish kind of place. If you go during a rush, food may be cooked fast, you may be scuttled out of your seat as soon as you are done eating, you know...that kind of thing.

In general though, the ingredients were good, and the portions were decently sized (I got 2 rolls...and I was happily full). A little pricey, but that seems to be the trend with these nouveau deli-style places, so I wasn't too surprised. Nothing here that would prevent me from coming back, but I'd like to give it a little bit for the hype to wear off and for the place to get its ducks lined up a bit better.

As an added bonus though - hottie alert making wraps that day! She even had a hot accent and everything...nothing like some easy on the eyes service to help out the wait. Dear hottie, if you are reading this, and remember a dashing, chivalrous, USDA prime grade male specimen (who has a much smaller ego than that last sentence would suggest), and would like to meet him in person, write me!
author: Sean C.

description:
Call it an upscale/trendy Indian taqueria. They serve you like a taqueria, but the layout and decor definitely say "we're cooler than a taqueria."

The menu is limited, but maybe that allows them to focus on what they do best, because the food is really tasty. My girlfriend and I split a thali plate with chicken tikka masala and a 2 kati roll plate, one with chicken tikka and one with lamb curry. 

The chicken tikka masala had a kick - I was impressed - and the sauce wasn't overly creamy like you get at some other restaurants. The daal was too creamy for my tastes, but I'm probably unfairly comparing it to my mom's daal.

I was afraid the chicken tikka kati roll would be too dry without any curry sauce, but no, it was moist and delicious. The lamb curry kati roll was also great, but messy. I think the next time I eat there, I'll ask them to wrap the kati rolls in foil, so I can unwrap and eat like a burrito.

They have Kingfisher and a Belgian ale on tap (I had the Belgian ale) and they even have Thums Up and Limca in bottles! Pretty sweet.

Total for 2 plates and 2 drinks: $30 (poor value for a taqueria, great value for tasty Indian food).
author: Ranjit S.

description:
I went to Kasa last week and have thought about it almost every day since!!! It's great, you can either get the plate or the roll. 1 roll would be enough for me but I went with a friend and we wanted to try everything, so we got 4 rolls and split them each. 

My favorite - chicken tikka masala and the karahi paneer. 

This place gets 5 stars for a few reasons:
1) portions are HUGE!
2) price is reasonable $5.50 for 1 roll or $8.95 for 2
3) it's actually clean - yes it's clean!
4) the service is fast and friendly - a side note on the service, my favorite barista from Starbucks on Bryant is now at Kasa!
5) spicy- now some people have complained here on yelp about the spice level, let's get real, it's Indian food and it's supposed to be spicy. If you don't like spice, don't eat Indian food.

Great for take out or to eat in - good for 2 or a group. 

Finally, you can walk to Bi-Rite Creamery afterwards for some to die for ice cream!
author: Teresa J.

description:
Had a late lunch here today, and it was fine.  Had the lunch special with 2 katis, one chicken tikka and the other lamb curry.  The chicken was good (esp with the spicy sauce and raita), but the lamb was surprisingly lacking in flavor; not even much lamb flavor!

it's definitely a sterile, industrial feel.  Even though it was a warm sunny afternoon, it felt a bit cold inside...

not bad, I would go back if I'm in the area, but not worth a special trip.
author: John R.

description: Fast Food I can really stand behind!  I love ordering a Thali here (my favorite is the amazing lamb curry) and one minute later, you have your large plate, subdivided by numerous delicious accompaniments.  With a pint of fine beer on tap or the thick-bodied Lassis, you will have yourself a wonderful dinner.  Just try not to eat this totally addictive food way to fast (I always fail).
author: Thor T.

description: This place is fantastic and I'll definitely be coming back.  I ordered the paneer and chicken tikka masala plate which was delicious with all the multiple sides they loaded onto the plate.  The combo of chutneys, marinated red onions, and spiced cool yogurt with the bread was pretty delicious.  And you can't beat the price!
author: Jac J.

description: It was okay, I don't know what all the hype is about.  Tasted fine, price was fine, but nothing spectacular.
author: Melissa D.

description: The food was great, the service was great too however, I thought it being an indian restaurant there would be someone indian behind the counter or in the kitchen, I was surprised to see all non-indians working there. Seemed a bit odd. But the had good knowledge and were very courteous. They even have a food truck!
author: Praful G.

description: For something fast, inexpenive and light head to kasa. The lunch specials are a must with drink included under $10!
author: Melissa A.

description:
4 stars... but it should get 5. Here's why.

I found this place on grubhub.com which is also kinda awesome but that's for another reivew. I've ordered twice and both times I accidentally ate everything. That wouldn't have been a problem except it was enough for 2 days... for 2 people. Since then they stopped delivering to my area. Something about me living in the ghetto and guns and the food being cold by the time they managed to get past the bullets and the guns.

Anyway, that's my problem, not theirs. So now I'm gonna make this REALLY SIMPLE for you.

2 KATI ROLLS (chicken Tikka Masala)
ALOO JEERA
MANGO LASSI

Eat that.

Thank me later.
author: ShaColby J.

description:
Wandering around the Castro area and stumbled onto this place.

Wonderful experience.  Food was simple, tasty, spicy and cheap.  Had the Chicken Tikka which was nicely grilled, good flavor and not overly cooked (as in it wasn't cooked into a form of chicken jerky that one often gets in this sort of place).  

Service was friendly, and quick.  Plenty of seats.  

Bottom line - Fast food Indian.  Go, enjoy, you'll like it.  Worst case you'll have only spent a few dollars to try something new - a very low risk gamble.  I'll be back (actually thinking about it for lunch today!).
author: Andrea v.

description: This place is great for a quick, filling, delicious meal in the Castro. Definitely go for the chicken tikka masala and add the egg to it!
author: Jeff C.

description:
I have to start by saying that I've never really been in to Indian food, but that I'm trying to broaden my palate by regularly sampling different cuisines.

So, with that out of the way, I can say that I really like the concept of this restaurant. It's very clean (both in design and upkeep), there is plenty of seating, and the menu is pretty simple. The kati rolls aren't huge and they're not as cheap as a burrito of comparable size would be, but they are carefully prepared and served with a "garnish salad and cooling raita." I got the Chicken Tikka Masala. It was a little spicy for me (but, then again, most everything is) and it had quite a lot of raw onion, but the chicken was tender and tasty. The salad was definitely not my thing (a combination of diced carrots, peppers, cabbage, onions, etc.)--not, bad, just not for me--but the raita helped cool my tongue, just as they promised.

They seem to be very concerned with freshness here, as they waited to make my roll until there was fresh sauce, rather than giving me what was at the bottom of the pan. 

Also, they seem to have two vegetarian specials every day, but you have to know to ask for them, as they aren't posted anywhere. Today's were eggplant and cauliflower. 

In short, it's not my thing so I won't go back, but I will send others there.
author: Katie I.

description: Extremely efficient and personable catering. Lunch for 80 people, worked with our budget and gave us a very good price. Food was delicious and just the right amount. Delivery driver was on time, very helpful, with hot food. What blew me away was a reassuring email from the owner when I was having a panic attack the night before the event. Really professional with high standards.
author: Sara R.

description:
Kasa, like so so so many new eateries in San Francisco, has an identity crises going on. It's "nice" but its an indian tacqueria. It's fast-food, but it's not too fast. It's even Indian, without being Indian so much. Part of this is obviously intentional, but part of it wasn't.

The good news is that the food is really great. It's fresh, prepared right in front of you, it's flavorful and overall a success. Yes, its slightly Americanized, but really, you can't blame them for that because that's sorta what they were going for. Other good news includes the friendly staff, the wide-open windows, naturally-lit space, and the simple joy of having Indian sodas in bottles and two well-chosen beers, Tripel Karmeliet and Kingfisher (both PERFECT for indian food) on tap.

The bad news is that the service is really slow. Yes, they just opened, yes, they have a cute note saying "please be patient while we work out the kinks", but no, I won't let it go. The whole concept this place is a modern eatery, serving what are essentially Indian versions of a Burrito or a Shawerma. Therefore, speed is of the utmost importance.
The other bad news is the pricing per portion. I have two rolls on a plate with some raita for $9. The rolls were very small, delicious, but too small. This would be a killer deal if the two-roll plate was $6.95. But at $9, and with the wait we experienced, you're much better off getting a more authentic "indian junk on rice" at a traditional restaurant.

Good food, high prices, identity crises. Here's hoping they figure it out!
author: Tolga E.

description: Delicious food--I had 2 kati rolls (Chicken Tika, and Chicken Tika Masala)  They were really tasty, and surprisingly very filling.  They also have a nice selection of beer with some local Indian specialties.  Kingfisher was a highlight.  Very friendly service, patient employees, and street parking was a breeze!  Will definitely be back.
author: Mary S.

description:
5 stars for freshness, quality, simplicity and accessibility! Kasa has them all to the highest degree. Tonight was my inaugural night after previously sampling the Chicken Tikka Masala one day on my way home from work when I couldn't resist dropping into the inviting atmosphere; that had melted in my mouth and in the spirit of diversity, this time I opted for the Thali with Chicken Tikka & Lamb Curry (they let you sort of create your own configuration of main dish which is great); as with all Thalis, this was accompanied by veggies, yogurt, dal (as a nice twist, the owner, Anamika, was perched off to the side poring through the lentils to ensure the utmost quality which added a nice homey touch to the experience) and of course, flaky bread & rice. 

As for freshness & quality: the meat is savory soft and well-spiced. Note I am a vegan 90% of the time but since it's free range I have no qualms eating it here, esp. given how tasty it is. 

As for simplicity: 2 for 2 as menu offers the key essentials which again are happily configured by the helpful waitstaff; and the hours delightfully uncomplicated (11-10 7 days a week). 

As for accessibility:  the service is fast and the ambiance open and location is right off Castro so not in the obnoxious thick of things but still quite easy to get to. 

I'm so glad I live 1.5 blocks away so I can justify the indulgence on a regular basis.

11/20/08 update - check out the well-deserved buzz they got @ SFGate:
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/11/19/NS9B14653D.DTL
author: Diane B.

description:
FINALLY, something worthwhile in the Castro!  Great for drunken stupors and Indian cravings.  My friend Shilps and I talk about it ALL the time.  Kati is the new crack!   


I could go for some Tikka Masala raita 'bout now.

Props to the owner!
author: Paul D.

description:
I came here for a late-night dinner a few nights ago with some friends. I was impressed by how busy it was at 9pm on a Thursday, and excited to try out their menu.

When we walked in, I realized it was like Indian fast food - kinda like a Subway or a Chipotle. You stand in line, and then give your order to the first dude putting the wrap together. He puts something on it, then passes it on to the next guy. He asks you if you want raita and/or onions. And so on. Then they put it on a tray and you pay at the end of the line. 

The menu is pretty small - they only have about 6 different wraps (kati) to choose from and a few "meal" options. The entire menu fits in large print on the wall. I read the whole thing and decided I wanted 2 wraps; the turkey kebab and chicken tikka masala. The price seemed fair - $8.50 for two wraps.

As my kati rolls went down the line, I watched them being assembled, and everything looked and smelled delicious. When we sat down to eat, however, I bit into the kebab, and my friend, who also ordered the chicken tikka masala, bit into hers. We both started fanning our mouths.

It was wayyyyy hot! Adding raita and drinking ice water didn't help. Both dishes left the kind of burning sensation that blocked out all other taste, and my whole mouth was throbbing with pain after a few bites. However, I was so hungry (and of course wasn't about to waste $8.50 in food) that I continued eating only to stop the hunger, even though for the rest of the meal my lips, mouth, throat and stomach were on fire. 

I have always been sensitive to spice, but I usually order food at the "mild" setting, and I'm fine. Maybe I've just gotten used to living in a de-spiced, Americanized-ethnic food world and now assume that no choice of spiciness level equals a default on "mild". I also guess I could have asked about the spice level of the food before ordering. However, since none of the dishes had any warning about spiciness, I assumed they must all be relatively mild. You can always add spice, but you can't really take it away.

A few minutes into our meal, an employee came over to our table. He asked how we liked everything. I told him that it tasted good, but that it was a bit too spicy for me to have an enjoyable dining experience. He advised us to try putting raita on it. I explained that while I appreciated his advice, I had already tried the raita and it just wasn't enough - the food was too spicy. I asked him if they made multiple versions of the same dish so that you could order a mild, medium, or hot version. He apologized, saying there just wasn't enough room. Understandable. So then I asked if there were items on the menu that were less spicy. He said everything on the menu was pretty spicy, but that they had lots of food that wasn't on the menu; "you just have to ask". 

I thanked him, and he walked away. But actually, I was super annoyed by that response. It felt like he was in essence saying, "Well, we're not going to warn you that our food is ridiculously spicy, but if you *do* happen to burn your mouth off, then at *that* point, you should think to ask about food that's not on the menu." 

So, first of all, what restaurant has food that's not on the menu?!??! That doesn't make sense to me. If people don't know what you offer, how will they know to order it? I told my friends I had never heard of that concept, and they informed me that lots of restaurants do this. Apparently, this practice helps to make customers feel like it's "their" restaurant, so they can order "their" special off-menu dish, because they *know* about what's not on the menu.

If this is what Kasa is trying to do, then it makes me feel excluded, not included and part of the Kasa patron *elite*. If you don't at least warn me that your food is excessively spicy, then when it burns my mouth and makes for an unpleasant dinner, why would I want to come back? On top of that, you told me about other "off-menu" options *after* the fact that your food caused my dinner to be unpleasant and painful.

Also, throughout the whole conversation with the employee, he had a big grin (smirk?) on his face and a bit of a condescending attitude, which came off like "Well, it's not *our* fault you didn't ask for something that's not on the menu", when really, what I wanted to hear was, "I'm sorry it's too spicy for you. Next time, I would recommend ordering the _______. It's not on the menu right now, but it's a very mild dish and I think you'd really like it."

Sorry, Kasa, but your mix of chili powder and attitude will keep me away for quite a while. Maybe if one day I hear that you have options (and empathy) for those of us with sensitive taste buds, I'll try again.
author: Maria P.

description: Everything is well prepared and tasty.  My only gripe is it's agonizingly slow if you get stuck behind people with a million questions and/or who just aren't familiar with Indian food (or any food that contains condiments other than salt and pepper).  I realize it's the city and all, but it sure would help if they could put together more than one order at a time...so, maybe take a lesson from every taqueria in town?
author: Doug J.

description:
This place has a lot of potential, but it's going to have to work out some of the kinks.

I was very pleased at the friendly staff, which included one of the owners coming to our table and asking how the food was.  This usually doesn't happen in more formal restaurants, much less a place where you take the food back to your table.

I was a little taken aback by the limited menu choices.  There were basically two choices and 5 dishes.  The two choices were to have one of the main entrees as a wrap, or to have it as a plate of food.  If you had the wrap, then you could choose how many pieces.  (This was sort of like choosing how many inches you want your submarine sandwhich to be.)  We were hungry, so we choose the plate of food.

The plate was $11.xx and consisted of a portion of the entree that you choose, a portion of daal, a small naan, a little crispy vegetable salad, a very small portion of two different sauces, a taste yogurt side and a large pile of rice in the middle.  When I was done I was still hungry, which is not what I would have expected for the price and considering that the service is similar to a taquieria.

Still, everything did taste good, and I do think that with a little jiggering, that the place has a ton of potential.  Everything did taste fresh and good, and everyone that worked there seemed to be in great spirits.

UPDATE - The owner wrote me a follow-up email giving me details on how they were working on every issue I brought up.  I promise that I'll be going there again soon, and updating this review!
author: Trigby P.

description:
I went to Kasa for lunch the other day. I had the tikka masala, which was dry and rather dull. The rest of the food on my thali plate was neither very interesting nor very good. The friend I went with felt about the same. 

I worked in the South Bay for a number of years and don't think I ever went to an Indian place there that wasn't better. Well, maybe that one Indian buffet on Tasman. Why, oh why, won't Dasaprakash open a branch in the City?

Most of the Indian restaurants I've been to in the  South Bay are cheaper, too - I thought Kasa was a little overpriced.

Meh. Not awful, we might give it a second chance, but not what I was craving.
author: David G.

description:
So the hubby and I show up at our friend's house to go out for Sunday brunch...and they suggest Indian. I was mentally prepared for eggs, toast, maybe some smoked salmon, not Indian. Our friends must see the hesitation on my face and explain, it's not typical Indian - it's more like an Mexican Burrito place that serves Indian. This doesn't allay my concerns - but, I'm flexible and just need the two block walk to mentally prepare myself for Indian/Mexican whatever.

It is totally like a Mexican burrito place - you point to what you want and you can watch while they pull it all together for you. I get the Karahi Paneer Thali. It was fantastic! The portion wasn't huge - but not terribly small. I could have done with more lentils. 

Overall, they've done a pretty good job with what they're trying to do. It's not fine dining - it's convenient, quick, neighborhood grub. The 4 of us (plus a baby) were satiated for $45 and were able to sit and chat as long as we wanted.
author: Amanda S.

description: I ate the best samosa of my life at off the grid. The cilantro-mint (I think!) sauce on the side really clinched the deal.
author: Caroline C.

description: Haven't tried their kati roti rolls, as end up always getting lured into the Thali's, which provide an assortment of sides, sort of like ban chan of Indian food. Love the daals, mint chutney and raita. Would suggest the chicken tikka or the Turkey Kebabs, the latter of which are oh so authentic, bus no, seriously, they are good! Also pair it with a vegetable dish, which are generally pretty good, but can occasionally be hit or miss. Have tried the lamb curry a couple times and it seems a bit tasteless, so have learned to pass on it.  The great thing is all the yummy food doesn't make you feel heavy and bloated like most other Indian establishments. The thali is pretty filling, so if its two people with not so large appetites, maybe a thali and a roll is what the doctor ordered.
author: Summit S.

description:
I've come to think of Indian food as comfort food since moving to SF. Give me a large heap of rice and chicken smothered in butter tomato sauce and I'm in heaven. So I usually crave it on cold foggy nights when we're staying inside.

I think this place is more suited to a hot day when you want a cold beer and not too much to eat.

UPDATE: We went back a few evenings ago and had a better experience. They increased the portion size which was nice and the spices seem to blend better together. We ate our meal there and the atmosphere is nice - very lively and casual.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
I call this our local "Indian Taco" joint, since that's basically what you're getting.  We went right after they opened, and I was really disappointed - you needed 3 rolls to make a decent meal out of it; they were also really crowded/busy and botched my order.

However, we've been back a few times since then, and they've managed to work out most of the kinks.  Notably, the kati rolls have gotten much bigger, so that 2 rolls is plenty for me, or you can split 3 between 2 people.  The chicken tikka seems to be the best filling - flavorful and quite spicy.  Chicken tikka masala is very disappointing - don't expect a "traditional" tikka masala as your filling.  The lamb was OK, but a bit too mushy.  

Short answer: stick with the chicken tikka.
author: John H.

description: Not your average looking Indian eatery.  It definitely has a modern twist to it.  The food is a little on the pricer side and the food was okay.  The portions were small as well.
author: Ricky M.

description:
Absolutely great place to grab a bite to eat in the Castro.  Their food is wonderful and reasonable.  I highly recommend the turnip and sweet pea main.  I think it was a special, but it was so good.

It's clean, friendly, and fun!
author: Eric S.

description:
I have never maybe been so indecisive when reviewing a food place in the city.  At first I thought Kasa's kati roll was the best invention since the corn dog or fried Snickers bar.  With a kati roll, think Pancho Villa meets Naan N Curry.  It's Indian food rolled with roti (resembling a small burrito).  The first roll I tried was the chicken tikka masala, which was delicious but the other rolls went downhill for the most part after that.  I would give the chicken tikka masala close to a five, the lamb curry a solid four, and the rest of the rolls a three for an overall rating of a high three star for Kasa.

The chicken tikka masala and lamb curry are the standout rolls.  The sauces and seasonings on these dishes were above the rest of the dishes, and I'm not usually a huge lamb fan.  I've also tried the turkey kebob, chicken tikka, and a few of the other special vegetable rolls but each of those has lacked the flavorful ingredients found in the chikka tikka masala and lamb curry.

At 2 kati rolls for $8.95, this place is on the more expensive side for fast food but the ingredients do seem better than average.  With 2 rolls, you can get full, and 3 rolls for $11.95 you will be stuffed.  Your best bet is to get one chicken tikka masala and one lamb curry roll.
author: Josh K.

description:
Toned down, contemporary, self-service, fast-food, trendy Indian.  Emphasis on "toned-down".  Is this really Indian.  I'm for creativity and fusion cuisine, but this is a miss.  The flavors are boring and bland.  And the attitude at the cash register made the whole experience even worse.  Expect  to spend around $10 per person here.

If you're comparing this joint to other American fast food (i.e MC D) then it's a good place to go.  Otherwise, don't bother.
author: Paul K.

description:
Today is my birthday, but before I lay down to rest my eyes... I must say this is some dame good food. Professionalism, good food, clean and sanitary presentation equal 5 stars on my menu. Tim ...from kasa ( co-owner...)I want to thank you... You did a marvelous job so knowledgeable ...the crowd that came out to celebrate made the indian experience as realistic as possible .... I am very picky on comments. And all yelper's this is a real authentic review....... no review boosters here.


FYI catering is a plus... You must try it.
author: D Y.

description:
I like Kasa a lot and think it is a great value.  I like the humane and innovative approach they are taking towards Indian cuisine.

Pros:
- Alcohol: Kingfisher on tap!!!  I loved KF when I lived in India and am amazed to see it in the Bay Area on tap.  Also, a Belgian Tripel on tap which is incredible.  Good wine selection too.
- Atmosphere:  I like the sophisticated interior quite a bit.  The branding for the menu is also nice and clean.
- Food:  Great selection of both veg and non-veg mains.  I think I prefer the thali as the kati roll is messy and doesn't lend itself to slowly enjoying the food.  Raita and chutney were delicious.

Cons:
- Price:  I want to preface this by saying that Kasa is a great value!  However, everytime I go it feels a little bit like cafeteria-style food (in terms of preparation) with restaurant prices.  
- Kati rolls:  I wanted to like the Kati rolls a lot (Indian burrito?? I'm in!) but they were really oily and left my hands a mess.  All of the flavors mushed together in the kati roll and the food sauce kept on pouring over my hands and plate.

I think Kasa is my favorite Indian food in SF.  While more expensive than Naan n Curry/Chutney, I enjoy the food and experience (and don't get food poisoning!)
author: Jeff A.

description:
I tried this last night - finally! The food was good overall. Definitely a different take on Indian food, but a great addition to the neighborhood. I would recommend the chicken takka masala, but how cliche is that?!

It did take FOREVER, but I'm not going to knock the staff too much for that because I know they're working out the kinks after just opening. My suggestion to management: improve your employees' workspace, that'll speed them up.
author: Alex K.

description:
I remember when Kasa opened a little over a year ago. What a huge bonus to an already great neighborhood in SF!! When they opened, locals and tons of press raved about it straight away (7x7, Daily Candy, numerous blogs like this one, etc.). A year later, with awards under it's belt, it lives up to it's yummy reputation.

The most exciting thing aside from watching their already famous  kati rolls being made, hand-rolled and grilled on the spot, is a welcoming family-run feeling about the place. The food is delicious and unless you've traveled to India and had their street food, you'll be in for something surprisingly different in SF.

I always get 2 different types of Kati rolls because it's so hard to pick one dish...oh and try a homemade chai for the walk home. The chai is awesome!
author: Zuzy M.

description:
They made the smart decision to choose to keep their menu simple-- they serve only a few dishes and do them very, very well.  I am such a lightweight when it comes to spicy that I'm glad all dishes come with raita.  And their raita is great.  We sampled pretty much everything on their menu, with an Indian friend in the mix, and we all loved everything we tried.  Authentic and tasty.  And the staff was really friendly.  

And the price was right too.
author: Wilson H.

description: First Indian restaurant which had no Indian employees. Mango lassi was excellent. Thick with cardamom. Flavorful. Chicken tikka masala had an English touch to it. Aloo Jeera could be used in Pani Puranas (gol gappa). Food has a homemade feel to it. Thali with chicken tikka masala, aloo jeera, rice, roti, condiments and a mango lassi as part of lunch special was $11.06. Filling meal.
author: Sahil L.

description:
I saw this place on yelp first when scoping out restaurants in my neighborhood and vowed to try it. Then I asked an Indian (American born) what he thought and to my surprise he thought it was to spicy. Then I brought my British boyfriend and he thought it was perfect. Now when I raised that question - it is quite spicy, but I would place it more in the moderate category. They do give you some yogurt sauce to put out the fires with however. Anyway, it took a bit of deciphering to figure out the menu and what to order. You order the same dishes either Roti or Thali and all it means is they serve it to you in bread or you have the option to put it in yourself (like with fajitas). We weren't overwhelmingly hungry so we got the Plate with two dishes, Chicken Tikka Masala and the Daily Vegetable Special (they have two to choose from). It put mine in the roti and at it like that. Very tasty! They do have wine and beer as well btw, although I had a very sweet mysterious guava drink.
The decor is a little spars, to the point that the place seem too empty. I suppose it is too look modern, but it has been rainy and grey here the last couple of months and starring out into a dark wet world doesn't seem ideal right now. I sorta feel like I want to put some curtains in there. Then again I am always trying to redecorate everything haha! Anyway this place is a much better option (I think) to getting a tired old burrito - although you'll end up spending a little more. They also deliver after 6pm.
author: Alexandra G.

description:
I went to college in Delhi and needless to say Kati rolls were a part of our lives. I was skeptical walking into the trendy Castro cafe-like Kasa, but everything from the smells, fresh rotis and my favorite spicy green chilli chutney was India!

I always get 3 rolls (and they often ask me if I need 2 plates but it's all for me :) I recommend unda style with chicken tikka ~

While the Kingfisher is good for novelty (and I love love love that they have it on tap) -- the Belgian beers are way better than the Indian/ Singaporean beers :)
author: Shipra K.

description:
OK as usual I'll try to keep it short and to the point...

Kasa is very good.  However, don't expect the "charm" and authenticity of classic Tenderloin dives like Shalimar or Naan & Curry.  

Kasa is a definitely more upscale and serves a very fresh and simple menu to a more refined crowd; probably 60% of their business is take-away.  

I had dinner with two beautiful women and we tried nearly every roti item on the menu and washed it down with a draft Kingfisher and a Belgian ale (total was about $50).

It was a unanimous decision... Kasa makes some damn good roti, but don't expect as diverse a menu as in a typical Indian/Pakastani restaurant.
author: Marc H.

description:
Kasa has its ups and downs - but I feel most of the downs have to do with the food itself.  I visited Kasa twice and found the food to be really bland both times.  I was hoping the first time was just a bad day for Kasa,  but the food was the same during my second visit - bland and boring.  

I'm a vegetarian and ordered the veg thali plate both times.  I was so excited about the karahi paneer dish the first time (who DOESN'T like lots and lots of paneer?), but after a few bites all I tasted was cheese and very little spice and flavor.  I think the blandest item was the "slow simmered daal" that comes standard - there was absolutely no flavor to it at all.  In fact, it tasted like black beans all mushed up and heated out of the can.  My mother makes one heck of a good daal, and Kasa's interpretation doesn't come anywhere close to it.  Lastly, I found the roti to be extremely buttery and rich - but at least it had some depth to it.  My favorite item was the raita, an extremely difficult thing to mess up.

The service was great both times, and I was very impressed with how to-go food was packaged.  But when it came to the food, I just didn't enjoy myself that much.
author: Nina V.

description:
This place is the new Indian way of eating. The modern design of the interior and serving plates blend old world Indian Thali plates with best in class service and style.  When ordering, the staff are always smiling and helpful with menu items you might not be fully familiar with. 

Now on to the Food.  The Kati Rolls are simply awesome. You pick the best flavor you like to full them such as Chicken Tikka, or Tikka Masala, Lamb Curry, or my favorite the Turkey Kebab. They wrap the rolls tightly with an awesome fried bread.  Many have likened the experience to and Indian version of Chipotle, but I have to tell you it is much better.  Do your self a flavor favor and check this place out. It will not disappoint !
author: Devery J.

description:
Yummy!
I decided to try lamb for the first time in my life, and I can assure you that it was a great idea. 
Not the most amazing Indian food I've ever had, but a perfect place to get a light dinner or lunch that nips that craving in the booty.
author: Laura L.

description: Delicious indian food without the formal sit down experience. It's not necessarily the same as what you would get at one of the nice Indian buffets, but it's definitely awesome in its own right. You have two options - cute little burrito-like rolls, or a big platter with one or two entrees and several sides. I always opt for the former and sometimes a side of daal with rice. Both the chai tea and mango lassi are excellent too. The lassi is more yogurty/less sweet than most I've had in the past, which I love. I'm not an Indian food connoisseur, but I definitely love it here.
author: Caitlin J.

description: Had the aloo gobi and lamb curry plate. With all the accompaniments, it was like a mini feast. And the roti is soo delicious, as was everything else. Still, I wish the portions were bigger but I'm glad they weren't--my fat ass doesn't need to be any more so.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
This place is the cleanest fast food Indian place I have ever been to. The food was OK. I ordered Chicken Tikka Masala, Turkey Kababs, Mango Lassi, and Chai. 

The food here is spicy. (I am not a big fan of spicy food). 

The Mango Lassi has small grain size stuff inside of it. 

It was easy for take out for dinner.
author: Kathryn W.

description: I had the Lamb Curry & Rice.  Bad food. No spice and no flavor. Strictly for people who like their food bland and undercooked.
author: Vasudevan S.

description: I'm a huge Kasa fan!  They won me over on my very first visit.  The Kati Rolls are aawweessoommee (double awesome!) and the plates are delishhh!  You get to choose which meat/veggie option you want.  If you're going to order the Kati Rolls, I recommend 2 rolls as a meal, 1 for lighter eaters or those looking for a quick nosh... My personal favorites are the Chicken Tikka and the Lamb Curry... I've pretty much given up on everything else and only order the Lamb Curry now... Their yogurt sauce is cool, minty and compliments any of their dishes perfectly!  Prices are very fair.  Strongly recommend you check out Kasa if you haven't been here before!  I need to stop writing, just thinking about Kasa is making me hungry!!! ahhh I'm such a fiend!
author: Bobby P.

description: Like the food but not the deafening music. It felt like having lunch at a night club.
author: Prague G.

description: The food here is so good, so damn tasty and such a good deal, I can barely believe it. I would eat here every damn day if I could simply remember to do so. Just about perfectly executed. Freaking AWESOME. Thanks to my friend Peter for introducing me to this place.
author: Bowen D.

description:
I admit, it's a bit weird and "Americanized" to serve traditional Indian foods and flavors in a burrito-style roll wrapped with roti.

But Kasa is not having an identity crisis, nor is it pretending to be something it is not.  Quite simply, it is a new interpretation of Indian food designed to be quick and more affordable bites.  And I think it does a good job--the flavors are still there, and even though it is isn't necessarily made to order (they keep previously prepared food on a hot plate), the food is still quite good.

Love it for what it is.

There are plenty of traditional or "sit-down" Indian restaurants out there, and Kasa is not one of them.  However, I think it fills a nice niche of good quality, quick, and affordable Indian American eats.
author: Trix L.

description: Fantastic, nothing left on my plate. Will be back! Fast, fresh and finger-lickin good. Not bad eye-candy either.
author: George L.

description:
Pretty damned good Indian fast food. A tiny bit pricy, but so worth it. Well, usually. I have eaten there dozens of times and only had one bad meal (the chicken tikka was a little too charred). 

For the health-concious, you can get adjustable portions. And, they have vegetarian and vegan choices, like every good Indian place should.
author: Dave R.

description:
Love this place,  its offers something different in a neighborhood and city filled with cookie cutter food.  

Kati rolls are delicious, the yogurt sauce is delicious,  I can't wait to put them in my mouth, yummmm!
author: Princess T.

description:
I loved the kati rolls. My introduced me to the kati roll and found this place. It has easily become one our favorites and probably our best new find for 2010 [for us that is]. These things are like Indian street food burritos!

I love their chicken -- always cooked perfectly. The rotis are well made, very good absorbing the "gravy" or "russo" if I am gonna get ethnic on you. Spice levels are great as well. The thali plate is a lot of great tasting food but served in a more traditional format. 


We want to be regulars, so that when we walk in, they know us by name. We're well on our way!
author: Rahul T.

description:
Kasa had a lot of work to do because I had a special affection for the tasty burritos of the taqueria that was here before. The soccer games on the TV above the door. The red-stoner eyes and ready smiles of the servers...

The folks at Kasa are even friendlier than the taqueristas they replaced. This is one of those "fast casual" places that really is addictive. It's one of the staples of my diet now because it's easy and delicious (and affordable). I think there may be health consequences in eating too much, but that's why I'm taking up running again. 

My favorites are the lamb and the paneer. The little pepper-and-whatever-else-is-around salad they serve with it is sometimes amazing, sometimes ehn. But it tastes very fresh every time.
author: Tyler S.

description: Kati rolls were good.   Flavors and spice are what you would expect, but nothing drastically great about this place.  It's a good casual option, but nothing more.  Will be back when I'm looking for some easy and affordable Indian.
author: Ian F.

description: Loved stumbling upon this place. We had two thalis and I wish it wasn't our last day in sf, because we would've gone back for more. Everyone was really nice and the food was delicious. The only weird thing was they had compost, yet not compostable cups.
author: Skye F.

description:
Fantastic. Yummy! And the guy at the register hooked me up with a free small side salad cuz he thinks he messed up. Nah, he was just cute :)

Keep it up, boys, and add some more free veggie sides to bring me back more often!
author: Carrot C.

description:
**UPDATE**

It looks like Kasa listened to my suggestions because now they have delicious veggie options!  Bengat Bartha was devine!!!  

They also have mango lassi... yummm!

4 stars!!!

________________
I was super excited to find Kasa on yelp and decided to surprise my sweetie and bring him to this spot.  We are totally Indian food addicts, we even adventure down to Mountain View for chaat (we are city dwellers so this speaks a lot).  

I got the roti wraps which were delicious. The chicken tikka was juicy and with the perfect combination of spices. The rotis were excellent.  I would definately go back based on my meal.

However, my boyfriend was very disappointed (and I have to say after trying his dishes it disappointed me as well).  He felt that as a vegetarian all of the choices were extremely potato heavy and were bland. I have to say I tried the dal and it wasn't good at all.  

Kasa: Please make a flavorful, sauce based dish for vegetarians. Saag paneer, chana masala and bengat bartha would be some great choices.

I will be back based on my meat friendly meal, but veggie choices aren't strong.

NEW SAUCY VEGGIE DISHES PLEASE!!!!!!!!
author: Erica B.

description: Really yummy Indian "fast food". If you enjoy naan and lots of it, you'll love this place. My only complaint is the relative lack of thick cream-based curries like you might see in your typical Indian restaurant in the city. Even their CTM dish is a little too watery. No doubt this is for health reasons, and so it's forgivable!
author: Bryan K.

description:
The food at this "fast food" indian restaurant was pretty good for the price, but not if you like it spicy.  
Dining in this place was dreadful.  For a straight half an hour (or more) one of the employees was chopping onions right there where you order which made it extremely loud through the entire meal.  I lightly mentioned this as we paid and the person taking our money paid me no mind.  We finished our tea outside where we could still hear the incessant chopping.  I will not return.
author: Carlee C.

description:
Deliver to my house in 40 minutes on a Friday night?!  I would be a fan even if it tasted like cardboard.  Was so happy that I ventured out to eat there again tonight.

Had Kati rolls (chicken tikka masala and lamb) with a lovely beer (can't remember what kind). Am now full and happy!

Beer cost 6.50, slightly overpriced, 3 rolls were very well priced.  Roti a little overdone tonight, but still tasty.
author: Poppy C.

description: Terrible, food is awful and bland and just not like Indian food anywhere else.  Thank goodness. I miss the Taqueria that was there before, was so excited to get an Indian place nearby and so sad when I went there, waited many months tried again, terrible two out of two times. I am so shocked people like this and wonder if they have had Indian food before...
author: Joseph F.

description:
Yes, yes, yes! This place is one of my favorites in SF. Not only do I take my friends here when we are drunk after happy hour in Castro, I would take them here sober, which obviously means a lot!

I always get the plate with lamb curry and chicken tikka masala. I also love the cauliflower. I have to be honest though, I could probably just eat a whole plate of the raita and roti for days.
author: Danny H.

description: Woo!  This places rocks!  Delish, fresh, spicy food and the staff is very nice.  I had the lamb curry with potatoes and it is was tender and amazing, not greasy at all.  The side salad and the yogurt dip were also perfect!
author: Prexious R.

description: My go-to lunch spot when I was living in San Francisco. Really good lunch deals (lower price on the same quantity of food you'll get for dinner.) Everything was always fresh, the staff is kind, and the food is delicious.
author: Adam B.

description:
Its a 3 1/2 star rating.
