Finally a new choice in indian cuisine (which is just as diverse as the country). As far as kati rolls go, they have done a good job. The food is fresh and the vegetarian selections are yummy. 

However, i missed a couple of things - 1) some sort of spicy sauce and 2) Dessert!!! They dont have any.

Also, I wish i dint have to see them use their hands to pick up the meat and then make my veggie wrap. I am not a strict vegetarian, but someone who is will find it objectionable.
author: Paawan K.

description:
I was happy with the spice level of the food, but I was dismayed by the selection and service. 2 items to choose from? You could mix it up with having it thali (sandwich style or open face, but I wanted more than just tikka masala and masala potatoes (I think that's what it was). 

I was also dismayed by the speed that we got our order. With things so simple I would have thought it would take less than 20 minutes to go through 10 people. The line felt unnecessarily long. Or have an option to order, then another place to pick it up. We went at a late dinner time, but the line went out the door quickly enough. 

I am a harsh critic on Indian places in general, though, I admit. This place is fun to go if you are OK with the wait and the selection. 

The food, when you get it, is really good. Well spiced and at $9-$10 it is a good price. They also had some good Indian style fruit drinks. I haven't had those since I was in Bangalore. 

And since I'm a non-Indian, I guess my opinion doesn't matter as much. ;)
author: Benjamin T.

description:
Excellent SF-yuppified, white-bred Indian treats! 

The spices were perfect in my Chicken Tikka Masala and the yogurt sauce divine. 

One kati was simply not enough though and next time I'll order two to fill up.
author: Whit P.

description:
Perfect on the go meal, though there are some glitches still with getting you out of there quickly (could be because they've been training new staff). First time I went there with my friend, it was quiet. The guy with the braces making our meal was SUPER NICE-all sales and food reps should work towards attaining that level of godly customer service. He was chatting it up with us (more so than the cashier who had time to talk to us, though he was pretty nice too) and seemed genuinely interested and nice. Funny enough, I think the manager might have also been there, typing away on his laptop-I wasn't quite sure cuz this guy barely looked up, much less said hi.

The second time, we were barely acknowledged by the staff there (though it was probably because there was a line behind us since they were training a newbie who didn't even know what Chicken Tikka Masala was). By this time, I've tried most of their variations of Roti stuffings and I can definitely say that they are all good. The only downside would be that the portions are a little bit small for the prices, though they are somehow quite filling (I was full after one and bursting after two). The space is clean, modern and spacious. Side note: the salad and raita are a laughingstock-I thought they were sauces at first because they came in the same containers.
author: Jenny W.

description:
Decent food, okay price, good service. Overall pretty good but doesn't really stand out among all the great restaurants in SF to me.

They have a unique approach to your typical Indian dishes which was fun. My favorite filling (and I tried all 4 of the meat options) was the Turkey Kabab roll, tons of flavor.
author: Audrey N.

description:
Kasa, Kasa, Kasa...

We ordered delivery, which they stated would take one hour. It took two hours and we live 2.1 miles away. So after waiting two hours for the food we were starving...however, we don't think our being famished influenced our experience of the food. 

We ordered the kati rolls: chicken tikka, chicken tikka masala, lamb curry and aloo jeera. They were all amazingly delicious but our favorites were the lamb and the chicken tikka masala. 

We definitely will eat here again because the quality and flavor were superb. I hope they improve their delivery service.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
A quick and easy, matter of fact, artimede light-fixtured spot for a tasty little indian nosh. This place still has a bit of new car smell left in it, 4 months after opening. A nice addition to the neighborhood. 

Seviya Kheer (Vermicelli Pudding) was the night's dessert special. Never having tried it before, I didn't know what to expect, but loved the texture of noode-ly bits in this light and refreshing, pistachio-ed meal-finisher-upper.
author: rebecca z.

description:
I agree with the enthusiasm expressed by most other reviewers.  I want to add my appreciation that they compost everything possible, which I wish more places did instead of sending everything into the trash.  

I also want to add too that it is surprisingly a good place for kids, although you're not likely to see many in the Castro.  I went last night with my 4 year old and one year old.  They had a high chair and booster seat (very unusual for the Castro).  All of us loved the fabulous homemade mango lassi.  My one year old liked the dal/raita/roti, and my four year old liked the lamb kati roll, even though it was a touch spicy for him (but, really, none of the food here is all that spicy).  You can also get kati with just egg, which the friendly owner recommended for kids.  

Despite the fact that the kati look like mini burritos, the food doesn't feel fake -- to me the flavors were more fresh, vibrant, and interesting than most indian places in town, although I'm guessing the real thing is a lot spicier.  Is that cilanto chutney in the kati?  I guess I'd be interested in hearing what indian food sophisticates think of Kasa.
author: Victor O.

description:
Nice industrial chic decor with "Slumdog Millionaire" aesthetic (black and white snaps from rural india on otherwise bare walls, with chalkboards thrown in to further rusticate the experience). A very yupster/huppie crowd queued up to decipher the menu, which I find very intelligent.

Kasa leverages an "iPod strategy" (constrain choices to produce radical simplicity) to help a Castro audience appreciate (a specific genre of ) indian food. It calls itself an "indian Taqueria", to help San Franciscans relate to the Kathi Roll (by virtue of its similarity to burritos?), and you can have em with any one of the 5 standard fillings, and a daily special. Additionally, there are "bundles" (2 roll combo, and a lunch discount). If you like to skin your iPod, get it with egg on the inside. The best part is the "Thali" (which Kasa describes as a "deconstructed Kathi Roll), which I always thought of as a synthesis of various things, but must admit, is better understood as a ripped open Kathi Roll. The visual merchandising and decor are impressive, and marketing is FAB!

The execution could improve, perhaps the rolls could be packed a bit "longer" than "fat", to make them easier to bite into (unless we are expected to eat them with a fork, eww!). Maybe a paper/foil wrap will make handling easier. There is a decent selection of beers, but for "street food gone upscale" I would expect larger pints with less head.

Good start - I think Kasa is onto something. I patronize them whenever I have a craving for parathas, panneer etc. (and lack the stomach for Shaalimaar/Pakwan's greasefest) - but its only a matter of time before someone comes up with "an Udipi to their Dosa".
author: Amit S.

description: My favorites are the Lamb and Potatoes with Hot Chutney and the Turkey Kebab.
author: J T.

description:
I love the food here. It's a good break from the typical Indian restaurants in this town. Also, unlike the let's-keep-it-real Indian places, I like the fact that the people working here are pretty friendly. 

The food is excellent, but it's a bit pricey for the portion. I had almost everything there and nothing has disappointed me. I love the roti. You can get extra one for just a buck...which is a bargain. The mango lassi is very good and their Chai is pretty damn good as well. Thumbs up ;)
author: Yung K.

description:
Really good food, served fast with friendly service. Reasonably priced lunch special. 

Sometimes the dance music is a tad loud, but that's a quibble.
author: Wayne B.

description: This is the best place to go for Indian food! Having been throughout India, can safely say this is as authentic as it gets! Great service, delicious food and they even have Kingfisher. AND it's cheap - less than $15 for a meal. Just go here. Period.
author: Kate D.

description: Shannon B hit the nail on the head.  Although the food is very tasty, and it's very affordable, and the staff is very friendly, I have to say that it's become somewhat of a joke between my roommate and I.  Every time (and I mean, every time) we eat here, although we enjoy the food at the moment we are eating it......we are forever cussing ourselves hours later.  All I can say is thank God I live across the street, and the bathroom is nearby.  I LOVE Indian food, and have never been bothered by spicy food before, but whenever I eat here, I'm in agony.  We keep "testing" ourselves because we like it so much (and hey, it's really convenient).  It's just not conducive with our digestive systems.  It's interesting that others mention this fact too.  HMMM
author: Vance P.

description:
Love this place.  No fuss- just honest to goodness flavorful indian "burritos".

Get three and save some for later.
author: Donny B.

description: Nice! Came here today. Clean vibe. Good tasting food - it was fresh and delicious. Great portions - one plate was large enough to food two ladies! Wish they had endless chai!
author: Erin P.

description:
I've been a HUGE fan of Kasa since they opened last year.  Their food is super fresh and unique to SF.  The Castro definitely needed a place like Kasa that offers good, healthy, affordable food!

Because I love Kasa so much I approached them to sponsor our softball team and they said YES!  The "Hot Messes" are throwing a fundraiser on February 22nd from 2-7p to support the San Francisco Gay Softball League.  There will be $3 beers, good people, music and $5 mixtapes provided by me Ms. Jackson.  Please come to support 2 awesome local businesses!

Keep on eatin'!
author: Leah J.

description: Seriously. Hard to find delicious delicious indian food in SOMA. But these guys rock. Their Chicken Tikka was just like mom makes.  All the great taste without having to undergo parental inquisition.
author: Justin S.

description: i'm not changing my stars, since i havent eaten here since Aug 2008 when i last reviewed it. i dont live around the corner anymore. BUT, i did hear they now have mango lassis so j and i stopped in to try one today. they are gross. $3, mine was CRUNCHY and didnt taste mango-y at all. it was orangey. j managed to finish his but i threw out mine. the guy at the counter was nice and asked if i didnt like it and tried to give me a free chai. i almost took it but i wasnt in a chai mood. so i wont take off any stars..just they must be made in a totally different style than we are used to. i will not get one again.
author: Merredith L.

description: Casual, quick, delicious food. The rolls tend to be a bit oily and doughy for my taste, and they could put more meat in them, but what is lacking in quantity is perhaps matched with savory goodness. They also serve very nice beers. For the amount of food, one would probably pay less at other places.
author: Leo D.

description: Nice simple fast food. Thali plate is LOT of food at a decent price.
author: Joey D.

description:
I went for lunch on the first day Kasa opened, so there were a few very small kinks that will easily work themselves out.  The decor as others have said is minimalist, clean and open.  The service was great.

O.k., the food.  You are in control of the portions, which is great if you either like a smaller portion than the average American eatery  (me) or are starving.  You can choose from one to three (I imagine you could get more) Kati rolls or a thali plate.  For the Kati rolls, a savory filling is wrapped inside a roti flat bread and served with a refreshing side salad and raita.  I had the paneer cheese and the chicken tikka massala.  The roti bread was made upon order, so it was fresh & toasty, the filings were fresh and spicy.  All of it went great with my King Fisher beer.  

I am happy that the chef/owners are using high quality meat & vegetables because it shows in the taste and appearance of the food.  As others said, the menu is well edited, offering 8 choicses, two of which are vegetarian.  I hope they'll bring in one non-spicy, kid-friendly kati so I can go for lunch alone and dinner with my tiny ones.  

This was a great lunch, a great addition to the neighborhood and a well needed change from the standard sandwich or burrito.
author: Kat M.

description:
I hope this place does well. Think of it as an Indian Taqueria, which is a nice change to the dozens of burrito shops in every neighborhood. The food was full of flavor and spicy! The person behind the counter was very helpful for my first time visit. 

I had the Chicken Tikka Masala and Kebab. Both really good and I was full before I could finish the second one.

This is a great place for a quick and easy meal in the Castro when you don't want a slice of pizza or a burrito.
author: Gregory W.

description:
Mi Kasa e Su Kasa.

Kasa is yummy for my tummy Indian food in a cool urban atmosphere.

I LOVE the metal trays, the uber-simple menu, the perfectly spiced dishes, and the husband and wife duo who run the joint.  I HOPE they iron out some of their flow issues, and make sure that A) there's enough chow for the customers in line and B) the line moves FAST.  Seriously, given that there are like only 6 menu options (most of which are a combination of any three items), it really shouldn't be that hard to slop down the goods and get us through.  

Once they perfect items A & B, they should be rolling.  Hopefully, then, they'll be rolling on out a second location in my neck of the woods.
author: Luna K.

description:
We happen to walk pass by this restaurant a few weekends ago and saw that it was quite packed. So we came back today and got dinner there and to my surprise and delight, it was not bad. It's a rarity to find a quick and affordable Indian food, and this one does offer that.
I tried their Kati Rolls (2) with their Chicken Tikka and Turkey Kebab for under $10. What a delight.
author: Chad B.

description:
Finally! SF has long been in need of a joint like this. It was lightyears (or maybe just 7 years) behind NYC in the kati roll department.

As far as the rolls go, i'd say they taste fresher and much less greasy than those at the Kati Roll Company in NY (real hole in the wall, but nevertheless good) although the fillings offered here are different and not entirely traditional. Turkey kabob, eh?

Actually the turkey one was pretty damn good. Chicken tikka masala, another unusual choice for a filling, was even better. The other choices are all pretty common variations. Still have to try the karahi paneer.

I especially liked the raita and little side salad that accompany the rolls. They're a good contrast to the heavy, fatty rolls and will make you feel like less of a glutton. Yes, despite the fact that you are ingesting more food.

Lets just get one thing straight here people... it seems like a lot of San Franciscans are seeing this restaurant as some kind of Cal-Mex-Indian fusion place, as so many confused souls are using the term "indian burrito". There is not, and has never been, any such thing as an Indian burrito. These are kati rolls, an 100% indian snack that was NOT invented by some indians who moved to california, fell in love with its food and hipsters, and decided to open up their own wacky version of a burrito place on 18th street. No.

After all, do you go around calling moussaka "Greek lasagna"?
author: A K S.

description:
Chipotle meets Indian food, that tastes like Italian food, presented like Mexican food. It's not that great, especially for the high price they charge.

My chicken tikka masala tasted more like a cacciatore, and the tortilla-like thing they give you was hard and stale. Where's my naan?!?

I will say the yogurt sauce (raita) and condiments weren't bad, but for the same $12, I'd be much better off at an Indian buffet.
author: Kenny P.

description:
I just went into Kasa on 18th Street the other night. What a great experience. The food was excellent. I had a sort of Turkey kebab roll that was spiced just right. I also had a side of diced veggies that had a mild dressing. They served it up instantly and with a smile, and even with a chai tea, the meal was under $10 bucks. The owner dropped by my table to say hello and I got to observe the many people walking up and down 18th Street. 

If you want to eat good food, served quickly - and you don't want to wait at the neighboring spots, this is a find.
author: Greg J.

description:
I guess the owners read the yelp reviews, and Tim (one of the three owners replied) saying that they never got my email.  I thought that was kind of funny since usually when an email does not go through the server accounts (Google, Hotmail, and Yahoo) will send you a generic response on why the email failed to reach the recipient.

Anyhow, the point is that Tim did respond which was very gracious of him to do so.  We discussed what might have happened with our order.  He said that he would notify his staff of the yelp special, but then they just took it off yelp entirely because I'm guessing they didn't want to deal with another headache review if the staff failed to comply again.

Overall, how could I not give the restaurant four stars.  Tim did reply to me with an apology.  He invited my family and I back to the restaurant on them to correct the not so pleasant experience the first time around.  We did have to email back and forth for over a month or so, but he stood by his word.  Perhaps the holiday season is not the time to have big expectations, but it shows that most good restaurants have someone follow up on customers' negative reviews and make them positive ones.  

So all in all, if you don't like your food or the service you received, I noticed if you are polite about bringing it up to the owner(s) attention that the good ones do reply in kind.  Trust me, I had to deal with some of those reviews myself with my parents' restaurant when they had it running.  I realized that if you sincerely apologize and then offer a solution that meets both parties' expectations then the customer is usually grateful for that and will return.  So it's a win-win for everyone.

Happy holidays everyone, and may 2011 be a wonderful year for all.  :)
author: Maggie L.

description: Very very good.   I am indian and I know my food.  This place is quick, cheapish and delicious.
author: A K.

description:
Could get addicted to this little place. I had been eyeing it for a while, but the husband is not very into Indian food, so hadn't had much chance to check it. Then on Friday I was like, "OK, we are trying it" and had to come back two days later, I loved it so much.

The space is nice, sorta industrial-sparse, but comfy. The big windows, on a sunny day like we've been having as of late, make it terribly inviting inside. There's no clutter, the lower tables are lined up to the wall, with some high tables in the middle. Concrete floors, and a counter in back. Everything looks sparkling clean.

The lunch deal is awesome - 2 Kati rolls and a drink for $7.95. I had a chicken tikka masala and an aloo jeera roll. The bread they use is amazing - fluffy, light and oh so tasty.  I came back a couple of nights later after a few beers and the spicy food was just what I needed to get me home satisfied. The food leans towards spicy courtesy of the spicy sauce they add, so you may wanna tell them to go light if you can't handle it. 

People are super-nice. I'll be coming back here often - The one bummer is that I can't take this place on the road with me when I am away...!
author: Marcelo T.

description: Place was extremely clean. It's open late. And it's fast.  They have some great Kati Rolls. It was intimidating for me at first cause other than one experience with Indian food it is new to me. It's almost like a taqueria place. (But definitely NOT a taqueria) Where everything is on their counter and you can choose a plate meal or a Kati Roll for $4.50 The roll is a nice size for the price and VERY tasty. I'll be back for sure.
author: Ms. T.

description: I think I'm in love.  I just had my first meal at Kasa and I can't wait to go back.  The food was delicious and fresh, and I loved the service.  Everyone was so friendly.  We couldn't decide which wine would pair well with our meals, so they gave us a personal wine tasting!  The decor is slick and modern and they play cool house music.  They've honored Indian tradition through the amazing food, but created an ambiance that is fresh and cool.
author: Michael P.

description: Delicious all the time, but especially affordable at lunch when they have tasty and cheap specials. If going at dinner, be advised that 3 Kati rolls is a nice dinner for two, on the cheap!
author: Beth T.

description: Stumbled upon this place while strolling through the Castro. I was pleasantly surprise by how delicious and well prepared the food was. They have perfectly executed fast casual Indian food. Their samosas are great, but I really like the combo plate because it lets you sample so much. Whenever I want to go out for a casual dinner this is a frequent pick.
author: Anthony M.

description:
i love this place! i go there 1-2 times a week. The plate with the tikka masala is fantastic, and i love that the sauce isn't overly creamy or sweet. or sometimes i go for a side of Daal and some rice, the daal is perfectly creamy and spicey....and always, always EXTRA RAITA.

Kasa if your reading this....your raita is amazing...i could bathe in that raita i love it so much...i i have been on a quest to recreate it at home with no luck !
author: Pauline M.

description: What a great concept. When a friend suggested, I was immediately intrigued as being Indian I always liked to see this cuisine fused. Kasa did not disappoint. The kati rolls were delectable. The turkey kebab is super spicy and delicious. The bread is perfect to hold the ingredients and allow for dipping into the perfectly spiced raita.  It may not be super traditional but it is super tasty. Get a kingfisher to go with your meal and enjoy!
author: Alexandra S.

description: We catered Kasa for my daughter's first birthday party at Crissy Field and it was the best catering I've ordered. It's not cheap- but they were on time and the food was de-lish!!!  We ordered the Baigan Bartha, Kadai Paneer and Gobi Manchurian rolls. All three were super tasty. They delivered on time and the delivery guy was super nice....he even offered us matches when he overheard us  figuring out a plan B for how to light her birthday candles. It was overall a great experience!!!
author: Reena B.

description:
Kasa had a great concept in serving kati rolls - an Indian street food concept which has been missing in the Bay Area... The ambience is nice, the staff is friendly, the price is not cheap but not unreasonable, however the execution in terms of food flavor is quite lacking.  
  
The food is ok at best.  If you have no idea what authentic Indian food tastes like you'll probably like it.   Saw only one table with Indian customers, and none amongst the servers or staff - yes, I do think that it takes an Indian chef to cook or at least create that authenticity.

We found the chapatis (used as the outer part of the roll) smelling of oil.  The chicken tikka masala was like grilled chicken with ketchup, the turkey and lamb curry was bland.  I just don't understand why you would try to wrap a curry in a roll - it was dribbling out every time we picked it up for a bite.  The paneer was the only tasty thing we had amongst our group, and the side raita and salad was nice too.

What really irked me was the sign on the menu explaining the "thali" as a deconstructed roll.  That is totally ridiculous, and I don't know how they get away with it in an area where so many people will actually know the truth.
author: S C.

description:
As much as I welcome a new restaurant in the Castro and applaud someone for trying an interesting new concept, I can't recommend Kasa -- at the moment.  There are a lot of tweaks and kinks to work out when first opening a restaurant, and hopefully the process is ongoing.

I wanted to like it. I really did.  The concept is simple and straightforward, the service is friendly and the ingredients are fresh.  

Maybe the Kasa-ians have been reading Yelp and trying to make adjustments because my chicken tikka masala was anything but bland.  It was practically nuke-ular, to quote a lame duck.  The chicken didn't stand a chance, it was so seriously outnumbered by whole peppers  (the stems still in tact I assume to provide some justification for spitting beyond not liking the food).  Just for fun I decided to count and my humble single serving had 15 whole peppers.  Thank god I didn't order it in wrap form and dive in unaware, I'd have never been able to sit down again.

I remain hopeful for Kasa, but dine at your own risk for the time being.
author: Matt O.

description:
This place has a cool, modern vibe.  I stopped by yesterday after work for dinner.  It's fun that they serve your food cafeteria style and you get a little variety when you order the thali plate (like I did), which makes it really affordable if you're grabbing something to-go for just yourself.   I really liked that they had a simple menu, saving me time agonizing over what I should get.  My boyfriend was happy.  The main dish I chose was the chicken tikka masala.  It wasn't really anything special.  It wasn't creamy and definitely did not taste like any chicken tikka masala, I've had at authentic indian restaurants.  I did enjoy the buttery roti and daal tho- 
delicious!  I definitely will give this place another try but next time I'll try one of the Kati Rolls, bc the roti was that good.  But with something vegetarian inside, bc I didn't enjoy the chicken.
author: Kristinalisa M.

description:
Although this restuarant offers something different than the umpteen other indian places in the city, the food here isnt anything special.  
The kathi rolls tasted nothing like the authentic ones i've had back in india. 
 The roti used to wrap the filling (chicken tikka or turkey kabab etc.) was too soggy. The veggie kathi roll was too bland. and I was still hungry after eating a couple of rolls.  Stick to your neighborhood Naan and Curry... better bang for your buck.   Sorry, i can only give this place 2 stars.
author: Gokul R.

description: Convenient location, fast and friendly service, and reasonable prices are among the strong points here. Delicious and expertly prepared food, unfortunately, are not. The chicken tikka was good but not excitingly so. The potatoes might have been good had they been more than slightly above room temperature. The dal was thin gruel indeed, mostly liquid with few lentils. Overall, the food is quite adequate without ever actually being good.
author: David K.

description: Delivery driver didn't have enough change for 2 $20s.   I generally tip well, and I forgive him that he was expecting ~$9 tip on a $23 dollar order, so *maybe* I shouldn't have been so stunned after I asked him to bring back change and he snapped back my thali plate and khati rolls in disgust and declared he would never return.  Be careful quibbling over change, maybe no soup for u too.
author: john X.

description: Awesome value, awesomely quick, and quite tasty.  The Roti is top notch, and the variety and amount of food you get quickly for 10 bucks is pretty hard to beat in this town.  I love the idea, and I love that it works.  Hooray for Kasa!  A great tasty dinner option for those nights when you just don't want to cook or shell out a lot of money for dinner.
author: Sean H.

description: This is the worst Indian I've had in San Francisco.  There are so many better places in San Francisco.  The food was cold the flat bread they served was greasy and had a bad aftertaste.  You have to stand in line to order and then clean your own table.  Definitely won't go back.
author: J B.

description:
Kasa is great for three reasons:
1. I love Indian food and I love things that are close to my house, Kasa is both. The food is great and quick. And it is right on the corner of Noe and 18th.
2. The food is separated on the plate. So I know that the point of some foods is to mix them together and enjoy however I am from the camp of my food not touching and Kasa's cafeteria style dishes allow me to quite enjoy my neuroses. 
3. Indian style burrito!
* here is the only down side, as a vegetarian I felt that there were not as many options that I could get at a more traditional Indian restaurant. The menu is small but the food is amazing.
author: Jessica G.

description:
Ina  few words--it is the INN-N-OUT of Indian Food... great wraps and chai...
haven't tried the thali.. bcoz I love inn-n-out ;)

great selection of vege and non-vege food... a go-again place for all !!
author: hardik k.

description:
I love love love this place. The one thing that really brings me back is the service. Everyone that works there are so friendly and welcoming. They don't make me feel bad if I go here two days in a row.

The food is great. I always get a plate of both of the veggie dishes of the day and it is always amazing. My only "complaint" would be I wish it was spicier. I love my food to burn my mouth and the hotter the better. I guess this might be just right for most people but its a little too mild for me.
author: Karen B.

description: I absolutely love this place and go here for lunch whenever I can! The 2 kati roll special is a great deal! I'm not sure which I love more, the food or the delicious mango lassi!
author: Robyn C.

description: Anesthesized Indian food. Toothless and lame, this place is a dissappintment. I had a Thali with lamb curry and a cauliflower curry. Things were watery, gamey and altogether unimpressive. It was actually watery. Not saucy. Watery. Not worth saying more. Don't bother.
author: Mario T.

description:
This is the only Kati roll type of place that I know of in San Francisco. They have a good selection of different rolls which I really appreciate.

I personally liked the chicken tikka, the paneer and the lamb curry. Since the selection is quite limited, the ordering and service is fast. Its great for picking up on the go.

I also ordered the thali for the first time. Lots of little dishes, dahl, side, saland and raita along with the main subji and roti. It wasn't a lot of food but enough to keep my hunger quelled.

Its simple and clean decor make dining quick and hassle free. I rate this place quite highly though to get the maximum rating there's got to be a bit more 'twang' to the grub.
author: Krishnan S.

description:
I LOVE Indian Food! 

If you like it spicy - come here, it's fairly priced and it's great! 

Downside - they don't have buffet! LOL 

If you like buffet style go to Star India... good Indian food as well and very affordable.
author: Charlage W.

description: This is more 4.5 stars, but I believe in rounding 4.5 down to 4, and it's not quite as good as Vik's Chaat, although close. Delicious, simply prepared Indian food. They prove that you can have quality food at low prices.
author: Mark A.

description: Kasa is one of those places that constantly tempts you to toss your cooking plans aside for the night and roll on in for  some tasty treats. I have had countless nights where I've started to cook some bland boring ass meal and then thought, maybe I should just get some kati rolls and a chai instead. Don't even get me started on their chai. Good God, that is some good stuff. I stop by at all sorts of random hours just to grab a chai and nothing else. Chicken Tikka Masala is incredibly yummy, in a thali or in a kati. The staff are really friendly and cool. It's also a good spot on a warm night, since you can sit outside and eat.
author: Becky P.

description:
This place was awesome! Great concept (I wish I would have opened my own restaurant like this earlier), great food, and great ambiance.

When I went, there was a line out the door, but the service was pretty efficient, and we actually managed to find a place to sit. 

Just like Chipotle, but waaaay more interesting..
author: Amit S.

description:
I have been to Kasa on 3 occasions (once for lunch and twice for dinner) and have had similar experiences each time.

Food - the quality of the ingredients is good and they point out that they use free range and grass fed meats. The chicken in particular was tender. I've had the chicken tikka, chicken tikka masala and the lamb. The only downside is the serving sizes - they mete out the smallest quantity of raita like it was being rationed, same with the veggie fresh salad - what's up with that? I like that the food is spicy with nice flavors.

Decor/Vibe - a bit spartan, hip, modern but with a funky layout so you stand in line in the middle of the restaurant with people eating around you, and then you have the pleasure of standing in front of the bathroom when you order your food, which seems a bit too close for comfort.

Service - Sure, I know it's a new restaurant and all, but service is maddeningly slow - which would be so easy to fix. How many people does it take to make a roll? At Kasa I counted 1) the woman who asks you what you would like and is in charge of the rolls and then spreads the chutney (again, as if it was being rationed) 2) the guy who gets the tray and asks again what you've ordered and makes the roll. 3) the guy who scoops the raita and salad. I think I waited 10 minutes in line and 5 for the making of one roll.  You can also look in the back kitchen and see loads of people - not sure why speed wasn't emphasized - go into any burrito joint and they speed down the line. Each of the servers seemed timid, unsure of the serving sizes. Also darn hard to hear what they are saying. 

The people who work there are friendly and all, but they look and act like they should be working at a clothing store instead of a fast food indian restaurant. Maybe they should hire some people who've worked at a taqueria to teach them some operational tricks.

Value - I think the value is OK, but the serving sizes could be notched up just a bit

I would like to like this restaurant more, but I get so frustrated at the wait and slow service.
author: Spoon G.

description:
A truly solid meal, for a decent price.  I kind of dig the short menu - you gotta figure if it makes the cut, it's gotta be good.  Ok, so I'm not entirely sold on the roti.  I grew up with 'em and so it'll take a bit more to wow me.  The chicken tikka masala was a clear winner, leaving me to curse my decision to start (and subsequently get filled up on) the paneer.

Point being, you should give this place a shot, check out the beautiful people about, tuck into something tasty, and complement the spice with a cool bubbly beverage of dubious nutritional value (Thums Up - taste the thunder!)

ps. Yes, it's spelled that way.  T-h-u-m-s.
author: Sujit R.

description:
This place really IS as good as it gets.

Kasa makes my heart sing for its concept, its attention to detail, and its crazy love for all things spicy. Literally, if you've sat here for over 5 minutes you've seen the cooks grinding up their spice mixtures fresh in the kitchen. (I really doubt anyone who cooks here has ever in their life used the ubiquitous pre-made spice known as "curry powder". ) Way to do it up right.

I would give this place an extra star, if I could, just for the fact that they only have two beers: Kingfisher and a Belgian Tripel. A Belgian Tripel is the hands-down best beer pairing for Indian food. Magic.
author: Laura S.

description: I had been putting this place off to the side because I had heard the portions were small.  Not a good thing in my book, no matter how the food tastes.  Well, went with my good friend Andy C. and he had the lamb wraps which tasted great [he shared the lil guys] and I had the lunch plate special.  My food was pretty dang good.  It seems more yuppie flavored than authentic like Indian oven or even Bombay, BUT, in true yuppie style, everything was fresh and presented well.  The staff was really nice and seemed used to having to explain their menu [think Asqew] and the lunch special was like 8 bucks [$1 more if you want a pint of PBR on tap!].  I was full and happy when I left [I had the turkey kabob, not a favorite.  and the chicken tikka masala, yum!  I'll get the lamb next time.]  The vegetarian options looked good too.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Wonderful food, and the chai is incredibly good. Watch out for the hot sauce though: they aren't kidding around.

The thali is a great lunch option and is a huge amount of food: two entree items, yogurt, bread, rice, lentils, chutneys and salad. All excellent. I'm a big fan of the karahi paneer and lamb options. I also appreciate that they have daily specials, and sometimes there are Anthony's cookies at the register!
author: Matt B.

description: I really like this place for quick Indian food in the city.  It tastes real fresh and is always very complex in flavor.  The sag paneer is really good - maybe one of the best in the city and the gobi aloo and the aloo something with cumin are also really tasty.  The vegetarian options are really a cut above a lot of Indian places.  I usually get the kati rolls and it's a great snack with yogurt and salad on the side.  Really good price.  Last night my boyfriend and I had kati rolls and decided to split a thali platter and they were so nice they gave us chai and extra sides on the house.  I don't live in the neighborhood but whenever I drive by if I have time to stop I get a roll.  I highly recommend.
author: Heather K.

description:
Fell very short of my expectations. I've been sick at home in bed and had to find a place nearby that delivers. Kasa is 0.3 mi from my house, yet somehow I was quoted an hour and a half wait time...seriously?
I got the chicken tikka masala and the portions were very meager. I had 2/3 as much rice and a spoonful of chicken. Also ordered a chai tea since they have a $15 delivery minimum.
I shan't be returning. Probably would've been better off making some old fashioned chicken noodle soup at home.
author: Alona N.

description: Unquestionably my favorite chicken tikki masala in the city. Perhaps even my favorite dish in the city. It's a little bit on the spicy side, but that's how I like it. Great music, awesome staff, and at least a few beers to choose from. If you want something fast, seasoned and delicious, this is the place to go.
author: Doug C.

description: The portions are more filling than they look. Always good food here, the optional spicy sauce is very spicy.
author: Thom N.

description: Delicious lunchtime spot! I enjoyed two kati rolls, one with chicken tikki masala and the other with karahi paneer.  The chicken was spicy and tasty.  The meat chunks were big and juicy.  Dipped in a little of the raita sauce made for a perfect spicy/cool combo.  The karahi paneer was flavorful and good.  I used some raita with it as well but it was less spicy and not as in need of the raita's cooling qualities.  Each roll was wrapped in a delicious roti, perfectly crispy and soft simultaneously.  These were my first indian rolls like this and I am an instant fan.  My lunch also came with a mango lassi for just $1 more, not bad! It was creamy and fresh.  Overall, I'd say the food is 4-5 star worthy, but the price swings my vote to 4.  My total came to just under $10 which is fine, but more than I'd like to spend on a regular basis.
author: Laura B.

description: 1.Food is bland, not traditional spicy & flavorful.  2.Food gets cold very quickly [3-4 mins; because they spread it out very thinly over large compartmental style metal dishes], "HOT" food eaten at room temperature is NOT appetizing.  3. Vegetarian food items are pretty dry, not moist [and are even drier when eaten with basmati rice].  4. Lentils are runny and without flavor, not savory.  5. Naan bread is a strange rubbery texture that tastes rather gritty and oily.  6. food and drinks are pricey.  7. Seating is cramped.
author: Paul In S. F.

description: The service was quick and very friendly and the prices are very affordable!  I had a thali plate which included Chicken Tikka Masala and the Lamb Curry.  The curry was soooooo tasty!  The masala I thought was a little salty, and the lentl soup was amazing!  I would definitely go back!
author: Clyde L.

description: The food here is really good, although it has suffered a bit but still very yummy! the staff, well, is just awful . They take their sweet time to help you when you are waiting to order and then give you an attitude like you are doing them a favor! I love supporting my neighborhood businesses and the food is very good, but how condescending the staff is and how stressful is becomes, I'll pass. it's a shame. Please train your staff to be nicer!!
author: M F.

description: I love their food, it is yummy and quick to serve...If you ask for half orders of things you can try out different dishes and not pay too much....I love all their food but the chicken tiki masala is just fantastic......
author: octavia h.

description: Like a moth to a flame, I'm continually drawn to Kasa's pleasant surroundings, great service and tasty, yet slightly unconventional Indian fare. Yet like that same moth, I always seem to get burned by indigestion. What to do?
author: Derek M.

description:
I love the food here.   The main offering is like an Indian burrito and has been tasty both times I have tried it.  I like to get quick dinner bites pretty often and this is such a nice alternative to neighborhood Thai, pizza or Mexican.  The space is pretty basic but the prices are very reasonable.  

Try the vegetarian.  You will want to dance like you are in a Bollywood movie.
author: John A.

description:
I've passed by Kasa numerous times on my way home from rock climbing at Mission Cliffs in the Mission.  Every time I think I should stop in I've either already had a burrito, or I'm on the way home for pasta.

Last night I stopped in for the first time and couldn't have been happier with my decision.  The food was delicious.  The service was interested in my well being.  And the ambience was awakening.  It was everything I was looking for.

I like the term another Yelper used..."fast casual".  This town is known for burrito shops.  Make this your regular Indian shop for "fast casual" dining.
author: walter k.

description:
a great concept and a place that we'll probably going back to for some quick eats.  the idea behind the kati roll is the same as any street food which is a getting a good fulfilling piece of food on the go.  

we ordered to go so we got the chicken tikka, 2 chicken tikka masala (1 unda style w/ egg) and karahi paneer kati rolls.  everything was pretty darn good.  the roti used for the rolls was buttery and flaky and the meat and paneer were all cooked very well with great flavor.  my only draw back would be the price is pretty high for kati rolls but you can't win em all.

when i picked up the food, the decor of the restaurant is pretty chill and cool so next time we'll have to try and stop by for food.  having the option to pick up or even delivery is very nice though.
author: Swarup B.

description: I really liked the paneer roti. The wrap is really really tasty, and the paneer was outstanding in terms of taste. Also, I liked the silver plate that they use and the sauce. Nice layout, very open. I would definitely go back and have the same meal again.
author: Glaciala A.

description:
i love good indian food, and i love instant gratification, so Kasa fulfills both.  they have a limited menu, but that makes your choice easier.  plus everything is good, so you can't go wrong.

you can either have one of the dishes as a kati roll, which is good if you're looking for something inexpensive yet  hearty (one kati = $5) or you can get a thalis plate w/ 1-2 choices, pickled veggies and relishes, raita, and daal for $10.95.  although many have said their prices are high, I can usually get 2-3 meals out of this one dish so it doesn't seem that expensive to me.  they have a nice selection of wine, beer and soda (some Indian) to wash everything down.  and their chai is delicious.  

and their ingredients are high quality and fresh, their service fast and amicable, and the food in your mouth within a few minutes.  the only thing missing for me were some mango and tamarind chutnies - but luckliy i always have a stash in my fridge.
author: Suzanne A.

description:
DELICIOUS AND HEALTHY....not like typical greasy and fatty indian restaurant food.

First of all and contrary to popular belief, not all indian food is SPICY and full of CURRY AND CREAM.

That's just what restaurants do to make it taste good....but its not really like that...and Kasa shows that.

Its absolutely delicious, CHEAP and features ORGANIC and CAGE FREE meats.

And you can get dinner for 2 with leftovers for literally $20 or less. Order sides of things for $5 they are bigger than entrees.

FREAKING DELICIOUS AND GUILT FREE...not rich and full of butter and cream....but just....eat it ok? Even if you think you won't like Indian food...you'll like the food here.

Promise.
author: N S.

description: Way better.  Quiet.  Yum.  Cauliflower.  Cute music.
author: Ian M.

description: oh man this place is amazing, we've been getting delivery from them pretty frequently since i broke my leg. a few things, its both authentic and neo-indian and the same time, obviously someone in the kitchen has some good recipes to go off of but is mixing things up a bit. The Daal is so good, probably the best daal i've ever had. oh and they import one of my favorite indian sodas LIMCA!
author: Jared Z.

description:
Stopped in today and tried the chicken tikka masala kati roll - it was delicious - and the staff was incredibly friendly. Good food AND good service? Wow. And the portion wasn't too small for me (I was full after 1 roll) - and for those with bigger appetites, it's only $8.95 for 2.

I'll be stopping here often on my walk home from work. Yum.
author: Kate R.

description:
What a GREAT idea!  Indian dishes wrapped in "flaky, buttery roti" and served taqueria style.  Technically called Kati rolls.  

In a town that has too many taquerias and too many mediocre Indian food restaurants this combo restaurant shines.

And to top it all off the prices are very reasonable.

Only draw back is the location.  Hard to find parking.
author: Jeff S.

description: I ordered from Kasa for the first time for my husband and I tonight, the bill was so low I worried I hadn't ordered enough for a real dinner.... but it turns out $22 worth is more than we could eat in one sitting. The food was not really like the traditional Indian food we are used to, but so fresh and well prepared we loved it. We got 3 different wraps/rolls and each was so good we couldn't decide which was the best.  A couple sides rounded out the meal. And they said it would be an hour for delivery but it was only 30 minutes. Kasa will definitely be one of our regular take-out favorites.
author: Sadie V.

description:
Kasa was pretty good.  The decor and music give it the feel of a nightclub However the food is still fairly traditional and yummy!  I had two kati rolls one with chicken tikka the other with tikka masala.  Both of them had a nice grilled flavor and the yogurt that came with it was also quite good.  I also had a mango lassi just a warning DONT GET THE MANGO LASSI.  It was a revolting mixture of ginger and spices with no mango flavor.  It was $3 and I couldn't bring myself to finish it.  My friend had one of the plates with one of the specials (it was vegan and had cauliflower) he liked it in general but thought the main course was a bit on the small side (I think they had just run out of it and he asked for a double portion).
Overall a yummy quick affordable spot.
author: Sesily M.

description: AMAZING high quality, fresh food with DELICIOUS taste at an affordable price. Not sure how they have done it, but it works and I will be a regular here. Just go there and be prepared for some delicious delicious delicious Indian food. :)
author: Rolf S.

description: Love Kasa. Such a needed place. I have to stop myself from going there every week lest I get tired of it. Love the kati rolls. Great place to have a sit down dinner and also a wonderful take out alternative to burritos or chinese. Hands down my favorite food in the neighborhood.
author: Blake R.

description: Kati Rolls?!  I'm a fan!  However, there's not much to choose from.  It's one of those places that makes Indian food hip and accessible, which I'm not against but if you want an authentic Indian meal, Kasa Indian Eatery isn't the place for you.  However, if you want an introduction and a fast meal that's prepared before your eyes, Kasa is all right with me.  It's also one of those places that really offers up some filling platters.  I had the Kati rolls (one filled with Karahi Paneer and the other with chicken tikka masala) because I never tried these entrees wrapped in a flour roll with a cool few dollops of raita.  Unfortunately, you have to order a side of veggie salad.  Boo!  Overall, Kasa is not that bad.  If you are into eating a bit more, don't order the rolls.  Get the rice dishes...
author: Dorothy S.

description: I stumbled in here tonight after the gym, starving.  Well, if you need some carbs and protein, this is the place.  Really good chicken tikka, pretty good lamb whatchamaaculit, terrible naan substitute.  Is this what they make those roll sout of, because if so, no thank you!  Next time I'm stumbling home I would pick up a couple items from this place, but not out of my way and hold the doughy thingy.
author: e w.

description: excellant healthy version of indian food. The rolls are not too oily, rich in fresh herbs, and not too spicey. Very good price.
author: Hamayun N.

description: Scrumptious. Chicken tikka masala roll was pretty amazing (nice n' spicy, too), and the thali was a huge old platter of food. Tasty turkey meatballs. Nice clean place, friendly service, will definitely return.
author: Cody E.

description:
we are really enjoying the proximity of Kasa. there was no indian in castro/noe.
The vegetarian dishes are worth 4.5 stars, but the meat dishes are worth about 2-3 stars. 
there is something funky about the lamb. it is way too tough and gamey in flavor (have tried this on 3 different visits). such a bummer. lamb is so amazing with indian.
the chicken is always too dried out (attempted 4 times). it almost seems like they pan fry it before putting it in the curry. thus creating an outer seal which prevents the flavors from truly marinating inside the meat. also, they may use only white meat (hence the super dry quality). generally dark meat is more flavorful and juicy.
the sauces however are super delicious and full of flavor. we prefer the thalis to the katis, because the variety of dishes is so wonderful. the salad is vibrant, the dal is comforting, and the portions are abundant.
we are fans of kasa vegetarian dishes!
author: SF U.

description:
As most everyone else has said - very yummy food. Love the simplicity of the menu too. I just had 1 Karahi Paneer Kati roll and it was filling enough for lunch, along with the most delicious mango lassi I think I've ever had. It had a hint of ginger or maybe it was cardamom? Totally delish. Liked the sides too - really good raita and salad.

But what's the deal with being out of the special at 1:00? Seems like maybe a little better planning is in order? Otherwise, I'm stuffed and very satisfied!
author: yvette b.

description: Could use more veggie options, but the food is amazing and just the right serving size. The beer selection is microscopic, but excellent. The price is a little high for lunch or a drunk craving, but perfect for a quick dinner with friends.
author: Jono S.

description: Totally unique, affordable, delicious, fast... a great experience all around!  They have lunch specials for 7.95, I believe.  The rolls are really tasty.  Two problems - not a lot of choices, and rather bad atmosphere (*cold and echo-filled.)
author: Aaron W.

description: The kati rolls are so soft and perfectly spiced. I get mine with the peppers and paneer, and their paneer is some of the best I've ever had (and I'm a paneer snob). The salad and raita are also amazing, although i've had better daal elsewhere. It's fast and decently priced, but doesn't feel fast-foody at all.
author: Bonnie C.

description: super fast & delicious.  I dig it the most.  indian + burrito = dynamite culinary innovation.  kingfisher on tap and yes I'll take 2... no I'm not sure what she's having.
author: Scott C.

description:
I came here for dinner with 4 former classmates of mine from BU. I wouldn't say we were all close friends in school and have had little contact since graduation, but for the first time ever, we made an effort to catch up. One of them suggested a "good Indian place" in the Castro and so we decided to eat at Kasa. The unusual and enjoyable food complemented the unusual and enjoyable company quite well.

I don't know if Kati Rolls are some popular new fad and I am behind the times or what, but this was the first time I had encountered Indian food like this. Being my first time, I decided to get the 3 roll combo in order to try several flavors. I ordered a potato roll, lamb roll, and a chicken tikka masala roll. My favorite was by far the lamb and the chicken tikka masala was quite good. I opted to have the roti in the potato roll dipped in egg first and that was a mistake. The combination of fried egg and potato gave it more of a breakfast burrito taste...not so much bad as just unwanted. Quality-wise the 3 rolls were a bargain for the $11.95. Quantity-wise, I was stuffed.

They are served with a smear of raita on a bare metal plate. I can't say they get points for presentation...it really looks prison-esque.

I suppose it is obvious and glib to describe the food as Indian burritos, but describing the establishment as an Indian taqueria is apt. Like any decent burrito joint, I would frequent it if it was in my neighborhood, but doesn't warrant a trek.

So, sadly, like the dinner with those former classmates, I think Kasa will be a one time thing.
author: Matthew C.

description:
WHAT A GREAT ALTERNATIVE to the standard fare.  The food is great, however my favorite are the Kati rolls and the service is great too.  Quality of the food is high and the flavors are so satisfying.  What a find!  Go and tell all your friends!

AND, if you have kids, ask for the Kids Roll - my 7 & 9 year old loved it and my other 9 year old ... she ate mine!
author: Kim K.

description: I'm not that much into Indian food, because everything has a kind of "soupy" consistence that unfortunately I don't enjoy. But not all is lost, my friend! Here comes Kasa to solve the problem. The food here tastes right, you can feel that is all but crap. It is like homemade. The combined plate is a steal, and I even like the Indian cola.
author: Javi V.

description: Lunch special M-F, 11a-4p: $7.95 for two kati rolls and soda or $8.95 for a thali and soda. Lassi or chai $1 extra.
author: Hiten P.

description:
They should change the name of Kasa to Unicorn. Because that's how rare a good, friendly, and affordable restaurant in The Castro is. 

Nearby, everything is overpriced, mediocre, and full of attitude. Refreshingly, Kasa is the opposite. Light on the wallet, generous in flava, and friendly in demeanor.

Oh, another reason to rename Kasa to Unicorn: they deliver!
author: Chanpory R.

description: good, cheap, fast indian food.  I grabbed koti rolls with tikka masala and paneer. both were good.  i like their emphasis on local and natural foods. the kati rolls are cheap ($4.50)  but other items/combos on their menu can start to get expensive for quick eats.
author: Jake L.

description: this place is really good....perhaps the best restaurant in the castro (frankly, most of them just aren't that great).  fresh, simple, and tasty!  highly recommended
author: Arnold Y.

description: I wanted to try this place for quite a while and finally had a chance. I ordered the plate and found the sides rather plain and the proteins way too spiced. I ended up with heartburn and definitely had better Indian cuisine elsewhere. On the plus side, it's affordable ($10) and my boyfriend liked his kati rolls.
author: Fil L.

description: Excellent Indian fast food. Perfect if you have a short amount of time to eat; I like to bring a book and read (although it gets a little messy). I always order the chicken tikka masala kati rolls. It's a bit spicier than maybe some other Indian places, but still super yummy.
author: Bill J.

description:
i moved away from sf and still dream about this place.  It's cheap and fast and YUMMY.
The kati rolls are delicious, the bread they use for the rolls are a little greasy but soooo worth it.

In general, I dont like paneer, but the karahi paneer here is one of my two favorite dishes.  The other is the Chicken Tikka Masala which is rather spicy in a good way.  

I wasnt a fan of the aloo jeera or the mango lassi.  The mango lassi had some unidentifiable but very pungent seeds mixed in which caused me to have to chew through the lassi, more than drink it.  I very much recommend NOT getting it.
author: Laurene C.

description: Went back there Friday night, tried different dishes and... it delivered again! Wow! Amazing flavors and so fresh! We have been telling our friends about it! Will be back soon :)
author: Stefanie S. J.

description: Yeah, we had a couple of the indian burritos; they were OK and a bottle of Thumbs Up soda that tasted like stale coca-cola. Its bare bones and assembly line so the food is standing out in the line and that's not really too healthy.  Its just OK,  but if you want really great indian try Pakwan on 16th X Valencia/Guerro or really authentic at Shalimar on Jones in the Tandoriloin.  Best yet.   Enjoy, Bill.
author: William G.

description:
super tasty, cheap, relatively healthy, quick bite, clean place, nice staff, what else should you ask for!
(my favorites are the tika massala roll and the saag paneer)
author: V. B.

description: One of my favourite places for a quick bite to eat!  They have a lunch special for $7.95 which you get 2 kati rolls, side of raita (yogurt) and a drink.  I always get a Chicken Tikka Masala and a Karahi Paneer with onions and chutney.  mmmmmm SO GOOD!
author: Jasen L.

description:
it is rare for me to be wowed by indian food. so many places get it all wrong...too dry or too tasteless or too swimming in a sea of grease. 
kasa is absolutely delicious. the food was fresh and bursting with gigantic, singing flavor. everything was perfectly seasoned and most dishes i sampled had a really awesome kick to them. the adorable husband/wife/friend ownership team seem like the loveliest of people, the kind of people you really want to succeed. the wife is the chef and she is using all of her aunt's recipes. all together now, AWWW! and they also have a small but great selection of beers and wines. i had a really great reisling, crisp and not too syrupy sweet. and i tried a beer that i actually loved and i HATE beer.  the decor is simple, minimal and clean. i love their chrome almost cafeteria-style trays. and i just love this place. aces!
author: Amy S.

description: Kasa no longer serves their refreshing side salad with their kati rolls.  This makes the one kati roll meal less of a value (I think it's still worth it if you order two kati rolls, since the pricing is not linear).  I guess everyone is suffering from the current recession and must cut back where they can.
author: Grace W.

description: The food here isn't bad.  But I'm giving only three stars because I want them to punch up the flavors, spice.  It's a good idea, and if they didn't tone it down for the local palate, it would be worth the wait, parking, and people bringing their dogs in a backpack to sit at the table with them (seriously, that's how you know it's not the real deal; for as much as I like canines, you're never gonna find a dog in a restaurant in India).
author: King E.

description: An awesome addition to the neighborhood.  Solid indian food at really great prices.  You can easily have a filling meal for under 10 bucks.
author: Courtney N.

description: Came here during my lunch break. Employees are very friendly and helpful. I was going to get the Thali plate but they suggested I get the Kati rolls since I haven't tried it. Had the lamb and turkey and it was really good! Plus, it only cost me around $8-9 for the lunch special and it included a drink. There wasn't too much people around this time and the place was really clean. I would definitely come back here next time! Place is great even if you're eating by yourself.
author: Christine R.

description: I like. good, reasonably priced food. clean space. friendly folk working it.  free-range chicken.
author: Cristian M.

description: RECESSION BUSTER ALERT - Now here this... this place could become seriously addictive, and it may just give the Mission burrito joints a run for their money. For under $10, you can enjoy (2) large and tasty Indian wraps that just melt in your mouth, along with a side salad and yogurt. Yesterday, I chose the lamb and kebab versions, which left me just as full as I like to be for lunch. YUM! Add to that the wonderful natural light (lots of windows), casual counter service, and friendly staff, and you really cannot go wrong. I adore the simple metal plates, bowls, and cups. So refreshing to have a quality ethnic eatery in the Castro that is good, cheap and, YES, open late, too! This one will be packed for months to come.
author: Marc S.

description: The food is delicious here.  The boyfriend has been eating here once or twice a week for the past several weeks.  This says a lot since he is a vegetarian and rarely eats anywhere out except for the safety of Papalote. Last night I tried the vegetarian Katis, one was cabbage and one was potatoe.  The yogurt sauce is delicious as is the dal.  I cannot wait to eat here again.  Note, I could not finish the two katis and I eat like a teenage boy; they are very filling.
author: Erin M.

description: I am addicted to Kasa.  I love Indian food but it's often too heavy to eat all the time.  However, food here at Kasa is light and yummy.  My husband and I have tried every dish and every one is delicious.  The staff is always so nice too.  The Castro location not too far from my house but I really wish it's right next door to me so that I can go even more often.
author: T. J. L.

description: nicely furnished, but the paneer kati roll i got was just ok. definitely sticking to more traditional indian food. chai was delicious though
author: Monika S.

description: I love EVERYTHING I ever have at Kasa (almost - actually I hated the karahi paneer roll because all I could taste was the cheese the entire time) but their Chicken Tikka Masala rolls and Gobi Aloo rolls are to die for. I also love their daal, rice, and raita combo. And make sure you get their special green chutney and raita on the side because it makes the meal 10 times better!
author: Pepper P.

description: Yay!  I finally went to an Indian Restaurant and I was so pleased!  The food is delicious!  I have had it home made, but never out, so I got to try so many new things.  I'm not usually a "mesh all the food on your plate into one and then go" kinda person, but with this food, its all works harmoniously.  Thanks for the great location and for having reasonable prices!
author: candice T.

description: Great Indian "fast food"  I love the minimal atmosphere of this place and the food is limited but darn tasty!
author: Mickey D.

description: I have had nothing but good experiences at Kasa. The staff is always friendly and helpful, offering help with explaining the menu to any new patrons. The food is always hot and fresh, and the daily specials keep variety while the permanent menu provides you with favorites worth returning for. Normally I am not into Indian food for lunch, but this spot is perfect for any time of the day.
author: Michael D.

description: I would be a fatty-gay if i lived near this ikea ad of a restaurant. Kari rolls are insane. Deep fried break stuffed with choice of meat and a huge helping of rita. Doesnt sound too exciting, but I forgot to breath as I inhaled the fried and perfectly spiced chicken tikka.  Service is fast, food is good and no frills. If you are REALLY hungry get the Thali plate. It comes was dahl the crack addictive fried bread and meat/veggie of choice. Be sure to sit away from the window as to not let people the the delicious food dippin down your gullet. Gays always need to be a little classy =) You can just dance it off later
author: Spencer N.

description: Indian Taqueria. I can dig it. The place looks cool. Their chai is good... does it even matter what I think since this is like the 200-something review.
author: danny e.

description: Ok first off let me preface this review by saying the food was good.  And I know curry, I'm British and oddly enough it's our national dish. This isn't like that, this is the Californian/Mexican variation.  Curries in a burrito. I would have given it 4 stars had it not been like the edible equivalent of an enema. 40 minutes later, and I was in the bathroom downing a bottle of pepto.  I don't think it was bad food I think it was just combination of the ingredients they use that somehow didn't agree with me.  I'd go again, only next time I'll have that bottle of pepto handy before I take a bite.
author: rhiannon B.

description:
A delicious little Indian place smack down in the middle of the Castro.  I went here because some of my Indian friends recommended it.  I didn't know what to order and the people behind the counter were really nice.  They walked me through and even showed me what each ingredient looked like.  I had 2 of the Kati rolls, one with chicken tikka masala and the other one with Turkey.  They were both delicious and great for the price.  The Turkey one was definitely spicier.  It's great that they use organic meats as well, very hard to find in Indian food.  I love the decor and the location as well.  They even have good beer on tap.
The only thing I would recommend is to either give you more Raita, or have a bar on the side where you can get more if you run out.  Also, some of the specials were scattered around the restaurant and not in one place, which made it difficult to decide.  Next time I will definitely try the specials though since they don't have much beyond the rolls.
author: Mitch A.

description: If I could I'd give Kasa 3 and a half stars but I can't. I went here because a friend of mine loves this place and can't stop talking about it. When I finally came I was slightly impressed but nothing warranting anything past three stars. Sorry Kasa, maybe next time bud.
author: Tommy P.

description: I went back and tried the Karahi Paneer (and got the Chicken Tikka Masala again) and oh man, this one was awesome. This place is beauty in simplicity. If you're the kind of person apprehensive about Indian food, this place makes it accessible. Plus it's quick - and you don't gorge yourself on an Indian food buffet and the place is a bit cleaner and higher quality than your typical Naan & Curry.
author: Ross R.

description: Excellent. good food.Good prices, good kingfisher. need saag panneer
author: Alejandro D.

description: Very good, nice menu options, not at all greasy.  Look for the food truck option as well to the store front!
author: Tristan C.

description: With many of us looking for a quality bite to eat during our busy schedules, you might want to squeeze in a Kati Roll in your rotation of sandwiches and burritos.  Assuming you are open to Indian Food, you'll love the large servings whether its a Thali (plate) or a Kati Roll (meal rolled up in a buttery roti roll).  After trying a wide range of items from the vegetarian to the turkey kebabs (meatballs), I can safely say that Kasa has got a good thing going.   Add on top the sustainable meat and the reasonable prices, you'll keep coming back for more!
author: Jason A.

description: This is a great spot to grab an inexpensive delicious bite to eat. The menu is very simple..which is kinda nice, allowing great attention to each item.  Decor is nice and clean.  Perfect amount of food (for me at least) but my bf left the place feeling a little hungry still.
author: Aleli L.

description:
Great place to get quick tasty, flavorful indian food. The quality of the food is very good and the emphasis is on freshness and flavor than on elaborate, rich dishes that tend to dominate most indian restaurants (most of which are really mediocre). I'm really glad that they opened such a place.

The atmosphere is simple, clean and functional and so don't expect anything fancy.  Service is friendly. Most importantly go for the quality of the good.

Btw, I'm Indian and very finicky about food - especially Indian food. There are only about 3 or 4 Indian restaurants in the city that I would even consider eating at and this is certainly one of them.
author: Srinivas N.

description:
The food here was decent.  The paneer was really good, the daal tastey, and the raita refreshing.  I wasn't a fan of the roti and the Aloo Gobi was undercooked.  The food is pre-made so you don't select the spice level, but it was more flavorful than the average buffet.  I find a majority of the bay indian restaurants love to put in tons of oil, and this wasn't super oily, yay! 

However, I would come back here bc of the convenience even though they don't have many dishes.  the chicken masala looked really good, didn't try it though.
author: Carla K.

description: Great simple menu - the spice (hotness) level maybe be toned down for some who are use to places in the Tenderloin - but I like how the food is not cooked to death with grease and you can still make out what you are eating - love the delicious pickle side dishes.
author: Joanna E.

description: It's sort of like an Indian Chipotle!  I had three kati rolls and because I wasn't watching the nervous guy behind the counter assemble my plate, it was a fun surprise!  Which one was the chicken tikka masala?  Which was the lamb curry?  Which was the karahi paneer?  It was impossible to tell until I bit into them, but all were totes yummy.
author: Marcus C.

description:
why are there so many bdays/going away parties/random events in july??  ...i've been left w/a gaping hole in my wallet.

consulted yelp and looked for an inexpensive place to eat before heading over to the lookout for my friend's going away party.

manuel p. and i decided on kasa.  i filled myself w/the lamb curry kati roll w/salad and raita.  ...pretty decent food for $5.50.

i'm a fan of the lunch tray-jailhouse-quasi contemporary platter that your food is served on.
author: Ting A.

description: We have done take out only and great great service to help you understand their process and food.  EVERYTHING IS GREAT.  The "rolls" are unbeatable, I could eat every day if only it was on my way to work I would buy them and have them for lunch.  Great grab on the go...eat these rolls now people.
author: Jessica M.

description: Simple kathi rolls and amazing masala tea. Can't wait to go back. Have to have the tea. It's worth it's fl oz in gold
author: C C.

description: Astounding!   The Kati rolls are the new burrito.  The staff is among the most bouncy and friendly, ever.  But boys, when I say no onions, I mean it!  Hence 4 stars and not 5.
author: Cinnamon Z.

description: Finally came to Kasa to redeem my Groupon gc.  Tried the Tikka Masala Chicken and the Aloo Jeera Kati Roll.  For $4.50/roll, they seemed kind of small, but they were flavorful and tasty.  The chai tea is good.
author: Katniss B.

description: No clue at all why people like this place, I had the tikka masala and it was soooo icky. Dry, bland, something very wrong with the balance of spices. It was very bad. I hoped the riata would make it tolerable but it was lame too. What a bad tasting lunch it was. I liked the idea of an indian place with organic meat but that was not worth it at all. Maybe people who like this place don't like real indian food.
author: Martha Sue H.

description: My first review on yelp, and this place is worthy of it. Really great, addictive food for a reasonable price. I'm a vegetarian, so I haven't sampled the meat katis, but both the standard veggie rolls are superb. Plus they have rotating veggie options and some good raita with every roll. They're committed to local stuff, which is always a plus, and location is great being walking distance from Dolores Park. Both the daal and the chai are awesome, and worth the extra $. The service could be a little warmer (pushing it to 5 stars), but a solid 4.5.
author: Dean W.

description: This place is great for eat in, but for delivery as I write this I have been waiting over a hour and they are about 5 blocks away.  Normally this place is fast food.  I recommend not ordering when you are hungry and waiting at home.  My poor boyfriend is sick and starving.  I had to call to ask where the food was.  Maybe it was a busy night, hopefully at least.  If I were a restaurant owner/manager I would at least call to say it was going to be late.  Just a little tip for the future.
author: Jocie H.

description: I wasn't quite sure what to expect but ordered several dishes last night for delivery. We had the lamb, chicken tikka masala, and the potatoes in the plated/deconstructed version of the kati rolls. Everything was delicious, fresh tasting, and fantastically spicy. I really liked that my meat was organic/free range. I did miss having some sort of vegetable option like a spinach or cauliflower dish. I also would have preferred naan to the roti wrapper. Definitely worth checking out!
author: Lisa L.

description:
i finally came here last night after a few failed attempts over the wknd, and i liked it.  we got here around 8 pm, and there was a pretty long line.  the line didn't move so fast, but at least we had time to peruse the (short) menu.  the place is very clean, and i like the communal table in the middle.  service was a bit spotty as there seemed to be some confusion in the assembly line.

if you are a vegetarian, the pickings are slim.  you can either get a roll w/ cumin-spiced aloo or a paneer dish.  i don't eat paneer, but luckily there was also a cauliflower dish that is not on the menu, and i got a roll w/ that.  we each got 2 rolls, which came w/ raita and a chopped salad.  we both asked for it spicy, but the sauce really isn't that spicy.

the rolls were good and the roti was nice and fluffy.  however, i was told that actual kati rolls are made w/ paratha, rather than roti, so it is usually more flaky and buttery.  also, the kati rolls here are rolled up like a burrito, whereas they should be more loosely wrapped just one time, kinda like a soft taco or gyro.  

either way, the rolls were tasty, and 2 were filling for me (esp if you get the aloo filling).  the cauliflower filling was a tad oily, but it was stil tasty.

i like the concept a lot here, and w/ time, hopefully they will add more choices to the menu and work out the little kinks.
author: Helen T.

description:
This was definitely a fun little stop for a lunch bite.  Walked out perfectly full after eating two kati rolls.

I was concerned when I say the Chicken Tikka Masala on the menu board say "in a creamy tomato sauce" and feared the sauce was gonna run out of the kati like no tomorrow, but that wasn't the case.

The industrial-chic was very well done. Staineless steel countertops, aluminum chairs and dark wood tabletops.  My only gripe: (yes, it's petty) the plates/trays.  They're these odd metal things, like the meal trays in prison (or in movie prison scenes).  Yes, I get it, it totally fits the decor, but, at the same time it was just a tidbit ambiance overboard.
author: T G.

description: Yum!  I had high expectations going in and was still very happy with my meal.  I had 1 chicken tikka masala kati roll with the side salad and yogurt.  It felt like the perfect amount of balanced food so I didn't feel immediately enormous and guilty the way that I sometimes do after eating a burrito.  The side salad tasted really fresh with tomatoes, cucumbers, cabbage.  The service was also great.  I went late right around closing but they were really nice about explaining the menu options and then coming by to bring us our food and silverware.  I definitely see more Kasa in my future.
author: l c.

description: This place consistently makes mistakes, every single time while I order food. I ordered in food for a party with 10 Kati rolls missing. The owner apologized, but did not change the amount that was charged. I let it pass, then on several occasions they either change the order or make some mistake.  Getting tired of the mistakes at this place.
author: Suj a.

description: About the food: We got the full-on thali platters, choosing lamb, chicken, and cheese paneer, from the great assortment  on the boards. The food came really quickly, and was MUCH better than we expected for the price.  If they charged more for the food, I'd be more willing to complain about the harsh lighting, awful music, and noisy metal plates. Maybe I should try take-out, so I could control the lighting and music. Either way, we'll be back!
author: laurence c.

description: Drippy oil alert -- They now slather their kati in butter!  Ack, ask for it without butter!  (Still tasty, just super greazy!)
author: Melanie C.

description: I wouldn't have given this place a bad review except that before ordering, I asked if I could order my food mild.  2 of the employees said 'yes' and I got what they considered to be the most mild food.  It wasn't.   I suppose if you're someone who likes the flavor burned out of your mouth, this place could work, but I'll never come back.  I get that a lot of people want their Indian food to be spicy (hot) -- but don't say that you have 'mild' options when you don't.
author: G M.

description: A kati roll that can't be missed.  A perfect mid-day snack.
author: Bhavesh M.

description: Indian food at its best, delicious & original.  Love everything on the menu.  They also deliver promptly!  Bienvenue au neighborhood!
author: Y B.

description:
Am I missing something here?  How is this place so highly rated?  
My meal was sloppy and not tasty at all.  The naan was rubbery and the daal was runny.  The waitress used the same gloves to slap put on my plate and to take my money.  Nothing about this place makes me want to come back.
author: J B.

description: Edit:  Finally came back and the serving sizes were back up to par and the food and service were good!!  I am a fan again.
author: Ed C.

description: The food is quite simple, yet delicious. The owner is really great and it's a fun place to get some quick, relatively inexpensive, tasty Indian Food in the Castro. The food is quite authentic too (FYI... I'm Indian).
author: Anand S.
