description: Yum!  Kasa was serving at SF Bike Coalition's Winterfest last night.  Absolutely LOVED the saag paneer and the chicken tikka masala.  I don't eat Indian food out very much because it tends to be too rich and creamy for me.  But this is (evidently) "homestyle", so the wholesome ingredients take center stage, vs. the creamy sauces of so many other places around here.  I will become a regular at the 18th + Noe location.  Thank you!
author: carol d.

description: Yummy and cheap. I actually would really like more options here, but it's great as is. I do kinda wish they at least put more chutney on, I could barely taste mine - but I bet they would if I asked them to! They messed up my order but fixed it immediately and were uber apologetic. I enjoyed it and only wish it was closer to me!
author: Monika M.

description: Very unique Indian fast food. 2 Kati rolls will do just fine. Under $10 and vegetarian options. Nice addition to the neighborhood for a quick bite.
author: Scott L.

description: Kasa is the local indian taqueria place. My favorite is the chicken tikka kati rolls.  It's always crowded, which makes for a fun atmosphere but you can always find a set too.  I once brought 20 people here for my boyfriend's birthday party - we had a blast.  Whenever I don't feel like cooking, I run to Kasa.
author: Diane L.

description:
I tried this place today after reading all the reviews, and I will certainly go back.

I got the lunch special - 2 rolls and a fountain soda for $7.95.  I had the tikka masala and turkey kebab kati rolls.  They were both flavorful and filling.  I'm still full 5 hours after eating there.  The tikka masala had a nice spice to it, and the turkey was deliciously tender and flavorful, but not spicy.

The only drawback is my pieces of chicken were just a little too big and so I had a tough time getting a clean bite.  But really, I can't complain.  I'll certainly be back to try the other rolls.
author: Julie H.

description:
Kasa occupies the space that had been a 3rd rate burrito place for too many years to count. It is such a welcome change! We already have good burrito places in the Castro, thank you.

The food here is tasty and fresh, reasonably priced and the service is pretty darn quick. My only critique would be the funky layout of the order line. If you stand where you can see the menu then you aren't in line to get served next. It could use some tweeking to be perfect. But the food, YUM!
author: Tim G.

description: Simple menu, fresh ingredients, delicious. Not many Indian "roadside cafes" like this in the city which makes it even more appealing. Another plus is you'll probably bump into someone you know here (due to location and friendly social layout).
author: Charlie C.

description:
worth actually writing about!!!!

I am indian and a huge foodie. but i am lazy. so i don't usually take the time to write reviews and I don't usually take the time to cook up gourmet meals. But when I do it, I want to do it right!

So, the reason I am writing about Kasa is because it was SUCH A SURPRISE!

As mentioned before, I am Indian and am too lazy (and untalented) to cook up the intricate dishes that my mom makes. So if I can't get homemade food, I will take my chances with the various Indian restaurants around. This is not always the most satisfying solution to my cravings. And my parents (esp. my dad) refuse to even go to the typical Indian restaurant because of the oil-sitting-in-your-stomach-afterwards feeling! Also, why spend money on food that tastes like it has been sitting around for days when the food is so good at home.

But after leaving Chicago, I have finally found my replacement for my mom's home cooked food. Yes, I do enjoy the occasional greasy, overly done Indian dish - but only so often. And I don't feel happy about it afterwards. However, finding an Indian restaurant that is CLEAN! COOL! DELICIOUS and AUTHENTIC was something I was not expecting in SF.  Kasa is a place that I could eat at more than a few times a week.

I've eaten the kati rolls and thali dishes about 4 or 5 times so far. And since other reviewers have explained these dishes I won't go into that. What I will say is that it is an unbelievable deal for the price. If you non-Indians had any idea what is involved in creating REAL INDIAN food, you would realize that this place is actually underpriced! I had a hard time finishing my thalis yet still WANTED TO LICK THE PLATE (which is also authentic!) The amount and quality of this food is way more than the price. I am actually offended to read some of the reviews from people who think it is overpriced and not authentic. 

You must be the same people who think that you can find delicious, authentic and well-priced Chinese food at Panda Express!

I just wanted to write about how I have finally found an Indian restaurant that I actually am starting to become addicted to but after reading reviews, feel like I need to defend my ethnicity's home-cooked food from people who think they know what good indian food is. Please!

I'll keep eating there until my mom comes to cook for me!
author: Annie M.

description:
Good food! 
Though in the future, I won't have the mango lassi from there.
I was there on a Sunday afternoon and parking didn't seem like much of an issue. I had the vegetarian kathi rolls and they were good.
I will definitely go back.
author: Paolo B.

description: I really wanted to like this place, as the menu looked great and I'd heard good things about it.  Unfortunately the food was pretty bland and uninspired.  I've tried it a few times, thinking that maybe I'd just hit a bad night the first time or two, but I've never gotten anything there that I'd actually say was good or worth ordering again.
author: Suzanne K.

description: Oh sweet delishus goodness!  I love this indian place. I've been to several all over the city and this is hands-down my fave.  I also enjoy the clean, easy going cafeteria feel of the space -- and the value is ridiculous, can't beat it.
author: Meg M.

description:
I had been directed to Kasa as being the closest thing to Na'an and Curry in the neighborhood.  This was misleading, but fortunately Kasa is nothing like Na'an and Curry in a good way.

They only serve Roti rolls and a small selection of sides, but it is quick and very tasty.   It  was a tiny bit pricier than I was expecting, but the quality of the food and the use of free-range meats totally made up for that.  The service is very friendly, and the dining room is kept spotlessly clean.
author: Jen D.

description: South indian food for meat eaters and vegetarians alike! I love that you see the food being prepared as you order, you can see the copious amounts of fresh, high quality ingredients they use. I appreciate the quick ordering system, but would have liked a cozier, less fast food-ish/cafeteria type seating/table situation...great food and a great place for take out!
author: j-bird y.

description:
i now know 7 different  people who have gotten food poisoning from this place- all on different days.  do not eat here!

food poisoning warning!!!!!!! 

i got really sick from eating here, and two other neighbors of mine did all on different days since they opened- 3 weeks ago. they might have a "pretty" facade but the food sucks, it's bland, not very tasty  and it will make you sit on the toilet or burry your face in it. 

food poisoning warning!!!!!!

if you want to vomit and be on the toilet all night, go for it.
author: Tasha A.

description: Wow. This place is WAY better than the taqueria it replaced. I had two rolls served with raita and a veggie salad with a side of mango juice. The chicken tikka masala was pretty good- not the best I've had but good. The lamb was outstanding. These people aren't afraid to make it spicy and I love it. The sweet mango cooled the small fire in my mouth and I was totally stuffed. This isnt a fancy sit-down restaurant- your food is served on shiny metal trays separated like TV dinners, and if you don't grab a smaller table, you're eating at a large family style table or on barstools by the wall. But I found that low-key vibe of this place meant I could have a good meal for $11.  I will definitely be back to try the other kati rolls.
author: Emily L.

description:
I went to this place on the opening day. 

My overall impression was "Eh."

The food was quite tasty, but the portions were on the small side. Also, they label themselves as Indian burritos but what I got more resembled a taco or more accurately some stuff kinda wrapped in some roti bread. 

The staff were super duper nice, but excruciatingly slow. In fact they often seemed confused and mystified with what they were doing. 

So overall - eh. I'll probably go back in a few months once they hopefully get the kinks out of the process.
author: A K.

description:
3.5 stars would have been my rating, but the Sous Chef introduced himself to everyone in the restaurant and was eager to please, so he gets 0.5 bonus.

We came on the 3rd night.  I had to wait 45 minutes to get food (BOO!), but I'll let it slide because they're new and will hopefully improve.

The lamb curry was spicy and delicious.  The Chicken Tikka Masala was rich and tasty.  For the price ($10), I would've liked a little bigger portions. 

I'll give it another shot.
author: Chris F.

description: I resisted at first cause it looks contemporary, self service and all but the food is quite tasty. I notice that customers always empty the food tray. Totally love it. The drawback is limited choice and limited space. I am used to with all the big space in LA.
author: Meo M.

description: Came here about a week ago, and still I can't stop thinking about the Indian burritos (my friends like to call them). Had the Chicken Tikka Masala and the Cauliflower, while my friend had the Okra Kati rolls. B'jesus- they were so tasty and flavorful :) We couldn't stop "mmm"ing after each bite. Our mouths & tummys were very happy. The Chai complimented the rolls perfectly- with not too much spiciness like Peet's but still creamy. Above all that, the person behind the counter was super friendly, and asked if it was our first visit- it was! He described each meats/vegetables that were available, told us about the menu and was very welcoming.
author: Karen Y.

description: Indian food, fast food style... It was not good, so don't go here unless you just happen to be in the area and are craving a little taste of India. Overpriced.
author: Justin R.

description:
I love restaurants that choose wisely and execute well!  Kasa is a delight: A simple but delicious and complexly flavored menu, and a simple ordering process that keeps the line moving and the tables turning, usually leading to seats for all fairly quickly even when the place looks crowded.

We went on opening night (which is the smoothest one we've seen) and again last night.  I've tried both the thali plate and wraps formats, and they're just WONDERFUL.  I have to say, this is some of the best FLAVORED Indian food I've had in the Bay Area - never bland, yet not so spicy as to overwhelm the whole flavor dance. 

I love this place - it has beer and wine if you want that, it has vegetarian and non-veg selections, it has a pleasant seating area and isn't run in the too common hippie-dippie spacey "Oh whaaaat, this table needs to be clearrrred or something?" way.  Thanks the stars for Kasa!
author: Zoe F.

description: The service is nothing great but the food and the value is good! There is too expensive but in the castro you can get a cheap beer anywhere. Go for the rolls and go elsewhere for the beer.
author: Tyler S.

description: The Kati rolls here are pretty good, and having tried all of them, my favorite was Chicken Tikka Kebab. Personally, I didnt like the rolls with the curry like masalas since it tends to get a little messy. Get the rolls 'Anda Style', where they dip the roti in egg before they heat it up and fill in the stuffing of your choice.
author: Venkat K.

description:
Magic.  Pure Magic.  This is what the Castro should have.  A culmination of experience and love put into a restaurant that is already a staple of the community.  The atmosphere is superb.  Cool colors that compliment the warm food and accent the colorful people dinning.  A place to grab a quick bite or to sit and have a long conversation.  And forget about busing your own table, it's part of the je ne se qua, a constant that can be found through out the specials, the pairing of beer & wine, the freshness of the food, down to the employees who are engaged in there endeavor.  Let's face it we all want to be engaged in some facet of our lives and as corny as this might sound, whether it be 15 minutes or an hour you will be engaged with this wonderful eatery.  

What you will find......
Meat that is cooked juicy and tender no matter what you get.
Specials everyday that make the mouth water.
Some of the best paired Belgian beer in town.
Friendly, well dressed employees who are engaged in what they do.
A Groovy unhurried atmosphere that compliments the food and patrons.

This is the culmination of Indian heritage, cuisine of the UK (renowned for Indian cuisine) and flavor of the Castro in the best location.  My advice is to try something new every time you visit.  Just remember you can adjust how spicy you want your dish.

Thank you Kasa, for being a first rate restaurant to open in the Castro.

Sincerely,  Customer #2
author: Brooke J.

description: This place is sort of unique I guess, kind of an Indian "burrito" almost, it's your standard Indian fare wrapped in roti bread and it's pretty good. I got the paneer roll and I really liked the paneer, it was nice and firm and tasted pretty fresh. The filling and veggies were a little dry and they do give you a generous helping of raita but I guess I'm such a curry girl that I prefer the tikka masalas (yes I know they're not authentic.) Everything was still tasty though. And don't miss out on the mango juice! So good. So overall, I wasn't so wowed that I would seek this place out but I'd definitely consider it if I was in the area.
author: Cathy T.

description: Seriously!  Where else can you get great food at such a a good price!  I love eating here.  Yummmy rotis with aloo bhaji and chicken tikka thali.  Makes me hungry and I just ate ...
author: Ramona D.

description: My new favorite indulgence. The kati rolls are delicious! Try the paneer and the veggie special. Get them to go and eat in the park, and be happy.
author: Emily B.

description: Last night I got an order to go and didn't realize until I was home that only 1/2 rotis made it into my bag. I called and they had my additional item delivered - with a cookie and $5 gift certificate. That's some great customer service!
author: Andi M.

description:
Kasa is not your typical Indian eatery. From its clean and well kept kitchen exposed for all to see, you would not know you stepped into an establishment that serve exotic dishes, except for the four large photographs of Indian street life hung on one side of the wall.

Without any outward adornments, and a pared down menu of either a kati roll or thali plate, make your selection buffet-style and grab your plate after you paid your meal. Okay, this must be cheap. Value over service...right? Perhaps if you took one kati roll and called it day, but a thali plate is not what I call "cheap".

We had dinner and chose the thali plate that cold evening amid a less-than-handful of diners.  Served on a chrome chinet plate, my suspicion of "cafeteria" apparently was not too far off the mark.

Style over warmth: that's how my butt felt on those cold aluminum stools.

Mind you, we are not neophytes to Indian cuisine: we've eaten in plenty of indian/pakistani enclaves in the Mission, Tenderloin, Berkeley, and Fremont areas and even in London.

With the Cure and Cyndi Lauper quietly echoing in our eardrums while we ate, the "value" concept was quickly replaced with longings for decrepit, roach infested hole-in-the-wall steamy windowed restaurants with Indians actually cooking Indian meals with tables full of people laughing and animated, ripping off chunks of naan and being served sizzling pungent iron plates of Tandoori chicken or fish that smoke up half the room. Strange concept, that it is.
author: Rod A.

description: this is a fun way to experience Indian food.  India taqueria-esque.  The non tradish set up kinda through me for a loop but I got the hang of it ...very tasty - def try it.
author: Mimi X.

description: I like discovering new foods. Especially foods that I thoughtI ate but I find hidden on the bottom shelf. Yes score! I discovered Kasa the other day wandering around Castro desperate for nourishment. You must understand I spent the afternoon working at a chocolate store surrounded by chocolate and was filled with chocolate and little else. I got the roll with tikka masala chicken. Biting into it  was pure bliss. Just the right amount of spice which I adore with some cooling sides was perfect. Loved the metal plates. Prison ware baby.
author: Sophia C.

description: Kasa is a great addition to the Castro. The food was good and I hope it only gets better the more they do it. They could use a sign or something to show people where to order, you do not start at the register!  I also hope the menu grows a bit, the choices are limited. We shared the Tika roll, the turkey kabob and the lamb curry, the food was not what I expected but it was delicious. This place will do very well, especially if they stay open late. Lunch for 2 was $24.
author: James S.

description: Always a pleasure to eat at Kasa.  The food is awesome and consistent.  However, the flow of the ordering is a bit of a mess and getting your food always seems to take longer than it should.  If the could streamline the ordering process this place would be a solid 5 stars
author: Bitzz B.

description: I was hungry and in the Castro, and my best friend and I are both fans of Indian food so we stopped in. I got two Kati rolls and it was $8.95 for two small wraps!!! The "salad" was like a cole slaw that wasn't bad. The food wasn't bad but it was definitely cafeteria-style and over-americanized. I'll take New Ganges any day. The food wasn't bad but there are very little vegan options and if I want a burrito I will go and get a burrito. I don't think I will be back here.
author: Amanda M.

description: Like the guy below me said it is the chipotle of indian food. I forget what I ordered but it was really yummy. I went to this place probably a year and a half ago and this review will be short. It tastes fresh.
author: Iba N.

description: I highly recommend Kasa for kati rolls. I'm from India and don't necessarily think they are "authentic" but they are close. I ordered a whole bunch for a party at Dolores park, and Anamika, the owner who told my order, was super helpful and did a great job of the party platter (mix of chicken masala, dry chicken, and paneer rolls) and the delivery. The guests absolutely loved them. They were very filling and a great party snack. Five stars to them for providing great party food! They cater all kinds of food not only what's on the menu so make sure you call in advance and see what they can make for you! My family in Noe Valley loves Kasa!
author: Sonia V.

description: What a find!!!  I'd travel to the Castro, struggle w/ parking to eat here!  The food is delicious and healthy using only organic/grass fed meat.  They also have veg. dishe(s).  The wraps are quite filling - I need only two.  The Thali is fun if you want to try everything.  The joint is super clean and had a nice vibe.  A gem!
author: FoodJunkie S.

description: A delicious fast food type Indian place. I had the chicken tikka masala plate. Everything is either on a plate or wrapped in a delicious roti. The food was flavorful and fast. They have a nice little dining area and better than normal fast food ambiance. I recommend it.
author: Raj T.

description: Yum.  I had the chicken tikka masala kati roll, and it had great flavor (with a bit of a spicy kick).  The raita helped mediate the heat, though.  My only quibble - the chicken tikka masala did not taste the way I've ever had chicken tikka masala so manage expectations that way.
author: Melinda C.

description: I wanted to love this place, but I just didn't.  They need to do something about using cafeteria trays.  And if they do continue to use them, put more food on the plates so it doesn't look so pathetic.  They also need to be a bit quicker in making the meals.
author: Christine L.

description:
Went for the first time last week - I'm a huge Indian-food lover, so I try to explore as many Indian/Pakistani food venues in the Bay as I can...

Though Kasa is a nice and fresh idea (i.e. how you order by choosing a combo of a few choices, and having either a wrap or a Thali), and offering fresh-fast-Indian-food, I was very disappointed...

The food was not at all Indian-flavored...it was way too tasteless, with no banging flavor of any sort...very, very Americanized...

The place was clean, 'hip', good location, the staff was nice...it's just the food was really not up to par at all...I prefer Udupi or Pakwan in the Mission...
author: Rollio R.

description:
This place is great.  Food is awesome and priced well.  It's clean and an overall fun place.  

I'd recommend the Chicken tikka masala kati roll and the lamb curry kati roll.  I also had the turkey kebab kati roll but the other two were better.  

Sidenote: just realized a former classmate from college owns this place.  Awesome place Suresh!  I'll be back!
author: P R.

description: I love their raita. One of the best I have had. Especially after enjoying their delicious Chicken Tikka Masala. I always get their Thali plate, and it's always great. However, the guy serving me the last time I went didn't put as much of the two entrees as I usually expect. Especially since the lunch special was already over, and I was paying full price. What, are you afraid you're gonna run out?
author: Zack L.

description: Interesting variation in a sea of indian restaurants, kind of like indian sandwiches (kati). The kebab had entirely too much ginger. The aloo was under cooked. The tikka was the best of the three though a little on the dry side. The raita was excellent. All together it is just OK.
author: Reza E.

description: This place is a neighborhood gem. I loved the chicken tikka and chicken tikka masala kati rolls that I tried. My gf got the side of daal and that rounded out a scrumptious meal, and on top of that, they're open until 2am on Friday's and Saturday's. I only wish I lived closer by!
author: Keyvan R.

description: Great PR work...but I was one of those who also got sick..needless to say I won't be going there again.
author: Karen A.

description: I made my way to Kasa. I'm not usually into food under heating lamps...but this was not your average food under heating lamp quality. It was very tasty and had a bit of a kick. There were not a lot of choices, 3 on the menu and that is it, with a few side choices.
author: Valerie D.

description: Ive never actually had the honor of eating at this little hotspot I've heard so much about but we had the company cater a lunch in the office.  The service was prompt & friendly.  Tim & his staff are great at picking out a selection for you if you are not familiar with Indian cuisine.  We had a good assortment including a nice salad, the everpopular chicken tikka masala, a lentil dish and rice.  They also brought us the specialty which were the kati rolls.  A big hit in the office.  If you are looking for a delightful and easy to deal with catering service, this is one to choose!
author: Tiffany L.

description: I went here the week it opened on a date-- the food is fast, tasty and fun to eat, sort of like a Chipotle-esque experience. You go in and either order the kati rolls individually, or you can just get a plate w/ the salad and chutneys as if you were at a restaurant. It's easy walking distance from either muni or Dolores park, and you can always hit up Samovar on Josephine afterward for some tea and relaxation to digest your meal
author: Heleena H.

description: Just wasn't that good. Menu is limited. The few dishes that are offered should be really special, and they aren't. They are not bad - at all - just not great and the price is inexpensive but not super cheap.  I have had better Indian at several other places. The veggie salad is not good, and the vegetables in the vegetarian dishes are largely overcooked.  The bread is ok, but pretty dense and flavorless to pair with the already heavy flavors and textures of the food..
author: S R.

description: Kasa is awesome, the perfect spot for lunch or a light quick dinner.  Simple, clean, fresh, tasty, relatively healthy with friendly service and a comfy light ambiance.
author: P H I L H.

description: What's not to love about a place that has incredibly affordable, fresh, and fast Indian food? The way this place works is simple--you walk in, order at the counter, and either eat in or takeout. The menu has 5 or 6 kinds of fillings and 2 ways that they serve them, either in a kati roll (for all intensive purposes, a burrito), or as a thali on some kind of plate as a combination dish. You get yogurt and a little salad on the side, and you can fill yourself up for under $10. On top of it, they serve a surprising variety of alcohol/other drinks, including creamy heartwarming chai. Not greasy, just the right amount of spicy, and oh so good. Tikka Masala, I'll never cheat on you...except maybe for the wok-tossed indian cheese. Maybe I'll go get some for dinner right now in fact.
author: Allison G.

description: Kasa has such a nice friendly atmosphere and delicious, high-quality but well priced Indian food. And if you like Chai, they serve the best in town!
author: Adam G.

description: kasa, i love you. i love you even more now that i know you deliver. and the size-to-cost ratio is spot on. one star off, 'cause i really, really, really wish you would have the saag vegetarian more often or have a paneer tikka masala for vegetarians.
author: Theresa P.

description: Went midday on a weekday and it was pretty empty. The woman with the British accent at the counter was super cool. I got the chicken tika masala plate, which was good. However, Hayato got the 2 roll plate... I had roll envy. That is definately what I would do should I be back in the area.
author: Matt C.

description: I loved this place. The food is authentic and delicious, (my mom is Indian so I am picky), and the service is lovely. I have enjoyed everything that I've tried on the menu which is almost everything! It's a really nice laid back spot where you can get great food, fast, at a reasonable price. Their raita, (yoghurt salad), is to die for and anyone who likes cardamom should definitely try the mango lassi- it's bursting with flavor. To top it all off, the head chef is a woman! Lots and lots of reasons to go here!
author: Christine N.

description: Nice, clean and simple Indian food...Small menu, good flavors...Thats all you need at Kasa =)
author: Jenny G.

description: Awesome food, great location, great vibes, great goal: "create food that makes our grandmothers proud"
author: Be H.

description: Got 4 Kati's delivered tonight (for 2 people). All were SUPER tasty. They look small, but are just the right size. We also got Chai Tea delivered!!! Only place that's been happy to deliver chai tea. That was tasty too. Will be eating in sometime very soon.
author: Wade M.

description:
its "ok" for quick, not-so-greasy indian roti burritos. however, my one big gripe is they are a bit pricey for what you get. i mean, these rolls are small (i'm a bit eater), so you need at least 2 to feel full. perhaps we are paying a bit extra for the clean decor...? i got 4 rolls for $19 inclu. tax.

i thought i was going to totally love this place, as the idea sounds interesting and i love roti for sure. psst, roti was a bit dry for my taste. i might stop by again, but not in a hurry. darn.
author: Miss Lili F.

description:
welcome addition to the hood - if only they had come sooner. but its great for a quick bite, and in the afternoon you actually can chat with the staff who are all super friendly and foreign! solid, tasty not bland indian food. 

the chicken tikka and lamb rolls are my fav.
author: Geetika A.

description: I really, really wanted to like this place, and I love the concept of fast, cheap, fresh, well-done Indian food in a chic setting, very near where I live no less.  But I had a kati roll with chicken, and it didn't agree with me at all.  My stomach felt unsettled the rest of the day and evening.  I enjoy Indian food and eat it fairly reguarly, so I don't think this was a case of a wimpy, non-adventurous stomach. Also was it just me, but wasn't the relish on the side a little bit tart, and not in a good way?  And as others have noticed, the roll was kind of drippy too.  Clearly I'm in the minority of reviewers in my negative experience, so maybe I'll give it another shot one day.
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Okay, so the he food isn't super authentic, but it is delicious! Upon my fist visit, the server made a variety plate for us, and came to talk to us a little while later to see how we liked it, he was very sweet. I loved  the Lamb Roti Rolls, extremely tasty, and very satisfying. I also appreciate the freshness and quality of the ingredients. I love the metal plates the use too, it reminds me of eating in a cafeteria, but in a good way!
author: Kelly L.

description: My partner and I live in the Castro and have been to Kasa about 4 or 5 times.  We do try to order different items each time but the Chicken Tikka Marsala roll always seems to be one of the items we choose.  Uusally order 2 rolls for $8.95, and with a beverage usually comes to $20 - $25 for two.  Not cheap...but when you want something quick and tasty, and are tired of pizza, pasta or burritos.. it is a great place to go.
author: Greg G.

description: I eat here often--probably too much, but only b/c I can't get enough of the Kati rolls.  Everyday there are special vegetarian options, never a disappointment in variety.  The service is SUPER friendly and cool too!
author: kyle w.

description: I love Kasa.  Their staff is friendly, the place is totally clean looking with nice lines and simple decoration, the flavors are totally great and the food is affordable, very very nice place that I would take anyone I know to for lunch or dinner.  I pretty much always get the 2 chicken tikka masala kati rolls for $8.65 (It's 8 something).  I used to go to Naan and Chutney on Haight Street when I had a craving for those flavors, but now I usually go to Kasa since it is right by my house, AND I get full and happy for 9 dollars where as it would be around $20 at N&C.  I have been to Kasa probably 5 or 6 times and will definitely be back, thank you!
author: Jonathan M.

description: Met a friend here for dinner and had the potoao kati roll. when we got our food, i was a little anxious, viewing my single roll next to my companion's full plate, in the oh-so-sexy chrome cafeteria-themed tray. but, to my great pleasure, the one vegetarian roll was enough to satisfy me and sustained me through drinks at the 500 club afterward. Plus this eatery is so clean, it was simply a joy to eat there. Highly recommended for dinner after a long day, or on a saturday night. ;)
author: Ginger B.

description:
This restaurant is like an Indian version of Chipotle. We each ordered Thali plates and two big platters were dished up. The choices weren't extensive. The food was tasty, but I didn't feel like I had been given a huge meal (contrary to what other reviews on here led me to believe). I was still hungry afterwards and had to search out something else to eat in the Castro. At 10.95, this seemed a little spendy to me. For the two of us, our bill was about $28. But SF IS expensive, I guess...

The place was busy and the staff was friendly, so it felt comfortable and fun. I wouldn't make a special trip, but if you're in the area, it's a fine choice for something fast.
author: Glenn W.

description:
This place is very good, but lacks the authenticity of India's kathi rolls (aka frankies), hence the 4 stars. I had two kathi rolls with the karahi paneer and the aloo gobi (the special) as fillings. I liked the paneer the best, but my boyfriend got the aloo jeera thali, which was also very good. My friend had the chicken tikka thali and said it was great. I really enjoyed the atmosphere and the service is top-notch and friendly. Points for serving Indian soft drinks like Limca and Thumbs Up. The kathi rolls I had in India were on the greasier side with lots of masala, so I guess I was expecting more spice and was a little let down. Overall, this place is a win since it's very clean, they play bollywood music,  food is simple and good, and the service is great. Just don't get the Kingfisher...I've never met anyone that likes it. Ever.

EDIT:
Went here last night and the service has horrible! The people working weren't very friendly and kept forgetting our order. They also downsized their kathi rolls a lot and we barely got any onions, chutney, or filling. This is very disappointing since the prices are still a high for very little food!
author: Rekha S.

description: Speaking with the owner (Suresh) this is a great first effort for him. He is confident in maintaining the food quality by ensuring that it was fresh and he was not kidding. It would be nice to see an expanded menu, but for now I would settle for quality rather than quantity. I gave Kasa 4 stars because the owners wife is a fellow Londoner!
author: Kiran G.

description: Delicious!  After finding this place on Yelp, I decided to try it for lunch.  I had the marinated chicken wrap.  I just bought one so I could "try" it and see what the craze was all about.  It was just the right portion for me.  It also came with a small side yogurt sauce and a salad.  Everything was good!!!  The Roti was tasty too!!!  Very flavorful!!!  Nothing bland or over salted - just perfect!
author: Kaitlyn G.

description: I'm a neighbor and a lover! Amazing food and friendly staff. Thanks!
author: Josie C.

description: For speedy, scrumptious food --eat at Kasa. It's decently priced, they serve beer & wine and you can sit outside and enjoy the busy neighborhood. The karahi paneer and aloo jeera are amazing. I got a side of daal, which was pretty good but not excellent. The kati rolls are a little too buttery/oily for me, but overall the food, service, bathroom, location and atmosphere are excellent. I will return frequently, if not to excess.
author: Stumbalina b.

description: Fresh organic Indian food. The dishes are few and simple, but they are delicious. Prices are fair.
author: SF N.

description: i love this place. It's nowhere near my home or work, but i'll make a special trip once in a while just for their kati rolls.
author: Chuck D.

description:
Kasa's food is good- it isn't that oily & the flavoring/spices are pretty good.

The thali is a great deal- you get a ton of food and it isn't too expensive. It's also a great option if you want to try a bunch of stuff. If you don't eat very big portions, it can easily feed you for two meals.

I wouldn't recommend delivery from Kasa. I should have known it was going to be bad when the woman kept me on hold (on the phone) for 7 minutes- she was really nice though, so I decided to go ahead & order. They told me ETA was 45 minutes.... an hour and forty minutes later I got my food. Needless to say it was cold by the time I got it :( Nothing I little microwaving couldn't solve, but still, cold delivery is never too appealing.
author: Sapna M.

description: Kasa is great! I had the plate with chicken tiki masala and saag paner for 11 bucks and I was completely full! I actually couldn't finish everything. And most of the dishes were spicy, which I sometimes find is lacking at the  Indian restaurants I've tried in the city.
author: Lola A.

description: This place wasn't as good as I had thought or expected it to be. Amanda and I walked in, hungry and cold from a wonderful bicycle ride. Reading through the menu, we found a few items that were vegan, which were very few, but alas we ordered. I had the Aloo Ghobi and a serving of rice. The Aloo Ghobi was nothing spectacular, a little on the bland side and as was the rice. It's not pricey, but I doubt I'd come back here again.
author: Federico V.

description: Absolutely fabulous!  Kasa is going to be packed all the time.  This place is great.  The roti bread really makes the dish.
author: Adrian M.

description:
i was happy with the food, once i got it... for a place with so few options i don't see the need of having a ton of people working with a single customer at a time.

they should go to pacho villa to learn how to quickly move a huge line that does out the door.

i'll definitely only come back here if i have the time to spend on it... but if you do, the food is great.
author: Afonso S.

description: It's basic indian food that's not particularly flavorful. The "indian burritos" are basic and decent but you'll need to eat 3 for a full meal. Just leaves you craving for a better restaurant. The staff is friendly and the place is clean with a modern spin on indian restaurants that you don't see very often.
author: Pierre C.

description:
it's a 3-3.5 star! possibly 4 but i have to go again to determine that. it's super CLEAN and MODERN. there's an industrial sleek feel to it like Frijtz on Valencia. the staff is super friendly. okay, it's obvious that this is NOT your hole in the wall authentic Indian food. it's American, modern, and a quick bite - that's their intent! [so don't hate!]

now to the food [the important part]. it comes out fast since everything is pre-made - despite the fact, everything still taste FRESH. the menu is super simple; you either get the kati roll or the plate [it's a full meal that comes with all the side dishes]. you just choose between the six filling/entree. 

i got the chicken tikki masala kati roll [$5.50]. i filled me up just fine. however, if you're really hungry, i suggest you get two rolls. it comes with a "garnish salad" [cabbage, tomatoes, onions, spices, and a vigerette = YUMMY] and raita which was a rice balance for all the spices in everything else. the only down side, the kati is pan fried i think cause it's a bit on the oily side. 

i left with my tummy filled and smiling. i can't wait to go again. yum, yum, yum.
author: Jocelyn T.

description: This is the second time an owner of an establishment has written me and personally apologized for the poor service I received at their restaurant - I highly respect this act and thus give back a star.  I believe Kasa serves excellent food and look forward to dining there very soon!
author: Tiberius A.

description: Indian burritos pure genius! Just moved to the neighborhood and was craving some Indian fare, to my demise no naan and curry in sight. So I checked out this place with a good friend and was thoroughly impressed. I had my doubts if the food would hold up on the spicy side but any doubt I had quickly faded, when I was reaching for my beer to put out the fire in my mouth. Overall the place hit the mark at satisfying my craving.
author: Nichole M.

description: Kinda like an Indian burrito shop - good price and I like that you can get small portions for a good price if you so desire.
author: Stephanie Z.

description: Everything I tried was yummy, eggplant, lamb curry, raita, rice...highly recommend mango lassi drink, and almond custard with pomogranite seeds.
author: Erin C.

description: Been to this place once - but am impressed.  The food is very simple, not overspiced - almost like something that you might get at home (assuming you were from India).  I'll have to check this place out again - and will probably increase the rating
author: Nick K.

description: went to this little restaurant with a few friends, there was a bit of a line but there quick, their way of ordering was a smart move on their part. but anyways i got the turkey falafel with some potatoes and everything was just amazing ! it had a little spicy but not to much and the portioning was perfect. this place was so good that i went to it the very next day with some other friends and they enjoyed it as well i will def be going back to this place to try more of what they have
author: christina a.

description: mmmm.....this food is super yummy.  And now you tell me they deliver.  I think I have died and gone to delicious convenient Indian food heaven. My food was a little too salty the last time I was there, but I am hoping it was just a one time thing.  The service is good, the portions are perfect, and I love their menu.  What else can I say? This place is good!
author: Roberta J.

description:
good, not bad, but there is so much better out there.  I first think of Pakwan, which in my opinion is much tastier and cheaper.  But this place does have a lot going for it.  first off, if you are on the hunt for a quick post happy hour meal  then this place is great.  the menu is simple - two types of dishes and about 6 or so options for those and the prices are very clear.  so to the buzzed thinking person this place would be easy to maneuver.

the food was good but not great.  i like the sides, the staff, the ease of ordering, and the space.  I guess it is sort of like an Indian taqueria and using that comparison I can compare an upscale Mexican restaurant to my favorite taqueria and with that philosophy I would give Kasa 4 stars.

I should go back and try more of the not so plentiful options and review again.
author: Marianne J.

description: Is it truly authentic? Is it just an Indian version of wraps or burritos? Who cares, it good! Loved the lamb and the Paneer. Certainly isn't on the same level as some other full service Indian restaurants in The City, but for a neighborhood that is lacking in tasty quick snack foods, this place is a blessing. (really, do we need three pizza by the slice places within a block of 18th and Castro?)
author: marc S.

description: Ever since I had a Kati Roll in NYC, I've been waiting for the day that we'd get a decent Katri Roll place in the Bay Area.  Kasa definitely does a great job with it, although maybe not quite as deliciously greasy as the NYC one, its still an awesome treat.
author: Fred H.

description: Ok, went back a second time and got the rolls instead of the Thali. My partner got three rolls and I got three, mixing up the different choices. Lets just say it was good enough that we went back for three more rolls to share. I upgrade my last experience from 3 to 4 stars.
author: kevin b.

description: Geez, this place is boring. It has Indian food which is ok but I will not go back. The chai tea was good. I really like Udupi palace, Zante's, Chutney's, or Dosa's much better than this place. I only go here before meeting friends in the Castro and it's proximity to Phils for a coffee. Nothing special. If you are in this area go eat at Escape from New York or Taqueria Zapata. I know, you want Indian food, just wait and go somewhere else because this place will not fulfill your want. There is also rude hipster contingent that runs the front who give you a big eye roll when you ask them to explain how to order. NOT friendly. My saag paneer was really bland and the naan was actually gross and did not taste like naan, more like some weird health bread. Did not like.
author: julie q.

description:
If I get a craving for Indian Food, I'll head over to Kasa for the Chicken Tikka Masala Kati Roll. Its my absolute favorite! The kati rolls are prepared right in front of you and depending on how hungry you are I would recommend starting with one since its packed with flavor. The roll is not spicy and this is coming from someone who has zero tolerance for spice. I've heard that if you ask for the hot sauce to be prepared because it is pretty spicy.
The service is fine and if you have any questions the staff is more than willing to help. Depending on the time of day it can get really busy but there is ample seating. I especially like the communal table in the middle with the high bar stools. The ambiance is mediocre, I think its really plain and simple and meant to reflect a cafeteria. The location is great if you live in the Castro and are walking; unfortunately parking can be a challenge so be prepared to circle around the block a few times.
author: N S.

description: Terribly inauthentic, bland food. Don't recommend this for seasoned indian food lovers. I was very disappointed and am never coming back here again!
author: new s.

description: I love this place. This and Shalimar are my favorite Indian restaurants in the city. This one make me think of really good (healthy) Indian fast food. And very friendly people running the place.
author: Byron R.

description:
General summary is that this place is overpriced (priced out of being "fast food," which kati rolls should be)  but it's very good and I'll be going back for more.  If a bit cheaper, this would be a more solid 4 stars (I'm thinking 3.5 right now, and giving them the bump due to the beer surprise described below).

The kati rolls are excellent, though a bit small.  The chicken tikka was cooked with wood or charcoal, with that excellent charred flavor, which is great.  I was initially concerned that the meat was already cooked sitting at the counter, but it was clear it had just recently been cooked, so staleness (especially the little charcoal-burned bits on the chicken going soft) was not an issue (hope that's always the case).

The parathas are nice and flaky without being too greasy.  A bit more greasy would be a bit more tasty, but I prefer it this way-- they strike the right balance for me here.  Finally, the paneer roll was excellent, really a worthy substitute for the chicken tikka, which is great news.  Another slight minus for not offering unda rolls, which would really complete the experience.  

The staff is super friendly.  The place is amazingly clean for a kati roll joint, and the seating very clean, spacious and airy, which almost feels a bit off (I'm used to grease, crowds, noise, and a hole in the wall atmosphere), but it's very comfortable.

The icing on this cake is that they serve Tripel Karmeliet on draft!!!!  Not very Indian, but bonus points for mixing 2 of my favorite things in the world (kati rolls an tripel karmeliet).
author: r h.

description: Great, casual Indian food, and you get to eat from silver dish which looks a lot like the kind I use to feed my dog dish. All the more tasty.
author: Ted F.

description: Yummy. Clean. Affordable. It's SF's answer to NY's Kati Roll Company. Friendly and helpful staff since we didn't know how / what to order. A must-go!
author: Leena K.

description: love this place for what it is.  Fast, fresh, delicious.  Not a million choices, but what they have is great. I can't wait to go back.
author: Anthony C.

description:
This place is fantastic.  Food is amazing.  I am from Chicago and figured I would try this place out while in town for business as a friend of mine from San Fran said it was great.  

I am not really into Indian food (just not my bag) but I am into Kasa.  I like the analogy to an Indian Chipolte..agree but the food is better.  The chicken and lamb are delicious and I will be making Kasa a staple in my west coast trips now.  Wish they had one in chicago...hopefully soon...
author: Robert D.

description: such a cute little place to stop in for a quick bite. i've been here twice (once before a movie at the castro and once before a show at the swedish american music hall) and will probably go there every time i need a quick meal before a night out near the castro. this last time, i tried one of their specials saag paneer kofta in a kati roll - creamy spinach and cheese fried into balls, topped with dollops this yellow chutney, wrapped in roti with onions and a green chutney  - awesome. i would skip dipping the roti in egg first though (unda-style?) because i didn't think it added all that much to the kati roll.
author: Angi C.

description: I love this place.  Quick delivery, delicious and healthy and always consistently good.  The menu is not hugely expansive..but the food is always spot on!
author: Sarah S.

description: What a hidden gem!  A no-frills, clean and comfortable place with a wanting-to-please staff (a pleasant surprise these days!) and a menu to tempt any appetite.  I ordered the Thali (plate) with Chicken Tikka Masala and Chicken Tikka - comes with rice, roti, daal, chutneys and a delicious indian yogurt (raita).  It was DELICIOUS and filling... perfect to arm us for the rest of the day.  Open kitchen was nice to see where all the food was actually being prepared.  Highly recommend!
author: Amanda H.

description:
I have to update my review, because they've gotten better!  I thought the atmosphere would have been a ton better if the lights weren't so jarring and there was music and they had something to explain the style of food --- all that has been done.  The roti has gotten more delicious and the food is just darn good.  And you don't have to wait so long now.  I still think they could improve their ordering system to serve more customers, but it doesn't really get in the way.  I'm hungry.  I'm going there right now.

8/2/08:  
I think this place is a great idea and a good alternative to Pakwan and other similar fast Indian places.  Food is higher quality than Pakwan and probably the same or a little better than Naan and Curry.  I personally like having a short list of good options vs. a laundry list of stuff from which I'd only eat a few things anyway.  I also don't mind that it feels like they started this place to launch a chain.  I can't stand the service.  Incredibly inefficient.  I only recommend going between 2:00 and 5:00.
author: caroll c.

description: Oh yeah baby....pass along another Kati roll!  Love the Indian food here and will most definately go back.  Quality is excellent and fast service too!  However, parking is a pain...you're better off taking MUNI to get here.
author: Daria i.

description:
Living nearby, I had high hopes for this restaurant, replacing a taqueria (which, contrary to other reviews, was the best in the area - I was sorry to see it go.)
1. The menu is very limited. This is somewhat understandable because of the limited kitchen space, but some more variety could be added - particularly in the appetizer and dessert categories (how about some pakoras and samosas, or different pooris on different days). A small restaurant needs to distinguish itself - adding dosas to the menu would do that.
2. The limited offerings were just run of the mill and very bland, though attractively presented. The kitchen is definitely spice challenged. It would have been more palatable to me if at least some spicy Indian pickle were offered. But alas!
3. Roti is the only Indian bread offered. How about naan as an alternative?

Overall, I would describe this restaurant as Americanized Indian food for the unadventurous.
author: David S.

description:
I tried Kasa a few days back. I got a thali and my wife got 2 rolls.
I got my parantha unda (un pronounced as the un in pun) ish-style. They got it spot on.
The menu was not huge, and they did a great job on what they have there. I thought the food was very simple (in a good way), you could taste the flavor of individual spices, and no not everything was made in the same sauce. There was no dessert (but they had kingfisher :)), I would rate it a notch below dosa and roti in w portal, but considering the price.. :)
author: sachin n.

description:
i don't get it! i read some good reviews and a friend recommended it, so went last week armed with a groupon. ordered two thalis with chicken tikka, chicken tikka masala, aloo gobi, and lamb curry.

the food was eh--had none of the intense, rich flavor i eat indian food for. the sauces were watery and bland. halfway through i realized that the chicken tikka masala, which was the best of the bunch, tasted almost exactly like trader joe's FROZEN tikka masala--definitely not a compliment for a fresh-food restaurant.

service was fine--wasn't expecting much one way or another. the acoustics in the restaurant were atrocious--i and my bf could barely hear each other talk because of the noise level of the three tables on either side of us. had the food been good, that would be no problem. but all together, it was a very unpleasant experience, and we couldn't get out of there fast enough.
author: Yelp Y.

description: Este es mi Review y esta de pelos!
author: Gian Franco P.

description: I don't mind that it isn't super authentic. I don't think it's trying to be super authentic. And I love the prices- definitely affordable. But at the end of the day, it's just OK and you can pay only a little more for food that is way way more delicious. The big issue is that is all sort of tastes the same- semi greasy Indian food. Definitely not something to go out of your way for.
author: Karyn S.

description: My friends are getting tired of asking where I want to go to get a quick bit to eat.  Even though it's a bit of a hike to get there from SOMA, my answer is always Kasa.  Like others have said, the kati rolls are getting to be an addiction.
author: Danny T.

description: really awesome, consistently so.  probably best indian in the city.  one star off for limited menu.
author: jon s.

description: Delicious bites and casual hip atmosphere. I've been to Kasa a  couple times now. I think that the food is a value, I've left with a satisfied tummy after every visit. The roti bread is made by hand and is thick and flaky. From each bite you can tell the ingredients are quality and the meats aren't greasy or too salty. Many of the other Indian and Pakistani restaurants in town may be cheaper, but the environment is not as enjoyable and the owners and staff of Kasa treat you with care and a smile. It is also a very kid friendly restaurant (they have booster seats/high chairs) :), today one of the owners asked if my toddler was enjoying the food and asked if it was to spicy. It (the chicken tikka masala) was actually a bit too spicy and she offered us a tot sized portion of the grilled chicken which was less spicy. We are thrilled that Kasa has opened up in our neighborhood and we'll be visiting on a regular basis, there aren't many places where you can get freshly brewed chai and friendly service in the Castro.
author: Stephanie ..

description: Kasa is about as indian as Taco Bell is Mexican.  I was very disappointed with the food.  The chicken masala was not really masala.  Instead of nan, they serve what looked like a tortilla dipped in grease. The service was unfriendly and the it was over-priced.  I would recommend other indian restaurants like Chutney or Lahore.
author: G A.

description: Amazing use of spices for a new, creative twist on traditional entrees! Try the mango lassi, too. Just a hint of cardamom gives this great clasic a savory update!
author: shelley p.

description: I was really looking forward to this place, my son, husband & bro who ws vistn from LA, came in to the city from the east bay to see the DeYoung Post Impressionist Exhibit, so we alwys look forw to good eats in SF. We found out about KASA thru CHEAP EATS the SF Chronicle review. Sooo dissappointed. Bland, bland, uninteresting. I had the "Gobi Aloo" :), the cumin (?) potats the roti. The husband & son had the chicken tikka and tkka masala. They "liked" it. But it was no great meal. I am  mostly vegetarian and crave indian becs of the wondrfl complexities in the cooking. This was so NOT the savory, yummy, spicy, sweet (no tamarind chutney) that I love.  I also would like to know, why is this place getting such great reviews? Somebody said the place was drafty and it IS! and the rubbery, oily roti just yuk. Give me naan with my indian.  But I do have to say the guy w/ the dread locks was really very nice.
author: Catherine B.

description: Ever have that stuffed, gross, what the heck did I do to my body feeling after eating at an Indian restaurant?  I have and I'm tired of it.  That's why I liked Kasa Indian so much.  It's not your typical Indian fare of heavy, overly creamy curries.  It's light, fresh, and tasty.  More like home-made Indian then restaurant-Indian.  Kudos to these guys for coming up with something novel and tasty!  FYI- the steel plates are actually very common in India and were at one time considered "the good china"...
author: B P.

description: After hearing so many rave reviews from my cousins I decided to try Kasa for the first time yesterday.  And I am glad I did.  Food is delicious and service is quick.  I had one Chiken Tikka kathi roll...and one is not enough to fill you up.  Go for two and definately go UNDA STYLE.  Prices are good...although I thought Thumbs-Up (indian version of Coca-Cola) was a bit expensive ($2 per bottle).  Loved the decor...was simple and clean.  Nice place to try out an alternative style of Indian food.
author: Milind P.

description: Thought this place was terrific.  Clean, quick and tasty.  A new twist on Indian.  I went for dinner, but could see this working for lunch (or even just a snack).  Will be back for sure.
author: Jeremy V.

description: Friends and I all experienced terrible indigestion after eating at Kasa last night. I love Indian food and this was decent (I still prefer Shalimar for authenticity), but the stomach upset was almost instant and lasted until this morning. My boyfriend, another friend, and I experienced mild stomach cramps, nausea, and just general ickiness. Maybe the food was heavily salt-laden? Whatever it is, I won't be going back. So-so food is not worth feeling like crap for the next 12 hours.
author: Brian J.

description: This place is awesome.  As an Indian living on the East Coast we have many hip fast food Indian options but the khati roll has always been missing in San Francisco.  Kasa brings that and much more.  Great location, fresh ingredients and a friendly staff.  The price is just right for a quick snack or sit down lunch and the fact that they have King Fisher beer on tap for $3.50 a pint... forgetta bout' it.  I'm a fan.
author: Rishi J.

description: I really like this place-- was obsessed with it for quite some time.  I'm not a big fan of the rolls, but adore the thalis.  The food is great-- well spiced, fresh and addictive.  The chai is like cozying up under the blankets on a rainy day.   I also like the aesthetic of the place as well as the casual feel  and the super friendly, helpful, easy going staff. It's my favorite lunch spot!
author: Laura B.

description: I went to a private party here and I am not into Indian food that much, but everything I tried was delicious.   The owners were so nice and gracious.  I loved it.  The restaurant was very clean.   I looked at the menu and it was very reasonably priced.  I will definitely go back.
author: Nora S.

description: the kati rolls are a great way to enjoy different dishes when eating alone.  i had the paneer and bengan bartha kati rolls, which were tasty.  the concept of the indian burrito was strange, but when i sunk my teeth into them i had no problems.  the raita they accompany with it is heavenly, and compliments the kati rolls.
author: Sheri N.

description: simple, tasty indian food served in finger friendly packaging.  avatar's panjabi burritos is a favorite of mine but kasa is even better.  the roti makes the roll.
author: Kumar D.

description: I LOVE KASA! I tried a dozen Indian restaurants and have been disappointed a dozen times when I stumbled on Kasa. The food is unique (at least to me here in SF) in presentation as either kati rolls or thali with a convenient location. I can't get enough!
author: Scot J.

description: Good ambiance, nice neighborhood, etc.  I would have given 4 stars instead of 5 if they had taken the time to cut up the chili peppers in the Chicken Tikka Masala.  Eating a whole pepper in your first bite ruins the rest of your meal.  Other than that, good value for the money.
author: Anuj G.

description: In Castro, modern decor, hip, etc.  I think it works in this neighborhood.  I like  roti but I had better version somewhere else.  Curries kind of different than I am used to.  For the money, I would go somewhere else.
author: Su Kyeong K.

description: yes.  it's good anytime. meals. snacks. hangover prevention and/or treatment. affordable and unique for out of town guests. dinnertime delivery.  the kind of meal where every bite tastes different. a brilliant blend of flavors and colors and textures.
author: mad m.

description: One of the owners sent me a message about my missing salad. Apparently they have since changed the menu to exclude the salad, and it was my misfortune to stop by while they were in the process of updating it. Nice to hear a response. Adding a star for owner niceness.
author: Kika S.

description:
i just love the people who work here
they are always warm and friendly
and the food being awesome is worth it
great spot for a great lunch
author: tobdevilish i.

description: This is one of my favorite lunch places in the city, although I often go there for dinner as well. This is a clean, affordable place, and food tastes quite 'home made'. I try to eat lean food and I always end up getting their grilled chicken or turkey kabob, either as a Kati roll or as a Thali. One thing I don't like is that they smother their rotis in butter. I just don't get it. I always ask them not to, but some butter from the pan gets on my rotis anyway. Minor quibble but worth noting. Their yogurt (Raita) is very creamy also, but they let you substitute it for salad or lentils. If you pick the right stuff to eat this place can be very rewarding; easy on the wallet too!
author: girish p.

description: Yum!  Like Indian style burritos.  Menu is limited but they always have a veggie special that surprises me.  Who knew turnip mash was so tasty? Prices are good and they have interesting beers when the mood strikes.
author: KM D.

description: We loved this place, fresh, delicious, tasty food and Kindfisher on Tap. Way better than any Indian food I have had in San Francisco. Looking forward to returning and sampling the rest of the menu.
author: s b.

description: Great concept.....an Indian Burrito joint.  We tried 4 of the 6 varieties and enjoyed them all.  We recommend this place and hope that they continue to develop and diversify the menu.
author: Leo S.

description: Now SF, has something to match NY's kathi roll.  This place is great for wraps. I have tried the jeera aloo, karahi paneer, and aloo gobi rolls. The karahi paneer isn't worth having. The other two rolls are great. You can get a thali, which I feel is a bit too expensive, and the main dish's proportion becomes too much. Parking is hard to find. All in all, a welcome unique place in SF
author: Kuldeep T.

description: i love indian food.  have probably tried every place in the city.  this is a great concept: fast, delicious indian food.  great for lunch!  i highly recommend this eatery.
author: Elizabeth B.

description: I really enjoy the delicious food and casual atmosphere of Kasa. Unlike many Indian places, the food at Kasa is a great value, is served quickly and without pretense. The menu is very simple, primarily kati rolls, either regular or Unda style in a couple of configurations. Fast, filling, and tasty food at a great price. If you're looking to be immersed in an Indian cultural experience, then perhaps Kasa might not be your cup of chai. There are no pictures of the Taj Mahal, no Shivas, no employees in brightly dyed traditional clothing - nope, the interior design is bright white with tasteful black and white photography adorning the walls. Instead of some Hindi music, they were playing some nice hip hop last time I was in. For me, this refreshing approach places the emphasis where it belongs - squarely on the delicious food. Bon appetit.
author: diego a.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE. My friend lives right across the street and every time I visit, we eat at Kasa. Some days I get full off of one kati roll, but other days I need two. The rolls themselves aren't too big, but for some reason they're really filling. They are a little expensive, but the price never stops me from ordering them. I do need to get more adventurous with the filling though; I always order chicken tikka masala.
author: Joseph C.

description:
it's like a taqueria, except indian...that's the way this place was described to me before i arrived and it was a dead on description.  you order, pay, and then bring your tray to your seat, but the decor is modern, so it feels like a nicer experience than that actually sounds.  

the place is comfortable and great food with big servings, but we did start a discussion as to why they have that think foam stuff underneath  all the tables??  the best answer we could come up with was to absorb sound...anyway, their beer was also good.  five stars!  bam!
author: Karen M.

description:
delish!

i tried both of the veggie kati rolls which were great.  prices are really good too.  yummy chai!

will be back!
author: n. h.

description: awesome place....love the remodeling considering it used to be a plain taqueria before.  food is fantastic and unlike any other indian restaurant in the city and they have a good selection of beer.  i just wish the menu could have a bit more to offer....
author: M. B.

description: If you are looking for great, authentic, not the normal Indian food, check out Kasa. I consider myself a food snob. I love my food with fresh ingredients and lots of flavor. This is what Kasa delivers. The time the chief Anamika Khana takes to marinate her vegetables, organic chicken, lamb, and turkey comes through in every bite. I usually do not eat Indian food because it is too spicy, but these dishes are just right. If you need your food super spicy hot they have chutney that will put some fire up you know where. Check out Kasa you will not be disappointed!
author: Marty G.

description: For what it is, what it costs, and the lovely sleek setting, this place is GREAT.  Tasty, fresh, friendly--the owner stopped by while we were eating lunch to see how we liked it.  Spicy with a great cooling raita.  I fully intend to stop here OFTEN and bring lots of friends.  You should too.  As has been noted a refreshing alternative to burrito night.
author: Katharine D.

description: I've died and gone to Delhi, Kati rolls rock ! Fresh, delicious and addictive. Excellent quality, cool surroundings, and something new in San Francisco---check Kasa out
author: james c.

description: We've been here a few times now and we dig it, both for dine-in and for take-out.  It's not a typical Indian restaurant at all but satisfying in part for how different is from typical Indian joints. The kati rolls are the real specialty and they fill them with lots of tasty choices, but our favorites are the chicken tikka masala (spicy, but not overly saucy) and the lamb curry with potatoes (very full of flavor but not overpowering), though we've had a bunch of the veggie ones too and they're also strong.  Only complaint is that the roti are pretty greasy, which is great but if you eat two or more kati rolls, you feel a little blech.  The plates are a good value too - you still get one roti and you feel a little better at the end of the meal.  The decor has never made a lot of sense to me - it doesn't really sync with the comfort food being served - and it prevents Kasa from being a place I'd go for a real sit-down meal.  But we've brought our 1-year old a couple of times and they've been very accommodating.  It's the only Indian restaurant near the Castro, so it fills an important niche, and fills my belly too.
author: Warren B.
